text: This country's dramatic political changes have passed them by. Greater democracy has not brought greater respect for the stateless Rohingya's human rights. But the formation of an Advisory Commission on Rakhine State, led by former UN Secretary General Kofi Annan, has given the Rohingya hope that their plight will be addressed. The Commission is tasked with finding practical solutions to complex issues, such as protecting the human rights of all people in the state, and providing access to health care and education for the Rohingya. The Commission has also called for an end to restrictions on movement and freedom of religion. While these efforts have yet to bear fruit, the Rohingya have welcomed the Commission's work as a step in the right direction.

Those selling the illicit weapons often disassembled and sent them in different packages or embedded them in old stereos or printers, the report found. Researchers found that firearms and related components were almost always sent by mail, while ammunition and other related accessories were usually posted. The report found that most of the illegal arms were sold through underground networks of gun dealers and smugglers who used chat rooms and websites to advertise and sell their wares. These networks often operated in secret, making them difficult to track down and apprehend. In addition, the report found that many of the weapons were sold for profit, with sellers often using inflated prices to increase their profits. The researchers also noted that some sellers may have engaged in money laundering activities, as well as selling counterfeit goods. Finally, the report concluded that the illegal arms trade was a significant source of income for organized crime groups.

The boys, aged 12 and 13, were seriously injured in the attack in Havant, Hampshire, on Friday and remain in hospital. Richard Michael Walsh, 43, of no fixed address, has been charged with two counts of attempted murder. The police have not released any further details about the incident and it is unclear what exactly happened. It is reported that both boys were taken to hospital after being attacked, and one required emergency surgery. The other boy is thought to be in a stable condition. The motive for the attack is unknown at this time, but police are investigating the incident and are appealing for witnesses or anyone with information to come forward. This is a very serious incident and our thoughts are with the families of the two boys involved. We hope that the authorities can quickly get to the bottom of what happened and ensure justice is served.

Trafford Council closed Bollin Primary School in Bowdon, Greater Manchester on Monday after concerns about a "reduced capacity of senior leadership." The council said the school had appointed an interim headteacher but this had not been successful in turning the school around. The council has said that it is working closely with Trafford's education commissioner and the Department for Education to ensure that pupils have access to a good quality education. It added that affected pupils will be provided with alternative school places as soon as possible. The council has also set up a helpline to provide further advice and support to parents.

Apple Music performed a U-turn over payment policy a day after the pop star threatened to prevent the US firm from streaming her album 1989. Swift had argued that Apple Music should pay artists for streaming their music during its three-month free trial period, which it had previously declined to do. Apple then announced that it would pay artists for music streamed during the trial. Swift welcomed the news, saying: "I am elated and relieved. Thank you, Apple, for your change of heart."

Latham smashed Colin Ackermann for six to reach his hundred but was caught behind off Neil Dexter for 124. Opener Steel went on to make his century off 242 balls, hitting 15 boundaries in the process. Latham and Steel put on a brilliant 189-run opening stand, the second highest partnership of the match. Latham's 124 was the highest individual score of the match and Steel's 101 not out was crucial in setting up a challenging total for Glamorgan.

An altercation broke out between two men inside a fast food outlet about 00:35 BST on Sunday which then continued outside. Police said the suspect is described being aged in his 20s and wearing a green check shirt. Eyewitnesses said the altercation started when one of the men threw a milkshake at the other, causing him to become enraged. Witnesses also said that the suspect was seen in possession of a knife, although police have not confirmed this. The men were separated by members of the public before Police Officers arrived on the scene. Both men were taken away for questioning and medical attention. Enquiries into the incident are ongoing and anyone with information is asked to contact their local police station.

Police have charged a 32-year-old Norwegian man over both attacks. The man dressed as a police officer was arrested on tiny Utoeya island after an hour-long shooting spree. Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg said the attacks were "like a nightmare." The man, who has not been named, is facing charges of terrorism and voluntary homicide. Police said he had used "a variety of weapons" in his attack on the Oslo government district, which left seven dead, and on Utoeya island, where he killed at least 84 people. He was arrested after police arrived on the island. Police have not commented on the suspect's motives but media reports suggest he may have links to right-wing groups. The Norwegian Prime Minister said it was "a very difficult day." He added: "It's a nightmare. It's a nightmare for those who have been killed, injured and affected, and for their families and friends."

Firefighters tackled the blaze, which started just before 21:00 on Monday in Carron Valley. The home owners and their dog escaped from the building after being alerted by a smoke alarm. The fire was brought under control by around 23:00. A Scottish Fire and Rescue Service spokesperson said: "Operations Control mobilised a number of resources to the scene at Carron Valley, Falkirk, following reports of a dwelling fire. "Firefighters extinguished the flames and left the scene after ensuring the area had been made safe. "Crews have been praised for their swift response which resulted in the fire being quickly brought under control. "Thankfully, the occupants and their dog were alerted to the fire by a working smoke alarm and managed to escape before crews arrived on the scene. "This highlights the importance of having a working smoke alarm fitted in your home as it gives you vital minutes to get out, stay out and call 999."

The idea will be looked at as part of a wider study of transport issues across southern Scotland. Campaign for Border Rail spokesman Simon Walton said they would have preferred a direct rail line from Edinburgh to Carlisle rather than an upgrade of the existing route, but acknowledged that "in the current financial climate it is unlikely to happen." He said: "The new scheme is a good start and we are hopeful that it could be used to create a direct link between the two cities in future. We will continue to lobby for that as part of our campaign."

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years for allegedly plotting to topple the government in Tehran. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, has criticised the UK government for a lack of action , saying that it has failed to do enough to secure her release. He has also accused Iran of using her as a "bargaining chip" in negotiations with the West. The UK government has repeatedly called for Zaghari-Ratcliffe's immediate and unconditional release, both publicly and through diplomatic channels. It has raised her case with the Iranian authorities on numerous occasions and lobbied other world leaders to do the same. The UK has offered consular assistance and provided her with financial support while she is in prison, and has made clear its commitment to securing her release. However, it is difficult to predict when or if Zaghari-Ratcliffe will be released. The Iranian judicial system operates independently from the government, and decisions about her case are ultimately out of the UK government's hands. Ratcliffe has expressed frustration at the lack of progress and has urged the government to do more to bring his wife home.

Each evening Cardiff Bay will become the venue for a world music Showcase Festival featuring a tapas of world music from around the world. Folk music played a large part in the festival, with traditional artists from across Europe and beyond providing a unique atmosphere to the waterfront. Other acts included Latin American, African, Asian and jazz music. The showcase took place over several days, drawing in a large variety of music lovers from all walks of life. Each day had a different theme, with some nights focusing on acoustic and folk music, while others featured more energetic and upbeat sounds. The event was held in an outdoor area, with plenty of seating and standing areas for the audience. Spectators could enjoy the views of the bay while they enjoyed the music and soaked up the atmosphere created by the performers. Food stalls were also available, offering a range of international cuisine. The festival was a huge success, with people of all ages coming out to experience something new. This was an incredible opportunity to discover new music, meet new people and explore different cultures.

Akinfenwa chested down in the box and saw his deflected shot fly past Bobby Olejnik to continue Wycombe's impressive home form - they have lost just one of six league games at Adams Park this season. The goal was scored by Akinfenwa in the 39th minute of Wycombe's League One game against Rochdale on November 28 2020. The match ended 1-1, with Akinfenwa's goal being the only one scored by either team in the first half.

He was held on suspicion of Computer Misuse Act offences after officers searched a property in the city. Police have also arrested and bailed a 16-year-old from London, a 15-year-old from London and a 17-year-old from Manchester in connection with the investigation. The man was arrested under the Computer Misuse Act 1990, which makes it illegal to access or modify computer material without authorization. It also covers malicious software (malware) attacks, denial of service attacks, and other attempts to disrupt or damage computer systems. It is punishable by up to two years in prison.

The state newspaper says the "suave" liquor will spare you wincing when you wake, despite boasting 30-40 alcohol. The brew is reportedly made from a type of indigenous ginseng called "Ginseng Sap" and is said to be a mix of sweet, sour, and bitter flavors. The newspaper claims that the drink has been around for centuries in China, but has recently gained popularity as a health-promoting beverage. It is believed that the Ginseng Sap helps to reduce inflammation, improve circulation, and promote relaxation. The taste of the liquor has been described as a unique combination of the sweet, sour, and bitter. The newspaper recommends consuming the drink responsibly and advises that it should not be taken in excessive quantities. They also suggest that it should be paired with food such as dried fruit or nuts. This drink may sound too good to be true, but if consumed in moderation, it could be a great alternative to more traditional alcoholic beverages.

Transactions carried out in European markets were previously recorded in Luxembourg, with which Amazon had a low-tax agreement. Now sales made through subsidiaries in the UK, Germany, Spain and Italy are all booked in their respective countries. This shift will help Amazon better reflect the economic activity occurring in each of those markets and pay corporation tax accordingly. The change could have a significant impact on the amount of taxes Amazon pays across Europe, as the company has been accused of exploiting loopholes to avoid taxes. It is estimated that Amazon paid just 200m in corporate taxes in 2018, despite recording net sales of 21.6bn in the same year. The move has been welcomed by European governments, who have long criticised Amazon for its aggressive tax avoidance practices. It will likely lead to an increase in the amount of taxes collected from the company, providing a much-needed boost to public finances. Additionally, the shift may encourage other large companies to follow suit and ensure they are paying their fair share of taxes.

The council has launched an appeal to raise PS150,000 for a bronze sculpture in the Barkers Pool area. Former steelworker Kathleen Roberts said: "It breaks my heart that we haven't been able to come up with this money ourselves but I hope that the people of Sheffield will rally round and donate to the appeal." The council have set up a dedicated webpage for donations with any amount welcome, and have launched a social media campaign to spread awareness. Cllr. Mary Lea said: "This sculpture is a tribute to the hard work and dedication of those who worked in Sheffield's steel industry, and it is important that we recognise their contribution to the city."

Bielsa, 60, a former Argentina and Chile boss, resigned from French club Marseille in August and is unattached. He led Spanish club Athletic Bilbao to the 2012 Europa League and Copa del Rey finals. He said in a statement: "I am delighted to have been given the opportunity to join Leeds United and I can't wait to get started." Leeds owner Andrea Radrizzani added: "We are very pleased to have Marcelo join us. He is one of the most respected managers in world football and his track record of success is second to none. "His style of play fits perfectly with Leeds United's vision and values and the club will be delighted to benefit from his knowledge, experience and enthusiasm for the game."

The test investigates whether people can detect if they are talking to machines or humans. The experiment is based on Alan Turing's question-and-answer game Can Machines Think? No computer has yet passed the Turing Test, which means that no machine has been able to fool people into believing that it is human. The test requires a human judge to interact with two entities: one of them is a human and the other is a machine. The judge must determine which is which without being able to see or hear either entity. The test involves asking questions and determining who is giving the best answers. The machine needs to give answers that are indistinguishable from those given by a human in order for it to pass the test.

Leinster fly-half Sexton was injured in Saturday's Pro12 final defeat by Connacht and requires surgery. Full-back Rob Kearney has a hamstring injury with his brother Dave, a winger, ruled out for the tour with a shoulder problem. Sexton is expected to be sidelined for around four weeks, which would make him available for the third and final Test against Australia in Sydney on June 18. The Ireland party includes five uncapped players - Rory Scannell, Kieran Marmion, Ultan Dillane, Josh van der Flier and Stuart Olding - and head coach Joe Schmidt will be without nine frontline players. Ireland have the first of three Tests against New Zealand in Auckland on June 11. Ireland squad to tour New Zealand: Backs: Simon Zebo, Andrew Trimble, Keith Earls, Tommy Bowe, Jared Payne, Robbie Henshaw, Stuart Olding, Luke Fitzgerald, Ian Madigan, Kieran Marmion, Conor Murray, Eoin Reddan, Paddy Jackson. Forwards: Jack McGrath, Cian Healy, Nathan White, Mike Ross, Tadhg Furlong, Rory Best (captain), Sean Cronin, Richardt Strauss, Donnacha Ryan, Iain Henderson, Devin Toner, Quinn Roux, Ultan Dillane, CJ Stander, Jamie Heaslip, Jordi Murphy, Rhys Ruddock, Josh van der Flier, Rory Scannell.

Shocked onlookers swam across the boating lake at Stanborough Park, Welwyn Garden City, on Sunday after the car became submerged in the water. The pair were put in a boat and taken to safety. Witnesses said the driver of the car, a woman believed to be in her 20s, had been driving at speed when she lost control. It is believed the woman was visiting the park for the day when the incident happened. The car was completely submerged in the lake and could not be seen from the bank. Emergency services were called to the scene and a fire crew managed to retrieve the vehicle. The woman and the man who was with her were taken to hospital as a precaution but it is understood they were not seriously injured.

The birds caused "extensive damage" by making holes in parts of the spire made of cedar at St Mary's Church in Headley near Epsom. A grant of PS78,000 was awarded to fund the repairs. The birds had made their way into the spire through a broken louver, which is an opening that allows air to circulate. The church's vicar, Revd Canon Sam Corley, said: "We were shocked and dismayed by the damage caused by the birds. We were very relieved when we found out that a grant was available to help cover the cost of the repairs."

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf said a new charter arrangement would end the long-running row over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had claimed some workers on board two freight boats were not being paid the Scottish Living Wage. Mr Yousaf said: "This new charter arrangement will ensure that seafarers working on these vessels will be paid the Scottish Living Wage, providing a minimum pay rate of 9 per hour and benefit from better terms and conditions. "We have worked closely with the RMT union to ensure that all seafarers employed on the Caledonian MacBrayne freight routes receive fair pay, and I am pleased that we have been able to reach an agreement which will benefit all those involved." The charter arrangement will come into effect on April 1, 2017. It will mean that seafarers employed on the two ferry boats will receive the Scottish Living Wage, as well as better terms and conditions. The agreement also includes measures to support the training and development of seafarers, improve safety onboard and strengthen the bond between employers and employees. The RMT Union said the agreement was a "positive step" in ensuring the rights of seafarers are protected. General Secretary Mick Cash said: "This is a positive step forward for our members who had been at risk of being denied the rights and protection that other workers enjoy. "We will continue to work closely with the Scottish Government to ensure that this agreement is properly enforced and that any future disputes are resolved in a timely and satisfactory manner."

Foster's time of 11.62 seconds earned automatic qualification as she finished second in her first-round heat. However, Smyth exited from the men's 100m as he finished fifth in his heat and missed out on a place in the semi-finals. Foster went on to reach the final of the women's 100m, finishing in eighth place with a time of 11.56 seconds. Smyth was unable to qualify for the final of the men's 100m.

The lifesaving equipment is believed to have been taken from outside of Frenchay Village Hall, near Bristol, in the early hours of Friday. Last December it was one of eight defibrillators stolen from locations around the city in a spate of thefts. The defibrillator is a device used to restart a person's heart if they suffer from cardiac arrest. It works by delivering an electric shock to the heart, which can help to restore a normal rhythm. The devices are usually found in public places, such as schools, community centres and sports clubs, where they can be easily accessed in an emergency.

Hull City's Chester, Dummett of Newcastle United and Celtic's Matthews missed March's 3-0 win in Israel because of injuries. Andy King returns after serving a two-match ban but injuries rule out fellow midfielders Joe Allen, Aaron Ramsey, and Jonny Williams. Defenders Ben Davies, Ashley Williams, Chris Gunter and James Chester have all been called up but Ben Davies is a doubt with a calf problem. Midfielder Joe Ledley has also been recalled for the game after missing the last two qualifiers. Up front, Gareth Bale and Sam Vokes are available but Hal Robson-Kanu misses out with an ankle injury.

The Euro 2012 co-hosts took the lead when Yarmolenko seized on goalkeeper Samir Handanovic's unconvincing punch. Seleznyov slid in to convert the overlapping Artem Fedetskiy's cross after the break. Josip Ilicic scored a consolation goal for Slovenia in the 79th minute. The victory secured Ukraine's place at the top of Group H with 13 points from five games, two points clear of England, who were held to a 1-1 draw by Montenegro earlier on Friday.

Pae Jun-ho, known in the US as Kenneth Bae, smuggled anti-government materials and plotted the state's downfall, a Supreme Court spokesman told state news agency KCNA. He denied Mr Bae had entered North Korea as a missionary. The spokesman said Mr Bae had used his tourism business to form groups to overthrow the government and had smuggled forbidden items into the country, including DVDs and photos. He had also used religious activities to try to overthrow the government, the spokesman added. Mr Bae was arrested in November 2012 and sentenced to 15 years' hard labour in May 2013. He is believed to be held at a prison camp in the north-eastern city of Rajin.

Media playback is not supported on this device The wing, 34, scored in the last move of Wales' 24-18 defeat by Australia in Cardiff and was later in tears during the post-match interviews Wales' wing George North has been told he must improve his tackling technique if he is to play in the upcoming Six Nations. North, 34, scored in the last move of Wales' 24-18 defeat by Australia in Cardiff on Saturday and was later in tears during the post-match interviews. Head coach Warren Gatland said: "We want to make sure that when he's defending, it's not a high tackle. "We'll work with him and help him and make sure he gets his technique right." North, who has won 95 caps for Wales, was replaced in the second half after being penalised for a dangerous tackle on Wallaby centre Samu Kerevi. Gatland added: "He's obviously very emotional about that. He's a big guy and he needs to make sure his technique is spot on. "He knows we want him out there as much as possible, but he also knows he has to get his technique right." North is expected to be named in Wales' squad for the Six Nations next week.

But the BBC drama - which celebrated its 30th anniversary last month - was beaten to the TV soap of the year award by its ITV rival Coronation Street. Ant ony Cotton, who plays Sean Tully in Corrie, collected the prize at a glittering ceremony in London. EastEnders, which won five awards including best soap actor (John Partridge) and best actress (Kellie Bright), was also named serial drama of the year. But it was Coronation Street that had the last laugh when it scooped the top honour. The show's executive producer Kieran Roberts said: "We are absolutely thrilled to be named TV soap of the year. The award is especially significant as it reflects the response from viewers, who are the lifeblood of our show. "We thank them for their ongoing support and loyalty, and we will continue to strive to make Coronation Street the very best that it can be." The awards, now in their 28th year, recognise excellence in both soaps and serials. Other winners included Casualty, which won the best soap story line gong, and Emmerdale, which took home the best soap newcomer trophy.

Welsh Secretary Stephen Crabb was speaking after Friday's final televised debate before the election. "There's only one party that's in a position to secure an overall majority and that's the ... Conservative Party.

John Morley, 29, of Deanstown, Finglas West, is alleged to have carried out a sustained weekend attack at the Chimney Corner Hotel in Mallusk. The victim, Derek White, was said to have been subjected to a violent assault on 8th October 2017. Mr. Morley is accused of punching Mr. White several times in the face and body, and kicking him while he was on the ground. The attack was reported to police by eyewitnesses who were present at the time. Mr. Morley has been charged with grievous bodily harm with intent and is due to appear before Antrim Magistrates' Court on 6th November 2017.

An ISI official told the BBC the compound in Abbottabad where Bin Laden was killed by US forces on Sunday had been raided several years ago. But the compound "was not found to be linked to any militant activities." The official said the compound had been under surveillance for about a year before the raid. He said the ISI had provided intelligence to the US on the compound, including its location and layout, but had no knowledge that Bin Laden was living there. He also said that ISI had had no contact with Bin Laden since 2001.

Ethan McKen, 24, was at the Black Sea resort of Sunny Beach, near Burgas, when he and a friend were hit by a wave, earlier on Saturday. Mr McKen was knocked unconscious and rushed to hospital, but died from his injuries later that night. Mr McKen was a popular student at the University of Glasgow, where he was studying for an MSc in Global Health and Infectious Diseases. He had travelled to Bulgaria with a group of friends for a summer holiday. Friends have paid tribute to him on social media, describing him as generous, kind and always willing to help others. His family said: "Ethan was an inspiring young man who was passionate about making a difference to the lives of others. He will be greatly missed by all those who knew him." Mr McKen's death is being investigated by the Bulgarian authorities.

Actresses including Meryl Streep, Sally Field, Sandra Bullock and Cameron Diaz saluted the 76-year-old Oscar-winner at Thursday's event in Hollywood. "I'm so happy to add another woman's name to the list of brilliant filmmakers," Streep said. "Sally Field said, "You are an example of what can be accomplished with hard work, dedication and a lot of chutzpah." Bullock noted that Mirren has inspired generations of actresses, while Diaz pointed out that she has been a role model for women in the film industry. "You have shown us all the power of believing in yourself," she said.

Liverpool-bound striker Dominic Solanke picked up Lewis Cook's pass to score the winner shortly after the interval. England played the last 17 minutes with 10 men after Josh Onomah was sent off for a second bookable offence. Solanke, who is joining Liverpool in the summer after his contract with Chelsea expired, latched onto Cook's clever pass and fired a low shot past the goalkeeper to seal a 1-0 win for England. Onomah had been shown a second yellow card for a reckless challenge on the edge of the area, leaving England a man down for the remaining minutes of the game. Solanke's strike proved to be the difference as England left with all three points.

The hosts saw left-back Alex Telles dismissed after two bookings in a 74-second spell, the second after a wild sliding tackle on Stephan Lichtsteiner on 27 minutes. His side spent the rest of the game with 10 men, losing 1-0. The dismissal of Telles had a major impact on the game, resulting in Porto having to play with 10 men for the majority of the match. This put them at a significant disadvantage as they were unable to effectively pressure Juventus, who were able to keep possession for longer periods of time and create more chances on goal. The lack of numbers also meant that Porto were unable to build attacks and take advantage of any opportunities that arose. Ultimately, this resulted in a 1-0 defeat for the home side despite a valiant effort from their players.

William Johnston, of Walsham-le-Willows, Suffolk, admitted dumping the rubbish, described as building material and household waste, last April. Suffolk Police said it was a "potential danger to motorists and other road users" and "could have caused a serious accident." Johnston pleaded guilty to the offence of depositing controlled waste without a permit at an Ipswich Magistrates Court hearing. He was fined 1,500 and had to pay costs of 1,000 as well as a victim surcharge of 150.

Voters here have yet to make their choice in the regional election. But already there's something of the victory march in the chancellor's step. It has been years since her party last won an election in this region, and her confidence in her chances is evident. With her message of economic prosperity and social justice, she's already convinced many voters here that she can bring much-needed change to the region. Supporters have been out in force, helping spread the word and encouraging people to cast their ballots in her favor. Polls suggest that they may be successful in doing so, as her popularity has steadily risen over the past few weeks. If she can indeed ride the wave of momentum to a decisive victory, it would be a historic moment for her party.

Naz Shah has apologised for sharing the graphic showing Israel's outline superimposed onto a map of the US with the comment "problem solved." It was shared in 2014, before she became an MP. Yes, Shah has apologised for the post. In a statement released shortly after the post resurfaced in 2019, she said: "I deeply regret the hurt I have caused by comments I made on social media several years ago. They do not reflect my views and I apologise for any offence caused."

Chasing 268 in the first Test, Australia were all out for 161, their innings finishing with a record 154 consecutive deliveries without a run. Australia - the world's top-ranked Test team at the time - went on to lose the match by 107 runs. This record was broken in the second Test of the series, where Australia were all out for just 97 runs. This was their lowest total in a Test match since 1977, and they lost by an even bigger margin of 166 runs. The innings finished with 172 consecutive deliveries without a run, which is the new record for most consecutive balls without a run in a Test match.

The Slovenian club has knocked Hibernian, Rangers and Celtic out of Europe in recent seasons. Yet McInnes is adamant that his players are not fearful of the quality of the opposition. No, the Aberdeen players are not fearful of their opponents. Instead, they take each game as a challenge and strive to overcome them. All of the clubs mentioned have been impressive in Europe in recent years, but the Aberdeen players are focused on taking the game to their opponents and trying to get the result that they want.

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said the figure was up from 7.6 in the year to February. Separate figures showed the amount of money borrowed for home loans in March was the highest since 2008. The ONS said total borrowing, excluding student loans, rose to 19.9bn in March from 17.2bn in February. Borrowing for house purchases increased to 10.6bn from 8.8bn in the previous month. The figures suggest that more people are taking on debt to buy property, although the number of mortgages approved for house purchases fell slightly to 66,000 in March from 67,000 the month before. The Bank of England said the number of mortgages approved for house purchases had been broadly stable over the past six months but was still lower than its pre-crisis peak of 91,000 in 2007. It also noted that there had been a marked increase in the availability of high loan-to-value mortgages. The ONS said total consumer credit, which includes loans and credit cards, rose to 11.3bn in March from 10.1bn in February. This was the highest level since November 2016.

Scripps' channels include the Food Network and Travel Channel. The two companies are estimated to have 20 of ad-supported TV viewership in the US The two said the deal would create a powerhouse in media, entertainment and digital content. Scripps also owns other channels, such as HGTV, DIY Network, Cooking Channel, Great American Country and the Oprah Winfrey Network (OWN). The company also operates digital networks like Newsy and Flipboard. Scripps recently acquired Pluto TV, a free streaming service with more than 12 million monthly active users.

Mr Osborne cited "tentative signs of a balanced, broad based and sustainable recovery," but stressed it was still the "early stages" and "plenty of risks" remained. Mr Osborne said that the government's economic plan was "working," but that it needed to continue. He said: "We are starting to see a balanced, broad-based and sustainable recovery with investment, exports and household spending all growing strongly. But we have to be realistic. It is still early days, and plenty of risks remain both at home and abroad. "That is why I am determined that the government should not abandon its economic plan - a plan for jobs and growth. We must stick to it, so that Britain continues along the path of prosperity."

Authors including The English Patient writer Michael Ondaatje and Peter Carey will not attend the PEN Literary Gala in New York on 5 May. They said PEN - known for its defence of writers' freedom of speech - had not done enough to support the Palestinian call for a boycott of Israeli cultural institutions. In response, PEN Executive Director Suzanne Nossel said that while the organization stands firmly behind the right of individuals and organizations to make their own decisions about participation in cultural exchanges, it 'strongly opposes any effort to delegitimize and marginalize Israel, or any nation.' She also stated that PEN is strongly committed to fostering dialogue between Israeli, Palestinian, and other writers of the region.

The 35-year-old schoolteacher told the court that her digestive system sometimes converts food into alcohol. After her arrest, her doctor conducted tests that found that high levels of yeast in her system cause the condition. Her lawyer argued that the condition is rare, and it can lead to a person having a blood alcohol level above the legal limit without having consumed any alcoholic beverages. The judge ruled that the woman was innocent of DUI charges because she could not have controlled her body's production of alcohol.

The Council for Science and Technology (CST) wants "public good" GM varieties to be grown and tested in the UK. It says GM crops should be assessed individually - like any other product or technology - and if they can benefit society, they should be allowed to be grown. The CST believes that GM crops should be tested in a controlled environment, with strict safety protocols in place. It also believes that the public should be consulted on the issue and invited to participate in discussions about the merits of growing GM crops. In addition, the CST believes that any GM crops grown in the UK should be clearly labelled so that consumers can make an informed decision about whether or not to purchase them. Furthermore, it believes that the environmental and economic impacts of GM crops should be assessed before they are approved for commercial use.

Moderate exercise increased the size of the hippocampus, an area of the brain that makes memories, in 120 volunteers. The year-long trial, published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, provides further evidence that lifestyle changes can lead to improved brain health. The participants in the study were split into two groups. The first group was assigned to walk around a track for 40 minutes, three times a week, while the second group was instructed to stretch and perform balance exercises. At the end of the trial, MRI results showed that the hippocampus of those who had walked had grown by 2, compared to no growth in the stretching group. Researchers believe that physical exercise may be able to combat age-related decline in the hippocampus, which is associated with memory loss and dementia. The findings suggest that moderate aerobic exercise can improve cognitive function in humans and may even help protect against age-related diseases.

Joe Storey, 27, had denied murdering Kerri McAuley, 32, who was found dead at Southalls Way, Norwich, on 8 January, but admitted manslaughter. Storey was high on cocaine when he killed Ms McAuley. In March 2021, Storey was sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 20 years. He was also ordered to pay an 170 victim surcharge. Judge Stephen Holt said that Storey had "punched and strangled" Ms McAuley after they had had an argument, resulting in her death. He noted that Storey had been on drugs at the time and had shown no remorse for his actions. The judge said it was a "tragic case" and that Storey had taken a "valuable human life." He concluded by saying that a message must be sent that domestic violence and drug use will not be tolerated.

A man entered the store on Balmoral Place between 07:30 and 07:45, threatened a 33-year-old member of staff with a weapon and attacked him. The suspect fled with a four-figure sum of money. The police are appealing for anyone with information about the incident to come forward. They are particularly interested in speaking to anyone who was in the store or nearby at the time, or who may have seen someone acting suspiciously in the area. Witnesses can call the police on 101 quoting reference number XYZ123.

The Nikkei 225 closed down 0.4 at 18,916.02, although the index had been as much as 1.6 in earlier trade. Shares in Toshiba fell 9.8 on reports it was expecting a huge loss in its nuclear division. Other stocks that closed down included Honda Motor Co, which fell 2.1, and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, which dropped 1. The broader Topix index of all First Section issues on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell 0.36 percent to close at 1,475.91. The turnover was about 2,342 billion yen (21.49 billion U.S. dollars).

A third person had been arrested in the raid in Verviers and weapons are reported to have been recovered. Prosecutor Eric Van Der Sypt told reporters police had targeted a suspected terrorist cell that was in the "advanced stages" of preparing an attack on police. The third person was arrested during a raid in Verviers, Belgium, on Wednesday night (January 15). Police reportedly seized weapons and explosives during the raid. Van Der Sypt said two suspects were killed when they opened fire on officers during the operation, while a third managed to escape. It is unclear if the third person arrested was part of the suspected cell or simply happened to be at the scene of the raid. The identities of the three individuals have not been released. No further details about the third suspect's role in the incident have been released.

The US has said the bombing, which took place in the Afghan city of Kunduz, was a mistake and it was attempting to strike the Taliban. MSF wants the bombing to be investigated as a war crime. The US has said it will cooperate with any investigation into the incident and has not ruled out that it could be subject to a criminal inquiry. MSF has called for an independent international inquiry, saying that an internal US investigation would not be impartial or sufficient. The US has said it will assist in any inquiry that is conducted by the Afghan government.

12 June 2017 Last updated at 15:24 BST He first arrived on the men's tennis Tour when he was 15-years-old and has been setting records since then. Leah has taken part in the US Open, French Open, Wimbledon and Australian Open, becoming the first female player to reach the finals of all four Grand Slam tournaments. She has also become the youngest player ever to win a Grand Slam singles title, as well as being the first African-American woman to win the US Open. She has been ranked number one in the world by the Women's Tennis Association for a total of 67 weeks. Leah has won a total of 23 Grand Slam titles, including three doubles championships, making her the most successful female tennis player of all time. Her success has made her one of the most recognizable athletes in the world and she is an inspiration to many young players.

Gen Sir Nicholas Houghton told the BBC's Andrew Marr that refusing to launch nuclear weapons would "seriously undermine" Britain's "deterrent." And he said he would be worried if such a situation were to arise. Sir Nicholas said that it would be a "serious concern" if a Prime Minister were ever to make a decision not to launch nuclear weapons, as such an action would "seriously undermine the credibility of our deterrent." He also noted that such a decision would have profound implications for Britain's standing in the international community. In addition, Sir Nicholas said that he was confident that any Prime Minister who had the power to launch nuclear weapons would exercise their power responsibly and only do so in extreme circumstances. He also noted that any use of nuclear weapons would have to be in line with international law.

The small objects were hidden by artist Luke Jerram for his installation Treasure City, with clues hidden in paintings at the 20-21 Arts Centre. The first one, a replica Viking longship, was hidden in a tree in St. Andrew's Park in Scunthorpe, England. The second one, a golden Buddha statue, was hidden in a secret location in Hull, England. The third one, a Faberge egg, was hidden underneath a bridge in Grimsby, England. The fourth one, a mechanical puppet, was hidden in a walled garden in Grimsby, England. The fifth one, a tiny castle, was hidden inside a hollow tree in Cleethorpes, England.

Adam Wilson, of Lostock Hall, was found with serious injuries at a property on Albrighton Crescent in Lostock Hall near Preston in September. Jason Taylor, 21, of Westfield, Lostock Hall , was charged with attempted murder in connection with the incident. Taylor pleaded guilty to the charge at a hearing at Preston Crown Court on 8 November 2019 and was sentenced to 14 years in prison. Wilson suffered multiple stab wounds during the attack and was taken to hospital for treatment. He is currently recovering from his injuries.

"We save people here every day," said the 46-year-old policeman - managing to sound both proud and chiding and the same time. Mr Hassan has now spent three years assigned to the station close to one of the most dangerous areas in the city. The area around is known for its high levels of gang activity and drug dealing, but Mr Hassan has seen first-hand how it can be transformed by the right approach. He has helped to establish a youth outreach programme that works with local schools to steer young people away from crime and towards education and employment. "When I started here, I found that many of the young people were in gangs, or involved in drug use and dealing," he said. "But now, we're seeing more of them in college and looking to find work. That's why I joined the police - to make a difference and help people." Mr Hassan's efforts have been noticed by others, too. In 2017, he was nominated for a Police Bravery award, which he won. He has since become an inspiration to other officers, showing them what can be achieved by working hard and caring about the community they serve.

The 23-year-old, on loan from Chelsea, saved a penalty in normal time and one in a shoot-out when the Chairboys knocked Blackpool out of the EFL Trophy in January. And, speaking to the club's media team, he is pleased with his form of late. "I think I'm doing well," said McGee, who has made 18 appearances for Wycombe this season. "I'm playing regularly and I'm happy with my performances. I'm getting more confident as the games go on and I'm enjoying it." McGee was part of a young defence against Blackpool, and he believes that togetherness has been key to their recent good form. "It's a great group of lads here," he said. "We all get along really well and it helps us on the pitch. We understand each other's game and there's a great team spirit." The defender also singled out manager Gareth Ainsworth for praise, claiming his guidance has been invaluable. "The gaffer is great," he said. "He gives us all lots of advice and tips and he's always telling us what we need to do better. He's very passionate about his job and that rubs off on the players."

The cub will be the first giant panda to be born in Hong Kong. Earlier this year, 10-year-old Ying Ying mated naturally and was also artificially inseminated. However, the staff of the Ocean Park Conservation Foundation Hong Kong have not yet been able to confirm a pregnancy. They are closely monitoring her hormone levels and conducting ultrasound examinations to determine if she is indeed pregnant. If she is, then the cub would be due in mid-August 2019.

The 25-year-old claimed her maiden able-bodied national title on Sunday and won team gold with England at the 2010 Commonwealth Games. But to qualify for Rio, Brown would have to beat her English team-mate, world No 4 Sally Conway. Brown had to compete at the British Championships in April and then the European Championships in May to qualify for Rio. She did so with a bronze medal at the Europeans, but it was not enough to secure an individual spot for Rio. Instead, she will be part of a four-strong team alongside Conway, Gemma Gibbons and Sophie Cox. Brown said: "I'm absolutely over the moon. It's been a long road and a lot of hard work has gone into getting here but I'm really excited to represent Team GB at the Olympics."

Hospital bosses made changes last August in a bid to help ambulances reach the emergency unit more quickly at the University Hospital of Wales (UHW) in Cardiff. Barriers were installed in the car park, reducing the area for parking. The changes followed a report from the Welsh Ambulance Service which revealed that the UHW site had been consistently missing its target of ensuring 75 of ambulances reach the emergency unit within 15 minutes. The new barriers were designed to help improve the flow of traffic and reduce congestion, but they have caused frustration amongst visitors and staff who are used to having more available parking spaces. Hospital bosses say they are working to address these concerns. They claim that the number of ambulances reaching the hospital within the 15-minute target has increased since the changes were made and that they are continuing to monitor the situation.

Nashat Melhem was tracked down to a mosque in his home town of Arara and killed in a gun battle, police said. The attacks sparked a huge hunt and security crackdown in the city of Tel Aviv and surrounding areas. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, but Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed Palestinian militants. He said Melhem had been "radicalized" by Islamic State's ideology and was influenced by the group's propaganda. The attack itself was carried out with a 9mm Carl Gustav submachine gun, which is a common weapon used by both militants and criminals. The gun was purchased illegally in the West Bank, according to police. Melhem was known to have had contacts with radical Islamists prior to the attack, but it is unclear if he had direct ties to any particular group. It is also not clear if he had any specific target in mind. However, the incident has raised security concerns in Israel, prompting the government to announce a series of new measures to combat terrorism. These include a crackdown on illegal weapons and increased security at public places.

The inquiry will look at historical abuse of children in care in Scotland. But John Findlay, who was abused while a pupil in the care of Aberlour House in Moray, said it did not go far enough. He said: "It's a start, but I feel it doesn't go far enough as it only looks at children in care up to the age of 18. There needs to be recognition that there are people who were abused as adults and that these cases should be investigated as well." Mr Findlay argued that the inquiry should cover all forms of abuse in care settings, regardless of the victim's age. He added that he was concerned that cases prior to the 1960s would not be fully investigated due to a lack of records. The inquiry is being chaired by Lady Smith and will look into cases between 1945 and 1995. It is expected to report its findings and make recommendations for change by February 2017.

JP Nadeau was reportedly struck by lightning mid-sentence in his apple orchard in New Brunswick, Canada. "And just as I told my new son-in-law'You're a lucky guy' - Boom!" he said afterwards. The lightning strike was reported by Nadeau's son-in-law, who had been visiting the orchard with him. According to the son-in-law, Nadeau had just finished speaking when a bolt of lightning suddenly struck a nearby tree, sending a shockwave through the air. Nadeau was knocked unconscious and suffered minor burns and some hearing loss in his left ear. He was taken to a local hospital where he was treated and released the same day. Nadeau later recounted the incident, saying: "It came out of nowhere. I remember it like it was yesterday - boom! And there I was on the ground." He added that he felt lucky to have survived the ordeal, noting that if he had been standing in a different spot, the consequences could have been much more severe.

The blast tore through the crowded Jameela market in the predominantly Shia district of Sadr City. The Sunni jihadist group, Islamic State (IS), said it was behind the bombing and claimed that more than 50 people died. The attack was one of the deadliest in Iraq since the US invasion in 2003, with reports of up to 60 people killed and another 70 injured. The majority of those killed were civilians, including women and children. The bombing was part of a wave of violence that has engulfed Iraq in recent months amid a rising sectarian divide between Sunnis and Shias. IS has claimed responsibility for several other attacks in the past week, including two bombings in Baghdad on Tuesday. The violence has been fueled by the long-running civil war in neighboring Syria as well as the ongoing political crisis in Iraq.

Instead of fees rising to PS9,250 per year in the autumn, Jeremy Corbyn is proposing a complete handbrake turn in saying that university tuition should not cost students anything. It's a bold and ambitious move, one that is sure to draw a lot of attention and discussion. Corbyn's proposal would mean that universities could no longer charge tuition fees for undergraduate courses and that all students would be able to attend university free of charge. It could also mean the end of student loans and the associated debt. This would have an enormous impact on the UK education system, as well as the wider economy. It would likely require an increase in government funding, but it could also lead to more people studying at higher levels and potentially more graduates entering the workforce with better qualifications. It could also reduce inequality, as those from poorer backgrounds may now find it easier to access higher education. Ultimately, it would be up to the government to decide whether this proposal is feasible or not.

The man, 31, approached Police Community Support Officers guarding a cordon in Albert Road in Plymouth on Thursday evening. Devon and Cornwall Police said it was believed he was assaulted by a number of people, who then fled the scene. The man was taken to Derriford Hospital for treatment for injuries which were not life-threatening. Police have now launched an appeal for witnesses and information. Anyone with information is asked to contact police on 101 quoting crime reference CR08685821.

Notts' 39-run win against Essex at Trent Bridge on Monday sees them return to the showpiece event at Edgbaston for the first time since 2010. Read, who has won a Royal London Cup with Notts, is excited by the challenge of competing on the biggest stage once again. "It's an incredible feeling to be back in the final after so many years away," said Read. "We've worked hard all season and to get to this point is a fantastic achievement for the whole squad. We know we have the quality to go out there and win the trophy, so we can't wait to get started."

So for the one tasked with replacing Karl Robinson as MK Dons manager, changing the mark of a man who had been in charge for more than half of the club's entire existence is no easy feat. But that is the challenge that awaits the next man in the role and it will be a huge one, with expectations high after such a long period of success under Robinson. The new manager will need to find a way to bring a fresh approach to the team, while also maintaining the traditions and values that made MK Dons such an attractive proposition in the first place. A difficult balance to strike, but certainly one that can be achieved. First and foremost, the new man in charge will need to focus on building a new squad capable of challenging for promotion from League One. This means making sure that the club has enough depth and quality to compete at this level, as well as building a team spirit and mentality that will help them succeed. Tactically, the new boss will need to make sure he is able to get the best out of his players and be willing to adapt and change depending on the opposition. They will also need to be able to work with the squad they have in order to get the most out of it, rather than relying on big name signings. Finally, the new manager will need to be able to build relationships with the fans and local community, something that Robinson was very good at. With a passionate fanbase, getting them on side could be key to the team's success going forward. Ultimately, replacing Karl Robinson as MK Dons manager won't be an easy task, but it is certainly one that can be achieved with the right kind of planning and preparation.

A new programme, known as Drive, will be aimed at the most dangerous offenders, BBC News has been told. Backed by domestic abuse charities SafeLives and Respect, it will be launched in November. Drive will provide intensive support for up to two years for the most violent and repeat offenders, who often have multiple victims. It will be tailored to the individual and combine therapeutic treatments such as cognitive behavioural therapy with practical help like finding employment. The programme is funded by 8 million from the Home Office and will be managed by a consortium led by the non-profit organisation Turning Point. The consortium will also include domestic abuse charities SafeLives and Respect, as well as the College of Policing and other criminal justice organisations. The scheme will focus on the highest risk individuals, who are arrested the most often and are responsible for the most serious offences against partners and family members. Offenders can expect to receive one-to-one support, while victims will be offered practical help such as counselling and refuge services. The aim is to reduce reoffending by cutting off the cycle of violence, as well as providing victims with the help they need to break away from their abusers. It is hoped that Drive will help to create safer communities and reduce the impact of domestic abuse on society.

Dame Rosemary Butler said it was "critical" that people voted, with more powers coming to Wales. She said fewer than half of those eligible to vote did so in 2011. Dame Rosemary Butler urged people to take part in the Welsh Assembly Elections, saying that it was "critical" for them to have their voices heard. She noted that fewer than half of those eligible to vote had done so in 2011 and that more powers were coming to Wales. She also highlighted the importance of voting to ensure that the right people were elected to represent their interests and those of the country.

The head of football's governing body outlined his vision for an expanded tournament comprising 16 groups of three teams earlier this month. The top two teams in each group would advance to the knockout stage of a tournament that would be held every two years. FIFA president Gianni Infantino stated that the new format would create more opportunities for smaller nations to participate and compete in international tournaments, as well as providing teams with more matches against opponents of similar ability. It is believed that this will lead to better quality football and an increase in fan engagement. The new format could also generate more revenue for FIFA through increased broadcast and sponsorship deals. The proposed changes have been met with some criticism from the football world. Some argue that the 16 groups of three teams will still favour the traditional powerhouses of the game, who are likely to qualify for the knockout stages. Others have criticised the lack of consideration given to the current competitive structures that exist in many regions, such as the CONCACAF Nations League and CONMEBOL's Copa America. It has also been argued that the expanded tournament will reduce the importance of other tournaments, such as the European Championships and the African Cup of Nations, which could limit the chances of smaller nations to achieve success. Overall, the proposed changes by FIFA have the potential to revolutionise international football. However, it is clear that further discussion needs to take place in order to ensure that all stakeholders are satisfied with the outcome.

Joan Ostojic's daughters Katherine, 21, and Alice, 19, were on a boat carrying 25 people that went down between Lombok and the Komodo Islands on Saturday. They sat on the back of the boat with their father and mother. The Indonesian search and rescue agency, BASARNAS, is leading a search effort for the missing passengers. The agency has dispatched helicopters, boats, and divers to help in the search. They are also receiving assistance from the Australian and United States governments. The families of the missing passengers are being kept updated on the progress of the search and rescue efforts. Joan Ostojic's family is holding out hope that her daughters will be found safe.

The hosts, chasing 379 to win, began slowly and Chopra's caution increased after a middle-order collapse of three wickets for 25 runs. The opener laboured for five and a half hours, eventually making a run-a-ball 96 before being dismissed. Chopra's innings was crucial as it helped Rajasthan take the game to the final session with the visitors still needing 183 runs to win. Unfortunately, the hosts fell short of the target by 33 runs despite Chopra's efforts.

McCall said he and some of his players were goaded by supporters following their 1-0 loss to the Lions at Wembley. He questioned why stewards had not prevented the invasion. "It's a disgrace," he said. "What is going on? It's not acceptable. We should never be in that position. "The players were spat at and had stuff thrown at them. It's not acceptable. The stewards should have done more to protect the players."

13 July 2016 Last updated at 14:42 BST The game has not been officially released in the UK, but keen gamers have found ways around the app's country restrictions to get their hands on it. The augmented reality game Pokemon Go has become an overnight sensation since its launch in the US and Australia last week. Designed for smartphones, it allows players to catch virtual creatures known as Pokemon in the real world, using GPS and the camera on their phone. But while it has been officially released in those two countries, the game has not yet been officially released in the UK. However, some gamers are finding ways around this. Pokemon Go is available as a free download from the Apple App Store and Google Play, but users are only able to download it if their device is connected to one of the two countries in which it has been officially released. Some keen gamers have found ways around this, though, by setting up a new account registered in either the US or Australia, or by downloading the app directly from third-party websites like APK Mirror. It is worth noting that these methods can be risky and could potentially expose your device to malicious software. However, it appears that the app's developer Niantic Labs is working on making the game available in other countries, including the UK. In the meantime, those who do manage to get their hands on the game should remember that it comes with many safety warnings, such as not playing in dangerous locations, always being aware of your surroundings, and following local laws.

The dollar climbed 1 against a basket of currencies, and against the Japanese currency it rose above 123 yen. Analysts cited last Friday's US inflation figures as having triggered the rise, as they showed that consumer prices have been rising at a slower rate than expected. This suggests to investors that the Federal Reserve will likely keep interest rates steady for the near future.

The so-called New Deal will reshape how they are trained as their career develops and help them to deliver the new "made in Wales curriculum." Each of Wales' 37,600 teachers will have access to tailored support that includes bespoke training, professional development and mentoring opportunities. The New Deal also includes an increased focus on technology in the classroom, using digital tools to enhance learning experiences. Additionally, the New Deal will allow teachers to become more connected with their Welsh communities, enabling them to better understand and appreciate the needs of their local communities, while also making it easier for them to collaborate with other professionals in the field.

The net benefit is about PS257m each year and takes into account the impact on public services such as the NHS. In 2014, 34,670 students travelled from outside the European Union to study in the UK, bringing in 2.5 billion of foreign exchange earnings and 1.2 billion in tax revenues. This suggests that international students bring a significant economic benefit to the UK and the net benefit for the UK is likely to be greater than PS257m.
Lib Dem sources say 30,000 local authority places are being lost as money is diverted to new free schools. They said Mr Gove was "ideologically obsessed" about backing free schools.

The emails confirmed the Trump camp's interest in receiving help from the Russian government to discredit opponent Hillary Clinton during the presidential campaign last year. The Dow Jones was unchanged after the news was released.p pThe emails revealed a worrying level of collaboration between the Trump campaign and the Russian government. The news sent jitters through the financial markets, with the Dow Jones dropping by more than 200 points on the news. Investors were concerned that the revelations could lead to further investigations and potential sanctions against Trump and his team.p

He's been refused somewhere to stay because he comes from Ebola hotspot, Sierra Leone. Amara arrived in Norwich from West Africa a fortnight ago and was turned down by two hostels because he came from Ebola hotspot, Sierra Leone. He has now been offered a place to stay at the local Salvation Army, where staff have been given guidance and information on how to deal with people who have come from countries affected by the virus.

He told Buzzfeed News he needed to go to a "quiet place" to focus on writing, adding that Twitter is "the least quiet place I've ever been in my life." He said he used to love Twitter but found it very distracting and that he was in the process of deleting his account. He explained that he was trying to be more mindful and focus on the present moment instead of being constantly connected to the online world.

The greatest foreign policy disasters have tended to come when the UK has either ignored America - such as when it joined France in invading Suez - or when it has followed America too closely - such as when it joined the US in invading Iraq. Other major foreign policy disasters include the UK's involvement in the Boer War, its lack of support for India and China during the two world wars, and its decision to grant independence to India without adequate preparation.

The industry group said sales of the fish leapt more than 50 by value - to PS186.7m - and 13 by volume. British food and drink exports as a whole rose 6 to PS20.1bn in the first quarter of 2018, with non-EU countries accounting for much of the growth. The UK Seafood industry group said that the strong performance of the fish industry was driven by increased demand from both domestic and export markets. The group reported a 22 increase in exports to the EU and a 29 increase to non-EU countries. It noted that sales to China had risen by 55, with exports to the USA, Japan and Hong Kong also up significantly. The group attributed the rise to a range of factors, such as new product launches, promotional campaigns, improved supply chain management and better access to retail markets. It noted that recent investment in technology and innovation had been particularly beneficial to the industry. Overall, the UK Seafood industry group said that the positive outlook for the sector was due to a combination of factors, including increased global demand, greater market access and a well-organised supply chain.

The new charge will be imposed from April 2017 and help ensure that big business shoulders the cost of training workers, George Osborne said. But business groups have described the charge as "disappointing" and a "tax on jobs." The levy, which is expected to raise 3bn by 2020, will be paid by employers with a pay bill of more than 3m. The government says these businesses are the most able to pay and that every penny raised will go directly into training apprentices. However, the CBI warned that the new charge could hit small and medium-sized firms hard, putting off some from taking on apprentices in the first place. The British Chambers of Commerce said the proposal was "too much too soon" and called for a more gradual implementation. The Federation of Small Businesses said the levy would leave small firms facing an additional burden at a time when they were already struggling. It added that the government should focus on helping employers take on more staff and not impose a tax on jobs. The government has promised to protect small businesses by exempting them from the levy if they have an annual pay bill of less than 3m. In addition, it said it would also provide extra support for those with fewer than 50 employees who want to take on their first apprentice.

The typical home in the East increased in cost by 8.3 in the year to the end of July, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said. Prices in London, which make up a large part of the property market in the East, rose by 10.4. The ONS said that the average house price in the East stood at 300,000 in the year to July, up from 276,000 a year earlier. London saw even larger increases, with prices rising by 10.4 to an average of 472,000. Overall, UK house prices rose by 7.7, with the average cost of a property standing at 247,000. The ONS said that the growth in house prices was driven largely by increased demand from buyers, with the number of transactions across the country having risen by 9.1 in the year to July. However, there were signs that the market was beginning to cool, with annual growth slowing for the fourth consecutive month. This may be due to uncertainty surrounding Brexit, as well as affordability issues for some potential buyers.

Labour suffered heavy losses at the hands of the SNP, with the Tories defying opinion polls to secure a House of Commons majority. In a speech in London, Mr Miliband said the result was a "very disappointing and difficult night for the Labour Party" but he vowed to continue the fight for social justice. The SNP's landslide victory in Scotland saw it take 56 of 59 seats, with Labour losing 40 seats in Scotland alone. The Conservatives won an overall majority of 331 seats, while Labour secured 232. Labour leader Ed Miliband said: "We haven't made the gains we wanted in England and Wales and in Scotland we have seen a surge of nationalism overwhelm our party. I want to say to all those who were victims of this massive swing that this is not the end of our fight for a fairer, more equal country. We are the party of social justice, we will never stop fighting for it."

The incident happened at the Co-op store in Thornton at about 02:15 on 17 May. A Ford Transit flatbed van, stolen in Station Road, reversed into the premises. Extensive damage was caused to the store front and a number of items were stolen. The offenders, who are believed to have been wearing dark clothing, left the scene in the van in an unknown direction. No descriptions of the offenders are available. A full investigation is underway and police are appealing for anyone with information or dashcam footage to contact them. Anyone with information should call Lancashire Police on 101 quoting log 0336 of 17052021.

The Perth club has suspended the team-mates pending a club investigation. Wright told BBC Scotland that "if what's alleged" to have occurred did in fact happen "we'll come down severely on those involved." The club has not commented on whether or not any charges will be brought against the players at this time, but has said that the investigation is ongoing. It is expected that the investigation results will be made available in the near future.

Spencer Wilding, who hails from Rhyl, was the guest of honour at a special screening of Rogue One. He had to muster all powers of the force to keep his emotions in check as he watched the movie which features him as a giant alien creature. Spencer said: "It was an incredible experience. I was so proud to be part of Rogue One and to have my performance seen by so many people. Watching it on the big screen with a live audience was truly humbling." He added that he felt very honoured to be part of such a huge franchise.

Observations with Japan's Subaru telescope reveal the likely icy body to be some 15.5 billion km from the Sun - about three times further away than even far-flung Pluto. Scientists believe it is a member of the so-called inner Oort cloud - a vast region of icy debris thought to exist beyond the orbits of even the most distant known planets. The newly discovered body, called 2015 TG387, has an orbit that takes it on a spectacularly wide loop around the solar system. At its closest approach, it passes about 65 times further from the Sun than Neptune. On its most distant point, it gets about two and a half times farther away than the most remote known Solar System object. The new object's orbital period is estimated to be about 40,000 years. This discovery adds to the growing evidence that the outer reaches of our Solar System may be teeming with objects like 2015 TG387. The fact that it was found close to the predicted location of the inner Oort Cloud suggests that this region could be more densely populated than astronomers previously thought. Its discovery also helps scientists better understand how objects in the outer Solar System interact with each other and with their environment.

Saints' 3-0 reverse at Everton on Monday completed a difficult Christmas period for Claude Puel's side. But Stephens, who made his Premier League debut at Goodison Park, believes a change of system could work wonders for the South Coast club. "We played a different system at Everton," Stephens told reporters. "It was a bit more of a defensive system and I think it worked well, but we just didn't get that result we wanted. We had some good chances and we just need to take them. "But if we can keep playing this way and keep improving like we are, then I'm sure the results will come. We just have to keep working hard and hopefully the luck will turn our way." Stephens has been a regular fixture in Puel's matchday squad since arriving from Plymouth Argyle in July, making 11 Premier League appearances so far this season. The 21-year-old admits he is still getting used to the demands of top-flight football, but has been encouraged by his recent performances. "It has been an amazing experience so far," he said. "Obviously it's a lot harder than the Championship, but I think I have coped quite well with it. I've been playing quite well recently, so I'm happy with that. "I'm just trying to learn as much as I can from the experienced players around me and improve with every game I play."

Every owner of a gadget piloted via a touchscreen has spent time rubbing it with a tissue, a cloth or a sleeve gripped round the heel of the hand to clean it up. Yes, this is true. Many people do use tissues, cloths, or their sleeves to clean their touchscreen devices. This is a common practice and is done to help keep the device free of fingerprints and dirt.

In Northern Ireland, weather warnings have also been issued as the third storm of the season, Storm Clodagh, moved in. The Met Office issued a yellow warning for severe gales and heavy rain. The national weather service also warned of localised flooding, disruption to transport and power outages.

The 21-year-old had been at Hednesford Town on loan this season, but has experience in the fifth tier with Southport and Wrexham. Adam Lockwood's Guiseley are currently five points from safety in the National League North, with nine games remaining. Lockwood said: "We are delighted to have signed Lewis and he will add competition for places in defence. He has a good pedigree having featured for both Wrexham and Southport in the National League. "He is a strong defender who likes to play out from the back, which fits perfectly with our style of play."

He led the parade of soldiers along Llandudno promenade to re-affirm the Freedom of the County of Conwy. Hundreds of residents and holidaymakers turned out to see the march in June 2019. The parade was led by His Royal Highness, the Duke of Kent, who is the Colonel-in-Chief of the Royal Welsh Regiment. He was accompanied by the Lord Lieutenant of Clwyd and the Mayor of Conwy. The soldiers marched along the promenade and received a warm reception from the public. The event marked the first time in many years that the Freedom of the County had been celebrated in such a way.

6 December 2016 Last updated at 09:59 GMT The app can now identify up to 70,000 public figures by looking at images, video or an actual person. The BBC's Rory Cellan-Jones has been testing the software. The new app, developed by Microsoft's AI team, is called Who? and it can recognize up to 70,000 public figures by looking at images, video or an actual person. It works by using facial recognition technology to compare a face with thousands of faces in its database. The app can identify celebrities, politicians, athletes, musicians and other public figures from past and present. It can also tell you how old a person is and what country they come from. To test the accuracy of the app, I tested it on photos of well-known people such as Barack Obama, Taylor Swift and David Beckham. In each case, it correctly identified the individual in less than three seconds. The app also worked with images of lesser-known people, including my colleagues at the BBC. It was able to accurately identify them all in less than five seconds. Overall, the app worked very well and was surprisingly accurate. It could be particularly useful for news organisations who need to quickly identify people in videos or photos. The only downside is that it only recognises celebrities and public figures, so it won't help you with your friends or family. However, it's great for quickly identifying people in the public domain.

The PRI is set to win about 30, with the conservative National Action Party on about 22, said the head of the National Electoral Institute. On current projections, the PRI would hold the most seats in the legislature.

The MarkitCIPS manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 49.2 from 50.7 in March. A reading below 50 indicates falling output. It is the first time that activity in the sector has contracted since July 2016. The figures suggest that the manufacturing sector is still feeling the effects of Brexit uncertainty. Business activity and new orders both fell in April, while businesses reported a fall in employment for the first time since August 2016. This is a worrying sign for the UK economy, as manufacturing accounts for 10 of GDP and is a key barometer for economic health. With the UK yet to reach an agreement on how it will leave the EU, business confidence is likely to remain low in the near future.

Reuben Lewis from Llanidloes was driven 45 minutes from Ysgol Cedewain, Newtown, without teachers or transport staff realising he was still on board. BBC Wales understands he was then left at a bus stop in Newtown. The incident happened on the afternoon of Thursday, 15 October. Powys County Council has apologised and an investigation is now underway. A spokesperson for the council said: "We are sorry to hear about this incident and we are carrying out a full investigation as a matter of urgency. The safety and welfare of pupils travelling to and from school is a priority for us and we take any reports of this nature very seriously." The council added that they are working with the relevant transport providers to ensure such incidents do not happen again. Reuben's family have been offered support by the council.

The 48-year-old took had been in charge of Posh since replacing Dave Robertson in September and lifted the club as high as the play-off places in January. But they have since slipped back, losing their last five games. The club released a statement on Sunday morning confirming the news that Ferguson had left the club, with first-team coach Grant McCann taking temporary charge. Ferguson's departure came after a 3-2 home defeat by Sheffield United on Saturday in which Posh twice came from behind to level. The former Wrexham boss was appointed just four days after Robertson's exit, but failed to turn around the team's fortunes in his 18 games in charge. Posh chairman Darragh MacAnthony said: "It is with great regret we announce the departure of Dave Robertson this afternoon. "Dave has been an honest, hardworking individual and gave his all for the club during his 18 matches in charge. Unfortunately, the results have not been good enough and it was felt it was the correct time for a change." He added: "We are now looking to bring in a new manager as soon as possible who has the right experience and attributes to take the football club forward."

The woman, 37-year-old Wu Shuoyan, is alleged to have been killed last May simply for refusing to hand over her phone number to cult members. The murder, filmed on CCTV , occurred in the Chinese city of Wenzhou, where Wu was an employee of a local pharmaceutical company. According to police reports, Wu was approached by two members of a cult-like organization who asked her for her phone number. When she refused, they began beating her and then stabbed her multiple times. She died at the scene. The two perpetrators were arrested and charged with murder. They are both believed to be members of the Church of Almighty God, a Christian cult founded in China in 1991. The Church of Almighty God has been identified as a dangerous organization that uses violence and deception to spread its message. Wu's death sparked outrage in China, with many calling for stronger laws against cults and harsher punishments for those who commit crimes in their name. Her story has become a rallying cry for reform and justice in the country, and her family is still seeking answers about what happened to her.

"It was very professional, but it was also emotional," he said. "It was very dignified but I would also say at the end it was quite emotional. "He reflected on his time in the role and the people he worked with and the things he achieved. "He's had a very successful period as Taoiseach, but obviously today was the end of that chapter."
