Mr Varadkar was accompanied at the meeting by Tanaiste Simon Coveney and Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe. Mr Martin is due to arrive in Government Buildings this afternoon to become the new Taoiseach. Irish Independent

Elisa Bianco said she had just months to live and Sally Retallack funded a PS2,500 final trip for the 22-year-old, London's Appeal Court heard. Bianco, of Station Road, Fowey, Cornwall, who had terminal cancer, was given the opportunity to fulfill her last wish - a trip to Florida with her family. Bianco died in April 2019. Retallack's generosity meant that Bianco got to experience a last holiday with her family, creating memories that will be cherished by all.

Mr Trump called off a rally on Friday night in Chicago after clashes between protesters and supporters. The Republican who has won a string of primary contests has blamed the violence on protesters, saying they had "planned" to cause trouble. But his detractors have accused him of creating an atmosphere of hate and intolerance with his rhetoric. Mr Trump has denied any responsibility for the violence, and insisted that he "does not condone it." He also claimed that some of the demonstrators were "professional agitators," although there is no evidence to back up that statement.

Police said the boy was badly injured in the incident, after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency crews were called the scene on the town's Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at around 3.15pm yesterday. A Police Scotland spokesman said: "The eight year old was taken to Monklands Hospital where he is being treated for serious injuries. "Enquiries are ongoing and officers are appealing for information." Anyone with information is asked to contact police on 101 quoting incident number 2162 of Wednesday, August 26.

The mutation was also present in our evolutionary "cousins" - the Neanderthals and Denisovans. However, it is not found in humans' closest living relatives, the chimpanzees. As early humans evolved, the mutation may have given them an increased ability to adapt to changing environmental conditions and survive. It is possible that this mutation was beneficial in some way, allowing humans to have greater success in their evolutionary journey.

Guy Hedger, 61, died in the early hours of 30 April after intruders reportedly broke into his home in Ashley, near Ringwood, and opened fire with a shotgun. Marine officers from Dorset Police said a firearms and explosives search of the property was being carried out in conjunction with military colleagues. The motive for the attack is not yet known. Mr Hedger's family has released a statement expressing their "total shock" over his death, saying he was a much-loved husband, father and grandfather who will be greatly missed. Detectives from Dorset Police are appealing for information and have asked anyone who may have seen suspicious activity in the area to contact them. A spokesman said the investigation is in its "very early stages."

The City Council wants to add an extra 700 spaces to the east of the Seacourt site, which currently has 794 spaces in an attempt to ease congestion. Proposals include: 1. Adding an additional 400 spaces to the existing 794 space lot. 2. Creating a new 300 space parking lot in an adjacent location. 3. Installing pay-by-space meters in both lots. 4. Increasing the time limits for parking in the existing lot. 5. Establishing a carpooling program to encourage commuters to drive fewer vehicles. 6. Creating a shuttle service to the Seacourt site from nearby public transportation hubs. 7. Installing electric vehicle charging stations in both lots. 8. Creating an app that allows drivers to reserve a spot in advance. 9. Working with local businesses to offer discounts to employees who use alternative forms of transportation. 10. Implementing a congestion pricing system during peak hours.

The park authority's planning committee said the land involved was earmarked for housing. However, it added that the developer's three planning applications for the project were "not deemed to meet the high standards of design and layout expected." The committee said it was "minded to refuse permission" unless the developer revised their plans to meet the required standards. The park authority will now consult with local stakeholders before making a final decision.

Julian Lewis, chairman of the Defence Select Committee, said the former prime minister had "charm and ability." But he had "dangerously" delayed renewing Trident, Mr Lewis said, also questioning Mr Blair's "willingness to take Britain into war." Mr Lewis noted that Mr Blair had "great strengths" but added that he had a "flawed judgement" when it came to foreign policy. He said that the former Prime Minister had an "abysmal record of decision-making in relation to Iraq, Libya and Afghanistan." He also questioned the decision to take part in the 2003 invasion of Iraq, saying that "it remains one of the greatest mistakes any British government has ever made."

Media playback is not supported on this device Platini wants to restore the image of world football's governing body in the wake of serious corruption allegations. "We want a reform of FIFA, a real reform," he said. "We want to restore the credibility and trust in the organisation. We need transparency and we need more democracy." Platini has pledged to put an end to the culture of corruption in FIFA and has promised to implement reforms that will make the organisation more transparent and accountable. He has outlined plans to introduce greater financial oversight, stricter ethics rules and term limits for senior officials. He also wants to ensure that elected members of FIFA's executive committee are fully independent from any commercial interests.

The Amateur International Boxing Association has said pro boxers will compete in Rio if a constitutional change is agreed next month. But Tyson, 49, a former Junior Olympic winner, said: "I don't think it's the right thing to do. Professional boxers have had a long history of being excluded from the Olympics, and I think that should stay the same. The Olympics is a place for amateurs who have dedicated their lives to the sport. Professional boxers are already making good money and having success in their own realm of boxing. They don't need the Olympic platform." Tyson's opinion represents a common sentiment among professional boxers that the Olympics should remain an event reserved solely for amateur athletes. Professional boxers often have more experience and resources than amateur athletes, which could be seen as unfair to give them access to the Olympics. Additionally, professional boxers may not take the Olympics as seriously as amateur athletes, thus undermining the importance of the Games.

The antiques, valued at between PS2,000 and PS3,000, were taken from Osterley Park House in Twickenham, south-west London, on 16 July. They were taken from a locked cabinet in a room in the house that is not open to the public. The items stolen include a bracelet, necklace, and a pair of earrings made from gold, rubies and sapphires, as well as a porcelain snuff box. The antiques are believed to date back to the 18th century and are rare and of great value. Police are appealing for anyone with information about the theft or the whereabouts of the items to contact them. They are asking people to check any second-hand shops they may frequent and to be aware that the items may be offered for sale online.

Food price inflation was 4.9 in June, compared with 3.2 in May, with rising pork prices partly to blame. While the headline inflation number was above analysts' expectations, it remains well below the Federal Reserve's 2 target. Food price inflation is a measure of the rate of change in prices for food over time. It is important to track because it can provide insight into the overall cost of living, as well as the health of the economy. When food prices rise, there is less money available to purchase other goods and services, which can lead to slower economic growth. The Federal Reserve uses the rate of food price inflation to help guide its monetary policy decisions.

Jessica Taylor suffers debilitating fatigue and painful muscles caused by Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, also known as Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME). The 25-year-old, of Cliffe Woods, Kent, met Samuel Bearman, 24, through mutual friends and they instantly clicked. They now live together in Gravesend and Samuel does his best to give Jessica the support she needs. Jessica's days are spent trying to manage her illness and finding ways to get through each day. She explains that it can be hard for people to understand what ME is, as it's not visible. Most of the time, she has very little energy and struggles to do simple things like getting dressed or washing her hair. She gets tired easily and often has to take naps when her fatigue becomes too much. Samuel goes out of his way to make sure that Jessica feels supported and loved. He helps her with household chores, cooks dinner and helps her manage her finances. He encourages her to rest when she needs to and takes care of her when she's feeling down. He also tries to understand her condition and never judges her. Jessica says that having Samuel in her life has made her journey with ME easier to deal with. She loves him for understanding her better than most and for loving her despite her illness.

Revenues of PS1.43bn for the six months to 25 October and underlying earnings of PS218.5m were below analysts' forecasts, making the stock the worst performer in the FTSE 100. The company blamed the disappointing results on "challenging trading conditions" in the UK and Europe, with sales growth lower than expected in both regions. The news was particularly disappointing for investors as the company had previously reported strong revenue growth of 8.3 in its first quarter. Chief Executive Officer Roger Holmes said that despite the difficult conditions, he remained confident that the company's "long-term prospects remain sound." He added that the company was taking steps to address the challenges and is focusing on cost control and operational efficiencies to drive further top line performance. The company also announced a new restructuring plan which will involve the closure of up to 60 stores in the UK and Europe, as well as a reduction in staff numbers. It is hoped that the restructuring will help improve profitability and long-term growth prospects for the business. The company has stated that it is committed to providing support to those affected by the changes.

In the footage, which has been widely shared on social media, the policeman headbutts, slaps and kicks the driver as they quarrel beside the lorry. The incident happened at Wadi Al Kabir, Muscat. The Royal Oman Police (ROP) have said that they are investigating the incident and will take "necessary legal measures" against those involved. In a statement, the ROP said that they "condemn such behaviour" and that it is "not in line with its values and principles, which focus on respect for human rights." They also called on citizens and residents to cooperate with the police in maintaining law and order, and to report any violations or abuse of power.

The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency says young people are gambling with their health by using prescription medicines in a bid to get higher marks in exams. Many websites are offering prescription medicines without a prescription. The MHRA strongly advises against buying medicines from any website that doesn't require a valid prescription from a registered healthcare professional. Not only is it illegal to buy prescription medicines without a prescription, but the products may be of poor quality, counterfeit or potentially dangerous. Prescription medicines are powerful drugs and they can have serious side effects. Taking them without medical supervision could put your health at risk. If you are feeling overwhelmed by the pressure of exams, talk to someone you trust or visit your GP. There are other ways to manage stress and cope with exam pressure.

A Department for International Trade report shows 5,443 new posts were created in 2015-16 - a 7 increase on the previous financial year. Almost 7,000 jobs were created or safeguarded by inward investment in the same period. The report shows that the majority of the new jobs came from US-based companies, with a total of 2,766 posts created or safeguarded in 2015-16. This was followed by China (1,282), Japan (835) and India (660). The report also revealed that the automotive sector was the biggest source of inward investment, creating or safeguarding 3,013 jobs in 2015-16. Other sectors included engineering (2,247 jobs), IT and communications (1,914) and pharmaceuticals (1,179). Overall, UK inward investment projects increased by 7 per cent to an all-time high of 1,205 in 2015-16. This is attributed to the UK's continued attractiveness as a destination for investment, due to its strong business environment, legal framework, skilled labour force and access to the single market.

But why has this always been such a struggle? You could build a paper mountain out of all the plans to give vocational education the same status as university degrees, only to have it crumble when the next education minister comes along. This struggle is likely due to a lack of political will and long-term planning. Vocational education can have many benefits, but these benefits may take a while to become apparent. Politicians may not be willing to invest in vocational education if they are only looking for short-term gains. Furthermore, there is often a bias towards university degrees over vocational qualifications, which can make it difficult for vocational education to compete for resources and recognition. It is also possible that policymakers may lack an understanding of the value of vocational education, leading them to prioritize other areas.

Media playback is not supported on this device The Scotland head coach's side sit second bottom of Group F ahead of the game at Hampden Park on 26 March. "We need to win the game," Strachan said. "It's a must-win game for us and we know that." Scotland have failed to reach the finals of a major tournament since the 1998 World Cup and they are five points behind Group F leaders Slovakia with three games remaining. Strachan is confident his side can still qualify, but knows they have to beat Slovenia in order to keep their hopes alive. "We have to go out and be positive and think we can win it," he said. "We have to find a way of getting through this group and we will do our very best to do it, whether it's with a bit of luck, or if we play really well. We'll give it everything we've got." The Scotland boss is boosted by the return to fitness of captain Scott Brown and striker Steven Fletcher who missed the last two qualifiers. "Steven has been training really hard, he's back and looking really sharp," Strachan added. "And Scott has been training like a madman. He's worked ever so hard to get back. It's great to have them both available."

The Lord Advocate said he had informed First Minister Nicola Sturgeon of his intention to quit the post after five years in the job. He said it had been a privilege to serve in the role, but he felt it was the right time to move on. Mr Shatter said: "It has been a great honour and privilege to serve as Lord Advocate for the past five years. I am grateful for the opportunity to have served in such an important role. "I have worked hard to ensure Scotland has a strong, independent and impartial prosecution service, and I am proud of the achievements made during my term of office. It is therefore with regret that I have decided to step down as Lord Advocate. "I would like to thank the First Minister, her cabinet colleagues and the many others who have supported me throughout my time in this role. I will continue to be available to assist the Scottish Government in any way I can in the future."

Carlos Ghosn said there was a need to build a "much higher awareness" of the company's products in Brazil. When Nissan took the decision to back the Games, the Brazilian market had already become a key focus for the carmaker. Ghosn suggested that the company wanted to use the Olympics as a platform for highlighting their brand and introducing new products to the Brazilian market. He said, "The Olympic Games are very important from an awareness point of view. It is also a great opportunity to launch new products." Nissan launched several new vehicles during the 2016 Rio Olympics, including the Kicks crossover, the Note hatchback, and a special-edition March model. Ghosn noted that the company was focusing on making sure the Brazilian public was aware of these new models. He said, "We are using the Games to make sure the Brazilian population knows about our cars." In addition, Nissan also announced a multi-year partnership with the International Olympic Committee (IOC), which further solidified the company's commitment to the Brazilian market. The partnership included a four-year agreement to provide a fleet of vehicles to be used by the IOC during the Olympic Games. This partnership and Nissan's presence at the 2016 Olympics provided the carmaker with a unique opportunity to increase its visibility and reach in the Brazilian market. Ghosn noted that the company was taking advantage of this opportunity to build a stronger presence in the country. He said, "We are here to stay and we want to be part of the future of Brazil. We have a long-term commitment to the country."

The Public Health Wales study looks at adverse experiences in childhood (ACEs) which include parents separating. Children with four or more ACEs, around 14, are three times more likely to become obese adults. The findings of the study suggest that it is important to identify and address childhood adversity in order to prevent adult obesity. This can include providing support for parents who are separating, as well as providing wraparound services such as counseling and parenting classes. It is also important to create safe and supportive environments for children, as this can reduce the likelihood of them developing ACEs and thus reduce the risk of obesity later in life.

Diana Sacayan, a well-known activist for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) rights, was found dead in Buenos Aires on Tuesday. It is the third violent transgender death in the Argentinian capital this month. Sacayan, a transgender woman, was an active member of the LGBT community and had been involved in activism for years. She was part of the Gender Identity Law that was passed in 2012, granting transgender people the right to change their name and gender on official documents. Sacayan's death is being investigated by the police and no details have yet been released about the cause of her death. However, it has been reported that she had received threats from unknown individuals and had expressed concern for her safety in recent weeks. The LGBT community in Argentina is deeply saddened by Sacayan's death and outraged at the violence against the transgender community. They are calling on the government to take steps to ensure the protection of all transgender people and to provide justice for those who have been killed.

A report commissioned by Food Standards Scotland found that in-store promotions were heavily weighted in favour of food with high levels of salt or sugar. The Stirling University academics behind the study said that almost three-quarters of in-store promotions were for food with high levels of sugar, salt and saturated fat. They found that only one in four of the products promoted met the nutritional criteria for a healthy diet. The report also highlighted that children are particularly vulnerable to these promotions as they are more likely to be attracted by food with high levels of sugar, salt or saturated fat due to their sweet and salty taste. The academics noted that there is an urgent need to reduce the number of unhealthy promotions in stores and to encourage the promotion of healthier options instead. This report highlights the need for supermarkets to promote healthier options in order to help consumers make healthier choices when shopping. It also demonstrates why legislation and regulation is necessary to ensure that supermarkets do not exploit consumer loyalty and manipulate them into buying unhealthy food.

The German car giant reported pre-tax profits of 3bn euros (PS2.5bn), a 27 jump from the same period in 2016. BMW said the value of the stake in Here had risen by PS1 billion since last year, while its luxury car division posted a 10.9 increase in pre-tax profits to PS3.3bn. Profits at its Financial Services division also rose by 11.7. Revenue for the first quarter of 2018 was up 5.6, to PS24.3bn, compared to the same period in 2017. BMW said that strong demand for its cars in China and Europe had driven the growth. The company said it expects its full-year earnings to be in line with its expectations. BMW said it is continuing to invest heavily in new technologies such as electric vehicles and self-driving cars, and will launch 40 new or updated models this year. It also announced plans to expand its production capacity in China and Mexico.

Jason Van Dyke was heckled as he arrived at court where he denied six counts of first-degree murder. Video released earlier this year showing the shooting of Laquan McDonald sparked outrage in Chicago. The heckling of Van Dyke is indicative of the intense emotions surrounding this case. The video depicting the shooting of Laquan McDonald sparked widespread outrage in the city and prompted calls for justice. It has become an emblematic symbol of a police department accused of using excessive force and neglecting to hold officers accountable. As such, it is understandable why many in Chicago are so eager to see Van Dyke face justice for his actions.

Sharnford Traffic Action Group (STAG) said some motorists were clocked at "eye watering" speeds topping 100mph. It has campaigned against dangerous driving on Aston Lane and the B4114 in Leicestershire . The group has urged the local police to take steps to prevent further speeding, including speed cameras and better signage. They have also called for a review of road layout and speed limits in order to reduce speeds. STAG is also working with local councillors and the county council to find a solution that works for everyone.

Arthur Cory, 49, said the flag had been kept in a cupboard at Penllyn Castle near Cowbridge, since he was a boy. The flag, one of only three surviving from the battle, was presented to him by his father, who had been given it by his grandfather. The flag is believed to date back to the Battle of Fishguard in 1797, when a French force of about 1,400 soldiers attempted to land in Wales and were defeated by local forces. The flag is thought to have belonged to one of the officers of the invading force. It bears the words 'Toujours Pret' (Always Ready) along with the royal arms of France, and is made from silk and velvet. Cory said he had kept the flag for many years as a family heirloom, but had decided to donate it to the National Museum of Wales in Cardiff so that it could be seen and appreciated by others.

The 35-year-old former West Ham and Derby man was approaching the end of his contract at the club. Bywater, whose previous clubs include Millwall and Sheffield Wednesday, has not played for the Potters since October. Bywater joined Stoke in 2009 and made over 200 appearances for the club, helping them to promotion from the Championship in 2008. He also won the League Cup with the Potters in 2011. The goalkeeper was a key figure in Stoke's run to the FA Cup Final in 2011, but had been allowed to leave the club earlier this season. Bywater had recently been training with Burton Albion and is now expected to join the League One club on a permanent basis.

She left after her GCSEs to work in a factory but the money was poor, as were the conditions. So when she got better exam results than she expected she decided to go to university. She was able to get a grant from the government to cover her tuition fees and living costs, and she worked part-time in a bar to help make ends meet. She was also able to take advantage of student discounts on travel and food, which helped her to save money. Throughout her studies she maintained a focus on her career goals and worked hard to achieve them. She developed good communication skills and was able to use her knowledge and experience to secure a good job when she graduated.

Guy Tomlinson, 37, was being chased by officers when his car hit a tipper truck in Leicester on 9 March 2016. David Anger and Christopher Needham, who were both passengers in the car, later died from their injuries. Tomlinson was sentenced to 10 years in prison for causing death by dangerous driving and other related offences. He was also disqualified from driving for 10 years. In addition, he was ordered to pay 170 in costs. The judge said that Tomlinson had driven with "a flagrant disregard for the safety of his passengers and all other road users." He said that Tomlinson had acted with "indifference to the consequences of his actions" and had shown a "reckless and callous disregard for life."

The IFG says legislation will be needed to establish new policies on areas such as customs and immigration. The extra measures will place "a huge burden" on Parliament and government , requiring a "significant increase in resources." The IFG recommends that the government set up an independent body with legal and policy expertise to help it develop and implement the legislation. This body can also provide advice on other areas, such as trade, taxation, and labour rights. The IFG also suggests that the government should create an online platform to allow businesses to access the relevant information and guidance they need to comply with the new policies. This would make it easier for companies to understand the requirements and ensure compliance. Finally, the IFG recommends that the government should create an oversight body to monitor and enforce the new policies. This body should be independent and have the power to take action against those who fail to comply.

The striker took his tally to five goals in two games when hitting the opener and winner in an ABAX Stadium thriller. Marriott fired Posh ahead two minutes into the second half, slotting home from close range after a brilliant run and cross from Jason Cummings. The visitors equalised through an own goal from Tyler Denton just after the hour mark, but Marriott had the final say in the 77th minute, lashing home a superb effort from the edge of the box to win it for Posh. Sign up to our daily newsletter The i newsletter cut through the noise Sign up Thanks for signing up! Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later. Submitting... "I was pleased to get two goals and obviously to get the winner made it even better," Marriott said. "It was a good performance overall and we did what we had to do. "We knew it was going to be a tough game and that it was a must-win for us. But we stuck together, put in a great shift and got the three points. "The first goal was a good move. We worked it well and I was just happy to have been on the end of it. It was great movement. "The goal to win it was one of those where you hit it and you know it's going in. It was a good feeling and I'm pleased with it. "We've been working hard on our shape and the intensity of the press and that showed today. We pressed them high and when they had the ball we jumped on them. "That's how you win games and that's how we're going to keep winning games. "We just need to build on this now. We'll take it game by game and hopefully keep getting more wins." Marriott has now scored nine times since his move to Posh in January. "I'm enjoying it here," he added. "It was a big move for me and I'm pleased with how it's gone so far. "I'm learning every day. It's a new team and I'm sure I'll keep scoring goals if I keep playing the way I am.

The 28-year-old's contract with Korona Kielce in his homeland had expired and Grzelak has also played for Wisla Plock, Dolcan Zabki and Podbeskidzie Bielsko-Biala. He becomes head coach Ian Cathro's ninth signing of the summer. Cathro said: "He's a big, strong defender and he has good ability for his size. He has experience in the Polish league and also in the Europa League, so he brings a lot of experience with him. "We have been looking for someone who can bring that combination of physicality and technical ability. We felt he was the right fit for us." Source: PA

Speaking at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES), Herbert Diess, head of the VW brand, said the company would have a fix in the coming weeks or months. But the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) says the company must come up with a fix by the end of January. The emissions scandal, which was first revealed in 2015, has seen VW pay out billions of dollars in fines and compensation to customers. The company has also been forced to recall millions of cars worldwide. At CES, Diess said that the company would be introducing a software update for some of its diesel vehicles in the US market. He added that the update should help reduce emissions from the affected vehicles. VW has previously said that it is "working hard" to resolve the issue, but has not provided a timeline for when the fix will be available. It remains unclear if the update will be enough to satisfy the EPA or if more drastic measures may be required.

This year's award was won jointly by Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, the president of Liberia, Leymah Gbowee, the Liberian peace activist, and Yemeni pro-democracy campaigner Tawakkol Karman. They were recognised for their efforts to promote peace, democracy and gender equality. The award citation noted that the three women had "harnessed non-violent means to promote peace and advance women's rights in their countries" and "refused to accept the status quo and risked their lives to bring about change." Sirleaf is the first woman elected head of state in Africa. She has worked to restore stability and economic growth to Liberia after a devastating civil war. Gbowee is a social worker and peace activist who organised a successful campaign against former president Charles Taylor. Karman is a journalist and human rights campaigner who has been leading protests against the government of Yemen since 2007, demanding greater freedom and political reform.

The availability of psychoactive drugs was also a concern following a spate of hospital admissions. Progress had been made since the last report but concerns remained, the chief inspector of prisons said. He noted that the prison service had implemented measures such as increased searches and drug testing, but added that more needed to be done. He also raised concerns about the availability of new psychoactive substances, which were increasingly found in prisons.

Stephen Pearson and Martyn Woolford gave the hosts a deserved half-time lead after a dominant first half. Joe Mason's header gave Cardiff hope, but a slick counter attack saw Woolford tap home his second to ensure the points stayed in Scotland.

A 34-year-old man was arrested in connection with an outstanding warrant and is expected to appear at Glasgow Sherriff Court on Monday. A 15-year-old male was arrested for offensive behaviour and has been released on an undertaking to appear at Glasgow Youth Court at a later date. Police Scotland said that the 34-year-old man was detained in connection with an outstanding warrant and will appear at Glasgow Sheriff Court on Monday. The 15-year-old male was arrested for offensive behaviour and has since been released on an undertaking to appear at Glasgow Youth Court at a later date.

The Murrayfield side are seventh in the table and face a difficult run-in as they seek a top-four finish. "We have five huge games coming up and I think we can keep on pushing for a top-four finish," said head coach Richard Cockerill. "We know how difficult these games are going to be but we have a really strong squad and a great work ethic so I'm confident that if we continue to work hard, we can achieve something special this season." The Edinburgh side face a tough test against the likes of current league leaders Leinster, Glasgow Warriors, Munster and Ulster in their remaining fixtures. Cockerill added: "We know the challenge ahead and it's important that we focus on each game one at a time and take the points on offer. We believe that if we do that then we can reach our targets this season."

But they have also had three points deducted after the game on 14 October was disrupted when a drone flew over the stadium with a political message. The drone carried a banner that read 'Boycott Azerbaijan'. The game was suspended for half an hour while the drone and banner were removed. The decision to deduct three points was taken by UEFA's Control, Ethics and Disciplinary Body.

Prime Minister David Cameron announced the deal as he started a Jamaica visit. The project has been agreed to break the deadlock in negotiations over a prisoner transfer deal between the two countries. The deal is expected to cost around 25 million and will see prisoners serving sentences in Britain being allowed to serve their sentences in Jamaica. Under the deal, hundreds of Jamaican prisoners currently held in British jails will be able to serve out their sentences in Jamaica, while those sentenced in Jamaica will be able to return home to do the same. It is hoped that the deal will help reduce overcrowding in British jails and free up prison places for other inmates. The agreement has been welcomed by both sides as a positive step in improving relations between the two countries and addressing prisoner transfer issues. However, there have been some criticisms of the deal, with some arguing that the money could be better spent on crime prevention measures or other social services. The UK government has said that the money will be used to improve security and infrastructure in Jamaica, and to fund programmes to help ex-offenders reintegrate into society.

Chernova, now 27, beat Briton Ennis-Hill to gold at the 2011 World Championships in Korea. This week she was given a ban and had earlier results annulled after a sample from 2009 showed evidence of doping. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) found her guilty of using the banned steroid turinabol, and stripped her of the medal won in Daegu. Ennis-Hill, 30, was given retrospective silver but has yet to decide whether or not to accept it. "I'm so disappointed to hear about the CAS ruling," she said on Twitter. "It's a sad day for our sport. I have fought long and hard for what I have achieved over the years and this has been taken away from me." The Briton added: "My thoughts are with all clean athletes who have now been robbed of their moment in the spotlight."

Ron Stone has been described as a "true champion" of St George West, the ward he had represented on Bristol City Council since 1985. The leader of the Labour group , Stone had been an active campaigner for the local community, leading campaigns on a range of issues such as education, housing and health. He was a vocal advocate for the area's young people, establishing a youth forum to ensure their voices were heard at the council. Stone was a strong believer in local democracy and he was known for his hard work and dedication to improving the lives of local residents. In 2015, he was awarded the Freedom of the City of Bristol in recognition of his service to the city over three decades. Stone passed away in January 2020.

Elizabeth Timar, 18, was last seen near Blackpool Sands at 19:45 BST on Monday. Romanian Ms Timar, from Exeter, had been "at the beach for the afternoon with a male," Devon and Cornwall Police said. Police are appealing for information about her whereabouts and have urged people to contact them with any information they may have. Ms Timar is described as 5ft 4in, of slim build, with long black hair and brown eyes. She was last seen wearing dark-coloured shorts, a white t-shirt, tan boots and carrying a small rucksack.

Speaking during a parliamentary debate, Philip Hollobone said individual fireworks are extremely dangerous. But business minister Jo Johnson dismissed a ban and insisted current laws work well. The debate came after a review of fireworks safety was announced by the government. Mr Hollobone said: "It's about time we had a proper look at whether it is still appropriate that individual members of the public can buy extremely dangerous explosives, that is what fireworks are." However, Mr Johnson replied: "We have to be careful that any changes to the law should not have unintended consequences for businesses or for legitimate community events." He stated that current laws are adequate and that the review will help ensure they remain so. He added: "I think it is right that the government undertakes a review of the situation. We want to make sure that people are able to enjoy fireworks safely."

Jamie Spendiff's attack on Craig Logie, who was out with friends on a stag night, was captured on CCTV. Spendiff took part in a further assault on other men with a pool cue, causing injury. In a criminal case against Jamie Spendiff for the attack on Craig Logie, the CCTV footage would be relevant evidence that could be used to prove Spendiff's guilt. The video could show the assault on Logie, Spendiff's involvement, and any other actions taken by Spendiff during the incident. This evidence could be used to establish the charges of assault against Spendiff, as well as any additional charges related to the use of a pool cue during the assault.

The men from the 1st Battalion the Yorkshire Regiment sat on the floor when ordered to stand to attention. The protest by 16 soldiers was sparked by grievances with their commanding officer. The regiment said it had "robust procedures in place to deal with any issues raised by soldiers."

Wales international Huws, 23, is a Manchester City academy graduate. Samuel, 22, came through the ranks at Reading and has two goals in 16 senior appearances for the Championship side. Huws, who has two Wales caps, joined the Blues from Ipswich Town in the summer of 2015. He spent the second half of last season on loan at Wigan Athletic, where he made 17 appearances in all competitions. Samuel, meanwhile, is a former England Under-19 international who has been with the Royals since 2011. He has featured regularly for Jaap Stam's side this term, making 15 appearances in all competitions. The duo are set to become the first signings of new Latics boss Warren Joyce, who was appointed as Gary Caldwell's successor earlier this week.

The 20-year-old was shot in Malvern Road in Kilburn, north-west London, on Friday night and later pronounced dead at the scene. It is believed she was standing with a group of people in the street when a car pulled up and shots were fired. The police have not yet been able to identify the victim and are appealing for anyone with information to come forward. No arrests have been made at this stage and officers from the Metropolitan Police's Homicide and Major Crime Command are investigating. Detective Chief Inspector Helen Rance said: "This was a senseless and tragic loss of life of a young woman who had her whole life ahead of her. "We are doing everything we can to find out what happened and bring whoever is responsible to justice. I urge anyone with information, no matter how insignificant it might seem, to contact us." She added that there would be extra police patrols in the area to provide reassurance to local residents. Anyone with information is asked to call the incident room on 8099 or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.
Not sure what we're on about? Australia has run through a slew of prime ministers in recent years and is holding a federal election on 2 July. You can read more about the election here.

As part of the deal, the firm was meant to have built a saw line by Friday. Despite questioning by AMs, Emyr Roberts did not give a clear answer as to whether this had been done. If Emyr Roberts did not give a clear answer as to whether the saw line had been built, then it is likely that the firm has not met their obligations under the deal. It would be wise for the AMs to investigate further in order to confirm the status of the saw line. This may involve contacting the firm directly or requesting additional documents related to the construction of the saw line.

It was relief more than real jubilation. The simple truth was that the combined list of candidates headed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had performed disappointingly. But politics is about relative gains and losses, and in the end Netanyahu emerged victorious, with a larger party than he had before. The election result was a surprise to many. While all polls showed that Netanyahu's right-wing bloc had a clear lead, few predicted that the prime minister would win an outright majority. This was largely due to the fact that Netanyahu's Likud party had been polling slightly lower than its main rivals on the left. Nevertheless, the prime minister was able to secure enough support from smaller parties to form a coalition government. The victory was especially sweet for Netanyahu, who had been under fire from multiple corruption scandals and had become increasingly unpopular in recent months. The election results provided him with a much needed boost of confidence, allowing him to remain in office and continue his agenda. Looking ahead, Netanyahu will face many challenges in his next term, both domestically and internationally. He will have to navigate the delicate balance between his right-wing allies and more centrist members of his coalition. At the same time, he will likely have to confront a growing wave of international criticism over Israel's policies towards the Palestinians. Regardless, Netanyahu has once again proven his political resilience and ability to overcome adversity. With another term as prime minister, he is now firmly established as one of the most influential figures in Israeli politics.

The UK must go further to ensure those settling learn English "so they can be more integrated into our country." Asked about the issue at Prime Minister's Questions, Mr Cameron said: "I absolutely agree that learning English is essential for those settling in the UK. That is why we have invested significantly in language tuition, including providing free English classes for adults who are not already proficient in the language. We are also working closely with local authorities to ensure that all new arrivals have access to the language support they need to integrate into our society."

As Ron Jones, from Newport, prepares to mark Holocaust Memorial Day on Friday with a service at the city's cathedral, he says that amongst all the terrible memories, there will be one thought that will bring him some comfort. "I will take comfort in the knowledge that the world has learned from the Holocaust and is now doing more than ever to prevent such a tragedy from happening again," said Jones. "That is why I am so passionate about Holocaust education, so that future generations are aware of the horrors of the past and never forget."

Responsible Travel, based in Brighton, specialises in wildlife holidays and says keeping animals in zoos is inhumane. About half a dozen tours that involve zoos are being dropped from the website, including a trip to South Africa that includes a visit to Johannesburg Zoo. The company said it had decided to remove the tours after reviewing its ethical policy on animal welfare and zoos. Responsible Travel said it was aware that some zoos may be providing valuable conservation initiatives and education but that this did not outweigh the confinement of animals in captivity. The company is urging other travel operators to review their policies on animal welfare and zoos and to consider dropping similar trips from their range of services.

Radical preachers will be banned from posting material online and anyone with convictions for extremist activity will be barred from working with children. Deradicalisation classes will be made mandatory for young people in areas with high levels of extremism. The government will also increase funding for organisations that work to tackle radicalisation, and they will be tasked with developing counter-narratives to extremist ideology. Police forces will be given better resources to identify people at risk of radicalisation and intervene before it is too late. An online portal will be set up for members of the public to report suspicious activity. In addition, universities and schools will be required to adopt a zero-tolerance policy towards any kind of extremism, and their staff will be trained to spot signs of radicalisation. Social media companies will be asked to do more to monitor and remove extremist content from their platforms. The government will also work with other countries to share best practice on how to tackle extremism.

Venera Minakhmetova died when she was struck by lorry at Bow Roundabout, on Wednesday. The Russian, who had been on the Cycle Superhighway 2 (CS2) just before the collision, was pronounced dead at the scene. The Metropolitan Police said they were called to the Bow Roundabout shortly after 8am on Wednesday, following reports that a lorry had collided with a pedal cycle. The driver of the lorry stopped at the scene and no arrests have been made. The London Ambulance Service attended but Venera Minakhmetova was pronounced dead at the scene. The Met's Serious Collision Investigation Unit has now launched an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the incident. The police are asking anyone who witnessed the collision, or who may have dashcam footage of the incident, to come forward.

Jamie Taggart, from Argyll and Bute, failed to return from a plant-hunting trip to the northern mountainous area. He has not been seen since 2 November, when his rucksack and hat were found close to a mountain path. A large search and rescue operation was launched by the police, mountain rescue teams and Coastguard helicopter, with assistance from local hillwalkers and climbers. Search teams have scoured the area for any sign of Jamie but, as yet, there has been no trace of him. Local people have expressed their concern for Jamie's safety and well-being, particularly as the weather conditions in the area have become increasingly severe in recent weeks. The weather is now so bad that the search teams are having to take extra precautions and focus on more sheltered areas. It is hoped that Jamie will be found safe and well, but his family and friends are becoming increasingly worried as time passes.

In an election pledge, Labour said giving working parents 30 hours free childcare a week for 48 weeks of the year would cost an extra PS84m annually. Economist Gillian Paull said the true cost was more likely to be more than PS200m. The Labour Party's estimate of the cost of providing 30 hours free childcare a week for 48 weeks of the year is likely to be an underestimate. Economist Gillian Paull suggested that the true cost of the policy could be more than double at over 200 million annually. This figure is likely to take into account additional costs such as staff wages, training and building infrastructure for the expanded service.

Alistair Spagnoletti, 21, of Luton, and Curtis Walker, 23, of Watford, pleaded guilty to controlling a child at Harrow Crown Court. Callum Ward, 19, of Watford, was found guilty of the same charge. The trio had been charged with controlling a child, namely a 15-year-old girl, between February and June 2019. The victim was known to them and they were found to have manipulated her into having a sexual relationship with one of them. The court heard that Spagnoletti and Walker also threatened and intimidated the victim in order to maintain control over her. Spagnoletti was sentenced to four years in prison, whilst Walker received a sentence of five years imprisonment. Ward was given a sentence of three years and eight months. All three will remain on the sex offenders register for life. Judge Richard Foster said: "This was a case of the grossest abuse of an innocent and vulnerable child. You each took advantage of her naivety and innocence by manipulating her into engaging in a sexual relationship with one of you." He added, "You showed no regard for her wellbeing or safety and your actions were nothing short of predatory. This type of offending will not be tolerated and I hope this serves as a warning to others."

Mencap president Lord Rix urged the speaker of the House of Lords to push through legislation allowing those in his situation to be assisted to die. He had previously opposed assisted dying when it was debated in the House of Lords. Lord Rix has not changed his position on assisted dying and continues to believe that it should be a matter for individuals to decide for themselves. However, he believes that people who are terminally ill or have disabilities should have access to the same rights and services as everyone else, including the option of assisted dying. In an open letter to the Speaker of the House of Lords in 2018, Lord Rix stated that "it is essential that we ensure that those with life-limiting conditions and disabilities have parity of choice about how they live and die." He concluded the letter by asking the Speaker to "find a way to enable us to debate this issue in a respectful and meaningful way."

Tandridge District Council leader Martin Fisher gave planners a shortlist of five areas for such a scheme. He said one new Surrey village is better than "scatter-gunning" homes and cramping existing villages. The shortlist includes: Limpsfield Woldingham Godstone Lingfield Outwood The scheme would see up to 1,500 new homes built in a village-style setting, with services and facilities such as shops, schools and community centres. It would be designed to enable people of all ages and incomes to live together, rather than segregating them by wealth. The aim is to create sustainable communities that are connected to the wider area.

The incident on 23 April involved a Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter and a US intelligence-gathering RC-135U. The US plane was flying a routine mission in international airspace over the Sea of Okhotsk when the Russian fighter approached it from the side and then flew in front of the US plane, crossing within 100 feet of the American aircraft. The US crew reported that the maneuver was performed in an "unsafe and unprofessional" manner. The incident lasted for several minutes before the Russian jet veered away. The US State Department criticized Russia for its actions, saying they were "provocative and unhelpful." The US also expressed concern that a similar incident could result in a tragic miscalculation. Russia denied any wrongdoing, claiming that their jet had acted in accordance with international rules and that the US plane had entered its airspace without permission.

Temporary closure notices were placed on the shellfish beds after high E.coli bacteria readings last week. Latest tests have showed satisfactory water quality levels, said the FSA. Closures remain in effect on the beds until further notice. The FSA has lifted the temporary closure notices on the shellfish beds following satisfactory water quality levels from recent tests. The beds are now open for harvesting and consumption. The FSA will continue to monitor the water quality of the beds and may impose closures in the event of any future high E.coli readings.

The rock legends' set went out on the BBC World Service as part of Alexis Korner's Rhythm and Blues programme and was taped from an AM radio in Europe. It is not known if the recording was broadcast on other radio stations at the time.

Media playback is not supported on this device Bottom side United's first win in Perth in four years, and Kilmarnock's draw away to Partick Thistle, means the gap between them is now down to four points. Kilmarnock's draw against Partick Thistle in the Scottish Premiership on Wednesday night means that the gap between them and bottom side United is now only four points. United have been rooted to the bottom of the table since October, but their 1-0 win over Perth Glory was their first victory in the city for four years. The result has given the club a much-needed boost after a difficult season and manager David Hopkin is hopeful that it can be a turning point for them. He said: "It was great to get our first win in Perth in four years. It gives us some confidence going into the second half of the season. "We need to keep pushing and take every game as it comes. We have to believe that we can move out of this position and climb up the table." United have eight games left to play this season, with seven of them coming at home. Hopkin is confident that his side can use their remaining fixtures to their advantage and climb the table. He added: "We have a lot of important home games coming up and if we can make the most of those then I'm sure we'll start climbing the table. "It's all about belief and attitude. If the players can stay focused and keep working hard then I'm sure we can turn things around."

Firefighters were called to a home in Marlborough Road just after 22:00 GMT on Saturday after a fire developed in the first floor and roof. A man was removed from the property before being taken to hospital. The fire service said four fire engines and 20 firefighters had attended the scene. A spokesman for Dorset Fire and Rescue said: "The cause of the fire is under investigation and at this stage is being treated as accidental." The man, who has not been named, was taken to Salisbury District Hospital where he is being treated for smoke inhalation. The fire caused significant damage to the roof of the property and a full structural assessment of the building is due to take place in the morning.

A Mass for Eoghan Chada, 10, and his brother Ruairi, 5, was said in St Lazerian's Church, Ballinkillen, in County Carlow. Parish priest Father Declan Foley said the boys' deaths had left their family and the community in a state of shock. The Mass was attended by an estimated 600 people, including local schoolchildren and members of the wider community. A guard of honour was formed outside the church by members of Ballinkillen GAA Club, who held aloft flags in honour of the two brothers. At the end of the service, the flag-bearing members of the GAA Club formed a guard of honour as the boys' remains were carried from the church to their final resting place at the nearby cemetery. Father Declan Foley spoke of the sense of grief in the community and said that the Chada family had been left devastated by the tragedy. He urged those present to support each other in their grief and to remember the Chada family in their thoughts and prayers.

Tevez, who missed a penalty against Wigan last Saturday, was back on the bench for the midweek Champions League game against Napoli. Mancini insists that Tevez, who failed to secure a move away from City in the summer, will not be leaving before January. Mancini said: "Carlos is happy here and he knows he can't leave. We will see in January. He is an important player for us but he is on the bench now because I wanted to use Edin Dzeko. But I don't want to sell him in January."

The 25-year-old, who is 6ft 9ins tall, joined the Minstermen from Tranmere Rovers on a two-year deal in May, but has only made five appearances. Mooney's first stint in professional football came with Northampton Town when he signed a two-year deal in 2014. Mooney started his career in non-league football, playing for clubs such as Atherstone Town, Hednesford Town and Chester. He was spotted by Tranmere Rovers and was offered a two-year professional contract at the age of 23. Whilst there, he also spent time on loan at Kidderminster Harriers and Altrincham. Mooney is an imposing centre-half and has been known to play at right back too. His height and physical presence make him a formidable defender and he is also comfortable on the ball. He joined York City to help their defensive efforts and will be aiming to secure a regular place in the first team.

The incident happened in December when the 18-year-old man suffered what was described at the time as a broken jaw. Police want to trace a woman and a man. The woman is white, around 5ft 7ins tall, of slim build and aged in her late twenties. She had shoulder-length brown hair and was wearing a black top and trousers. The man is white, around 6ft tall, of muscular build and in his mid to late twenties. He had short dark hair and a beard and was wearing a grey tracksuit. Anyone with information should contact police on 101 quoting reference number 468 of 13 December 2019 or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.

GM will also hire 1,000 new workers in Ontario to focus on research for connected and driverless cars. Canada and particularly Ontario has been promoting its car-making sector as it looks to get a bigger piece of the industry. GM will also invest 170 million into its Ontario operations, including a new research and development center in Markham that will focus on developing connected and driverless car technology. The new research center will create jobs for engineers and software developers. The investment marks an important step forward for Canada's auto sector, which has been struggling recently due to a decline in demand for traditional combustion engine vehicles. GM's investment will help position Canada as a leader in the development of connected and autonomous vehicle technologies, which is expected to become increasingly important in the near future.

Scotland's health boards paid more than PS20m in overtime and additional pay to some doctors in 201516, up from the PS14m paid out in 201415. The British Medical Association said the increase was due to a shortage of doctors, particularly in emergency medicine and psychiatry. The Scottish government said it was investing in training more doctors, as well as recruiting more medical staff.

The 32-year-old has agreed a two-year contract with the Rams and is the first signing by manager Gary Rowett. Davies made 29 appearances for Hull last season as they were relegated from the Premier League. He joined Hull in 2014 after spells with Preston, Derby and Southampton and has made a total of 521 appearances over his career. Davies is an experienced centre-back who will bring leadership and stability to the Rams back line. He is likely to be partnered by current Rams defender Curtis Davies who signed for Derby last summer.

23 May 2016 Last updated at 18:35 BST He's been given the boot after two years. United finished fifth in the Premier League this season, which means missing out on Champions League football. Van Gaal, who took over from David Moyes in 2014, has been under intense scrutiny this season and the club's failure to qualify for Europe's elite competition was the final straw. The former Ajax, Barcelona and Bayern Munich manager won a record 20th title for United with victory in the FA Cup at Wembley last month, but it was not enough to save his job. Former Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho is expected to take over at Old Trafford. In a statement on its website, United said: "Manchester United announces that manager Louis van Gaal has left the Club. "We would like to thank Louis and his staff for their work during the last two years and wish them all the best in the future." Van Gaal added: "I am very disappointed to be unable to complete our intended three-year plan. I believe that the foundations are firmly in place to enable the Club to move forward and achieve even greater success. "I hope that winning the FA Cup will give the Club a platform to build upon next season to restore the success that this passionate set of fans desire."

The 23-year-old, whose brother Sam has returned to the Rabbitohs after a spell in rugby union, said in May that he was keen to play in the NFL. Jarryd Hayne, who previously played for the San Francisco 49ers and is widely regarded as Australia's most successful NFL player, said he was confident that Burgess had the potential to make it in the league. "He is a great athlete, he has natural ability and he has been training hard," Hayne said. "I think he can definitely make it in the NFL." It remains to be seen whether Burgess will be able to make an impact in the NFL, but his athleticism and skill set certainly suggest he could make a big impression.

Haroon Syed, of west London, admitted preparing acts of terrorism after trying to source weapons including a suicide bomb and machine gun. He was caught after approaching MI5 officers, who were posing as bomb makers, money launderers and arms dealers. Syed was arrested in September 2016 after an undercover investigation revealed he had been searching for weapons on the dark web. He admitted to plotting a mass-casualty attack on a London landmark, with the aim of killing or injuring civilians. Syed, who had no prior convictions, was sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 16 years. The judge said that the intended target was "notional" and Syed had not taken any active steps to carry out the attack.

Most MSPs on the equal opportunities committee endorsed the Marriage and Civil Partnership Bill. But some members were either not convinced by the bill, or had concerns that it lacked sufficient safeguards for those with different gender identities. Despite this, the bill eventually passed and became a major milestone in the fight for LGBTQ rights in the UK.

Media playback is not supported on this device The 26-year-old British number one is taking a short break before preparing for the US Open in August. "I've got a massive five weeks coming up but I'm excited for it," she said. Murray is currently ranked world number two but will miss the French Open, which starts on Sunday, after failing to recover from a hip injury. The former world number one has been out of action since March and took the decision to rest rather than rush back for Roland Garros. The Scot, who won his third Grand Slam title at Wimbledon last year, says he is "feeling good" and is now ready to start competing again. "I'm taking this break as an opportunity to get physically and mentally strong again before I start my pre-US Open preparations," he said. When asked if he was worried about missing the French Open, he said: "No, not really. It's been a long time since I played at Roland Garros and it's a great tournament, but my focus is on getting fully fit and healthy and then looking ahead to the summer."

Aston Villa's Jordan Ayew opened the scoring on 62 minutes, curling the ball past Ley Matampi in the Leopards goal. Paul-Jose M'Poku equalised for DR Congo with a sensational long-range strike that flew into the top corner, before Ayew restored Villa's lead just three minutes later with a powerful header from a corner. The game then went to extra-time, and it was M'Poku who grabbed the winner for DR Congo in the 107th minute. He drove forward at pace and fired a low shot into the bottom corner, sending his team through to the next round.

Emergency services were called to the scene at Main Road, where the A78 Largs to Seamill road was closed to traffic. The woman's 60-year-old husband and the lorry driver, 54, were not injured. Police Scotland said the woman was treated at the scene by paramedics before being taken to Inverclyde Royal Hospital, where she later died. The road was closed for four hours while the accident was investigated.

The singer - who is the first woman to win the award twice - also won best pop vocal album and best music video for her track Bad Blood. Rapper Kendrick Lamar won best rap album for To Pimp A Butterfly and best rap performance. Taylor Swift is the first woman to have won the Grammy Award for Album of the Year twice, her first award being in 2010 for her album Fearless. She also won Best Pop Vocal Album for 1989 and Best Music Video for Bad Blood in 2016.

The paper claims London-based private doctor Mark Bonar prescribed banned performance-enhancing drugs to over 150 British athletes including footballers. Arsenal said they were "extremely disappointed" by the publication of the allegations. Arsenal released a statement saying that they were "extremely disappointed" with the publication of the allegations and confirmed that they had launched an internal investigation into the matter. They urged anyone who had any information regarding the allegations to come forward. The club also stated that it was committed to ensuring that all its players and staff adhered to the sport's anti-doping regulations and codes of conduct.

Whether or not he is on the formal menu, Mr Snowden will certainly colour their conversation and the press conference that follows. Ms Merkel's trip to the US is markedly different from those she has made in the past, as it is the first time since Mr Snowden's revelations that she has visited Washington. The two leaders will likely discuss the US surveillance of Germany and Ms Merkel's condemnations of such activities. It is unlikely that they will reach any specific agreements regarding limits on US spying, but they may make some statements about increased cooperation between the two countries and a commitment to better protection of their citizens' rights.

The region's number of under 15s taking alcohol remains above the national average, according to the Highland Alcohol and Drugs Partnership. Its campaign Meet the MacPhersons draws on evidence gathered from local schools which found that the region's rate of alcohol use was higher than the national average. The campaign seeks to change attitudes and behaviours around underage drinking in the Highlands, by raising awareness of the risks associated with it and encouraging people to talk more openly about alcohol and young people. The Highland Alcohol and Drugs Partnership works with partners including Police Scotland, NHS Highland, Highland Council and other statutory agencies, as well as local communities, to tackle misuse of alcohol and drugs. This includes providing education and support for those who are vulnerable or at risk of becoming addicted. Additionally, the partnership is involved in a range of activities such as media campaigns and the provision of information and advice on drug and alcohol misuse to communities.

Couples have been decorating the Ponte Milvio bridge on the river Tiber with locks for several years. They are meant to symbolise the locking of hearts, inspired by a story written by author Federico Moccia. The tradition is believed to have started in 2006 when Moccia wrote a book entitled "Tre Metri Sopra il Cielo" (Three Steps Above Heaven). In the story, two protagonists lock a padlock on the bridge as a symbol of their undying love and throw away the key in the river. This romantic gesture has become popular among couples in Rome and around the world, who inscribe their names or initials and date of their visit onto a lock and attach it to the bridge together. The locks are meant to represent eternity and undying love between the couple.

The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) missed a deadline to name a squad for the tournament after the International Cricket Council (ICC) changed its revenue-sharing model. However, the BCCI eventually named a 15-man Team India squad for the ICC World Cup 2019. The squad consists of Virat Kohli (captain), Rohit Sharma, Shikhar Dhawan, Mahendra Singh Dhoni (wk), Kedar Jadhav, Vijay Shankar, Kuldeep Yadav, Yuzvendra Chahal, Ravindra Jadeja, Hardik Pandya, Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Mohammed Shami, Jasprit Bumrah, Dinesh Karthik and KL Rahul. The team is well balanced in terms of batting, bowling and fielding. It includes experienced players like MS Dhoni, Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma who have been part of successful teams in the past. It also has some promising young talent like KL Rahul, Hardik Pandya and Jasprit Bumrah. The spin attack will be led by Kuldeep Yadav and Yuzvendra Chahal, while the pace attack will be spearheaded by Bhuvneshwar Kumar and Mohammed Shami. All-rounders like Hardik Pandya and Ravindra Jadeja will provide balance to the side. Overall, the Indian team looks strong and is capable of challenging any opponent on the world stage. With their experience and skill, they will be one of the favorites to win the tournament.

The base will be home to HMS Queen Elizabeth and HMS Prince of Wales, the largest ships ever built for the navy. Work on Portsmouth's jetty, built in the 1920s , has been completed to enable the aircraft carriers to berth. It will also be home to a range of support ships including frigates and destroyers as well as supply ships and naval auxiliaries. The base will also host the Royal Marines, Fleet Air Arm, Royal Navy Reserve and other personnel. The base is expected to become fully operational in 2020.

But Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw says the process to close such schools is "inadequate." Where there is such "illegal activity," he says, the "full force of the law" should be used. He has called for the police to become more involved in the process, and for local authorities to take a more proactive approach to tackling such issues. The Department for Education (DfE) says it is committed to stamping out illegal schools and that it is working with Ofsted and other partners to ensure that all unregistered schools are closed. It says that it is taking action to prevent unregistered settings from operating and that it will take "swift and robust action" against those who flout the law. The DfE also says it is making sure any unregistered settings which remain open are subject to regular monitoring and inspection to ensure they are meeting their legal obligations.

Ahmed Awad bin Mubarak was handed over to a delegation of tribal leaders. He was meant to be released last week as part of a deal agreed with President Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi's government. He was arrested in October 2015 on charges of supporting the Houthi rebels who control much of Yemen's north. The release of bin Mubarak is part of a larger agreement between the Hadi government and the Houthis to exchange prisoners and detainees held by both sides, as well as open humanitarian corridors for aid to reach civilians in need. The deal was agreed upon at the recent consultations in Sweden, which saw the first official talks between the warring parties since 2016. Bin Mubarak's release has been welcomed by international human rights groups, who have long called for his release and an end to arbitrary detention in Yemen. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Michelle Bachelet, said that she "welcomed" the release of Ahmed Awad Bin Mubarak and urged all parties to comply with their obligations under international law and ensure the humane treatment of all detainees.

He passed away peacefully in hospital on Tuesday after a short illness. Born in Tourmakeady, County Mayo, he worked as a teacher before securing a part in the premiere of John B Keane's 'Big Maggie'. He went on to become a prolific stage actor, appearing in many of Ireland's renowned theatres. He also appeared in some Irish television programmes and movies, including the lead role in the popular comedy-drama 'The Riordans'. He devoted much of his time to charity work, especially for those with mental health issues. He was also very active in the Irish language movement and was a founding member of the Galway Gaeltacht Club. He will be fondly remembered by all who knew him as a generous, kind and loving person. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends and colleagues in the theatre industry.

Media playback is not supported on this device The hosts had the better of the chances against their League One rivals and were denied three times by the woodwork in the first half. The hosts started brightly and almost took the lead after just two minutes, when winger Junior Morias cut in from the left flank and fired a low shot which beat the goalkeeper but cannoned back off the post. Manager David Holdsworth then saw his side denied twice by the woodwork in quick succession, as Morias' effort was soon followed by a header from defender Michael Harriman which also hit the frame of the goal. The visitors had their moments too, with Jay Emmanuel-Thomas forcing a smart save from goalkeeper Ryan Clarke with a powerful long-range strike. But it was the hosts who were the dominant force and they deservedly took the lead just before half-time, as Mark Marshall raced onto a loose ball before finishing confidently past the helpless stopper.

Trouble prompted police involvement outside the ground before violence behind one goal as players warmed up. "Projectiles and fireworks launched from the stands require fans to take refuge on the pitch." Police are working to identify those responsible for the violence outside and inside the ground. They have urged anyone with information or footage of the incident to come forward. Police have said they will take a zero-tolerance approach to any individuals or groups involved in trouble. The police have increased the presence outside the ground and have encouraged people to report any suspicious activity or any potential troublemakers. The police have also warned that they will take action against anyone who engages in criminal behaviour. Furthermore, they are working closely with the club to ensure the safety of fans attending future matches.

The man, believed to be a Polish national, was found badly injured in the early hours of Wednesday at flats in Thurso Crescent. He later died at Ninewells Hospital. A post-mortem examination is to be carried out. Detective Chief Inspector Keith Hardie said: "Our inquiries are at an early stage and we are working to establish the identity of this man as quickly as possible. "We know from our inquiries that he was within the local area over the weekend and I would urge anyone who may have seen him in the Thurso Crescent or surrounding areas to contact us." Anyone with information should call Police Scotland on 101 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

A letter sent by party activists in north Wales claimed Michelle Brown has been "abrasive and discourteous" to them. It was sent to UKIP's national executive committee (NEC) before a meeting in which Brown was expected to be ratified as a UKIP AM for the region. The NEC responded by saying that they take all complaints seriously and will investigate the claims thoroughly. They added that they were not going to rush into any decision on the matter and would allow due process to take its course. The NEC also said they would be open and transparent with the party activists throughout the process and would ensure that their views are taken into consideration before any decision is made.

The deal will see the firm taken over by holding company Cheil Industries, another part of the Samsung group. The merger is strongly opposed by some of Samsung CT's shareholders, who say they will vote against the deal at a shareholders meeting next month. The merger has been criticized by some for being a way for Samsung to consolidate its control over the company and limit shareholder dissent. In addition, it is seen as a way for Samsung to further diversify its businesses and increase its market power. However, Samsung CT's shareholders argue that the merger would significantly reduce their ownership stakes and therefore their ability to influence the company's decisions. Ultimately, the decision on whether or not to approve the merger will be made by Samsung CT's shareholders after the meeting in February. If approved, the merger would create one of the largest conglomerates in South Korea, with Cheil Industries gaining control over a vast array of businesses. This could have far-reaching implications both domestically and internationally, as Samsung's presence in various industries is already incredibly strong.

The New Zealand fighter failed to impress against the Romanian who took the bout at two weeks' notice, winning a 119-108 117-110 117-110 decision. The champion landed sporadic flurries throughout the fight, but the challenger's reach advantage, combined with his effective use of jabs and combinations, made it difficult for the New Zealander to make any real impact. Despite being outworked in most rounds, the champion was able to land some good body shots and counter punches, making it a competitive bout.

Yellow "be aware" warnings are also in place for Scotland for Wednesday to Saturday. The Met Office said a storm, named Storm Barbara, could see winds gusting to 90mph over the western isles. The warning states: "A spell of very strong southerly winds is expected to develop across parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland on Wednesday afternoon. Gusts of 70-80 mph are likely across some exposed parts of Scotland, with a more localised 90 mph gusts possible over the Western Isles. Winds will gradually ease through Thursday. "In addition heavy rain is expected in places, which when combined with the strong winds may bring some disruption."

Vicky Cherry, 44, had been missing for 15 months when police found her body wrapped in a duvet and plastic sheeting at a house in Toronto Street, Bolton, in January. The cause of death has not yet been ascertained, but a post-mortem examination is due to take place. Vicky's family have said they are "devastated" by the news. Police believe that Vicky had been living at the address for some time and that she may have been dead for several weeks before her body was found. They are now working to piece together the circumstances leading up to her death and are appealing to anyone who knew her or saw her in the months before she died to come forward.

The US-owned retail firm, which processes hundreds of thousands of online orders each week, could have put millions of transactions at risk, security expert Paul Moore estimates. He first noticed the issue on April 26 and reported it to the company, which then took action to fix the problem. The company reportedly failed to encrypt customer data such as credit card numbers, names and addresses. This means that anyone who had access to the server could have obtained the personal information of millions of customers. The retailer has since taken steps to protect customer data by implementing robust security protocols and encryption measures. It is also working with third-party cyber security firms to investigate the issue and enhance its defenses against future attacks. The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of maintaining secure systems, particularly those dealing with sensitive customer information. Companies should ensure their systems are regularly updated and monitored for any potential vulnerabilities. They should also take steps to educate staff about cyber security risks and how to mitigate them.

Media playback is not supported on this device Malan targeted South Africa's seamers, striking 12 fours and two sixes in a 44-ball knock as England posted 181-8. Chris Jordan took the Man of the Match award with a three-wicket haul The second international Twenty20 between England and South Africa in Paarl ended in a thrilling victory for the hosts. South Africa chased down England's total of 181-8 to win by three wickets with four balls to spare, as Reeza Hendricks hit the winning runs off Tom Curran.
