Dawid Malan starred for England, smashing 78 from 44 balls, while Chris Jordan picked up 3-39. But JP Duminy (47) and Farhaan Behardien (34) guided South Africa home to take a 1-0 lead in the three-match series. England, who won their first two Twenty20s against the Proteas in June, made a strong start after being put into bat at Boland Park. Malan, playing his third international Twenty20, was particularly destructive, hitting 12 fours and two sixes, while Jason Roy chipped in with 39. Jordan then took centre stage with the ball, taking the key wickets of AB de Villiers and Farhaan Behardien as South Africa lurched to 62-4 in the ninth over. But Duminy and wicketkeeper Heinrich Klaasen (35) combined for a crucial 66-run partnership to get South Africa back on track. The Proteas needed 22 from the final two overs but Duminy saw them home with five balls to spare. England will now be looking to level the series in the second match in East London on Sunday.

A long, slow sigh sounded in the room. Then a consolatory hand on her shoulder. Shortly after, the sinking feeling in the pit of her stomach. Canon Enid Morgan remembers the moment she was told her father had died. "I felt a mix of emotions," Canon Morgan recalls. "Sadness, emptiness and a little bit of fear. I knew that life would never be the same again." The death of her father marked a turning point in Canon Morgan's life. She was just 12 years old at the time and it made her realize how precious life is. She decided from then on to make the most of every day, no matter what. "My dad had an incredible zest for life and his passing taught me to be more present in my own life and appreciate every moment," she says. Canon Morgan has since gone on to lead a fulfilling life and career, most recently as Canon of Christ Church Cathedral in Oxford. She believes her father's legacy has been a source of strength and inspiration throughout her life. "I'm reminded of him every day, and I strive to live my life with the same enthusiasm and zest that he did," she says.

Mourinho, 52, is halfway through a four-year deal signed on his return to Stamford Bridge in June 2013. And further talks are expected in the coming weeks with the club keen to tie him down for the foreseeable future. Mourinho has been a huge success since returning to Chelsea, leading the club to their first Premier League title in five years last season. He has also guided the Blues to the League Cup and the Champions League semi-finals this term.

Conservative-run Bath and North East Somerset Council is holding a presentation of initial concept pictures of the redevelopment. Banes recently agreed it had to save PS2.6m from its PS351m budget , leading to redundancies and cuts in services. The presentation will demonstrate the progress that has been made so far and will present initial concept images of the redevelopment. The presentation is open to public attendance, but providing feedback at this stage is not possible. This presentation will be an opportunity for the public to get a first glimpse at the plans for the redevelopment and to see what the council has achieved so far in terms of savings and improvements. It will also provide an opportunity for the public to ask questions about the project and how it is progressing.

Towell, 25, was knocked down twice during the bout in Glasgow on Thursday and died in hospital on Friday night. His partner Chloe Ross revealed he had been suffering migraines in the days leading up to the fight, and said it was "heartbreaking" her partner had died from something he loved. The British Boxing Board of Control has launched an investigation into Towell's death and the governing body for boxing in the UK has promised a "thorough and comprehensive inquiry." Speaking after the fight on Thursday, his trainer Shane McGuigan said Towell had done "everything right" in the run-up to the bout, adding: "I'm just devastated for him and his family." Towell is survived by his fiancee Chloe and their daughter, five-month-old Roe.

Wallace's name might not have the same cachet as Keegan, Dalglish or Rush but his place in Liverpool history is unassailable - he scored the club's first European goal. His signing in 1960 was a statement of intent from Bill Shankly, who had just taken over as manager. Wallace made an immediate impact at Anfield with his hardworking, no-nonsense approach to the game. He quickly became a fan favourite and went on to play 316 times for the Reds, scoring 62 goals. His most famous moment came on October 4th, 1965 when he scored the club's first ever European goal in a 3-2 win against Anderlecht in the European Cup. Wallace was part of the team that won Liverpool's first two league titles under Shankly in 196364 and 196566. He also played in three FA Cup finals during his time at the club, winning one in 1965. His career ended in 1973 after 13 years with Liverpool, but by then Wallace had left an indelible mark on the club.

The Austrian opened the scoring with a penalty after Ashley Westwood brought down Phil Bardsley. He set up his second with a looping header which he then chested in. Leandro Bacuna also got on the scoresheet for Villa in the 3-1 win. Leandro Bacuna scored Villa's second goal of the match, finishing from close range after being picked out by a cross from Conor Hourihane. Jack Grealish then sealed the win with a superb solo effort, beating three defenders before firing home.

Ethnically it is highly diverse, with more than 300 local languages. The people range from rural hunter-gatherers to a modern urban elite. Sophisticated kingdoms existed before the arrival of the Europeans. There is a wide variety of cultures and customs, due to the vast size of the country and its ethnic diversity. The main religions are Christianity, Islam and traditional beliefs, although there are other minority faiths.

The 28-year-old left Rovers after their National League promotion final defeat by Grimsby earlier this month. He made 33 league appearances this season, scoring six goals from defence, and has also been at Dover, Chelmsford City and Eastleigh. Manager Ryan Austin said: "Dan has great experience of this level, having played almost 300 games in the National League, which is invaluable when building a young squad like ours. "He has a great left foot and can play centre-half or left-back so gives us great versatility, and he's a leader who speaks up on and off the pitch. "I'm delighted to get him on board and I know he was very keen to come here, so hopefully he'll be a big asset for us."

Artis Sterkis, 37, collapsed on the Peterhead-registered Starlight Rays. He was taken to hospital by rescue helicopter after the incident in August 2011, but he never regained consciousness. James Thores en, the skipper of the vessel, said that he had seen Mr Sterkis collapse and fall to the deck. He immediately radioed for help and a rescue helicopter was sent to the scene. Mr Sterkis was airlifted from the vessel and taken to Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, where he remained in a coma until his death on the 31st October 2011. An investigation into his death found that he had suffered a cardiac arrest due to an undiagnosed heart condition. His family expressed their gratitude to the crew of the Starlight Rays and to the emergency services who had done all they could to try and save his life. They paid tribute to him as a loving son, brother, uncle and friend, and said that he would be greatly missed.

Ties have sharply deteriorated in recent years, and the government in Warsaw has sharply criticised Russia's conduct in Ukraine. But Mr Andreyev's interpretation of history brought relations to a new low. He said that the Poles were responsible for starting World War Two and "further deepened the tragedy of Europe." His comments sparked outrage in Poland, where leaders from both the ruling conservative Law and Justice Party (PiS) and opposition parties condemned them.

The ship took shelter near Mounts Bay after an initial rescue at 22:00 BST on Sunday failed due to poor weather conditions, the coastguard said. The men were airlifted to safety by a helicopter at about 01:00 BST. The Royal Navy and the Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) had sent out a search-and-rescue team to locate the vessel after it was reported missing near Land's End on Sunday evening. The men, who have not been named, were taken to hospital in Penzance for a check-up. They are believed to be members of a fishing crew from the nearby village of Cadgwith. A coastguard spokesman said: "We can confirm that the two men have been rescued from the vessel and are safe and well. We would like to thank all those involved in the successful rescue operation."

Officers were called to Derby Road, Enfield at 15:30 GMT on Saturday after reports of a gun being seen in a car. A Metropolitan Police spokesman said the reported car was stopped and three men were arrested on suspicion of possession of a firearm. The men remain in custody at a North London police station. A search at the scene was carried out and no firearms were located. Enquiries into the incident are ongoing.

The newly minted millionaire was reported to have just returned from a holiday with his family when they were told the news. "My husband was literally pumping the air when we heard the news," his wife said. "It was the most incredible feeling of joy that I have ever experienced." The couple said they plan to use some of the money to travel, buy a new home, and help their family and friends. They also plan to donate to charity and set up a trust fund for their children. "We want to make sure our kids are taken care of," they said. "We believe in investing in our future generations."

Among those arrested were six suspects in Italy, four in Britain, and three in Norway. Police say some of the suspects may have travelled to Syria or Iraq. Italy's Ansa news agency said the suspects had been in contact with an Islamic State operative in Iraq. The arrests were part of a joint operation by Italian and British police, which began in April. The investigation uncovered a network of extremists who were in contact with each other through social media and messaging apps. The suspects are believed to have planned attacks in Europe and elsewhere, and discussed ways to fund their activities. Italian police said the suspects had "strong links" to IS ideology and had sought to support its aims. They also said the suspects had actively recruited new members for their extremist network. Police said they seized weapons, explosives, and computers during the raids. They added that the suspects had used encrypted communications to hide their activities from law enforcement. The arrests come as European countries are on high alert for terrorist attacks. This week, Britain raised its terror threat level from "substantial" to "severe," citing an increased risk of attack.

Myra Forde's ex-lawyer says she did not state that the late PM was a client, nor did she threaten to expose him if a prosecution against her was continued. Forde 's lawyer did state that the PM had been her friend, but refuted any claims that he was a client. Forde herself stated that the late PM had offered her legal advice in the past, but denied that he had ever acted as her lawyer.

The announcement of the coaching changes at Surrey on the day of the Australia-Sri Lanka Champions Trophy game at The Oval meant juggling meetings and phone calls with stints in the TV commentary box. To accommodate the announcement of coaching changes at Surrey on the day of the Australia-Sri Lanka Champions Trophy game at The Oval, I had to juggle meetings and phone calls with stints in the TV commentary box. As a result, I was able to stay on top of the situation while still providing analysis for the match.

At least 1.8 million more households will be looking to rent rather than buy a home by 2025, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics) claims. It has called on the government to increase its ambition in tackling the housing crisis, warning that the UK is facing a "major shortage" of properties for rent. Rics said the number of households in the private rented sector (PRS) could reach 5.93 million by 2025, representing around 25 of all homes in England and Wales. This figure is up from 4.1 million currently and 3.6 million in 2010. Rics said the growth was partly driven by an ageing population, which is increasingly opting to rent rather than buy. However, it warned that the lack of housebuilding meant there were not enough homes being built to meet demand. It said that the majority of new-builds were for sale, meaning that people who wanted to rent had fewer options. The report called for the government to introduce measures such as rent controls and tax incentives to encourage more landlords to provide homes for rent. It also suggested that local authorities should be able to borrow money to build their own PRS stock. Rics chief executive Sean Tompkins said: "The UK's housing market is fundamentally broken. We are facing a major shortage in the number of homes available to rent, and rising rental costs are pricing many people out of the market. Unless we take action now to address this growing problem, more and more people will be left without access to secure, affordable accommodation."

The 26-year-old Ivory Coast international began his European club career with Standard Liege in 2009. He then joined Anderlecht, for whom he scored seven goals in 47 league appearances, before signing for the Hornets in August 2014. The central midfielder has since become a regular starter at Vicarage Road, making 117 Premier League appearances and scoring six goals in the process. He was part of the Watford side that reached the 2019 FA Cup final, and has also featured in the Europa League during his time with the club. Capoue is currently in his sixth season with the Hornets, but he is out of contract at the end of the current campaign and has yet to agree an extension. According to reports in France, Capoue's representatives have been in talks with both PSG and Marseille over a potential move this summer. However, it is claimed that Watford are keen to keep hold of Capoue and are hoping to tie him down to a new deal before the transfer window opens.

Georg Niedermeier's own goal gave Pep Guardiola's side a half-time lead, which David Alaba doubled. Daniel Didavi fired into the top corner for Stuttgart, but Douglas Costa's long-range shot sealed the win for Bayern shortly afterwards.

Last year's runner-up will bid to become the first top weight to triumph since Red Rum in 1974. A sell-out crowd of 70,000 is expected at Aintree Racecourse on Merseyside. The 2018 Grand National runner-up was Minella Rocco, ridden by jockey J.J. Codd and trained by Jonjo O'Neill. He finished 2nd by less than a length behind Tiger Roll, who went on to win the race again in 2019.

Aiden Hughes, with an address of Balmoral Road, Bangor, posed as a teenage boy before meeting his victim in a Belfast park. During the meeting, he touched the girl over her clothing and tried to kiss her. Aiden Hughes was arrested by the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) on suspicion of sexual assault and child abduction. He is currently being held in custody pending further investigation into the matter.

Radwan Hamed collapsed during a game in Belgium in 2006. Last year a judge ruled Spurs breached its duties to him. In a screening prior to signing for the club, Hamed was found to have a heart condition that might put him at risk during physical activity. Despite this, Spurs signed him and allowed him to play without disclosing the diagnosis or providing adequate advice or monitoring. Hamed had sought to recover damages for the breach of duty, including loss of earnings, medical expenses and pain and suffering. The judge eventually settled on a total amount of 1.25 million in damages payable by Spurs. This amount is inclusive of any and all legal costs.

The West Ham striker is charged with driving a car while a baby was being held by a passenger. Snodgrass, 29, is alleged to have driven on Duke Street, Glasgow, on March 29 this year with a child being held by another person in the car. If convicted, Snodgrass could face up to six penalty points on his driving licence and a fine of up to 2,500. The footballer has been released on bail and will appear at Glasgow Sheriff Court on August 11.

General Vladimir Padrino tweeted that the "leaders and masterminds of the paramilitary and terrorist assault" had been arrested. The suspects are a 38-year-old former captain, Juan Carlos Caguaripano Scott, and two other people. The Venezuelan government accused them of attacking a military base on Sunday and attempting to overthrow the government. Padrino said that the suspects had ties to the United States and Colombia and were funded by "extreme right-wing" politicians in both countries. He also added that the attack, which was led by Caguaripano, was "a terrorist act orchestrated from abroad." Padrino promised that the government would continue to defend democracy and the rule of law in Venezuela.

Media playback is not supported on this device Drogba, 39, has not played since leaving Major League Soccer club Montreal Impact in November. He will start out as a player -coach at Phoenix Rising. The former Chelsea and Ivory Coast striker has won almost every major honour in football, including the Champions League, four Premier League titles and two FA Cups. Drogba said: "It's a great move for me. I'm really excited to be part of Phoenix Rising, a team that is on its way up. I can bring my experience and help them develop into a winning team. "I've already been talking to the players about the game, so I'm looking forward to getting out there and helping the team progress." Phoenix Rising, who play in the United Soccer League, are owned by Peter Guber and Brett Bouchy, who both have shares in NBA side Golden State Warriors. Guber said: "Didier Drogba is one of the greatest players of all time, and we are proud to have him join our organisation. He joins us with a wealth of experiences, successes and knowledge that will be invaluable to our club and to the entire community."

He was taken to the Royal Sussex County Hospital following the incident just before 06:00 BST on Saturday. He is reported to be in a stable condition. Sussex Police said the incident was not being treated as suspicious. The South East Coast Ambulance Service said a man in his 40s had been taken to hospital with "multiple head injuries."

No, President Xi Jinping of China isn't back for second helpings from the Buckingham Palace banquet, this time it is the Indian prime minister who is stopping by. India has had a long-standing tradition of exchanging state visits with the UK, so Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India was invited to attend a banquet at Buckingham Palace in April 2018.

Cyber-attacks, trolls, terrorist propaganda, sexism, racism, Twitter mobs.... stop the web now, Mr Berners-Lee, we want to get off. So, when it came to compiling 2015's list of the most pressing issues and challenges facing the web, this was certainly one of them. The most pressing issues and challenges facing the web in 2015 include: 1. Cybersecurity: With hackers becoming increasingly sophisticated and cyber-attacks becoming more frequent and dangerous, it is essential that steps are taken to protect our data, identities, and networks from malicious actors. 2. Data Privacy: As the amount of personal data stored online continues to grow, protecting our privacy becomes increasingly important. Governments and businesses must work together to ensure that individuals' data is kept secure and that appropriate permissions and restrictions are applied. 3. Net Neutrality: The concept of net neutrality has come under fire recently, as some governments seek to limit access to certain types of content or websites. It is essential that the open nature of the internet is preserved and that users have equal access to all content. 4. Online Hate Speech: From racism to sexism, online hate speech is becoming an increasingly common issue. It is important that we create a safe, respectful environment for everyone online, and take steps to prevent bullying and harassment. 5. Fake News: With the proliferation of news sources on the web, it can be difficult to determine which sources are reliable and which are not. It is important that users are able to differentiate between real news and fake news, and that they are aware of the potential dangers of relying on false information.

The scooter Danny Glass was riding on with Sophie Emma Rose Anderson collided with a truck in Phuket on 8 May. Mr Glass, 29, originally from Margate, escaped serious injury. The truck driver, Mr. Jun Loon, was taken to hospital but is expected to make a full recovery. The incident is being investigated by the local authorities, who are asking for any witnesses to come forward with any information they may have. Police are also appealing for CCTV footage of the incident that may be available.

Once Kyle Abbott dismissed Sri Lanka captain Angelo Mathews for 59 in the third over of the day in Port Elizabeth, the tone was set. Abbott (2-38), Kagiso Rabada (3-77) and Dale Steyn (4-36) ran through Sri Lanka's batting lineup, as the visitors were dismissed for 201 in the first innings of the second Test. South Africa then took advantage of their strong position with an impressive batting performance led by debutant Temba Bavuma (78 not out). Quinton de Kock (51) and Hashim Amla (50) put together a solid opening stand of 106, before captain AB de Villiers (68 not out) and Bavuma added an unbroken 123-run partnership to take South Africa to 264-3 at stumps on Day 2. The hosts now hold a lead of 63 runs and will be looking to extend it further when play resumes on Saturday.

The home secretary wrote to cabinet colleagues in December seeking approval to "reduce significantly" one type of stop and search, Newsnight has learned. Despite setting a 12 December deadline, the proposal has not yet been approved. Theresa May wrote to other cabinet ministers on 12 December, asking for permission to reduce the use of section 60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act. This type of stop and search is used in areas where there is a risk of serious violence, but it does not require officers to have reasonable suspicion that someone is carrying a weapon. In her letter, Mrs May said she wanted to make sure that the use of section 60 was "targeted and effective." She also proposed introducing an independent oversight body to monitor the use of stop and searches. However, it is understood that the proposal has not yet been agreed by the cabinet. Some ministers are believed to be concerned that any reduction in its use could lead to an increase in violent crime.

The concerns came amid Sportscotland plans to reduce sport funding in Scotland by 20. The news of sport funding cuts in Scotland has been met with dismay by many organizations and individuals. Scottish Athletics, which runs the non-club running initiative, said that it was "extremely disappointed" to hear about the proposed 20 reduction in sport funding. Without the necessary financial support, the organization fears that its program will suffer, as well as other grassroots sporting initiatives across Scotland. The move is particularly concerning for those involved in the sport, who believe that without sufficient investment, the development of young athletes will be hindered and the future success of Scottish sport itself could be at risk. The lack of funds could have a knock-on effect on physical health and wellbeing, too, meaning that fewer people may benefit from the physical and social benefits of taking part in regular exercise. Sportscotland's decision to reduce sport funding in Scotland is an unfortunate one, as it not only puts pressure on the sport's governing bodies, but also risks damaging the development of sport in Scotland. It is essential that the Scottish Government finds a way to bridge the gap and help ensure that sport remains accessible to all.

Jon Schueler, who died in New York in 1992 at the age of 75, created many of his pieces from a studio in Mallaig in the Highlands. He was inspired by the rugged beauty of his Scottish surroundings, and his abstract expressionist works reflected the contrasts between land and sea. His work has been exhibited in galleries around the world, and his influence on modern art is recognized today.

Councils are relying on agency workers to cover nearly 4,000 out of 5,500 otherwise empty posts. Social workers say they are under constant pressure because of media coverage and criticism of the service, with some councils turning to agency workers to cover the gaps. Councils are using agency workers to fill the gaps because it is often more cost-effective than recruiting and training new social workers, or hiring permanent staff in times of financial difficulty. Agency workers can also provide additional capacity when necessary, such as during periods of high demand. However, agency workers may not have the same level of training or experience as permanent staff, and they often lack the same understanding of a particular council's systems and culture. This can lead to poorer outcomes for vulnerable people who rely on social services.

All four opposition parties at Holyrood want to repeal the football act. But the Scottish government says it will not do so without a "viable alternative" being put in place. The Football Act was introduced in 2012 to tackle sectarianism in Scottish football. It made it an offence to sing offensive songs or display offensive banners at football matches. However, critics have argued that the legislation has been used to target fans and has had a chilling effect on freedom of speech. The Scottish government has said that it is open to discussions about the Act with all stakeholders, including the police, clubs and supporters' groups. However, they have stated that any changes must ensure that the Act is still effective in tackling sectarianism. They have also called for a "viable alternative" to be put in place before considering repeal.

Turner, who spent nine years as a player with Posh before winning back-to-back promotions as manager in the early 1990s, was diagnosed with frontal lobe dementia in 2006. His wife , Mel, was made aware of the situation a few years earlier. "I knew something was wrong in 2003," she told the BBC. "He was forgetting things and getting confused. I just put it down to him being a bit muddled. "It was only when I took him to the doctor that we found out he had dementia." Turner was forced to retire from football management in 2004 due to his deteriorating health, but remained involved in the club until 2009. "It's been a very difficult journey for us as a family," said Mel. "It's been hard to watch Chris go from being this strong and capable man to being so vulnerable and reliant on us for everyday tasks." She added: "But despite all of this, Chris still has moments of clarity and understanding. He knows who his family is and loves spending time with us. "We've been overwhelmed by the support we've received from Posh fans and the wider football family since Chris' diagnosis. It's been a great comfort to us all, and we are so grateful."

The 42-year-old had regained the lead from Frenchman Armel Le Cleac'h, but was second as he passed the halfway mark just off New Zealand's south island. The group, a mix of students and activists, were arrested while taking part in a protest two weeks ago against a new education bill. They face possible jail terms on charges of disturbing the peace. They feature on the International Impac Dublin Literary Award's 2016 longlist, alongside BBC journalist Kirsty Wark's debut The Legacy of Elizabeth Pringle. The 35-year-old wing has signed for the Mitsubishi Dynaboars in Division Two of the Japanese League on a one-year deal. Williams scored twice in his final competitive game as Ospreys. The county has received PS1bn of aid over the past 15 years with more than PS400m in the pipeline until 2020 because of its relatively weak economy. Intense negotiations are under way between political parties amid public anger at a one-off levy of up to 10 being imposed on savers. There were 69 claims against peacekeepers in 2015, up from 52 in 2014 was 66 in 2013. Almost a third of the 2015 claims were made in the Central African Republic (CAR). The 2015 claims were the highest number of allegations against UN peacekeepers since 2005. The majority of the complaints were related to sexual exploitation and abuse (SEA). Other allegations included abuse of authority, theft, and assault. After an independent review panel recommended in 2016 that the United Nations take additional steps to address the issue of SEA, the world body launched a more comprehensive strategy to combat the problem. This includes enhanced training and vetting of personnel, increased monitoring and oversight, and improved victim assistance services. The UN is also taking measures to investigate and hold perpetrators accountable for their actions. In response to the 2015 allegations, the UN Secretary-General established a special team to look into the allegations and implemented a "zero tolerance" policy for SEA. The world body also conducted its first-ever global survey on SEA involving more than 7,000 respondents from over 100 countries. The UN has made strides in addressing the issue of SEA, but there is still much work to be done. It is critical that all member states support the efforts of the UN and provide adequate resources to ensure the protection of vulnerable populations around the world.

The 1 mile (1.5km) park between Alum Chine and Southbourne in Bournemouth is due to open on 13 April. The??700,000 attraction will include a multi-sports arena, sporting events site and a cycle route linking the two areas. The park will be divided into four distinct zones that will offer activities and facilities for all ages and abilities. Zone 1 - Adventure Play This zone will feature an adventure play area with swings, slides, climbing frames and other equipment suitable for children aged 3-12 years. There will also be a large seating area so parents and guardians can relax while their children are playing. Zone 2 - Multi-Sports Arena The multi-sports arena will provide a venue for a range of sports including basketball, netball, football and tennis. There will also be a running track suitable for joggers and walkers. Zone 3 - Sporting Events Site This site will host a variety of sporting events including 5K and 10K runs, charity bike rides and triathlons. The site will also have a large grassed area suitable for picnics and outdoor games. Zone 4 - Cycle Route The final zone will feature a cycle route that links Alum Chine and Southbourne. This route will be suitable for cyclists of all levels and will include bike racks for easy storage.

The review into 22 abuse cases in Northern Ireland criticised the authorities for not doing enough. The young people went missing a number of times over a 20-month period while in the care of the Northern Ireland Department for Health. The review found that most of the young people had been placed in unsuitable homes, with some of them being moved between multiple locations over a short period of time. In addition, there was inadequate oversight and monitoring of their placements. Furthermore, the review noted that there were insufficient safeguards to protect these vulnerable children from harm. The report concluded that the Department for Health failed to provide an appropriate level of support and care to the young people. It also highlighted the need for improved inter-agency working, better governance arrangements and increased accountability. In response to the findings, the Department for Children and Young People committed to implementing all of the recommendations from the review. This includes more robust assessment of potential foster carers and improved communication between agencies. The Department has also launched a new helpline for vulnerable children and young people so that they can access immediate help and advice.

While its existence has become a source of controversy on both sides of the Channel, some are also angry at attempts to destroy it. The campaign was successful, with the plans rejected by the government. The White Cliffs of Dover have also been used as an iconic symbol of freedom throughout history, most notably during World War Two when British Prime Minister Winston Churchill declared them "the guardian of our coast." Confessions had been forced from the Muslim men after they were beaten up in custody, a rights activist said. They were among a group of people arrested late last year. In some cases, detainees were held for months without charges or access to legal assistance. Activists are calling on authorities to take action against those responsible for the torture and mistreatment of the Muslim men, as well as to investigate all allegations of abuse by police officers. It was a sensational finish, which sealed the win for Hibs and sent the away support into wild celebrations. Mallan's strike was the difference between the two sides and it will be remembered as one of the most memorable goals in recent history.

The price of West Texas crude sank to 37.65 (PS24.99) a barrel, a drop of 5.8, while Brent Crude fell 5.3 to 40.73 a barrel. The slumping price comes as the coronavirus pandemic continues to weigh on global demand for oil, and as OPEC and its allies struggle to agree on a production cut.

Severe storms in December 2013 caused damage to an existing dune system to the east of Barkby Beach in Prestatyn. A report, to be considered by Denbighshire councillors, says there is a need to replace the dunes to protect the beach from further damage. The report recommends creating a new dune system, which would involve the planting of more than 1,000 sand-loving plants, such as Marram Grass and Sea Purslane. The dunes would also be reinforced with rocks and boulders to provide additional protection against future storms. The cost of the project is estimated to be around 60,000. The report also suggests that the new dune system could be beneficial in other ways, such as enhancing the biodiversity of the area and providing a habitat for local wildlife. It is hoped that the project would help to attract more visitors to the beach, boosting the local economy. Denbighshire councillors will now need to decide whether or not to approve the project. If approved, the dune system would be constructed during the summer months to ensure minimal disruption to the beach over the busy holiday season.

The 28-year-old was an ever-present in the side which won the County Championship title in 2016. "He is one of the finest cricketers in the country," managing director of cricket Angus Fraser said. "At the crease he is elegant, focused and determined. Away from it he is popular, hardworking and committed."

They said this will amount to double the number of apprentices created each year - currently about 28,000. All parties are promising to create more apprentices or equivalent schemes to support young people entering the workplace. The government has said it will create 3 million more apprenticeships over the next five years, while the Labour Party has promised to triple the number of apprenticeships created each year. The Liberal Democrats have promised to create 2 million new apprenticeships and guarantee quality skills training for all young people.

Obituary: Francisco Blake Mora The helicopter was flying to Cuernavaca in neighbouring Morelos state for a prosecutors' meeting when it went down. All eight people on board were killed. President Felipe Calderon expressed his deep sorrow at the news of the death of Francisco Blake Mora, who was the Mexican Secretary of Interior. Francisco Blake Mora was a Mexican politician and public servant who served as Secretary of the Interior in the cabinet of President Felipe Calderon from June 2009 until his tragic death on November 11, 2011. He was born in Mexico City and graduated with a law degree from the National Autonomous University of Mexico. Blake Mora is remembered for his commitment to making Mexico a more secure country for its citizens and for his dedication to fighting organized crime and drug trafficking. He also worked to improve citizen security and public safety, strengthen anti-corruption measures, and promote economic development and international cooperation. He was an advocate for human rights and the protection of vulnerable groups. He initiated several reforms, including a measure to help protect journalists and other media professionals. He spearheaded efforts to reduce poverty, improve public education, and ensure access to health care. Blake Mora was admired by his peers and colleagues for his hard work, loyalty, and integrity. His untimely death came as a shock to many and left a huge void in the political scene. He will be remembered fondly and missed dearly.

Mr Blunkett said using the same funding formula applied to Wales - which has a devolved budget - Yorkshire would be entitled to a PS24bn budget. "You put great store by the fact that Scotland has a devolved budget - and rightly so - and yet you are ignoring the fact that Yorkshire is a very substantial county which makes a huge contribution to the national economy," he said. Mr Blunkett argued that Yorkshire should be given a devolved budget, similar to those of the Welsh and Scottish governments, in order to ensure that the region's resources are used more effectively and efficiently. He pointed out that the government should use the same formula applied to Wales to calculate the amount of funding Yorkshire would receive, noting that this would likely amount to around 24 billion. Mr Blunkett also highlighted the need for Yorkshire to have more autonomy in order to better address its specific needs, such as investing in infrastructure and tackling unemployment.

The Center for Disease Control (CDC) said 45 people had been infected with a strain of E. coli, 43 of whom reported eating at a Chipotle restaurant. The cases were reported in six states: California (7), Minnesota (2), New York (1), Ohio (3), Oregon (13) and Washington (19). The CDC is working closely with public health and regulatory officials in these states to investigate the outbreak and determine a source. The agency is also conducting laboratory testing of food, environmental, and clinical specimens collected from ill people to identify the type of E. coli causing the illnesses. Results of this investigation are expected in the coming weeks. In the meantime, the CDC recommends that people in the affected states should not eat food from the Chipotle restaurant where they ate before getting sick. If you have eaten at this restaurant recently, watch for symptoms of E. coli infection, which can include severe stomach cramps, diarrhea (often bloody), and vomiting. Most people get better within 5 to 7 days.

The 56-year-old ex-Derbyshire skipper leaves his post as club president to take the newly created job. Graeme Welch left as elite performance director in June, having been appointed following a previous spell as bowling coach. Woolley first played for Derbyshire in 1985 and was captain from 1992 to 1995, leading the club to promotion to Division One of the County Championship in 1994. He said: "I am delighted to accept this role and look forward to working with the club to help enhance our performance both on and off the field. "Having worked closely with Derbyshire for a number of years, I am confident I can make a positive contribution by helping to shape the direction of the club moving forwards."

The skull of an adult male was found by the M54 slip road on Thursday by workers surveying a roundabout near Telford. The find sparked a West Mercia Police inquiry , but so far no cause of death has been established. It is likely that forensic teams will be brought in to investigate the skull and determine its identity. The police are working with local councils and other agencies to try and trace the man's family and will be looking into any historical records or missing persons reports that may be relevant. Given the lack of information available at present, it is not yet known when or how the man died or who he was. However, West Mercia Police have urged anyone with any information on the case to contact them as soon as possible.

Alexander sustained a broken cheekbone in the last week's victory over former club Rangers. And Gallacher twisted his ankle in training, making him a doubt for Sunday's Edinburgh derby with Hearts. Alexander is expected to be out of action for at least 6 weeks, while Gallacher will have an MRI scan later this week to determine the extent of his injury. The club's medical staff are optimistic that he could return in time for the derby.

The latest threats bring the number of incidents to 69 in 27 states in the past month, according to the JCC Association of North America. No bombs were found at any of the sites targeted. The threat Tuesday targeted JCCs in Wisconsin, Illinois and Indiana. About a dozen JCCs received emails with a bomb threat, according to local media reports. In Wisconsin, two JCCs in Milwaukee and one in Whitefish Bay were threatened, WTMJ-TV reported. In Illinois, at least three Chicago-area Jewish Community Centers were among those targeted, according to the Chicago Sun-Times. On Monday, the FBI released a statement on the nationwide wave of threats, saying it is "investigating possible civil rights violations in connection with threats to Jewish Community Centers across the country." The bureau also said it is working with the Department of Homeland Security and state and local law enforcement agencies to investigate the threats.

Daly spent two seasons at Ibrox after leaving Tannadice, where he has been training since pre-season. "I would never say never," the 32-year-old said of the possibility of signing for United. "I had a great time at Dundee United and I would love to go back there. "At the same time, I'm enjoying my football here in Glasgow and I'm happy with how things are going. "It's not something that I'm actively looking for or anything like that, but if the opportunity came along then I would certainly consider it."

It says increases will be needed if current trends in teacher recruitment and retention continue. Nevertheless, the STRB has recommended a pay rise of just 1 for teachers in England and Wales. The STRB recommendation of a 1 pay rise for teachers in England and Wales is not enough to address the current trends in teacher recruitment and retention. Increases in pay will be necessary if these trends are to be tackled successfully. The government must take action to ensure that teachers receive adequate wages to attract and retain them in the profession.

We've asked BBC Sport readers to predict the top three before every race this season and, after the British Grand Prix, we got our calculators out and had a look at the results. The most popular predictions were Lewis Hamilton to win, Max Verstappen in second, and Valtteri Bottas in third. That's exactly how the race finished, so well done to those who got it right! In total, we had over 17,000 entries for the British Grand Prix alone, and almost 130,000 entries across all of the races this season. When it comes to the overall standings, Daniel Ricciardo came out on top as the most popular prediction to finish in the top three, with an average of 61.6. Sebastian Vettel was second with an average of 57.9, and Charles Leclerc was third with an average of 54.6. It looks like BBC Sport readers are pretty good at predicting who will be on the podium, so let's see if they can keep it up for the remaining races this season!

The accident, which involved a white Vauxhall Astra van, happened on the A701 Howden Hall Road in Kaimes at about 07:50. The woman was taken to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary. The road was closed for four hours while emergency services attended the scene. Police Scotland said that their inquiries into the incident are ongoing and asked anyone who witnessed the crash to come forward with information. They can be contacted on 101, quoting reference number 0787 of 21 October 2020.

Gen Christophe Gomart told a parliamentary commission in May that a "partner agency" warned of the plot by a Brazilian Islamist militant. No further details were given. Gen Gomart made the remarks while giving evidence to a commission of inquiry into the attack, which left 129 dead and more than 350 injured. He said the French intelligence services had been told of a "possible attack" on France by a Brazilian Islamist militant three days before the incident.

The head of the mission, Peter Graaff, met the Ghanaian president to thank the country for hosting the agency since it was set up in September last year. A small number of staff are based in Accra, the capital of Ghana. The mission was established to help countries affected by the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, which has killed more than 11,000 people since it began in December 2013. Graaff said the UN mission has already achieved a great deal since it was set up, including helping to contain the spread of the virus and supporting the recovery of affected countries. He added that the UN will continue to support the region in its efforts to achieve full recovery from the outbreak. Ghanaian President John Dramani Mahama thanked Graaff for the visit and expressed his appreciation for the work the UN had done in responding to the Ebola crisis. He also said that Ghana had made a significant contribution to the response effort and called on other countries to do their part to help end the epidemic.

All 26 are accused of evading tests but say there was an administrative error. The list includes Fabrizio Donato, triple jump bronze medallist at London 2012, and Andrew Howe, who won the silver medal in the long jump at the same Olympics. The other accused athletes are: 1. Alex Schwazer, Olympic gold medallist in 50 km race walk at Beijing 2008 2. Andrea Lalli, member of Italy's 4 x 400 m relay team at London 2012 3. Antonella Palmisano, 800 m runner at London 2012 4. Giaccherini, 31, joined the Black Cats in 2013 from Juventus for PS6.5m but, after an impressive first season, he struggled to make an impact. He played 43 times in total , scoring three goals. Giaccherini spent last season on loan at Bologna and was part of their squad which finished 14th in Serie A. He previously had spells with Cesena, Empoli and Juventus.

However, the report concluded there had been "no overarching state conspiracy." Sir Desmond de Silva's review confirmed that agents of the state were involved in the 1989 killing and that the killing could have been prevented. The de Silva review was commissioned by the British government in December 2012, to examine if there had been any involvement by state agents in the 1989 murder of Belfast lawyer Patrick Finucane. The review concluded that there was "collusion" between the security forces and loyalist paramilitaries in relation to the killing, but there was no overarching conspiracy by the state to murder him. It also found that there were serious failings in the investigations into the murder, and that some police officers had lied about their involvement. The report recommended that a new inquiry should be held into the case, which the UK government has yet to decide on.

Mr Trump broke a long-held tradition by not releasing his paperwork during his presidential campaign. His critics want to know who he has been dealing with and if there are any conflicts of interest. Trump has refused to provide financial information and other documents that other presidential candidates have released for decades, citing an ongoing IRS audit. The lack of transparency has led to speculation about the source of his wealth and potential conflicts of interest.

An inquiry for "attempted terrorist murder" has been launched into Saturday's attack in Charleroi. The man reportedly shouted "Allahu Akbar" God is greatest during the assault outside a police station. The man was shot and killed by police. The public prosecutor's office of Hainaut has launched an inquiry into the attack for "attempted terrorist murder," a spokeswoman said on Sunday. Police are still trying to establish the identity of the attacker, who is believed to be an Algerian national in his 30s. The spokeswoman said that the investigation would try to determine whether or not the man had links to any terror organization and if he acted alone. Investigators will also look into where the attacker may have gotten weapons or other materials used in the attack. In addition, the inquiry will examine any possible accomplices or people who might have been aware of the attack beforehand. The public prosecutor's office is working with Belgian intelligence services, local police, and other law enforcement agencies in their investigation.

It is expected to be wet and windy later, with the possibility of flooding in places from heavy rain and melting snow. The strongest winds are expected to be along the coast and in areas of higher elevation. It is important to be prepared for these conditions, especially if you live in a flood-prone area. Make sure to secure any outdoor items that could be blown away by the wind, and consider making alternate arrangements for travel if flooding is expected. Additionally, be sure to check on local weather advisories from your local government or news sources.

Andrew Haldane said in a speech he was downbeat over the UK economy because of weaker global growth, low wage growth and financial and political risks. "Put in rather plainer language, the UK economy is facing a perfect storm of headwinds," he said. Haldane's comments reflect the fact that the UK economy is in a precarious position due to external factors such as Brexit uncertainty, slowing global growth, and weaker trade. These issues are likely to put a dampener on economic activity in the months ahead, resulting in lower levels of business investment and consumer spending. This in turn could lead to slower wage growth and higher unemployment. The Bank of England has already warned about the risks posed by these issues and the need for policymakers to be prepared for a more difficult economic outlook.

Critics say the new contract involves pay cuts of up to 30, with "normal hours" extended to include 7am to 10pm on every day except Sunday. The British Medical Association has been vocal in its opposition to the new contract, arguing that it will lead to overworked and underpaid staff. They are further concerned that the contract does not properly account for the mental health of doctors, who are already known to be at risk of burnout. The BMA has also argued that the proposed contract does not provide enough protection for patient safety, as doctors may be too tired to provide appropriate care.

It could be over in hours - or it could take weeks. That's how unknowable an acute counter-terrorism investigation can be for MI5 and the police. While there is a lot of activity around the suspect, and a lot of information gathered from surveillance and other sources, it's impossible to predict how long it will take for an investigation to conclude. Generally speaking, however, investigations require extensive analysis, interviews, and evidence collection in order to come to a conclusion, so it is likely that an acute counter-terrorism investigation could take weeks or even months to complete.

North Wales Police and Crime Commissioner Arfon Jones said a so-called "fix room" could reduce drug deaths and the spread of infection. He said the proposed plan came in response to the rising number of drug-related deaths in North Wales. Mr Jones said he was looking into how such a room could work and what it would involve. He has also asked for an assessment from the Welsh Government on the potential benefits and drawbacks of such an initiative. The Commissioner said he wanted to ensure the safety of users and the wider public and that any solution would be evidence-based, with the views of health professionals and other stakeholders taken into account. He also said he wanted to ensure that such a facility would not act as a magnet for further substance abuse.

Edward Alexander Lee, 34, was sentenced to three years on probation at Belfast Crown Court on Wednesday. Judge Gordon Kerr QC said it was the best way of protecting society and that it was "clearly not a case of actual violence." Lee admitted two charges of common assault after an incident at an Asda store in Belfast on June 28 last year. He had been seen pushing and shoving staff members in the store and was later arrested by police. In a statement, Judge Kerr said Lee had shown remorse and had apologised for his actions. He added that he could have gone to prison but that a non-custodial sentence was more appropriate. The judge also told Lee that he must undertake a programme of alcohol treatment and counselling.

Ward, the world number 111, recovered from two sets down to win 6-7 (5-7) 5-7 6-3 7-6 (7-3) 15-13 in Glasgow. The Englishman needed six match points before finally seeing off his opponent. Ward's victory marked the first time in his career he had come from two sets down to win a match. He managed to break serve eight times and saved four break points during the course of the match. The three-hour and 36-minute epic ended with Ward serving out for the match to clinch his place in the quarterfinals. After the match, Ward said it was "one of the best wins of my life."

The Labour authority voted in favour of changing 2,700 contracts from 52 weeks to term time-only. The council said it would bring staff in line with the other 17,000 workers who were already on term time-only contracts. The council argued that the change was necessary to save money and ensure that they could continue to provide quality services to their residents. The council also said that it would help improve the worklife balance of staff, as well as reducing childcare costs for those with school age children. The change was opposed by some members of the public, who argued that it would mean less pay for affected staff, and an overall poorer level of service for residents. Despite these objections, the Labour authority voted in favour of the change, and 2,700 workers are now on term time-only contracts.

Leeds, 15th in the Championship table, looked vulnerable at the start of the season, particularly at set-pieces. But central defender Bartley has formed an impressive partnership with Pontus Jansson in the heart of defence, while left-back Charlie Taylor has been a revelation at the back. The team have also benefited from the arrival of new manager Garry Monk, who has instilled an attacking style of play that has seen Leeds become one of the most entertaining sides in the division. The Whites have scored the third-most goals in the Championship this season and have been particularly impressive on the counter attack. With the January transfer window now open, Leeds are expected to strengthen their squad in order to push for promotion. With the right additions, Leeds could be dark horses for the top six come May.

27 August 2016 Last updated at 12:34 BST The restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law was introduced allowing dogs to eat at restaurants - as long as they were accompanied by an adult. The restaurant, located in the south of England, is believed to be the first in the country to offer a special menu for canine customers. The restaurant's owner said that he had been inspired by his own dog to create the puppy platter, which includes dishes such as kibble, gravy and vegetables. The new law was introduced to allow people to take their dogs out to eat with them, as long as they are on a lead and fully supervised. Many restaurants already allowed customers to bring along their pooches, but this law formalised the practice. The restaurant's owner said that the response to the puppy platters has been overwhelmingly positive. He added that it was a great way for owners to bond with their pets, and for the animals to experience eating out with their owners.

Republicans ambushed a mini-bus carrying the men at Kingsmill in County Armagh in 1976 and murdered them after checking what religion they were. Senior coroner John Leckey is retiring this year and has requested that the inquest into their deaths, which began in February 2019, be concluded before he leaves. The inquest is expected to conclude in the coming months, and it is anticipated that the coroner will deliver his findings by the end of the year. The families of the victims are hoping for justice for their loved ones and for the truth about what happened at Kingsmill to finally be revealed. The coroner's findings could lead to prosecutions if there is sufficient evidence that links the murders to any individuals or organisations.

Pernod Ricard, which is based in France, is the second biggest distiller of Scotch after Diageo. Its brands include Chivas, The Glenlivet and Ballentine's. However, the distiller reported that Jameson's, its Irish whiskey, was the world's best-selling whiskey in 2018.

Three open-top buses took the first team, youth team and family members on a parade from Stamford Bridge towards the King's Road in west London. Chelsea ended their campaign eight points clear of Manchester United. The parade started with the team bus, followed by the youth team and family members, who were all waving flags, banners and singing songs to show their appreciation for the season's achievements. The route went from Stamford Bridge to King's Road and then on to Sloane Square, where the team stopped briefly to acknowledge the thousands of fans who had gathered to cheer them on. The parade then continued towards the Natural History Museum, before finishing at Kensington Palace Gardens, where the players disembarked and mingled with the crowd, signing autographs and taking photos.

The House of Lords heard the government had not yet taken a decision as to whether an inquiry will be held. Launching one now could prejudice the on-going investigations into the Iraq war by various organisations, including the police. The government has not yet taken a decision as to whether an inquiry into the Iraq War will be held. However, the House of Lords heard that launching one now could prejudice the on-going investigations into the Iraq war by various organisations, including the police. There are also several other factors to consider such as the cost, scope, and timing of such an inquiry. Therefore, the government is reviewing all the relevant evidence before making a decision.

Trapped by disadvantage are more than 730,000 youngsters, according to the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS). It laments a "national shame," and its research suggests about 13 of the country's poorest households with children suffer "persistent poverty," meaning that incomes remain below 50 percent of the median for three or more years. The causes of this phenomenon are complex, but there is a clear link to generational disadvantage and cycles of poverty. Many of these children come from Indigenous backgrounds, and their families have been living in poverty for generations. These children often face barriers to education, employment and social inclusion. In addition, many of these children experience an array of challenges such as homelessness, substance abuse, mental health issues, and family violence. ACOSS notes that these challenges can be compounded by inadequate access to essential services, such as housing, education, and health care, which further entrenches poverty. There is no quick fix to solving the issue of intergenerational disadvantage and poverty among Australian youth, but there are steps that can be taken to help protect vulnerable young people. For example, governments should provide increased funding for social and educational programs that target this group, including income support measures, training and employment services, and targeted health and mental health services. Governments should also prioritize initiatives that seek to increase participation in school, reduce the rates of early school leaving, and support those who do leave school early to gain the skills they need to enter the workforce. Finally, it is important to ensure that all children have access to adequate housing and nutrition to ensure they have the best chance of succeeding in life.

The former world champion will target the time trial and may also support Lizzie Armitstead in the road race. Pooley, 33, retired from cycling after winning two silver medals at London 2012 but returned to the sport in April. In a statement, Pooley said: "I'm really excited to be back racing with the GB Cycling Team. It's an honour to be selected for the World Championships and I'm looking forward to helping the team in whichever way I can. "The Worlds are always an incredible event and I'm sure that Ponferrada will be no different with some great racing on the cards." British Cycling's performance director, Sir Dave Brailsford, added: "We're delighted to have Emma back on the team. Her experience and ability will be invaluable in both the road race and time trial and of course she has already won a medal in this event before. "She has been training hard since her return to the sport earlier this year and we're confident that she can continue to perform at the highest level."

Media playback is unsupported on your device 9 August 2015 Last updated at 17:51 BST Petrol bombs were thrown at police and water cannon was deployed. Protesters also threw stones at officers during a demonstration in Belfast. The violence broke out during an Irish nationalist march in the city centre. The police said two petrol bombs were thrown and water cannon was used to disperse the crowd. At least three people were arrested in connection with the disturbances. The protest was organised by dissident republicans who oppose the peace process in Northern Ireland. Police had urged the organisers to call off the event but they refused. The Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) said it was disappointed that the parade had gone ahead, despite advice from its officers. It said the decision to use water cannon was taken to protect officers and the public and to prevent further disruption to the city centre.

The Waking the Dragon tower was granted permission by Wrexham council back in February 2011. Businessman Simon Wingett is trying to raise PS2.5m to build the bronze sculpture, cultural centre and cafe on the site of an old industrial building. It is hoped that the project will bring a boost to the local economy, as well as creating a destination for tourists and providing jobs for the community. The sculpture itself is inspired by the legend of Merlin and the red dragon, and will be built from bronze, with glass eyes that glow at night.

The Labour leader told the New Statesman his party opposed government plans to lower the overall household cap, introduced in the last Parliament. And his spokesman confirmed he was "very clear" Labour was opposed to the plans. Mr Corbyn said he supported a cap on the overall amount of welfare spending, but said it should be set in accordance with "what people need." He added: "We have raised concerns and we are absolutely opposed to the government's plans to cut the total household cap." The government has proposed cutting the cap from 26,000 a year to 23,000 for couples with children or 15,410 for single people without children. The cap was introduced by the coalition government in 2013 and limits the total amount of benefits that can be claimed by an individual or family.

Funding given to the charity, which collapsed in August, included at least PS28m from the Department for Education, the National Audit Office said. It received the money despite warnings about its financial health and failure to meet safeguarding standards. The charity, Kids Company, was set up in 1996 to provide support for disadvantaged young people in London. It received more than 45m from the government between 2011 and 2015, with a further 3m being sought just before its closure. The NAO said that "the Department did not always exercise due diligence or obtain value for money" when it gave repeated funding to the charity, despite warnings about its financial sustainability. The NAO also said that there were "significant weaknesses" in the charity's governance and financial management which had been identified but not addressed. The collapse of Kids Company has prompted calls for the government to review its procedures for disbursing grants and conducting checks on the performance and financial health of organisations it is funding. The government has said that it will strengthen its processes for assessing grant applications and ensure greater oversight of charities.

The interior of the Saab 340 that flies to and from Orkney was stripped out and renewed and the exterior repainted at a cost of almost PS270,000. Loganair, a franchise partner of Flybe, now operates the aircraft on its route to and from Kirkwall Airport. The aircraft features a modern interior with comfortable seating for up to 36 passengers, along with larger overhead bins, an extra-large lavatory and improved cabin lighting. The aircraft is also equipped with the latest in-flight audio system and entertainment options to keep passengers entertained during their journey.

Footage secretly filmed by France 2 TV shows Francoise Olcay selling dinghies and life jackets to migrants hoping to reach the Greek islands. The UN says 124,000 people reached Greece's shores in July alone. The footage shows Olcay, who is of Turkish origin, taking cash from the migrants for rubber dinghies and life jackets. She then helps them carry the equipment to the nearby beach in Turkey's western province of Canakkale. In an interview with France 2, Olcay said she was motivated by compassion for the migrants' plight. She said she had decided that if no one else was helping them, it was up to her to do so. The UN refugee agency (UNHCR) estimates that nearly half a million people have made the perilous journey across the Mediterranean to Europe this year, with more than 2,600 dying in the attempt. Olcay told France 2 she was aware of the dangers but that she felt compelled to help. "I know what I'm doing is illegal, but I'm doing it because I want to help these people," she said. "I don't think I should be judged for helping people in need." UNHCR spokesman William Spindler said he was encouraged by such acts of kindness but added that they would not solve the crisis. He said the only way to ensure safety and dignity for migrants was through a comprehensive system of legal pathways to Europe.

The PS230m development consists of 11 wind turbines. Mr Trump claims they would spoil the sea views for golfers on his course at Menie. He responded: "We will put our windmills somewhere else." Donald Trump has long been vocal in his opposition to the development of renewable energy projects near his golf course. His response here is indicative of his views on renewable energy, as he believes that his golf course should not have any obstructions due to its sea view. He is committed to finding a suitable alternative location for the wind turbines, even though this may be more difficult and costly.

The vessel's engine failed a mile north east of Muck Island on Thursday evening. Weather conditions at the time were described as good with a Force 3 wind and a 2 metre swell. The crew of the vessel made a call for help, alerting the Coast Guard to their situation. The Coast Guard dispatched a helicopter to the scene and rescued all crew members who were unharmed. The vessel was towed back to Muck Island by a commercial tugboat.

They talk of a boy who dressed smartly and worked hard, but who barely said a word during his time at school. Police officers have said he may have had some kind of mental health issue, and his classmates have said he was often seen by himself. He was never known to get into trouble or act out, but wasn't particularly close with any of the other students either.

The court in Novorossiysk gave two of the dancers 10 days in jail each, a third 15 days and two others received fines on charges of petty hooliganism. Prosecutors had asked for up to 15 days in jail for each of the women. The five dancers were arrested in late August after performing a dance routine on a Novorossiysk beach wearing nothing but body paint and underwear. The performance was part of a campaign to raise awareness about the risks posed by global warming. The court found that the performance had caused "public disorder" and issued fines and jail sentences for the dancers. The judge noted that the incident had "provoked laughter, whistling, and an indecent reaction from those present" at the beach, which disrupted public order. The dancers' lawyers argued that the performance was a form of art and was not intended to cause public disorder. They also pointed out that there were no complaints filed against the performance. Nevertheless, the court found that the dancers had violated public order and sentenced them accordingly. The case has sparked a debate in Russia over freedom of expression. Critics have argued that the court's decision was overly harsh and infringed upon the dancers' right to express themselves through art. Supporters of the ruling, on the other hand, have argued that the performance was inappropriate and disruptive, and thus deserved punishment.

Bernard Mensah struck a post for Aldershot after 11 minutes, but the visitors were a man down midway through the first half when Jim Kellerman saw red for a foul on Marvin Morgan. Morgan had the ball in the back of the net soon after, but his effort was ruled out for a foul. Aldershot then grabbed the lead just before the break when Jake Gallagher fired home from close range, and they doubled their advantage on the hour mark when Mensah found the bottom corner with a curling effort. Harrogate pulled one back 10 minutes later through Ryan Fallowfield's header, but the Shots held on to secure all three points.

HM Revenue Customs said the plant, on the outskirts of the city centre, could have cost taxpayers nearly PS138m a year in lost duty and taxes. Four lorry loads of illegal cigarettes and tobacco were discovered at the factory on Wednesday. HMRC said it was investigating the premises and that criminal proceedings may follow. The plant was set up to manufacture counterfeit cigarettes and hand-rolling tobacco, with a capacity of more than two million cigarettes and three tonnes of tobacco per week. HMRC said the illegal factory was "sophisticated" and had been equipped with specialist machinery and tools. A spokesman said: "This was an illegal operation which had the potential to cost the taxpayer around PS138m a year in lost duty and taxes. "We have now closed down this criminal enterprise and will be working hard to identify those behind it and bring them to justice."

Kirsty Williams told them they have a "responsibility as stewards of community, city and country," at a speech in Cardiff. The referendum showed "notions of togetherness" were "perhaps weaker than we thought they were," and it is a reminder that the Welsh Government must work even harder to bring people together. Williams said it was now more important than ever to focus on economic prosperity and education, as well as tackling poverty, inequality and social exclusion. She urged political parties to set aside their differences and focus on working together in order to deliver better outcomes for Wales. She also highlighted the need to ensure Wales is heard at the international level, and that Wales is represented in decision-making processes at the highest levels of government. In conclusion, Williams said she believed Wales could "stand tall and be bold" if it worked together and focused on delivering positive outcomes for its citizens. It is clear from her speech that she wants the Welsh Government to remain united and focused on improving the lives of its people.

Nia Griffith said her party offers "investment in Wales, versus cuts from Westminster" by the Tories. She urged people to "imagine the price" if there was a Conservative government in Westminster. Nia Griffith has been a vocal critic of the Conservative government in Westminster and its plans for cuts to public services in Wales. She has argued that investment in areas such as education, health, transport and housing is needed to ensure Wales can grow and prosper. She believes Labour's plans for an "investment-led recovery" are the answer to Wales' economic woes and will create jobs, stimulate growth and raise living standards.

Inspectors in abattoirs used to be able to cut open pig carcasses to check for signs of disease. But under new European regulations, supported by Britain's Food Standards Agency (FSA), this practice is no longer allowed. Instead, inspectors must rely on X-ray technology to detect signs of disease. The new regulations are intended to reduce the suffering of animals and improve food safety by making it easier to identify diseased carcasses. The FSA also said that the X-ray technology is more accurate than manual inspection and is less intrusive to the animal. In addition, it reduces the risk of spreading diseases between animals and speeds up the process of identifying suspect carcasses.

The pages from a 13th Century text of the holy book of Islam were purchased by the council in 1951. Conservator Richard Hawkes said: "This is the earliest example of the Qur'an we have ever seen in the UK. It is a wonderful and rare example of Islamic calligraphy and is likely to become an important part of our national heritage." The pages, which are written on vellum, each measure around 10cm by 7cm and feature verses from the 114 suras that make up the holy book. The text is written in Kufic script, a style of Arabic calligraphy developed in Iraq in the 8th century. It is believed that the manuscript was produced in Iran, possibly in the 13th century. The council said that the purchase was a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" to acquire such a significant item. The pages will be kept at the British Library where they will be preserved, conserved and studied. They will also be available to view as part of the Library's permanent collections.

Members of the Clwyd North Division are against the changes at Glan Clwyd Hospital, Bodelwyddan. These could see clinical staff transferred to Ysbyty Gwynedd and Wrexham Maelor hospitals from 6 July 2020. The Clwyd North division is committed to ensuring that local communities have access to the best possible care in their area. We understand that changes are needed to ensure that hospitals are able to cope with increasing pressures and meet modern standards. However, we believe that decisions such as these should be made in consultation with patients and the public, taking into account any potential impacts on patient care and local services. We have raised our concerns with Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board and the Welsh Government, calling for an urgent review of the proposed changes and for proper consultation to take place. We will continue to make our views known and work to ensure that local people receive the best possible care in their local hospital.

The area around Green Park, which also has a large business park, is notorious for its long traffic queues, particularly on match days. Plans for Green Park Station were put forward in 2004, but the project has stalled as of 2020 due to a lack of funding. The proposed station would have provided better access to both Oxford city centre and the business park, as well as improving traffic flow. The local authority is now exploring alternative ways to improve the area's transport links, such as private investment and public-private partnerships. These are being considered in order to reduce the congestion and delays caused by the current infrastructure. In addition, the council has been looking at ways to encourage more cycling and walking in the area, through initiatives such as bike hire schemes and building dedicated cycle lanes. Finally, the council is also looking into ways to make public transport more efficient, such as running buses on demand or providing more frequent services between Green Park and the city centre. This would help to reduce the need for cars and therefore alleviate some of the traffic issues.

Sales volumes increased by 1.7 in November from the month before, the Office for National Statistics said. Compared with the same month last year, sales were up by 5. However, the monthly increase was smaller than analysts had expected, and the year-on-year increase was lower than the 6.3 rise seen in October. The data suggests that while consumer spending has picked up slightly since the start of the winter season, it is still below pre-pandemic levels. The ONS said that despite the slight uptick in sales volumes, prices were still falling on an annual basis, down 0.7 in November compared with a year earlier. This could indicate that retailers are using discounts to attract shoppers. "While the month-on-month numbers look a bit better, this should be taken in the context of the sharp fall we saw in October due to the end of the Eat Out to Help Out scheme," said Jonathan Athow, Deputy National Statistician for Economic Statistics at the ONS. "Looking back over the three months as a whole, we can see that there has been a modest gain in retail sales compared with the previous quarter. This reflects a gradual recovery from the pandemic-induced lows of April and May." The ONS data also showed that online sales made up 33.9 of total retail sales in November, up from 32.7 the month before. This suggests that the shift to online shopping that began during the pandemic is continuing.

Parents and carers at Camau Bach in Aberystwyth were told someone trespassed into its Green Room from the outside play area. It said police had been told and were informing parents and carers on the matter. Camau Bach said it takes the safety of its children very seriously and have taken all necessary steps to ensure their continued safety. It said they have increased security around the outside play area and are reviewing their security procedures. They have also reminded all staff, parents and carers of the need to remain vigilant at all times.

A health tribunal has found Peter Sutcliffe no longer needs any treatment for any mental disorder. In 1981 he was convicted of 13 murders and seven attempted murders and given 20 life sentences. The Mental Health Tribunal for England and Wales concluded that Peter Sutcliffe no longer requires treatment for a mental disorder, ruling that he is not a danger to the public. The tribunal noted that the opinion of multiple psychiatrists was that Sutcliffe should remain insecure detention in hospital for the rest of his life. Sutcliffe was initially detained in Broadmoor Hospital, but was moved to HMP Frankland in 2016 after being deemed fit enough to move back into the prison system. In order for the tribunal to make their decision, they considered evidence from psychiatrists, psychologists, and other medical professionals.
