The tribunal also heard from victims' families and the police who investigated his crimes, as well as personal statements from Sutcliffe himself. The findings of the tribunal do not mean that Sutcliffe will be released; however, it could potentially reduce his sentence or lead to more favourable conditions in prison.

In a letter to all party leaders, the Equality and Human Rights Commission expresses concern about hate attacks that have taken place since the UK voted to leave the EU . The Commission calls on party leaders to act swiftly and decisively to ensure that such attacks are dealt with robustly and effectively. The Commission also reminds party leaders of their responsibility to speak out against any language or behaviour which could be interpreted as hate speech or inciting violence. The letter states that political leaders have a duty to set an example by condemning any incidents of hate and making it clear that this type of behaviour is not acceptable in our society. The Commission calls on party leaders to take action to ensure that the police and other relevant bodies are equipped and supported to deal with hate crime, and that appropriate measures are taken to prevent further incidents from occurring. It also urges them to work together to build a culture of respect for diversity and to promote a positive message about the value of immigration to the UK. The Commission concludes by stressing the need for party leaders to collaborate and make clear to everyone that hatred and discrimination will not be tolerated.

The 60-year-old man was scuba diving at Agincourt Reef in Far North Queensland when he was seen to be in trouble, tour operator Quicksilver said. The tourist, a certified diver, was rescued by a tour boat crew and taken to the mainland where he received medical attention. He was pronounced dead at a local hospital.

His lecture, to be broadcast later this year, is part of a raft of new BBC Radio 4 programmes unveiled on Monday. They include Glenda Jackson's return to acting, in a series of monologues about the life of Mary, Queen of Scots. The BBC said the programmes, which mark the channel's 75th anniversary, will "celebrate the past and look to the future." Other highlights include an adaptation of Virginia Woolf's classic novel Orlando, starring Doctor Who actor Jodie Whittaker, and a new sitcom from Ricky Gervais. In his lecture, Hawking will reflect on his work over the last 50 years and consider how science has changed since he first began working in the field. He will also discuss his views on the future of science, and the potential implications of new technologies such as artificial intelligence. Hawking is one of the world's most celebrated scientists, having made significant contributions to our understanding of the universe. His book A Brief History of Time sold more than 10 million copies and was translated into more than 40 languages.

Prison inspectors discovered the average period of stay at the facility near Gatwick Airport had risen from 28 to 48 days. Twenty-three people were held for more than a year. The prison inspection report also revealed that overcrowding had worsened, with prisoners often having to share cells designed for just one person. Inspectors found that the number of people held in overcrowded conditions had increased from 11 per cent to 16 per cent since the previous inspection. The inspectors also raised concerns about the mental health of many of those held and said some prisoners were subject to "unacceptable delays" when requesting medical attention from staff. They highlighted a lack of appropriate case management and recommended that more work should be done to ensure prisoners were released on time. The prison director has apologised to those affected and said steps have been taken to ease overcrowding, including hiring more staff and improving case management procedures. He said that measures had been put in place to reduce the average length of stay and the number of people held for more than a year.

A defence official said in a statement on Wednesday that its nuclear programme had "long been in the full-fledged stage of miniaturisation." However, analysts say while there is evidence the North has made progress in miniaturising warheads, there is still no concrete evidence that it has achieved a full-fledged capability. North Korea has conducted several nuclear tests over the past decade and is believed to possess enough fissile material for up to 20 bombs. It has also been working on long-range missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads, although it has yet to test one that could reach the US mainland.

Oldham went in front in the fifth minute when Marc Klok delivered a free-kick from the right to the far post, where unchallenged defender Peter Clarke scored with a downward header. The visitors almost equalised when Dale Jennings broke down the left and his low cross was met by Jason Scotland, but his effort from six yards was blocked well by Paul Black. Oldham continued to threaten in attack and they were two up after 26 minutes. Klok crossed from the right again, this time finding Filipe Morais, who got in front of his marker to head home. Barnsley had a good spell of pressure before half-time and Scotland's powerful strike was parried away at full stretch by Alex Cisak. But Oldham scored their third of the game on 42 minutes. The ball was worked out to Jose Baxter on the right, he cut inside and fired past Steele into the corner of the net. Barnsley pulled a goal back just after the break when substitute David Perkins headed in from close range from Craig Davies' cross. But Oldham sealed victory with 15 minutes to go when a defensive mix-up allowed Baxter to race clear and fire home his second of the game.

Police were called to the unusual double parking incident at 11:40 on Tuesday. It is not clear how exactly the silver-coloured Mazda ended up on top of the white Volkswagen , but one eyewitness reported that it was driven up onto the other car and then left there. The police have questioned several witnesses, including the silver Mazda's driver, and are trying to establish exactly what happened. They have asked anyone with information or CCTV footage of the incident to come forward. The owners of the two vehicles have been identified and police are working to ensure that they are both able to get their vehicles removed from the scene safely and without causing further damage. The investigation is ongoing and no charges have yet been made in relation to the incident.

The Coventry Festival of Motoring, which attracted 40,000 visitors in 2014, has had??20,000 of funding withdrawn by the city council. However, organisers Culture Coventry said the funding withdrawal was "not unexpected" and that the event would go ahead in May 2015. Organisers plan to use various other sources of funding to replace the money lost from the council, such as sponsorship and donations from local businesses. There will be a range of attractions at the festival, including classic and vintage cars, car club displays, live music, and food stalls.

Gregg McNally put Leigh in front early on before Atelea Vea crossed over soon after to extend their advantage. The hosts went in at the break with an 18-0 lead after Jonny Pownall kicked a late penalty. The second half started with Leigh piling on the pressure and it wasn't long before McNally was in again with his second of the afternoon. Leigh's dominance continued and eventually Ryan Brierley crossed over to give them an unassailable 28-0 lead. Oldham fought back late on with Chris Dean going over to secure their first points of the afternoon, but it proved to be too little, too late as Leigh took a 28-6 win.

The 46-year-old succeeds Ronnie Moore, who parted company with the club by mutual consent earlier on Wednesday. This is a first managerial role for Hignett, who had a spell as Hartlepool's assistant manager between 2012-14. Pools chairman Gary Coxall told the club website: "Craig has a wealth of experience both as a player and in football management and I'm sure he will bring his own brand of enthusiasm to Pools. "He's very highly thought of within the game and we're delighted to have him on board." Hignett also had a spell as coach of Middlesbrough's Under-21s before joining Scottish Premiership side Ross County as assistant manager in December 2014. He left in April 2015 and returned to Teesside, where he had been working with Boro's academy players since October 2015. Moore, who was appointed Pools boss in October 2015, leaves the club bottom of Sky Bet League Two. Source: PA

Moat Brae in Dumfries has been a private house, a nursing home and harboured hopes of being turned into a themed hotel. It has gone to the brink of demolition and, through the hard work of a dedicated team of volunteers, it has been saved. Moat Brae in Dumfries is now a Peter Pan themed centre for childhood imagination and play. The house, which was the childhood home of J.M. Barrie, author of Peter Pan, has been lovingly restored to its original state and opened as a visitor attraction and education hub in December 2018. The centre offers a range of events and activities for both adults and children, from exhibitions and talks to theatre shows and family workshops. It also features an outdoor playground and a Peter Pan statue at its entrance. The centre aims to inspire and encourage a love of imaginative play among young people, allowing them to explore their own creativity.

New figures show the total number of teachers across Scotland has risen, but 12 council areas saw numbers fall. Mr Swinney said the stats were "good news" in light of the challenges presented by Covid-19. The new figures show that teacher numbers increased by 0.2 in Scotland between August 2020 and February 2021, with the total number of teachers rising to 52,541. This is the first time since August 2015 that the number of teachers has increased. Despite this overall rise, there were 12 council areas that experienced a decrease in teacher numbers. These were Aberdeenshire, Dumfries Galloway, East Ayrshire, East Lothian, Fife, Glasgow City, North Lanarkshire, Renfrewshire, South Ayrshire, South Lanarkshire, Stirling and West Lothian. Mr Swinney said the figures were "good news" considering the difficulties posed by the coronavirus pandemic and the additional workload for teachers. He also said the government would continue to support teachers with additional resources and guidance.

While 7 of people underpay and could be fined, 13 are paying too much. The Office of Rail and Road (ORR) wants train companies to refund passengers who accidentally buy the wrong ticket. They are asking train companies to make it easier for people who have overpaid to get a refund. The ORR is also encouraging train companies to review their penalty fares and ticketing practices to ensure they are fair and proportionate.

Ashley Sibery, 39, persuaded Sital Sibery to take the class A drug minutes after she confronted him about his drug habit in their home. It happened on 2 April 2012 . Ashley Sibery was arrested and charged with supplying a class A drug. He appeared at Bristol Crown Court, where he admitted the offence. He was sentenced to 12 months in prison, suspended for two years, and ordered to carry out 200 hours of unpaid work. Sital Sibery was also arrested and charged with possession of a class A drug. She pleaded guilty and received a two-year community order involving drug rehabilitation, education and training.

The cinema chain has "provided the British public with unforgettable, cinema experiences," Bafta said. The awards will be held at London's Royal Albert Hall on 12 February. The Outstanding British Contribution to Cinema Award is given annually to individuals or organisations that have made a significant contribution to the British film industry. The award will be presented by BAFTA chairman John Willis, who said: "It is a pleasure to be able to recognise the hard work and dedication of the team at Odeon Cinemas for their continued commitment to bringing world class cinema to the British public. From the day it opened its first venue in 1930, Odeon has been an integral part of the UK's cinematic heritage and we are delighted to honour them with this award." Previous winners of the award include the producers of Harry Potter films David Heyman and Steve Kloves, and actor-director Kenneth Branagh.

Footage emerged online of people appearing to sing the anti-Irish "Famine Song" at the weekend, while a band played along. The council said the right of the Orange Order to march was "not in question" but insisted the song was "unacceptable." The Orange Order said it "roundly condemns the singing of sectarian songs and any form of bigotry or hatred" and is "appalled" by the incident. It added that a complaint had been made to police. The Famine Song has been widely condemned in Ireland, with Taoiseach Leo Varadkar saying he was "shocked and appalled" by footage of people singing it at an Orange Order march in Belfast.

It is a question that has long seemed impossible to answer, since players from different decades can never face each other at their peaks. Add in an element of nostalgia , and the debate can go on forever. That being said, there are some qualities that can help guide the discussion. Generally speaking, the greatest players of all time have had a combination of individual talent, team success, overall skill, and longevity. Players who have been dominant in their era, won championships, set records, and had an impact on the game for an extended period of time are usually considered to be among the best of all-time. Players like Michael Jordan, Bill Russell, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Magic Johnson, Larry Bird, LeBron James, Kobe Bryant, and Wilt Chamberlain are all widely considered to be some of the greatest players ever. It is difficult to definitively say which one is the greatest of all time, but most people would agree that these players are at least in the conversation.

Forest Green, promoted from the National League, will host MK Dons in their first appearance in the competition, while FA Cup giant-killers Lincoln will be away to Rotherham. The 35 other ties are: Bristol Rovers v Accrington Stanley Charlton Athletic v Doncaster Rovers Coventry City v Ipswich Town Crewe Alexandra v Bolton Wanderers Fleetwood Town v Wycombe Wanderers Gillingham v Milton Keynes Dons Hull City v Tranmere Rovers Leyton Orient v AFC Wimbledon Oxford United v Peterborough United Plymouth Argyle v Shrewsbury Town Portsmouth v Southend United Rochdale v Blackpool Sunderland v Burton Albion Swindon Town v Bradford City Barnsley v Notts County Blackburn Rovers v Oldham Athletic Bradford City v Grimsby Town Cambridge United v Mansfield Town Carlisle United v Exeter City Cheltenham Town v Colchester United Harrogate Town v Scunthorpe United Macclesfield Town v Walsall Morecambe v Stevenage Newport County v Forest Green Rovers Northampton Town v Port Vale Oldham Athletic v Wigan Athletic Rotherham United v Lincoln City Stevenage v Salford City Tranmere Rovers v Crawley Town Walsall v Barrow Wycombe Wanderers v Portsmouth Yeovil Town v Hartlepool United

The men, identifying themselves Andreas Richter and Piotr Koper, appeared on the country's TVP public television. In a statement they said they had "irrefutable evidence" the train existed, but failed to provide specifics. The two men said they had obtained documents from the National Railway Museum in Warsaw, and they were seeking help from the Polish government to find the train. They also said they had found a "secret tunnel" on their search for the train, although they did not provide any details about its location or contents. However, they said the tunnel contained "secrets that could change the course of history." The pair have since been widely criticised by members of the Polish media who have questioned their credibility and motives.

For many people with severe disabilities, their families and carers, this is a reality they are faced with every time they leave the house. In some cases it can leave them feeling isolated and unable to participate in everyday activities. The Disability Access Champions (DAC) program was developed by the Australian Human Rights Commission, in collaboration with local governments, to help create a more inclusive and accessible environment for people with disabilities. The program recognises and rewards local businesses and organisations that demonstrate commitment to improving access for people with disabilities. DACs are recognised as leaders in their community, providing access to services and facilities that may not be available elsewhere. The program provides resources and guidance to assist in making changes such as installing ramps, widening doorways, providing accessible toilets, appropriate signage, and staff training. By becoming a DAC, businesses and organisations can make an important contribution to creating an inclusive and accessible environment for everyone.

Guitarist and co-songwriter Johnny Marr has released an extract from his upcoming memoir Set The Boy Free in the Guardian and said he met with former band mate Morrissey in 2008 to discuss a possible Smiths reunion. Marr said that the meeting with Morrissey was "amicable" and that he was open to the idea of a reunion, but that he had reservations about it. He said that the reunion wouldn't have been "authentic," as there were certain conditions attached to it which he wasn't comfortable with. Marr also wrote that he was sad that the Smiths had never been properly recognised for their influence on modern music, and that he felt he had more to contribute to the music world. The memoir, which is due to be released in November 2016, promises to offer an insight into Marr's life, his career, and his relationship with Morrissey.

Gwen Thomson, 51, from Torry, died after the accident on Market Street on Wednesday morning. Insp Jon Barron said: "Our thoughts are very much with Gwen's family, friends and work colleagues at this difficult time. We will be conducting a full investigation into the circumstances of her death and would urge anyone with information to come forward as soon as they can." Our deepest sympathies go out to Gwen's family, friends and work colleagues during this extremely difficult time. It is heartbreaking to lose a loved one in such an unexpected and tragic way. Our thoughts are with them all. We are grateful for the efforts of the police officers leading the investigation, and we strongly encourage anyone with information to come forward so that justice may be served.

The Spaniard, whose opening round in Munich contained six birdies, trails leader Wade Ormsby of Australia by two shots and Belgian Thomas Detry by one. England's Tommy Fleetwood, who finished tied for second at the BMW International Open last month, is another shot off the pace on seven under. The best of the home players is Sebastian Heisele who is tied for fourth after a 68. "It's great to be back in Munich," said Garcia. "I always enjoy coming here and have some great memories, including winning here in 2008, when I had a great final round and came from four shots behind to win. "Today I hit the ball really well, especially with my irons, and gave myself plenty of chances. I was good around the greens, too, and made a couple of nice putts so I'm happy with the way I played. "I'm pleased with the position I'm in but there is still a long way to go and I'll need to keep doing what I did today if I want to have a chance of winning. I'm looking forward to the weekend and hopefully I can keep it going." Ormsby started his round with back-to-back birdies, then added further gains at the sixth, ninth and tenth to turn in 33. The 38 year old, who is seeking his first European Tour title, also birdied the 12th and 18th to take the lead. "I got off to a great start and played quite nicely all day," said Ormsby. "I've been playing well for the past few weeks so I'm not overly surprised to be up there. I've been driving the ball particularly well, which helps, and I'm feeling confident with my iron play.

Burnley Empire Theatre defaulted to the care of the Duchy of Lancaster as an "owner of last resort" after the ownership could not be established. Last used as a bingo hall in the 1990s, it was demolished in 2014. The demolition of the former Burnley Empire Theatre was approved by the Duchy of Lancaster in October 2014 after a lengthy planning process and consultation with local authorities and residents. The theatre had been unused since the mid-1990s, when it had been used as a bingo hall, and ownership could not be established. As such, the responsibility for the property defaulted to the Duchy of Lancaster, which acted as an "owner of last resort." The site is now being redeveloped into a retail and leisure complex.

Sexton suffered a suspected groin injury, before O'Connell was carried off at the end of the first half. Leading 9-6 at half-time, Rob Kearney's try increased Ireland's lead before O'Mahony sealed the victory with a try late on. Ireland: Kearney; Trimble, Henshaw, D'Arcy, Zebo; Sexton (Jackson 63), Murray; McGrath (Healy 45), Best (Cronin 68), Ross (White 45); Toner, O'Connell; O'Mahony, Henry (O'Donnell 58), Heaslip. Replacements: Cronin, Healy, White, O'Donnell, McLaughlin, Jackson, Madigan, McFadden.

Speaking to the BBC, Thomas Thabane said he would return from South Africa, which surrounds Lesotho, "as soon as I know I am not going to get killed." Reports say he had been in the country since June. Thabane has been accused of involvement in the murder of his estranged wife, Lipolelo Thabane, who was shot dead in 2017. He denies any involvement and says the allegations are politically motivated. The prime minister has been facing mounting pressure to resign, with the main opposition parties in Lesotho calling for snap elections if he does not step down. The army has also called on him to resign. On Monday, Thabane said he would return to Lesotho once the security situation there had been improved. "I cannot come back to a situation where my life is in danger," he told the BBC.

It was the famous Fairfield yard which took the Upper Clyde to great heights and worldwide prominence. The yard was founded in 1864 by William Elder, a talented marine engineer and shipbuilder, and was located on the banks of the River Clyde in Scotland. The yard quickly became a world leader in shipbuilding and marine engineering, producing some of the finest vessels ever built in Britain. In 1970, the company was nationalised and became part of British Shipbuilders. The yard was closed in 1971 due to changing economics, but its legacy lives on in the many ships it built which still ply the world's oceans.

Jack Keene, 17, from Hertfordshire, was involved in a collision between a Renault Clio and a minibus on the A4086 near Capel Curig in which five other people were injured. The North Wales Police are investigating the incident and have asked anyone with information to come forward. Keene was taken to hospital with minor injuries following the collision, which happened around 6pm on Thursday 4th June. The other five people in the minibus were treated at Ysbyty Gwynedd for a range of injuries. A spokesperson for North Wales Police said: "We are appealing for witnesses who may have seen the collision, or either of the vehicles prior to the incident. We would urge anyone with information to contact us as soon as possible." Anyone with information is urged to call North Wales Police on 101, quoting reference number X129968.

Media playback is not supported on this device Asked if Saturday's opponents have scrummaged illegally during the tournament, England head coach Eddie Jones said: "100. Terribly illegally." Jones says his team have been "absolutely outstanding" in their scrummaging and that the opposition had made illegal use of their feet and shoulders. He says it is something that needs to be addressed at the highest level.

On Wednesday, the electric carmaker reported a first quarter loss of 282m (PS195m) up from 154m last year. The loss was in line with investors' expectations, and the announcement that it had achieved significant cost savings, which included a 20 percent cut in operating expenses, was welcomed. However, Tesla's shares fell 3 percent in after-hours trading following the announcement. Investors were concerned about the company's outlook for the upcoming quarter, particularly in light of the ongoing trade war between the US and China. Tesla said that while its deliveries in China had been strong in Q1, it expected them to be lower in Q2 due to the current economic environment. The company also warned that tariffs on Chinese imports could result in higher costs to customers, which could impact future demand. Despite these concerns, investors remain confident in Tesla's long-term prospects. CEO Elon Musk has committed to continuing to invest in the company's infrastructure and technology, and the company is expected to launch several new models in the coming years. The company has also made progress towards achieving profitability, which could help to boost investor sentiment. In addition, Tesla recently announced plans to open a Gigafactory in Shanghai, which will increase its production capacity in China.

Speaking to BBC Radio 4's Today programme, he said he would build on the support he received at rallies to reconnect the party to voters. He rejected criticism from those who said he was too left-wing to lead the party and insisted that he would bring unity. Mr Corbyn said: "I think we have to reconnect with the people of this country who have been so badly let down by successive governments, both Conservative and Labour. "I want to open the door and say 'Come in, join us'. We have a huge number of members, huge amount of support out there. We need to draw that together. "We need to look at how we can ensure that everybody has a decent home, a proper job and a secure future, and that's what I'm going to be about."

Campaigners have asked the university to reconsider the move, highlighting its "strong record" in educating people from disadvantaged groups. But the university says it needs to reduce costs in line with income. The university has said that it is looking to make "difficult decisions" in order to save money, and that the closure of the department is necessary to ensure its financial sustainability. It also said that it would be offering support to staff affected by the closure. The decision has been criticised by many students and staff, who have argued that it is a short-sighted move that will ultimately lead to a loss of expertise and knowledge in an area of great importance. However, the university has said that it is confident that the move will not affect its commitment to social justice and equality.

The 49-strong team for the event, which will be at London Stadium in Stratford from 14-23 July, contains 10 athletes who won gold at Rio 2016. Two-time Paralympic champion Peacock, who is aiming to reclaim his T44 100m title, is joined by fellow gold medallists Kadeena Cox, Hannah Cockroft, Jonnie Peacock, Hollie Arnold and Sophie Hahn. The two-time Paralympic champion said: "I have been looking forward to the World Championships ever since the Rio Games ended last summer. It feels like an age away but I can't wait to get out there and compete with my team-mates in front of a home crowd once again. "The support we received at the London Stadium during the Olympic and Paralympic Games in 2012 was incredible and I am sure it will be even better this time around." Fellow Rio 2016 gold medallist Richard Whitehead MBE added: "I am really excited to be part of the team and I can't wait to feel that electric atmosphere from the crowd once again. "It has been a long journey since the Rio Games but I am feeling in good shape and ready to go for London." Ben Rushgrove, British Athletics Paralympic Head Coach said: "We are delighted to announce an incredibly strong and competitive British Athletics team for the World Para Athletics Championships. "The team features Rio 2016 Champions, world record holders and a host of emerging talent and I know they will do us proud at what will be a fantastic event. "Our athletes have worked incredibly hard over the past year, with many of them juggling training with their day jobs or studying, and they deserve to be rewarded with success on the track and field. "I am confident that our team will deliver some great performances and make Britain proud." The full British Athletics Team for the 2017 World Para Athletics Championships is as follows: Jonnie Peacock Richard Whitehead MBE Kadeena Cox Hannah Cockroft Stef Reid Sophie Hahn Hollie Arnold Paige Murray Stephanie Millward Nathan Maguire Kyron Duke Georgina Hermitage Samantha Kinghorn Maria Lyle Sabrina Fortune Libby Clegg Stevie McIntosh Olivia Breen George Peasgood Thomas Young Dominic Parsons David Henson Aled Davies Gemma Prescott Aled Sion Davies Gabby Downes Jordan Howe Dan Bramall Sophie Kamlish Sammi Kinghorn Susie Rodgers Katrina Hart Paul Blake Sam Ruddock Bethany Woodward Josie Pearson Jonathan Broom-Edwards Amanjit Singh Sabrina Sinha Diane Roy Mickey Bushell Ben Rowlings Rabah Yousif Steve Morris Carly Tait Martha Hill Stephen Morris Greg Rutherford Maddie Hinchliffe Sammi Kinghorn Sophie Kamlish Shaun Burrows Caroline Maclean Andrew Small Adam Knott John Stubbs

The drug had been injected into the soles of the sports shoes to look like shock-absorbing gel. Customs officials became suspicious after finding the man's suitcase contained six pairs of shoes with the same amount of gel in each. Customs officials became suspicious because it was highly unusual for one person to have six pairs of shoes with the same amount of gel in each. This was a red flag that something was amiss, so they decided to investigate further. Upon inspection, they discovered that the gel was actually a drug that had been injected into the soles of the sports shoes. The man was arrested and charged with drug smuggling.

Four police were wounded as they tried to arrest a man in the Bavarian town of Georgensgmuend, south of Nuremberg. The suspect, described as a member of the extremist Reichsbuerger movement, opened fire on officers who went to his home to serve him with an arrest warrant. The suspect was taken into custody after a two-hour standoff and the four police officers were hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries. It is unclear what charges the suspect will face in connection to the incident. The Reichsbuerger movement is composed of far-right extremists who deny the legitimacy of the modern German state and refuse to recognize its laws. The group has been growing in recent years and has been linked to several incidents of violence against police officers.

The evacuation of the Jet2 plane at East Midlands Airport was hampered when one of the escape chutes did not work. It came after the pilot was unable to check the brakes due to a fault. Passengers were forced to use the remaining chutes, with some having to use ladders to exit the aircraft. The airport was closed for several hours while engineers worked to fix the issue and the plane was eventually towed away. No injuries were reported.

Galvani Bioelectronics hopes to bring a new treatment based on the technique before regulators within seven years. GlaxoSmithKline and Verily, formerly Google, Life Sciences, are behind it. Animal experiments have already shown that stimulating the nerves controlling muscles can have a beneficial effect on conditions such as Parkinson's disease, chronic pain and heart failure. The aim of Galvani is to develop tiny implantable devices, powered by a patient's own body, which can send electrical signals to precisely target nerve fibres. It is hoped that this could replace traditional medications or surgery.

Oliseh, 42, who stood down as Super Eagles coach in February 2016, previously played for Dutch giants Ajax from 1997 to 1999. Since arriving at Fortuna Sittard two months ago, Oliseh has overseen a run of three wins, two draws and one defeat in six matches. This week, Fortuna Sittard announced that the club had extended Oliseh's contract until 2019, citing his "inspirational leadership" as a key factor in their decision. "This is a great day for me," Oliseh said in a statement. "Fortuna Sittard gave me the opportunity to return to the football business and I can proudly say that since I joined, the team has improved significantly. We are currently in a good position and there is still much work to be done to secure our place in the league." Oliseh was appointed as Super Eagles coach in July 2015 after leading the Nigerian U-23 side to a bronze medal at the 2015 African Nations Championship in Rwanda. He stepped down from his post less than eight months later due to "contract violations."

The Keep Military Museum in Dorchester plans to use the money to convert a bunker into an interactive experience. It also wants to create an online gallery of Dorset and Wiltshire servicemen and women who served in the two World Wars. The museum also plans to set up a series of educational activities for school children, including workshops on military history, storytelling and arts and crafts.

The economic research institute questioned 320 businesses following the vote on leaving the EU. The survey found more than 60 of Scottish firms believe Brexit would have a "negative impact" on their business. Of the businesses surveyed, 77 said that Brexit would have a negative impact on their ability to recruit and retain staff. In addition, 66 of respondents said that Brexit would make it more difficult for them to export to EU countries. The survey also found that 97 of the Scottish firms surveyed believed that access to the EU single market was important for their business.

The 73-year-old Oscar winner will be presented with the award on 9 June. AFI chair Sir Howard Stringer called Freeman "an American treasure" who brought a calm authority to his performances and said he was "a master at his craft." Freeman is known for his roles in films such as Driving Miss Daisy, The Shawshank Redemption, Unforgiven and Million Dollar Baby. He is also an acclaimed stage actor and director, most recently appearing on Broadway in the play A Raisin in the Sun.

The England skipper hit a run-a-ball 92 at Headingley, with James Taylor and Ben Stokes both scoring 41. David Willey had earlier reduced Australia to 30-3 with the new ball as England won the match by eight wickets.

Charlene Walker, 36, suffered a single stab wound at the Darlington home of Julie Gowling in December. The 44-year-old tried to cover up the killing and dispose of the weapon, but was eventually arrested and charged with murder. She pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was jailed for seven years in October 2017. Walker had been visiting Gowling, who was her sister-in-law. Evidence suggested that an argument between the pair, who were both under the influence of alcohol, led to Walker being fatally stabbed. Gowling initially denied murder, claiming Walker had taken her own life, however forensic evidence disproved this and she changed her plea to guilty of manslaughter. The judge, Mrs Justice Cheema-Grubb, said at sentencing: "You took away a much-loved sister, mother and daughter."

It was the 29-year-old Spaniard's first Grand Tour stage win and Movistar's first at this year's Giro - still led by Jungels, with Geraint Thomas second. Thomas' Team Sky team-mate Mikel Landa is third overall. Nibali, who had been among the favourites for the stage, was part of a breakaway that went clear shortly after the start in Rovetta, but he was unable to keep up with Lopez and eventually finished eight seconds behind him. Lopez, who has won the Tour of Poland twice, held off a late attack from fellow Spaniard Omar Fraile (Astana) to take the victory. Fraile was second, 28 seconds back, followed by Fabio Aru (Astana) in third at 33 seconds. The stage was the first of four mountain stages this week as the race heads towards its conclusion in Milan on May 28.

Lincolnshire Partnership NHS Foundation Trust was criticised by the Care Quality Commission (CQC) in March 2015. A re-inspection in April this year found it had made "positive progress" in some areas but still needed to make improvements in others. The CQC identified a number of issues, including the lack of sufficient staffing and resources, as well as a lack of training and guidance for staff on safeguarding and risk management. The Trust was also criticised for not having an effective system in place to monitor, assess and improve the quality of its services. In response to the criticisms, the Trust has taken action to address the problems raised. It has implemented a range of new systems and procedures, including additional safeguarding training, improved risk assessment processes and increased staffing levels. It has also established a Quality Improvement Board to provide oversight of the Trust's performance. The Trust is continuing to work with the CQC to ensure that it meets all of their requirements and that standards are continuously improved.

PC Gavin Smith, who appeared on Channel 5's Police Interceptors, died from cancer aged 34 on 15 February. Mr Smith, who lived in Bishop Auckland with his wife Kezi and three young children, had been diagnosed with a terminal brain tumour in August last year. Gavin was a popular and well-liked figure amongst colleagues, friends and family and the police force. He had served in the Durham Constabulary for over 11 years, joining as a PCSO before becoming a full-time officer in 2007. During his time with the force Gavin had worked in frontline patrol, neighbourhood policing teams, roads policing, motorway patrol and was part of the TV series Police Interceptors. The Chief Constable of Durham Constabulary, Jo Farrell, paid tribute to Gavin saying: "He was an outstanding police officer and a much-loved colleague who will be remembered for his commitment, dedication and enthusiasm." Gavin's family have asked for donations in his memory to be made to The Brain Tumour Charity.

Rafael Esquivel admitted receiving bribes in connection with the sale of marketing rights to tournaments. He was among seven officials arrested at a luxury hotel in Switzerland last year. More than 20 people were later charged in the scandal. Esquivel pleaded guilty to three counts of wire fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud, and was sentenced to eight years in prison in December 2017. He was also ordered to forfeit 1.1 million and pay restitution of 2.9 million.

There had been cases of "verbal abuse hurled" at ethnic minorities, and "despicable graffiti daubed on a Polish community centre," he told the Commons. Such attacks must be stamped out, he said. The Prime Minister said that the government had taken action to strengthen the law and would not tolerate such behavior. He said, "We have put in place a package of measures, both legislative and non-legislative, to protect those from ethnic minority backgrounds. We will not allow such abhorrent behavior to go unchallenged or unpunished." He added, "Let me be absolutely clear: there is no room for racism, hatred or prejudice of any kind in our society."

Islamic tradition requires the dead to be buried as soon as possible, unless an autopsy is required. The US military took this requirement very seriously, burying the body within hours. The body was traditionally washed and wrapped in a simple white cloth, with the head pointed towards Mecca. Prayers were said over the dead, usually by the Imam of the local mosque. Finally, the body was buried in the ground, usually with a stone or other marker placed at the head and feet.

It is being performed at Curve theatre in Leicester, the city where Townsend lived and where the book is set. The writer worked on the musical before her death last year and it was completed by her husband, Adrian Mitchell. The show is a celebration of Townsend's work and will explore the themes of love, loss and friendship. The production has been described as "an uplifting experience full of music, dance and comedy." The show stars a talented cast of actors, singers and dancers, including Jessica Bowles (Fanny), Jonathan Hansler (Frank), Gemma Sutton (Alice), David Hunter (Tommy) and Sophie-Louise Dann (Mrs Wigmore). It is directed by Nikolai Foster, with musical direction from Alistair David and choreography from Lucie Pankhurst. The show opened on 14 February 2020 and runs until 21 March 2020. Audience members can expect a powerful and moving performance, which promises to be both funny and touching in equal measure.

Systems at Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center had been affected for more than a week. Staff had been forced to carry out some tasks on paper. However, the hospital's chief executive officer, Allen Stefanek, stated that the hospital had regained full electronic medical record capability. He also said that the FBI was investigating the incident, which he called a "ransomware attack." The ransomware attack involved malicious software that encrypted data on the hospital's computer systems and demanded payment in exchange for the data to be decrypted. While it is unclear how much money the hackers demanded, the FBI is working to identify the attackers and recover the lost data. The FBI recommends that organizations affected by ransomware pay the ransom to get their data back, as they may not be able to decrypt the information without the key provided by the attackers. Hospital administrators have also recommended that organizations take preventive measures to avoid being targeted by such attacks in the future, including regularly backing up critical data and installing security patches to vulnerable software.

The former Huddersfield and Birmingham manager will need to hit the ground running at Rugby Park, with the team just one point above the relegation play-off place. And his old club Birmingham, who he left in April, are only four points ahead of Killie. Alex is no stranger to the Scottish game, having previously managed St Mirren and Dunfermline Athletic. He also played for Rangers during his playing days from 1996-97. He has been out of work since leaving Birmingham but he is sure to bring plenty of experience to Kilmarnock. The Rugby Park side have seen a number of changes in the dugout over the past few years, with Steve Clarke and Lee McCulloch both leaving the club in the last year. The new manager will be hoping to turn around the fortunes of the club and help them to move up the league table. With a handful of experienced players in their squad, including Alan Power and Stuart Findlay, there is potential for Alex Dyer to make an impact at Kilmarnock.

The Wikileaks co-founder sought asylum at London's Ecuadorean embassy in 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden. UK officials said the bill for policing the embassy, which stands at PS12m (18.8m; US24m), was "proportionate" and aimed at deterring a similar situation in future.

"The accident meant the motorway was closed, making travel to Mourneview Park impossible for the team and fans travelling from Belfast," said the Irish Football Association. A new date for the match has yet to be arranged. The Irish Football Association have expressed their deepest sympathies to those affected by the accident, and have urged all road users to take every precaution when travelling on the roads.

It has emerged that an original crash barrier was removed, even though the Roads Service could not find out why it had been put there in the first place. It is believed that the barrier was installed in order to protect a local school from traffic. The Roads Service has said that they will install a new crash barrier at the site, which will be tested and certified to meet safety standards. They added that they have already consulted with local residents regarding the installation of the crash barrier, and will continue to do so throughout the process.

The Good Fight star said: "The reason I'm doing so well is our training, our work ethic.... we learn our lines. "Why are we not trying to keep that here.... why is the bar so low for our industry? "It's not just about getting the job done, it's about being better and trying to elevate." She continued: "I think that's what we need to work on in this industry. We need to set the bar higher and challenge ourselves and each other to become better artists."

The stricken robot, made by Knightscope, was spotted by passers-by whose photos of the aftermath quickly went viral on social media. For some, the incident seemed to sum up the dangers of robots, while others were quick to point out the limitations of technology. Knightscope later released a statement saying that the robot was not at fault and had been knocked over by a human error. The company also said it would be reviewing its protocols to prevent similar incidents in the future.

13 January 2016 Last updated at 22:15 GMT Edward Hardy, who has dementia and lives in a care home in Wookey, Somerset, played for decades but had not touched the instrument for 10 years. But then a chance encounter with a care home volunteer changed everything. The volunteer, who happened to be a musician and sax teacher, lent Edward an alto saxophone and encouraged him to start playing again. Edward soon found that he still remembered how to play and the two started jamming together. Now Edward plays for two hours every week with the volunteer, who has since become a close friend. "He brings me such joy," said Edward. "Playing the saxophone gives me a sense of purpose, it's something I can do that's just mine." His care home manager said: "It's amazing to see Edward like this - so happy and full of life. He loves talking about music and playing his sax in front of others." Edward's weekly jam sessions have become a highlight of the week for residents, staff and visitors alike.

The 30-year-old Scot was sent off after 20 minutes of the Exiles' 45-14 loss to Bath on Saturday. Meanwhile, Wasps prop Lorenzo Cittadini has been given a one-week ban after being shown a red card in his side's 32-26 defeat to Harlequins on Sunday. Both players were sent off for dangerous tackles and have been given the same suspension, which runs until midnight on Saturday, 3 November. The Scottish Rugby Union (SRU) has said it will support both players through their disciplinary process and that they are expected to return to action within the next seven days. A statement from the SRU read: "We fully support the decisions made by the Rugby Football Union (RFU) in relation to these two players and we are confident that their suspensions are appropriate and fair. "We will continue to monitor their progress as they move forwards and will be providing them with all the necessary support throughout this period."

The artists wrote graffiti reading "Homeland is racist" and "Homeland is rubbish," among others. They say they were asked to write the graffiti in June to "lend authenticity" to a scene being shot for the show Homeland.

Police were called to Station Road, Wood Green, at about 03:20 BST after receiving reports of a stabbing outside the Jolly Anglers public house. Paramedics treated the man, named by police as Shomari Anderson, but he was pronounced dead at the scene. A post-mortem examination concluded Mr Anderson died from a stab wound to the chest. No arrests have been made and detectives are appealing for witnesses to come forward.

Andrew Apperley, 38, from Eastbourne, was reported missing after failing to return to his hotel four days after going to a Full Moon party. Richard Apperley said the situation was 'extremely worrying' as his brother had never gone missing before. A police spokesman said that they were "conducting a number of enquiries to try and locate Andrew." They also added that the search was being widened further afield and urged anyone with any information about his whereabouts to come forward. The police are advising travellers to remain vigilant when travelling abroad and to always let friends and family know their whereabouts. Andrew's family have set up an online appeal for help in finding him and it has been shared widely on social media. They are asking anyone who may have seen him or knows of his whereabouts to get in touch.

Edinburgh Airport said more than 781,000 passengers passed through its doors last month, a year-on-year increase of 11.7. Glasgow saw its traffic rise by 8.4 to nearly 600,000. Meanwhile, Aberdeen airport saw an increase of 11.6, with more than 397,000 passengers in October.

Fifty sheep were stolen from a farm in Ammanford and the farmer spotted a flock two weeks later at a livestock market in Llanybydder. After the ewes gave birth, paternity tests confirmed that the sheep at the market were indeed the same ones that were stolen. In this case, the farmer should contact the police and file a report. The farmer should also provide any evidence they have to support their claim, such as photos of the stolen sheep or records of their identifying marks. The police will then investigate the reported theft and take action accordingly. If possible, the farmer should also contact the livestock market and inform them of the situation.

A 38-year-old man, who was a back seat car passenger, is in a critical but stable condition in hospital following the B9080 crash at about 22:15 on Wednesday. The injured man, who is from the Lanarkshire area, was taken by ambulance to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow for treatment. The driver of the car, a 25-year-old woman from Kilmarnock, was pronounced dead at the scene. A second passenger in the car, a 42-year-old man from Kilwinning, was also injured and is being treated at Crosshouse Hospital in Kilmarnock. Police Scotland are continuing their investigation into the collision and have appealed for anyone with information or dash cam footage to contact them.

Shots were fired from a car near St Brendan's Primary School and the victim was hit a number of times. The shooting happened shortly after 15:00 GMT. Ch Insp Jon athon Morris, of the Metropolitan Police, said: "We believe this to be a targeted attack and there is no risk to the wider public." The police are appealing for witnesses to come forward with any information they may have. Detectives from Trident and Area Crime Command will be carrying out an investigation into the shooting. Anyone with information can call Trident on 8244 or, if they wish to remain anonymous, Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

Tunisia had faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until apologising to Caf for complaints it lodged against the organisation during this year's Nations Cup. Morocco, meanwhile, were expelled from the 2017 edition of the tournament for not hosting the tournament due to health concerns. In response to Tunisia's apology, Caf President Issa Hayatou issued a statement that "the Confederation of African Football (Caf) has decided to accept the apologies from Tunisia and its football association." The statement further noted that Tunisia would be allowed to participate in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations as planned. Morocco, however, were not so lucky. Despite their attempts to explain their decision to pull out of the tournament, Caf determined that their actions constituted a breach of contract and announced that they had been expelled from the tournament.

The draft legislation was approved by 494 votes to 122, and now moves to the House of Lords. Shadow business secretary Clive Lewis was one of 52 Labour MPs to vote against the bill, saying it "would make our economy more fragile and less fair." The bill seeks to transfer EU laws and regulations into UK law after Brexit. It also sets out a framework for the government to be able to implement changes to those laws and regulations without a full parliamentary debate. Labour has said this could lead to a "power grab" by ministers. The government argues that the bill is necessary to ensure a smooth transition when the UK leaves the EU in March 2019. Ministers have also promised to give MPs a vote on any changes that are made to the transferred laws.

Mr Poots made the comments on the BBC's Nolan Live on Wednesday night. Speaking to Sinn Fein's Alex Maskey, Mr Poots said: "We'll do business with you because it's in the interest of everybody that we do business." He went on to say that he had no intention of taking a hard line on any issues, but instead wanted to work together to find common ground. He said: "We don't have to be in agreement with everybody but we can still work together and cooperate." Mr Poots also said that he was willing to listen to all views and opinions and that dialogue was essential for progress. He said: "We need to talk, we need to come together and talk, and if we don't talk then nothing is going to happen."

Media playback is not supported on this device Guy, 20, took third behind winner Dutchman Sebastiaan Verschuren in the 200m freestyle after missing out on the men's 400m final. Tutton, from Wiltshire, finished in a time of 1:49.10 to take the bronze medal behind Verschuren, who won gold in 1:47.45, and silver medallist Kirill Prigoda of Russia (1:48.19). Guy Tutton has had an amazing performance at the European Championships in London, earning himself a bronze medal in the 200m freestyle event. Aged 20, Tutton was up against some of the best swimmers in Europe, including Dutchman Sebastiaan Verschuren and Russian Kirill Prigoda. Tutton produced an impressive swim, finishing in 1:49.10, just behind the two leaders. This result is even more impressive considering he missed out on the men's 400m final. Tutton has been swimming since a young age and has competed in numerous events over the years. He has represented Great Britain several times, winning medals and competing in international championships. His bronze medal at the Europeans is another great achievement for the budding swimmer and highlights his potential for future success.

Mr Kalashnikov had been involved in the "anti-Maidan" protests in support of deposed President Viktor Yanukovych. It is not clear if he was murdered or committed suicide. Police say an investigation is underway. Kalashnikov was a prominent figure in the pro-Russian camp during the crisis. He was an active participant in the anti-Maidan rallies, and had been an outspoken critic of the new government in Kiev. He had also previously served as a member of the Communist Party of Ukraine.

It was discovered by a passing police patrol near Holy Cross Boys' Primary School in Ardoyne in the early hours of Sunday morning. Ch Supt Chris Noble said the device was a viable pipe bomb and would have caused serious injury or death had it detonated. The device, which was made up of components commonly used in improvised explosive devices, was removed by Army experts for further examination. The police said the device was "clearly intended to cause death or serious injury" and appealed for any witnesses to come forward. The school has been closed while investigations are ongoing. No group has yet claimed responsibility for the device.

John Fell, from Cumbria, is confident his 1.5kg ostrich egg covered in meat will earn him a Guinness World Record. The existing record was set in 2008 in a London pub, where a 1.45kg ostrich egg was covered in 860g of pork sausage meat. It is possible for John Fell to set a Guinness World Record with his 1.5kg ostrich egg covered in meat, but he will need to meet the requirements set by Guinness World Records. To do so, he will first need to submit an application and provide evidence that his attempt meets the criteria for a record-breaking attempt. He will then be evaluated by Guinness World Records officials who will decide whether or not it is worthy of a record. If approved, he will be asked to attend a verification event, where he will have to prove that his dish meets the required standards.

The Yellows dominated possession but were caught on the break by Lenell John-Lewis who fired in spectacularly from 25 yards just before the interval. Pat Hoban rewarded Oxford's dominance when he headed in from close range five minutes into the second-half but the game changed again when Danny Hylton was sent off for a second bookable offence with 15 minutes left. From there, Stevenage held on to claim a deserved victory and move up to fourth place in League Two. Oxford United manager Michael Appleton said: "It's very frustrating. We played some good football in the first-half and created some good chances, but we didn't take our chances and then got hit by a wonder goal from Lenell John-Lewis. In the second-half, I thought we were very comfortable until Danny got sent off and then it's difficult to take." Stevenage manager Darren Sarll said: "I'm really pleased with the performance. We defended well and showed great character to come away with the win. It's a great result for us and it moves us up the table."

Prof Allyson Pollock and colleagues at Queen Mary University of London say the contact sport is too dangerous. They do not want an outright ban but say the sport must be regulated in the same way as boxing. The researchers suggest that rugby should be treated in the same way as boxing, with a compulsory medical check-up before each match and regular neurological scans. They also recommend that players must wear protective headgear, and that contact drills and tackling should be limited during practice sessions. The team argues that the current rules of the game are not sufficient to protect players from head injuries, and that further investigation is needed. They point out that there have been a number of high-profile cases of players suffering serious brain injuries as a result of playing rugby. Prof Pollock said: "We must act now to protect players and prevent long-term damage to their health. We believe that a thorough review of the game is essential if we are to ensure the safety of players at all levels."

The reactor at Yongbyon has been the source of plutonium for North Korea's nuclear weapons programme. The White House said North Korea should "focus instead on fulfilling its international obligations." The United States has long called for North Korea to take steps towards denuclearization, as outlined in the 2005 Joint Statement of the Six-Party Talks. This includes dismantling the reactor at Yongbyon and allowing international inspections to verify its compliance with its commitments. North Korea must also take concrete steps to irreversibly dismantle all nuclear weapons and related programs. The U.S. will continue to work with our partners in the region to urge North Korea to cease its provocative behavior, abide by its international obligations, and work towards a peaceful and diplomatic solution to the nuclear issue.

Police said the woman was the only person in a northbound vehicle that collided with a car occupied by two adults and two children at about 10:50. The occupants of the second car were not injured. Police said investigators from their major collision unit are looking into the circumstances of the crash and are asking anyone who witnessed it to contact them at .

Age Scotland says official figures suggest that each year about 8,640 people in Scotland wait longer than six weeks for a council care assessment. The average "worst case" is between seven and eight weeks. Age Scotland says that the wait times for council care assessments in Scotland are far too long and need to be reduced. The charity has campaigned for better access to social care services, with a focus on reducing waiting times for assessments and improving access to care support. The Scottish Government has committed to providing a single assessment process for older people who are looking for help with their care needs. This should make it easier for people to access the care they require, and reduce waiting times. It is also introducing legislation to give local authorities the power to charge for delayed assessments.

It may be their signature pose, but how and why the birds perch on one limb has been a longstanding puzzle. Now, a team from the US has shown that their behaviour probably evolved as a way to watch out for predators. The team studied the perching behaviours of three species of birds - Red-shouldered Hawks, Cooper's Hawks, and American Kestrels - in Arizona and New Mexico. They observed that all three species opted to perch on one limb rather than two, and that they positioned themselves so that they had an optimal view of their surroundings. The researchers then carried out experiments in which they hung stuffed predators and other objects around perches to see how it affected the birds' behaviour. They found that the presence of potential threats caused the birds to perch on one limb more often and from a higher vantage point. The findings suggest that the birds' single-limb perching behaviour is an adaptation to reduce the risk of predation. Perching on one foot may allow the birds to maintain a better lookout for danger, and by positioning themselves higher up, they can also be more aware of any potential threats from above.

The "surprising find" in Avebury, which is 30m (98ft) wide, is thought to be one of the site's earliest structures. The square of megaliths appears to have been erected around 4,500 years ago, which predates the other circles and henge monuments at Avebury. The megaliths are made of sarsen stone, similar to the stones used in Stonehenge, and are arranged in a square formation with one large central stone surrounded by four smaller ones. The discovery of this square of megaliths has been described as "the most significant find in Avebury since Silbury Hill was excavated in the 18th century." It is believed that the site may have had some ritual or religious significance for the people who lived nearby, although its exact purpose is unknown.

So, if you've been inspired by the action in Texas, why not grab your mates and give it a go yourself? Here former New York Giants team-mates Osi Umenyiora and Justin Tuck tell us how! Osi: The first step is to get everyone in the same room. Make sure you have enough space to move around and run plays. You'll also need a football, cones, and some sort of goal line marker. Justin: Once you have everything ready, it's time to get organized. Divide your group into two teams and assign each person their position. Get your team into formation and make sure everyone knows what they're supposed to do. The basic formations are offense (the team with the ball) and defense (the team without). Osi: Now you can start running plays. Have one team go on offense while the other team takes up positions as defenders. Call out a play, then watch it unfold. It's important to remember that football is a game of strategy and that each play should be well planned out. Justin: After each play, evaluate the results and adjust accordingly. Did the play work? Was there any confusion? Did someone miss an assignment? Make adjustments as needed, and keep playing until you feel comfortable with the plays. Osi: Finally, have fun! Football is a great way to bond with friends and stay active. And don't forget to practice good sportsmanship - winning isn't everything!

Media playback is not supported on this device Belgium, ranked second in the world, are the next test for Chris Coleman's side as they look to continue their remarkable progress Wales supervisor Chris Coleman has actually stated his side are" readying to take on the very best"as they prepare for the Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium. The Welsh face the second-ranked team in the world on Friday at the Cardiff City Stadium, with victory offering them a substantial boost in their pursuit of a place at next summer season's finals in France. Coleman is optimistic about Wales' chances, saying: "We understand how difficult it will be, Belgium are an excellent group and we're preparing to take on the best." He included: "I'm positive - I believe if you're not positive you have no possibility, however we understand what a huge difficulty it is." Wales players Gareth Bale and Aaron Ramsey will both miss out on the match due to the fact that of injury, however Coleman has actually expressed self-confidence in his side's ability to cope without them. "It's unfortunate we won't have them due to the fact that they would have been brilliant, but we have enough quality there," he said. "We have players who can step up and we're all positive." Wales have actually made an encouraging start to their Euro 2016 qualifying campaign, winning two and drawing one of their opening three matches. They are currently third in Group B, two points behind leaders Israel and four adrift of the second-placed Belgians.

In recent months, state media have been stressing the waters have been China's "since ancient times." Now, state media are rolling out masses of fresh material aimed at discrediting The Hague's ruling. China has been using a variety of tactics to discredit the Hague's ruling, including releasing reports and articles in state media outlets that emphasize their historical claims to the waters, citing "historic evidence" that predate the Philippines' claims. Additionally, Chinese officials have made numerous statements to world leaders and governments, emphasizing their position and attempting to garner international support for their stance. The government has also conducted military exercises near the disputed area and increased its naval presence in the area, sending a message to other countries in the region not to interfere. Finally, China has used diplomatic channels to pressure other nations, such as the U.S., to remain neutral on the issue.

Georgina Callander, 18, was among 22 people who died in the suicide bombing at Manchester Arena on 22 May. Hundreds attended the ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in Tarleton, Lancashire. The service was held to celebrate the life of Georgina, who had been a student at Runshaw College in Leyland before she tragically passed away. The church was filled with family, friends and members of the community who had come to remember her. The ceremony featured music from the local Tarleton Brass Band, as well as readings from Georgina's friends. Her brother Daniel paid tribute to his sister, saying that he would treasure the memories that he had of her. Songs including Beyonce's 'Halo' and Taylor Swift's 'Shake It Off' were performed in celebration of Georgina's life. At the end of the service, her father Simon said a few words about his daughter, who was described as an "energetic and vibrant girl." He said that despite the tragedy, he felt proud and privileged to have had such an amazing daughter. He asked everyone to continue to smile, just like Georgina did. The ceremony was followed by a private burial for Georgina and her family.

It forced the band to remain anonymous for almost a year: No photographs, no interviews, no videos. But there was an upside. Last year, as she caught a train home after a show, lead singer Sarah told me that this enforced anonymity had been an incredible opportunity: It gave people time to discover the music without being distracted by the band members' physical appearances. She said it also allowed them to create a mythos around the band, which generated even more interest in their music. The band's strategy of remaining anonymous paid off in the long run. They soon began to develop a cult following and fans were eager to learn more about the mysterious group. As the band's popularity grew, they slowly began to reveal more information about themselves, culminating with the release of their debut album. Fans were not only able to connect with the music, but also with the band itself. The band has since become one of the most successful indie acts of the past decade.

The 23-year-old from Guernsey appointed Veronelli in December 2013, but he is no longer able to commit to spending up to 40 weeks a year on the road. Veronelli, 36, said: "I am truly grateful for the opportunity. "It is a great pleasure and honour to have been part of this team and I will always look back fondly on my time here. I wish the team every success in the future." The 23-year-old Guernsey rider had been competing in the World Rally Championship since 2013, but he was unable to progress further than his initial season as he struggled to find a full-time ride. He made a brief return to the championship in 2015, competing in two events, but ultimately decided to focus on other racing commitments. Veronelli had previously competed in the European Rally Championship, and had been looking to use the experience gained from that series to help him make an impact in the WRC.

He suffered a stroke two weeks ago and his condition improved before a sudden deterioration on Tuesday. Mr Peres, who was one of the last of a generation of Israeli politicians present at the country's birth, passed away today. Mr Peres had a long and distinguished career as an Israeli statesman, serving twice as prime minister, three times as foreign minister, and twice as president. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1994 for his contribution to the Oslo Accords, which led to the establishment of the Palestinian Authority. Mr Peres was a strong advocate of peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors and worked tirelessly to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. His legacy will be remembered for generations to come.

There has been damage to property but no injuries. Forecasters have indicated that it will be dry and bright for most of Scotland by Wednesday afternoon. Ferry services have been disrupted due to high winds but are expected to resume normal service later in the day. Residents are advised to stay indoors, secure any loose objects and monitor local weather reports. Motorists are warned to be alert for falling debris on roads and bridges. People should avoid walking or cycling in exposed areas until the storm has passed. Emergency services remain on standby.

Nether Edge Green Party councillor, Alison Teal, was served with a legal notice for her involvement in protests against Sheffield City Council's tree felling programme. Ms Teal was previously arrested and charged with obstruction of a highway while protesting against the felling of trees in Sheffield. Yes, it is true that Alison Teal was served with a legal notice for her involvement in protests against Sheffield City Council's tree felling programme. She was arrested and charged with obstruction of a highway on May 19, 2018 during a protest against the felling of trees in Sheffield. Following this, she was served with a High Court injunction which stated that she was not to interfere with tree-felling operations taking place. Ms Teal has since continued to speak out against the tree-felling and has taken part in further protests.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) said he had been told not to report for training with the rest of the players on Monday. It is seeking clarification about an incident that took place at a nightclub in Cardiff on Sunday night. The WRU has said it is unable to comment further until it has received more information. It is understood Halfpenny was out with friends when he was involved in an altercation with another patron. He is said to have left the club shortly afterwards. The incident is the latest controversy for Welsh rugby, which has already seen one player banned for punching an opponent and another disciplined for making derogatory comments about women. Halfpenny is one of Wales' most important players and has been a key contributor to their recent success. He has scored more than 500 points in his international career, including two tries in the Grand Slam-winning campaign of 2012.

"This is where it all happens," says the star, who has scored more number one singles (seven) than any other British artist this decade, as he welcomes the BBC to his recording studio, a few miles from the centre of London. The space, which he has named "The Lightbulb," is where the singer-songwriter creates his music and produces his records. It's a modern studio filled with state-of-the-art equipment, vintage instruments, and eclectic artwork from around the world. The walls are lined with awards, gold and platinum discs, and other memorabilia. He has a large mixing desk at the centre of the room and several racks of outboard gear for sound processing. His guitar and bass rigs are positioned beneath the window, and his keyboard set is in the corner. The star talks us through the creative process that goes into making a record. From songwriting to production to mastering, he explains how he crafts his music and how he gets it ready for release. He also shares some tips on how aspiring musicians can get their own work noticed. At the end of the tour, the star takes a few moments to reflect on his success. "I'm really proud of what I've achieved over the past decade," he says. "It hasn't been easy, but it has been incredibly rewarding. I'm looking forward to continuing to make great music and connecting with my fans around the world."

The girls were "touched inappropriately" in the Castaway Camp playground at the park in Windsor, Berkshire, on Thursday 11 August. Thames Valley Police refused to give the suspect's age or any other details, but said that a male had been arrested in connection with the incident. The police said the girls were not physically harmed and that they are receiving support from specially trained officers. They have urged anyone who witnessed the incident to come forward.

Kim Wall, 30, was last seen on Thursday evening on board the vessel with the owner, 46-year-old Peter Madsen. The submarine later sank and Mr Madsen was rescued before being arrested on suspicion of involvement in her disappearance. A massive search operation has been underway since Ms Wall went missing, with police divers scouring the waters around Copenhagen for any sign of her. Danish authorities have continued to question Mr Madsen as part of their investigation into what happened to her.

The private CaixinMarkit manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) dropped to 47.8 in July from 49.4 in the previous month. It is worse than a preliminary reading of 48.2 and is the lowest level since February 2009. The PMI is a key indicator of China's manufacturing sector health, and a reading below 50 indicates contraction. The July reading shows that the country's manufacturing sector is continuing to contract at a faster pace compared to the previous month. The decline in the index was due to the weakening demand and falling output, as well as increased downward pressure on the labor market. The data also showed that new orders and new export orders both declined sharply in July, while the employment sub-index hit a record low. This suggests that the Chinese economy is still facing significant downward pressure, as businesses struggle to cope with the slowdown in global economic growth and the ongoing trade war between the US and China.

Media playback is not supported on this device The midfielder, 28, is under contract with Arsenal until 2018 but speculation over his future has been widespread. "It is definitely my intention to stay," he said. "I'm totally committed to the club and I've been here for a long time and, as I said before, I love the club and I'm totally committed to it. I want to be here for many more years. "I'm happy here and I think we have a great team and a great manager, so I'm looking forward to the future and hopefully getting some silverware."

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's World At One programme, General Lord Dannatt said it was wrong to "talk up" the incidents. Five Afghan soldiers died in an assault on the base in Helmand province on Sunday. Gen Lord Dannatt said: "I think it is wrong to talk up these incidents, it is wrong to dramatise them, it is wrong to think that the whole thing is on a knife edge and about to collapse, because it isn't." He said it was important to recognise that there had been successes in Afghanistan and that the UK had played an important part. But he added: "We shouldn't be complacent about it, we have got to get it right and make sure that we do everything we can to help the Afghans build their own security forces, build their own government and build their own nation."

The normal body tissues show up as green, while the cancer comes out as intense red spots. The team, at the University of Tokyo and the RIKEN Quantitative Biology Center, used fluorescent proteins to make the cancer cells glow. The cancerous tumors are visualized in real-time, and since the technique uses near-infrared light, it is non-invasive. This makes it a more gentle, yet effective way of imaging tumors and tracking their growth.

Nico Rosberg headed team-mate Lewis Hamilton by 0.505secs after the Briton made a mistake on his best lap. And the German was a massive 1.834secs quicker than Kimi Raikkonen, third fastest in the Ferrari. Rosberg has been the dominant driver throughout the weekend and his lap was a further demonstration of his impressive pace. Hamilton had looked like he might challenge Rosberg for pole but he failed to get the best out of his car on his final run.

Jocelyn McKay is now 81 and said she feels "released" from the feelings that gripped her for so long. "I may be old, but at least I am happy," she said. "The last few years have been difficult, but I am beginning to see that life is too short to be consumed with negative feelings. I can look back on my life and remember the good times and learn from the bad ones."

Protesters hung a sign over the city's famous Rialto bridge and some carried suitcases to symbolise having to leave. Locals say they are being forced out by high rents, housing speculation and the rise of Airbnb, which has taken over many of the city's apartments. The protest was organised by a group called "Venezia in Comune" (Venice in Common), which is fighting to protect Venice's fragile housing market. The group wants to see more affordable housing and restrictions on Airbnb so that locals can remain in the city. The demonstration was peaceful and ended with protesters gathering in Venice's St Mark's Square and chanting slogans such as "Venice is not for sale." The mayor of Venice, Luigi Brugnaro, responded to the protest by saying he would look into creating more affordable housing and considering stricter regulations on Airbnb. He said he wanted to ensure that local people have access to housing and that the number of people living in Venice does not decrease further. The protest highlighted the challenges faced by many Italian cities in trying to balance the interests of tourists, who provide much-needed revenue, with those of local residents, who are feeling the effects of rapidly rising costs. It also showed that when it comes to protecting their homes, Venetians will not stay silent.

Daniel Bragg, 37, hit Julie Cook, 44, so hard he broke her left eye socket in the assault, police said. Ms Cook fell and hit her head on the floor, suffering a concussion and a fractured skull. Mr Bragg was arrested and charged with assault causing grievous bodily harm.

It comes after Swansea City FC's American owners revealed they are in talks with the council over increasing capacity at the ground. The Swans want to add 12,000 seats but will require new infrastructure, such as additional roads and parking, to accommodate the extra fans.
