The club has previously said it is looking at a number of options to increase capacity, including installing modular stands. The council has yet to confirm if it will agree to the plans but has indicated that it is open to discussions. A council spokesperson said: "We are in discussion with Swansea City Football Club about increasing capacity at the Liberty Stadium. These are ongoing discussions and no decisions have been made at this stage."

His rival Yvette Cooper has called the war "wrong" while Andy Burnham has referred to it as "an incredibly difficult period" but said respect should be given to those who served in it. Yvette Cooper has been vocal in her criticism of the Iraq War, stating that the decision to go to war was based on "false information." She has also said that more should have been done to ensure that troops were properly protected and looked after when they returned from duty. Andy Burnham has been more measured in his approach, noting that respect should be given to those who served in the war, but also that lessons must be learned from the conflict.

Darby, 28, made 194 league appearances for the Bantams and helped them to promotion from League Two in 2013. New deals have been offered to goalkeeper Rouven Sattelmaier, defenders Matthew Kilgallon, Nathaniel Knight-Percival and James Meredith, midfielders Mark Marshall, Timothee Dieng, Nicky Law and Billy Knott, and striker Alex Jones. The club have also confirmed that defender Steve Davies and midfielder Kyel Reid will not be offered new contracts once their current deals expire in June. Bradford boss Stuart McCall said: "I'd like to thank all the players for their efforts over the season and wish them all the best for the future. "We are delighted to have been able to offer new contracts to a number of our players who have been instrumental in our success this season."

The suppliers, one making seats and the other parts used in gearboxes, have stopped delivering to VW in a contract row. Car and parts production has already been halted at several German factories. VW has stated that the suppliers, ES Automobilguss GmbH and Prettl Group, have failed to adhere to their contractual obligations and as a result, deliveries of parts used in gearboxes and seats have been halted. This has resulted in production at several VW factories being halted, including those in Wolfsburg, Emden, and Zwickau. The company is now attempting to find alternative suppliers in order to ensure that production can resume quickly. In the meantime, they are looking into ways to minimize the impact of the disruption on its customers. In response to the dispute, VW has released a statement saying: "We regret that our two suppliers ES Automobilguss GmbH and Prettl Group have not adhered to their contractual obligations and that this has led to a disruption in our production processes. We are currently assessing how to best mitigate the consequences of this disruption and we are making every effort to ensure that production can be resumed as soon as possible."

The 35-year-old will have security clearance and access to classified information, but no official title or salary when she works in the West Wing. She will serve as her father's "eyes and ears" and help him decide who to meet with, according to two people familiar with the plan. Ivanka's role will reportedly include advising her father on a variety of issues, including economic growth and the promotion of women in the workforce. She is also expected to be involved in policy development and implementation. The move has been seen as a way for Ivanka to play a more active role in her father's presidency, but some have raised concerns about potential conflicts of interest. Ivanka has already taken a formal leave of absence from her businesses and her husband, Jared Kushner, has stepped down as CEO of his own business.

One of the first out of the blocks is a touring production of All My Sons by black-led theatre company Talawa. The story centres on all-American couple Joe and Kate Keller, who in the aftermath of World War Two are struggling to rebuild their lives in the face of a shared secret that threatens to tear them apart. Talawa director Michael Buffong has re-imagined this classic play for today's audiences, with an all-black cast. "There is something really special about seeing black people telling stories that aren't just about our own experience," he says. "These stories can have universal resonance and offer a unique perspective on classic texts." The production stars Paterson Joseph as Joe Keller, debutant actress Ati Edo-Ekong as Kate Keller and Don Gilet as George Deever. It will be touring to five venues across the UK from April to June. Elsewhere, Chichester presents a brand new adaptation of Eugene O'Neill's classic play Mourning Becomes Electra at The Minerva Theatre. Directed by Blanche McIntyre and starring Kathryn Hunter, the production brings together elements of Greek tragedy, Shakespearean grandeur and 20th century melodrama to tell the story of an American family cursed by its dark past. At the Royal Exchange Theatre in Manchester, Director Sarah Frankcom is presenting a bold new vision of Lorraine Hansberry's A Raisin In The Sun. Set in 1950s Chicago, the play follows the Youngers, an African-American family living in poverty, as they strive to make a better life for themselves. Frankcom has assembled an all-star cast including Lucian Msamati, Sharon D Clarke, Shvorne Marks and Martina Laird. The play runs until May 11th. Finally, Theatr Clwyd in Wales is staging a new version of Arthur Miller's The Crucible, directed by Tamara Harvey. Set during the Salem witch trials of 1692, the play follows John Proctor, a respected local farmer accused of witchcraft and trying to save his reputation and his life. The production features a stellar cast including Paul Nicholls, Siobhan Finneran and Ncuti Gatwa. The Crucible runs at Theatr Clwyd until Saturday April 20th.

Kallum Watkins gave the bottom-of-the-table Rhinos an early lead but Willie Isa's first two Wigan tries put them 12-4 ahead at the break. George Williams, Dom Manfredi and Ben Flower also touched down in the second half, before Watkins scored his second try of the game to make it 32-10.

Two employees of the Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR) were initially quarantined in the office. A note reading "die a painful death, Muslims," was in the envelope with the package. The CAIR employees were deeply disturbed and horrified by the message, and CAIR released a statement about the incident. The organization condemned the hate-filled message and noted that such attacks would not be tolerated. They urged law enforcement to investigate and prosecute the perpetrator of the crime and called on all Americans to reject Islamophobia and bigotry in all its forms.

Syrian state media says toxic gas was contained in shells that rebels have been firing at government-held areas in the divided city. Russian news agency Interfax says seven people died in Tuesday's attack. Syrian state media did not identify the type of gas used in the shelling, but it said there were symptoms of "asphyxiation." The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which tracks Syria's civil war, says eight people died in the shelling and that more than 20 were injured. It said two of those killed were children. The Observatory said the shells landed in the government-held area of Sheikh Maqsoud in Aleppo. The Observatory said it was not immediately clear what type of gas was used in the attack. The attack comes as a humanitarian crisis has been deepening in Aleppo, with hundreds of thousands of civilians trapped by fighting between government forces and rebels.

The investigation by the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) follows a 2013 investigation by BBC Panorama into the Military Research Force, or MRF. Daniel Rooney was 18 when he joined the MRF. The MRF was set up in the late 1990s to gather intelligence about dissident Republican activity in Northern Ireland. The unit was disbanded in 2004 following the Good Friday Agreement. Rooney is alleged to have used physical force on suspects and was accused of failing to follow proper procedures when dealing with detainees. He has denied the allegations. The PSNI said it had received a complaint from Rooney that he was subject to "unlawful or improper treatment" while serving in the MRF. It said that it was treating the complaint seriously and would be conducting an investigation into the allegations. The PSNI added that it was committed to ensuring that any potential criminal offences were investigated thoroughly and impartially. It said it had taken the necessary steps to protect any potential victims and witnesses, and that its investigation would be conducted in a "transparent and fair manner."

Susan Fowler, a software engineer, wrote a blog post about a "very, very strange year at Uber." In it, she says her manager tried to have sex with her on her first official day of work, and that she reported the harassment to HR, only to be told that because he was a "high performer," they wouldn't do anything about it. She also describes a culture of sexism and sexual harassment at Uber, where women were treated unfairly and given fewer opportunities than their male counterparts. Finally, she talks about how the company brushed off complaints from female employees, even when the allegations were backed up with evidence. Fowler's blog post sparked intense media coverage, and led to an internal investigation into the allegations. The investigation ultimately resulted in the firing of over 20 Uber employees for various forms of misconduct, including sexual harassment. It also led to the resignation of CEO Travis Kalanick, who had been accused of not taking the allegations seriously enough. Ultimately, Fowler's blog post helped to spotlight the issue of sexual harassment in the tech industry and forced companies to take a closer look at their culture and policies.

Some dairy farmers have said they face going out of business if prices they receive for their products do not rise. They have held protests at supermarkets to show their anger at the low prices they receive for their produce, and to highlight their plight. They have also called for government support in the form of subsidies and other measures to help ensure their businesses remain viable. In the face of rising production costs, many dairy farmers are struggling to stay afloat, and some are facing bankruptcy. The government has responded to these concerns with a package of measures designed to make the dairy industry more sustainable in the long-term. These include grants to help farmers transition to new farming practices, such as organic farming; funding to improve farm infrastructure; and reform of the dairy supply chain to ensure better prices for farmers. The government has also committed to increasing monitoring and enforcement of anti-competitive practices in the dairy industry, and is providing financial assistance to farmers who want to switch to producing plant-based alternatives to dairy products. However, there are still concerns that the measures announced may not be enough to save some dairy farms. Many farmers feel that the government must do more to support them and to ensure that their businesses remain viable. There is a need for a comprehensive, long-term plan to secure the future of the dairy industry and protect the livelihoods of those who depend on it.

Lewis-Francis took up the sport four months ago with the aim of competing at the Pyeongchang 2018 Winter Olympics. He won 4x100m relay gold at the 2004 Summer Games. GB 's four-man bobsleigh team, which includes Lewis-Francis, are currently competing in the World Cup and will be looking to qualify for the Olympics. The team finished fourth at the 2016 World Championships. Lewis-Francis is one of Britain's most experienced athletes, having competed at six Olympic Games. He was a former world indoor champion, as well as a Commonwealth gold medallist. He has also won a number of medals at the European Championships and World Championships over the years, as well as setting British records. His current focus is on the four-man bobsleigh, which he hopes will take him to the Winter Olympics in 2018. Lewis-Francis says he is determined to make the most of the opportunity and is confident that the team can secure a place at the Games. He knows that success in this new sport requires dedication and hard work, but believes that the team has what it takes to succeed.

Steven Tolley, 48, from Tiverton was one of three men injured while working on the northbound carriageway of the A361 at Gornhay Cross, Tiverton. He was airlifted to Derriford Hospital in Plymouth with serious leg injuries. He is currently receiving treatment and his condition is described as stable. We wish Mr Tolley a speedy recovery and send our thoughts to him and his family at this difficult time.

They say the parts, possibly from a Buk surface-to-air system, are "of particular interest" and could help show who was behind the crash. But they say they have not proved conclusively that the aircraft was shot down. The Dutch-led Joint Investigation Team (JIT) leading the criminal inquiry into the MH17 crash has identified 100 people it suspects were involved in the tragedy, which killed 298 people. It says those responsible must be brought to justice.

Even though Cuba is less than 100 miles away from the US, the two counties fell out in 1959, and no American president has visited since then. The fall out was due to the Cuban Revolution, which saw Fidel Castro take control of the country and turn it into a socialist state. The US responded by imposing an economic embargo on Cuba, which is still in place today. Since then, diplomatic relations between the two countries have been strained, but in recent years they have improved. In 2014, the Obama administration re-established diplomatic ties with Cuba and eased some of the travel restrictions that had been in place for over 50 years.

Mylan said it expected to start selling a cheaper generic product "in several weeks" at a list price of 300 (PS230). That is about half the list price of the product sold by the drugmaker, Sanofi. Mylan also said it would launch a patient access program to help patients who have difficulty paying for their medications. The program will provide up to 300 in savings per fill, with eligible patients receiving up to three fills of the generic product at no cost. Mylan said that in addition to the list price reduction, the company is committed to working with payers and other stakeholders to further reduce out-of-pocket costs for patients.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs found the number had gone up by 200 million since 2013. There has been a big problem with plastic carrier bags in the UK, as they can take hundreds of years to decompose. The government has introduced a 5p charge on plastic carrier bags in England, with the money going towards good causes. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have also had similar charges for some time. This is one of several measures that have been taken to reduce the amount of plastic waste in the UK. Other steps include introducing laws banning microbeads from cosmetics, encouraging producers to use less packaging, and promoting reusable alternatives to single-use plastics. In addition, the government has invested 61.4 million since 2015 to improve recycling facilities, increase awareness of plastic waste, and fund research into new technologies to help tackle the problem. Overall, these measures have had a positive impact and the amount of plastic carrier bags used in the UK has gone down considerably since 2013.

It was always going to be a highly charged farewell, after 112 years, to this football bastion of east London and the one consolation was that at least no-one was going to leave the Boleyn Ground with any doubts as to the outcome of West Ham United's final match here. The current generation of players did justice to the occasion and their predecessors, past and present, with a suitably emphatic 3-2 victory over Manchester United - a team who, ironically, will be their new landlords when they move across London in the summer. It was a fitting end to an era for the club and its supporters and it was perhaps fitting that, after so many years of ups and downs, the Hammers finished on a high. The atmosphere was electric all night, with the home fans in full voice from start to finish and even the away fans getting in on the act. The game itself was an entertaining affair, with the Hammers taking the lead early on through a Cheikhou Kouyate goal before Anthony Martial equalised for United. Michail Antonio then put West Ham back in front before Mark Noble made it 3-1 with a penalty. A late Wayne Rooney goal gave United some hope but it wasn't enough as the hosts held on for a deserved win. There were emotional scenes at the final whistle, with the players, staff and fans all paying tribute to the ground they called home for over a century. It was a bittersweet ending but one that will live long in the memory of those who were there to witness it.

Matthew Gillard, of Connsbrook Avenue in east Belfast, pleaded not guilty to charges including kidnapping and false imprisonment. The defendant, 25, also denied charges of common assault, assaulting a police officer, possession of an offensive weapon, criminal damage and attempting to pervert the course of justice. The alleged offences are said to have taken place on December 3 2017 in east Belfast. Mr Gillard was released on bail and will stand trial on a date yet to be fixed.

Helen Smith, who lives in Deal with her British husband and their two children, applied for a new visa last September. But she is still waiting for officials to return her passport with the visa. Helen Smith's situation is unfortunately not uncommon. It can take months for an application to be processed, and even longer if there are any delays or complications. If Helen has already submitted her application and is still waiting for a response, she should contact her local Visa Processing Office to inquire about the status of her application. They should be able to provide her with more information on when she can expect a response. In the meantime, Helen should make sure to keep all of her documents and records up to date and in order so that she can demonstrate that she meets all of the requirements for the visa.

Anthony Tavernor has been restoring Plas Cadnant Hidden Gardens, near Menai Bridge, on Anglesey for 20 years, describing it as his life's project. But after days of heavy rain, a section of the garden's bank collapsed in October 2020, washing away part of an old stone wall and a walkway. In response to the incident, Tavernor has been working with engineers and experts to repair the damage done and ensure the garden remains safe. He is also seeking grants from organisations such as the Heritage Lottery Fund and Historic England to help fund the project. Tavernor is also exploring ways to make the gardens more resilient to extreme weather events in the future. This could involve installing drainage systems, raising pathways, and using more natural materials such as woodchip and gravel to reinforce walls and paths. The Plas Cadnant Hidden Gardens have been a popular tourist attraction for many years, but due to the pandemic, 2020 was a difficult year for the gardens. Despite the setback of the storm damage, Tavernor remains determined to restore the gardens to their former glory.

The neighbours entered the burning property in Milford Drive, on Sunday afternoon in an attempt to rescue two cats, police said. The occupants were not home at the time. No injuries were reported from the incident, and the two cats are safe and receiving veterinary care. The Milford Drive Police Department would like to thank the neighbours who bravely entered the burning property in an attempt to rescue the cats. For most of US history, party nominees have been decided by political power brokers and deal-makers behind closed doors. Parties operate like private clubs - they make their own rules , and those in charge can shape the process. In recent decades, however, the nomination process has become more open and democratic. Presidential primaries and caucuses give voters a direct say in who they want to see on the ballot in November. The parties also have adopted reforms to make the process more transparent and accountable. This includes rules that establish deadlines for when states must hold their contests and delegate selection rules that ensure minority representation.

Allardyce took charge of the Black Cats in October when they were winless in their opening eight matches, but guided them to 17th and safety. "I don't want to go through another relegation battle," he said. The Black Cats were relegated in 2014-15 and 2016-17. "We have to make sure we look at the recruitment process and make sure it is a lot more successful this season than it was last season," Allardyce added. "If we can do that, then hopefully we can make sure that we don't go into a relegation scrap again."

The Love Actually star will have a supporting role in the spy film, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Armie Hammer, Alicia Vikander and Man of Steel actor Henry Cavill will also star in the film. Within minutes, water cannon showered the demonstrators and there were loud thuds as tear gas canisters were fired. People ran into the side streets of this poor neighbourhood, on the outskirts of Bangalore, as the police charged in. The protesters had been demonstrating against the government's eviction of local slum dwellers and were demanding that they be provided with housing. The police responded with force, firing tear gas canisters and water cannon at the unarmed protestors. Some people were arrested while others were injured in the chaos. The incident highlighted deep-seated social and economic issues in India, where many people are forced to live in cramped and overcrowded slums due to lack of affordable housing. The government's eviction of slum dwellers without providing alternative housing has been widely criticised. In response to the incident, the government has promised to look into the issue of housing for slum dwellers more closely and ensure that they are provided with adequate housing. However, it remains to be seen whether the government will follow through on its promise.

Sean Earle snatched the bag of Linda Clarke, who had cut her wrists and walked out of hospital before sitting on a ledge over the M602 in Salford. All examples of this group, known as the Archosauromorpha, lay eggs. This led some scientists to wonder whether there was something in their biology that prevented live births. But examination of fossil evidence has revealed that some archosaurs, like theropods, did give birth to live young. Other examples of Archosauromorpha include crocodiles, birds, dinosaurs, and pterosaurs. All of these animals lay eggs, but some paleontologists suggest that some of the extinct species of dinosaurs may have given live birth. For example, the Maiasaura is believed to have been a dinosaur that gave birth to live young. Additionally, the fossilized remains of the dinosaur Protoceratops have been found in association with eggshell fragments, suggesting that it may have laid eggs and given live birth. Overall, while most members of the Archosauromorpha group lay eggs, there is evidence that some species may have given live birth.

Numerous fire and police vehicles were dispatched to the Froghall Gardens area, homes were evacuated and roads were closed. They are worried about losing a rare rest day and the effect on their awards night, Paul Struthers said. Oxfordshire Clinical Commissioning Group (OCCG), which overseas health services, has said the non-emergency service lacks "resilience." South Central Ambulance Service (SCAS) runs the phone line and has said calls have risen by nearly a third in the last four years. The chief executive of OCCG has said that they are working with SCAS to develop solutions which will improve the resilience of the non-emergency service. This includes providing additional resources and training for staff, improving the systems used to answer calls and ensuring that patients are seen in a timely manner. OCCG is also looking at ways to reduce the number of people using the service inappropriately and to make sure that those who do use it receive the best possible care. In order to ensure that patients get the best possible care, OCCG is undertaking an audit of the service and its performance. This will include looking into the number of calls being received, how they are handled and what happens when a patient is referred to a medical professional. The results of this audit will be used to inform decisions about the future of the service and any changes that might need to be made. OCCG is also working closely with local GPs and other healthcare professionals to ensure that the most appropriate care is provided for each patient. This includes making sure that patients are referred to the right place for treatment and that their needs are met as quickly as possible. Finally, OCCG is committed to engaging with the public to ensure that they understand the role of the non-emergency service and why it is important. This includes providing information on the types of conditions that can be treated through the service, as well as how to access it.

Some two dozen behemoths were identified, all with masses in excess of a hundred times that of the Sun. Four were known previously, including the remarkable colossus catalogued as R136a1, the most massive single star known. The newly discovered behemoths boast masses ranging from 150 to 300 times that of the Sun. Some are members of tight clusters, while others appear to be completely isolated in space. All of the stars belong to a special class of objects called Wolf-Rayet stars, which have extremely hot surface temperatures and strong stellar winds. By comparing the stars' locations in the sky with their distances from Earth, the team was able to measure the stars' absolute magnitudes - an indication of their intrinsic brightness. This allowed them to compare the stars' luminosities and determine the size of their respective masses. The study also revealed that the stars are all relatively young, at between 1 and 3 million years old. This suggests that these massive stars form more easily than previously thought. Overall, the findings shed new light on the nature of the most massive stars in our galaxy and provide important clues about how they form and evolve.

Researchers hope to learn how much it weighed, how it moved and what it used its iconic back plates for. A UK team has scanned each of its 360 bones to create a 3D model of the animal. The team hopes that their research will shed light on how the animal moved, what it used its back plates for, and how much it weighed. They plan to use the 3D model to study the dinosaur's muscles, tendons and ligaments, which could provide further information about how it moved and how it interacted with its environment. Additionally, they will be looking at the shape of the bones and the structure of the joints to gain insight into how much the animal weighed. Finally, they will examine the back plates to determine what function they served.

West Midlands Police said there was a "sweet irony" to officers using the centre for forced entry training when it had been paid for by money paid into the Proceeds of Crime Account (POCA). Figures from the university admissions service, Ucas, show it was the highest number for five years. Students placed through clearing tend to be those who did not get the grades they were expecting, or who made a late decision to apply. The number of applicants placed through clearing rose by 5 compared with last year and was the highest since 2013. A total of 9,860 students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland were accepted into higher education courses through the process this year, up from 9,410 in 2018. This includes students from outside the European Union (EU), who are not eligible for clearing. The rise comes as universities have become increasingly competitive with their offers and have been more likely to fill their places before clearing begins. It also follows a record high for the number of applications overall, with 690,930 people applying for university in England, Wales and Northern Ireland in 2019 - up 3 on 2018. However, the number of UK students accepted through clearing was down slightly, from 8,830 in 2018 to 8,780 this year. Ucas said the decrease in UK students accepted through clearing was due to the number of applicants falling by 1, while the overall acceptance rate remained much the same at 81. Ucas chief executive Clare Marchant said: "Clearing continues to provide an important route into higher education for those who may have changed their minds about what or where to study or whose results weren't quite what they expected. "There are still courses available in a wide range of subjects, so I'd urge anyone considering their options to look at all their choices, speak to advisers and make sure they understand the implications of their decisions."

Scores more are still missing in Teluk Wondama district after flash floods and landslides that were triggered when a river burst its banks. That is the eye-catching accusation in the Guardian, following a report in a trade publication, the Bookseller. Amazon will not confirm that it has managed to do this. The accusation is that Amazon has managed to establish a monopoly in the UK book market, controlling more than 90 of the e-book market. It is not clear how this has been achieved, as Amazon does not disclose sales figures for its Kindle devices or its e-book titles. However, some reports suggest that Amazon's aggressive pricing policy and tight control over the supply chain have helped it to dominate the market. In addition, Amazon's ability to offer vast discounts on books makes it difficult for other retailers to compete. Amazon has also been accused of using its vast customer base to unfairly influence publishers and authors into signing exclusive deals with them. This has allowed Amazon to further entrench its position in the market. It is unclear if Amazon's dominance of the UK book market is legal under anti-trust laws. If it is found to be in violation of anti-trust laws, regulators may impose fines, or even force Amazon to break up its business to allow competition.

Kirsty McGuire, from Dover, Kent, said her son Codie McDowell was left screaming with pain. The accident in East Sussex has led his family to warn of the dangers of Nerf guns Kirsty McGuire, the mother of eight-year-old Codie McDowell, is warning parents about the dangers of Nerf guns after her son was shot in the eye by a plastic pellet. McGuire said that her son was playing with the gun at a friend's house when the accident happened. She said that he was screaming in pain and she immediately drove him to the hospital. The doctors examined Codie and found that the plastic pellet had become lodged in his eye. They were able to remove it but he suffered from internal bleeding, scratches to the cornea, and bruising. The incident has made McGuire concerned about the safety of Nerf guns and other toy weapons. She is urging all parents to be aware of the potential risks and to ensure that children are supervised while using them. She also suggests never aiming the gun at anyone's head, even if it is a toy.

Foredowne Boarding Kennel is facing allegations about how dogs, seized by Devon and Cornwall Police and placed there, were kept without exercise. 2 October 2015 Last updated at 18:13 BST Speaking in an interview with BBC Newsnight's diplomatic and defence editor Mark Urban, he said UK policy in Syria had been hampered by divisions in the National Security Council. He said: "It was never a functioning body. It has been entirely unable to agree on any kind of decisions over Syria. "That's why I think our policy on Syria has been so incoherent and inconsistent over the last five years." Mr Fallon added: "We have been paralysed by disagreement within that council, with one part of it wanting to intervene, another not wanting to intervene, and the government not able to reconcile those two points of view." The defence secretary said he believed there was now an "emerging consensus" in favour of military action against Islamic State (IS). However, he stressed that any decision to extend RAF airstrikes from Iraq into Syria would need to be taken by a vote in Parliament.

On one occasion there was only one commode available for more than 100 patients at North Middlesex University Hospital, a report by the watchdog said. Invisible Edinburgh said the aim was to reveal a different side to Scotland's capital city. Dickson carried his bat for 207 not out, as Shiv Thakor's maiden five-wicket haul saw Kent all out for 412. Derbyshire's Billy Godleman retired hurt without facing a ball after being struck by a bouncer from Fred Klaassen. Kent's innings saw Zak Crawley (86) and Ollie Robinson (90) both hitting half-centuries, while Sean Dickson's 207 was the highest individual score of the match. He batted the entire second innings, becoming the first Kent batsman to carry his bat in a first-class match since Ed Smith in 2003. Shiv Thakor was the pick of the bowlers for Kent, as he claimed a maiden five-wicket haul with figures of 5137. However, Derbyshire's reply was cut short when Billy Godleman retired hurt without facing a ball after being struck by a bouncer from Fred Klaassen. The day ended with Derbyshire on 312, still needing 381 runs to win.

Sentinel-1b was carried into orbit by a Soyuz rocket that flew out of Sinamary in French Guiana. "We are doing all we can to ensure the coach and other staff members are paid as soon as possible." Sredojevic's qualification mission has been hailed by many in Uganda as a major success. The Serbian tactician took charge in May and admits he accepted a salary lower than what he had been offered elsewhere. He led the Cranes to their first Africa Cup of Nations finals since 1978, and currently top Group L of the 2019 qualifiers. Uganda have played seven matches, won four, and lost just once. "We are doing our utmost to make sure all our employees are paid their salaries," Watson added.

Firefighters dealt with blazes on Friday overnight at garage forecourts in Salisbury and Durrington as well as in residential areas of Amesbury. An aircraft was also found burnt out at night. In Salisbury, a petrol station forecourt on Old Sarum Airfield was damaged by fire. Firefighters from Salisbury Fire Station were called at 11.20pm and used two hose reel jets to extinguish the blaze. The fire also spread to an external wall of a nearby building but this was quickly extinguished. A Wiltshire Fire Rescue spokesperson said: "On arrival crews found a single storey commercial property alight with a fuel spillage. "Crews used two hose reel jets to extinguish the fire, positive pressure ventilation fan to clear smoke and thermal imaging camera for hotspotting. "The cause of the fire is believed to be accidental." At 12:35am, firefighters from Durrington were called to a garage forecourt in Rollestone Street after reports of a car fire. The fire was extinguished using two breathing apparatus wearers, one hose reel jet and small tools. At 1.45am, an aircraft was reported as being on fire in the airfield area of Old Sarum Airfield. Upon arrival, crews confirmed the aircraft had been destroyed by fire and that it was now out. They used one 45mm jet and a thermal imaging camera to check for hotspots. The spokesperson added: "The cause of the fire is believed to be deliberate." And at 9.50pm, Amesbury Fire Station attended reports of a shed fire in Stonehenge Road. The fire was extinguished using one hose reel jet and small tools. The cause of the fire is believed to be accidental.

Ajinkya Rahane became the fifth Indian to score centuries in both innings of a Test match as they declared on 267-5. In reply, captain Hashim Amla (23 not out) took South Africa to a one-wicket victory with a century of his own. Rahane scored 127 in the first innings and 103 in the second innings of the match. He joined the likes of Vijay Hazare, Sunil Gavaskar, Rahul Dravid and Virender Sehwag in achieving this feat.

Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's programme was pushed through without debate, according to parliamentary speaker Salim al-Juburi. Under the plan, Mr Abadi will cut spending and eliminate senior posts. It follows months of anti-government protests and a worsening economic crisis caused by falling oil prices. The programme, which was passed without debate, is the latest attempt by Mr Abadi to tackle the country's financial woes. It includes measures such as cutting the salaries of senior officials, eliminating the posts of vice president and deputy prime minister, and reducing the number of ministers from 22 to 16. The plan also calls for reducing spending on subsidies, raising taxes, and increasing public sector efficiency. Additionally, it will create a new "Anti-Corruption Commission" tasked with investigating cases of fraud and corruption. The programme has been widely welcomed by Iraqi citizens, who have been struggling with rising unemployment and poverty due to the economic crisis. Many Iraqis are hoping that the reforms will help improve their living conditions, while others are skeptical and are waiting to see how the government will implement the changes.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's son is the first member of the UK Royal family to have his first birthday marked by a new coin. The third in line to the throne, Prince Louis of Cambridge was born on April 23, 2018 and celebrated his first birthday on April 23, 2019. To mark the occasion, The Royal Mint released a commemorative 5 coin featuring an image of Prince Louis alongside a childhood quote from his father, Prince William: 'A child's spirit is like a rainbow.' The reverse side of the coin features four children holding hands around the shield of the Royal Arms.

To be 80-5 and give away a 200-run lead is a problem in any Test, let alone one where you know the pitch is going to get more difficult to bat on. It is a concern for the England team and they will need to find a way to rectify this problem if they are to have any success in the upcoming Tests. The first step in fixing this issue is to identify what went wrong. Was the batting too aggressive? Were bowlers too defensive? Was there a lack of discipline with either the bat or ball? Once you have identified the problem, then you can start to look at solutions. For instance, the batsmen may need to take a more measured approach when facing spin and be prepared to play for long periods. The bowlers could also look to build pressure by bowling more accurately and varying their lines and lengths. It is also important for the captain to be aware of the state of the pitch and adjust his tactics accordingly. This may mean bowling spinners early, setting attacking fields and placing an emphasis on taking wickets rather than runs. Finally, it is essential that the team keeps its composure throughout the run chase and focuses on each ball as it comes, rather than getting ahead of themselves. With determination, discipline and a sound game-plan, the England team should be able to turn this result around and come out victorious in the remaining Tests.

Revised growth estimates now suggest the construction industry shrank in the first quarter of 2012, but by less than previously thought. Analysts say the revision may be enough to mean the industry avoided a technical recession, which is defined as two consecutive quarters of contraction. The revised figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed that construction output fell 0.2 in the first three months of 2012, compared with an earlier estimate of a 2.5 decline. This was still weaker than the 0.8 rise seen in the fourth quarter of 2011, but the ONS said the first-quarter figure was much better than expected and "a sign that the sector may not have entered a technical recession." The industry has been particularly hard hit by government spending cuts, and the latest figures are likely to be welcomed by ministers, who had feared the sector would contract for two successive quarters. However, despite the more positive news, the construction industry is still facing tough times, as the ONS said its revisions merely meant the first quarter's contraction was less pronounced than initially thought. Analysts said the sector was still weak, pointing to other indicators such as housebuilding which have declined significantly. Overall, the UK economy shrank 0.3 in the first quarter, marking the third successive quarter of contraction, raising fears that the country could be heading for a double-dip recession.

In the space of two months, the 25-year-old has become one of the most controversial politicians in Hong Kong - and is now pitted in a court battle against the government. In that short span of time, Joshua Wong has become a symbol for the democracy movement in Hong Kong, leading rallies and protests against Beijing's attempts to limit democratic freedoms. His arrest on August 30 sparked a new wave of demonstrations, with thousands taking to the streets to demand his release. Wong has been active in the pro-democracy movement since he was 14, when he helped lead the successful campaign to stop the introduction of national education in Hong Kong schools. He went on to found the activist group Scholarism, which challenged the government's plans for electoral reform. Wong has now turned his attention to the current political situation in Hong Kong, denouncing Beijing's attempts to interfere in the city's politics and calling for universal suffrage. He and other activists are challenging the government in court over its decision to disqualify six pro-democracy lawmakers from office. Wong's activism has made him a target for the Chinese government, and he faces charges for participating in an unlawful assembly at the Hong Kong airport in July. He is out on bail, but could face up to five years in jail if convicted. Despite the threats and the legal battle he faces, Wong remains undeterred. He has vowed to continue the fight for democracy in Hong Kong, saying that people from all walks of life should be free to participate in the political process.

A 25-year-old woman testified that Larry Nassar molested her from the age of six until 12 during family visits to his Michigan home. Mr Nassar, 53, is accused by more than 150 women and girls of sexual assault under the guise of medical treatment. The woman, who was identified only as Victim J.L., said that Mr Nassar had convinced her parents that he was providing therapeutic treatments to help her with her gymnastics. She said that Mr Nassar would molest her during the visits and she would become so uncomfortable that she would put a blanket over her head or try to leave the room. However, she said that he would grab her arms and force her to remain in the room and continue the abuse. Victim J.L. stated in court that she "felt helpless" and "trapped" during these visits, as she was too young to understand what was happening. She also said that her parents were unaware of the abuse and that it continued for six years until she reached the age of 12. Victim J.L.'s testimony is one of many that has been presented in court by victims of Mr Nassar's alleged abuse. It is hoped that the testimonies can help bring justice to the victims and ensure that perpetrators such as Larry Nassar are held accountable for their actions.

Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group saw pre-tax profit increase by PS800,000, to PS3.5m, in the year to the end of June 2016. This was despite turnover falling by PS1m to just over PS160m. The strong results were driven by Harbro's focus on cost control and efficiency, which saw the group's administrative expenses reduced by PS1.4m. This was achieved despite the significant investment in new premises, technology, and staff to support the growth of its business. Harbro also achieved an increase in operating margin from 7.8 to 8.7, due to the reduced costs. The company also invested in a range of new products and services to meet customer needs and grow into new markets. Overall, the growth in profits is a positive result for Harbro, which has seen its revenue decline over the past few years due to difficult trading conditions in the agricultural market. The strong profit performance reflects the success of the group's strategic plans to reduce costs and invest in new products and services to drive future growth.

"The decision has dealt the final blow to democracy in the country," said the Organisation of American States. The court ruled that the assembly was in contempt and said it could dissolve it. The court's decision is a major setback for democracy in the country and has been widely condemned by international organizations and countries around the world. This decision effectively eliminates any checks and balances on the executive branch and gives the president virtually unlimited power. It also undermines the legitimacy of elected officials and sets a dangerous precedent that could lead to authoritarianism in the future.

The celebrated US fashion designer was found dead in her New York flat on Monday, in an apparent suicide. In a statement on his website, Sir Mick said he still could not believe it. "I am so shocked and devastated by the tragic news of the loss of our dear friend, the brilliant designer Kate Spade," he said. "She was a great talent who had an immeasurable impact on American fashion and the way the world viewed it. She was also a great person - full of energy, charisma, humor and style." He added, "My heart goes out to her family and friends, especially her husband and daughter. I will always remember her with love and admiration."

Media playback is not supported on this device The 20-year-old told BBC Sport he is motivated by trophies not money after rejecting a PS100,000-a-week contract. "Liverpool are one of the biggest clubs in the world, and I want to help them win trophies," he said. The 20-year-old's comments demonstrate his commitment to Liverpool and a desire to achieve success with the club. He has shown that he is not motivated by money but instead by the prospect of winning trophies. This attitude is likely to endear him to Liverpool fans, who will be hoping he can help bring silverware to Anfield.

The 27-year-old still had two years left on his existing deal but he has now committed himself to New Road for another season. He is the ninth player in five days to sign a new contract. The former Worcestershire skipper, who joined the club in 2012, has scored 16 centuries and 52 fifties for the Pears during his time at New Road. He has also taken 27 wickets with his off-spin bowling. Kervezee said: "I am delighted to have signed an extension to my Worcester contract. I have been part of the county since 2012 and I am looking forward to another two years at New Road. "I feel I still have something to offer the team, both on and off the field, and I am confident that we can make further progress over the next couple of years."

Police were called to Love Ranch brothel in Crystal, Nevada, after he was found unresponsive on Tuesday. The American had to be driven to hospital because he was too tall for an ambulance stretcher. Police are investigating the circumstances surrounding the death of the American, who was not named by authorities. They said he had been staying at the brothel since Saturday and that there were no signs of foul play. The cause of death has yet to be determined. The Love Ranch is owned by Dennis Hof, a notorious Nevada pimp and owner of several other brothels in the state. Hof died last October at age 72 after winning a Republican primary election for a Nevada state legislative seat.

Some reports put the number even higher. The roof of the church caved in on worshippers who had gathered for the ordination of a bishop on Saturday. Those inside the church were crushed to death by the falling debris. At least 200 people are believed to have been inside the church at the time of the collapse, and the death toll is expected to rise as rescuers continue to search for survivors. It is believed that many of those killed were elderly, as the church was hosting a special service for senior members of the community. The cause of the collapse is still unknown, though local authorities have speculated that it may have been due to structural issues or weather-related damage.

Mr Maduro said the room would be kept intact and a wing of the presidential palace turned into a monument to Mr Chavez's "Bolivarian revolution." Mr Chavez died of cancer in 2013. Mr Maduro said the furniture, photos and paintings in the room would be preserved "as a symbol of his legacy." The room was where Mr Chavez held meetings with foreign dignitaries and hosted private events. It has been kept largely untouched since his death, with only a few items moved to make way for a portrait of him that hangs over the fireplace. The move is part of a wider effort by Mr Maduro's government to preserve the legacy of Mr Chavez, who led Venezuela for 14 years before his death. The late leader's face has been plastered on billboards and buildings across the country, and his image is often seen at rallies and marches organised by the government.

Media playback is unsupported on your device 5 February 2014 Last updated at 08:46 GMT White lions are very rare - their zoo keeper thinks there's only around 90 of them left in the wild. They are born with a white mane and fur, which is caused by a gene mutation. The lions usually live in South Africa, where they are often kept in captivity to protect them from poachers. White lions have become popular attractions in many zoos around the world. However, there are concerns that the gene pool of white lions is becoming too small, and that this could lead to inbreeding and problems with their health. Zoo keepers are trying to conserve the species, and some programmes are working to reintroduce white lions back into the wild.

The 29-year-old terminated his contract with the O's after the transfer window closed, and cannot join another EFL side until January. "I wouldn't say I'm in a predicament, but I 'm in a position I wouldn't want to be in," Clarke told Sky Sports News. "I'm a free agent and I'm looking for a club, but the window is closed so I can't do anything until January. I'm training every day and staying fit, but it's hard not being involved in football." Clarke joined Orient from Leyton Orient in 2017 and made over 100 appearances for the O's, scoring 17 goals. He was part of the side that secured promotion to League Two last season.

Businessman Jeffrey Spector, 54, of St Annes, Lancashire, died on Friday following a six-year illness. He was surrounded by friends and family at a meal shortly before his death at his home. Jeffrey was a highly successful businessman who ran several businesses in the North West. He was best known for his work in the hospitality industry, where he created and managed numerous award-winning restaurants. He was also an active philanthropist, supporting charities across the region and abroad. His passion for helping people was well known and he had a deep commitment to providing opportunity and support to those in need. In addition to his business interests, Jeffrey was an avid sportsman, playing golf and squash regularly. He was also a passionate collector of classic cars and enjoyed driving them around the country. Jeffrey will be deeply missed by his family and friends. His memory will live on through the organisations and individuals he helped throughout his life.

Murray, 25, who has already secured Rio Olympic qualification, was down in 21st after the fencing round. Strong swimming and run-shoot combined events helped her climb to ninth and reach the eight-person final round. In that round Murray shot well, but was unable to make up enough ground on the track. She finished the event in ninth place with a total score of 6,004 points. She said: "I'm really pleased with today. I put together a good performance and I'm very excited for Rio now. "I'm really happy with the shooting, it's been a strong point for me all year. I've been working really hard on my fencing this season and it definitely paid off today. "It was a great atmosphere here and it was great to experience such a big crowd. I can't wait to get to Rio now and compete at the Olympics."

Media playback is not supported on this device At 44 years old, Owens was the oldest of the 12 referees chosen for the World Cup, but his age will not be a factor The World Cup starts on June 12th and there are 12 referees who will officiate the matches. Among them is 44-year-old Mark Owens, one of the oldest officials at the tournament. Owens, who has been refereeing since he was 16, says his age will not be a factor in his performance. "I don't feel any different to the younger referees," he said. "I have the same level of fitness, the same level of experience and knowledge of the game." Owens has been preparing for the World Cup for months, studying video footage of different players and teams. He has also been attending regular fitness tests to make sure he is in top condition for the tournament. Referees are also expected to be impartial and Owens insists that won't be a problem either. "I don't have any particular team I support, so I can make decisions without being influenced by my own biases," he said. For Owens, the World Cup is the pinnacle of his career and he is determined to make the most of it. "I'm looking forward to the opportunity and I'm going to give it my best shot," he said.

World road champion Armitstead finished in the peloton to extend her overall lead over South Africa's Ashleigh Moolman-Pasio to eight seconds. The 2014 winner Vos won the 119km stage from Al Qudra to Hatta Dam in 3:30.22. Results Stage 2 9 February 2015 - Hatta to Hatta Dam, 119km Stage 3 10 February 2015 - Dubai Silicon Oasis to Dubai International Marine Club, 117.5km Classification leadership table In the 2015 Dubai Tour, four different jerseys were awarded. For the general classification, calculated by adding each cyclist's finishing times on each stage, and allowing time bonuses for the first three finishers at intermediate sprints and at the finish of mass-start stages, the leader received a yellow jersey. This classification was considered the most important of the 2015 Dubai Tour, and the winner of the general classification was considered the winner of the race. There was also a points classification, which awarded a green jersey. In the points classification, cyclists got points for finishing in the top 15 in a stage. There was also a mountains classification. The classifications first climb came at the end of Stage 1, at the Jabel Hafeet summit, where the first rider over the summit was awarded points towards the classification. Each climbing point had a value of one, and with two categorized climbs on the route, there were a total of 8 available points. The leader of the mountains classification wore a white jersey. Additionally, there was a young rider classification, which was calculated the same as the general classification, but only riders born after 1 January 1990 were eligible. The leader of the young rider classification wore a blue jersey. External links Category:2015 in road cycling Category:2015 in Emirati sport 2015 Category:February 2015 sports events in Asia

The public car park is just off the Upper Newtownards Road, one of the main routes into the city. Thousands of wooden pallets are now piled up where previously there were cars parked. It is unclear why the pallets are there, but locals speculate that it could be for a number of reasons. Possibly, the car park is being used as storage for goods or materials, or it could be related to construction taking place nearby. The council has yet to comment on the situation.

Concern is mounting about the potential of a vicious power struggle in Addis Ababa, triggering a negative chain reaction across the region. For many of Ethiopia's Horn allies, the death of the country's Prime Minister in mysterious circumstances has been a cause for deep concern, and with his successor yet to be named, there is a fear that political competition could destabilise the fragile nation. The potential for violence and civil unrest is a key worry, as any unrest could result in a refugee crisis, which would put immense strain on Ethiopia's neighbouring countries. The death of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has left a power vacuum in a region already destabilised by pandemic-induced economic turmoil, and the threat of a power struggle is looming large. To prevent an escalation of violence, the international community must act quickly to ensure that a stable transition of power takes place. This should include mediation efforts, direct diplomatic support and increased funding for peacekeeping operations, if necessary. The African Union has already called for peaceful negotiations between all parties involved, and has promised to provide additional financial support to ensure security and stability during the transition. Furthermore, the United Nations has committed to supporting Ethiopia's democratic process, and has urged all sides to refrain from violence. In order to ensure that a peaceful transition of power takes place, it is essential that the international community comes together and provides the necessary support to safeguard democracy in Ethiopia. It is also crucial that all parties involved remain committed to a peaceful resolution, and work together to ensure that Ethiopia remains politically stable and secure.

RTE reports that a number of flights have been cancelled at Cork airport and weather warnings are in place. A number of power outages have also been reported with about 7,000 people affected in the Cork and Kerry area. The Irish Aviation Authority (IAA) has confirmed that a number of flights have indeed been cancelled at Cork airport due to adverse weather conditions. The IAA is advising passengers to check with their airline directly for any updates on their flight status. ESB Networks is reporting that about 7,000 people are currently without power in the Cork and Kerry areas due to the stormy weather. ESB is currently working to restore power as quickly as possible. Met Eireann has issued a Status Orange wind warning for Cork and Kerry and a Status Yellow wind warning for the rest of the country. The warnings are in place until 8am tomorrow morning. People are advised to take extra care while out and about.

8 March 2016 Last updated at 10:47 GMT This time he's explaining the difference between deficit and debt. But there's a catch: he has to do it in as short a time as possible. Deficit is the difference between what a government spends and what it earns from taxes. It is the amount by which spending exceeds income. Debt is the cumulative total of deficits over time. It is the total amount of money that a government owes from past and present deficits.

Upsetting events often make the news because they don't happen very often. This section gives you some tips about what to do if you are feeling sad about what you've seen or heard. 1. Talk to someone you trust - a family member, friend, teacher, counselor, or religious leader. Talking can help you work through your feelings and better understand what's happening. 2. Avoid excessive exposure to upsetting news stories. Too much exposure can cause you to become overwhelmed and isolated. 3. Take part in activities that make you feel good. Exercise, spending time with friends, or doing something creative can all help you feel better. 4. Limit your use of social media. Seeing other people's reactions to events can often make things worse. 5. Help out in some way. Volunteering, donating money or goods, or writing a letter to your elected officials are all ways to take positive action. 6. Learn more about the issue. Reading books, articles, and blogs on the subject can help you gain a better understanding of what's going on and how you can help.

The jury praised Ahmed Mansoor for regularly raising concerns about arbitrary detention, torture and degrading treatment in the Gulf state. As a result, it said, he had faced repeated intimidation, harassment and physical attacks. "The life of this courageous human rights defender is a testament to the power of one person's willingness to speak truth to power," it said. Mansoor was sentenced in May 2018 to 10 years in prison after being convicted of "publicly insulting the UAE's reputation abroad" and "publishing false information and rumours." The charges stemmed from posts he made on social media about alleged torture in UAE prisons and his calls for political reforms. Before his conviction, Mansoor had been subjected to a sustained campaign of threats and harassment, which included being placed under surveillance, having his phone hacked and being followed by unknown individuals. He was also arrested and threatened with criminal prosecution several times. "Ahmed Mansoor is a symbol of the struggle for freedom of expression in the United Arab Emirates and beyond," said Dr Agnes Callamard, Director of Amnesty International's Global Issues Programme. "He has paid a high price for his peaceful activism and we call on the authorities to immediately release him and drop all charges against him." Amnesty International is calling on the UAE authorities to unconditionally release Mansoor and to ensure that he is provided with adequate medical care while in detention.

Mr Charney, who also founded the company, was ousted last year because of the employee complaints and amid accusations of misuse of company funds. In the San Francisco court filing, he said the company had "wrongly accused him of misconduct, misused corporate assets and wrongfully terminated his employment." He sought damages and to be reinstated as CEO. Charney's lawsuit also alleged that the board of directors had a conflict of interest in his firing, because the board members stood to benefit from the termination. Charney's legal team argued that the board violated its fiduciary duties by not properly investigating the employee complaints against Charney, which they argued were unsubstantiated. They argued that the investigation was designed to push out Charney, and not to protect the company. The court ultimately dismissed the case, ruling that the board of directors acted within their rights when they fired Charney. The court noted that although the employee complaints may have been unsubstantiated, the board had a reasonable basis to believe that Charney had engaged in misconduct and misused corporate funds. Ultimately, the court found that the board did not breach their fiduciary duty to protect the best interests of the company.

SuperTed was born in south Wales as a book, before becoming a much-loved TV series on both sides of the Atlantic. It was shown as one of Welsh language broadcaster S4C's first children's programmes and was produced by Siriol Animation. SuperTed follows the adventures of an ordinary teddy bear who is brought to life through a magical star and given superpowers by an alien called Spotty Man. The series follows his attempts to fight crime and save the day, aided by his friends Texas Pete and Bulk.

Ali Asghar Zarean told state TV that Iran would sign an agreement with China to modify the reactor before doing so. On Monday, the semi-official Fars news agency cited unnamed sources as saying that the agreement would be signed "in the near future." The Arak reactor, which is still under construction, was part of a deal reached in July between Iran and six world powers to limit Tehran's nuclear activities in exchange for sanctions relief. Under the terms of the deal, Iran agreed to convert the reactor so it could not produce weapons-grade plutonium once it is completed. Tehran has said it plans to use the reactor for research and medical purposes.

Campaigners fought to save Ipswich Airport after it was earmarked for housing by Ipswich Borough Council, with some occupying the terminal building for about four months. The anniversary of the occupation was marked on 17 December 2009. The campaign had the support of local MPs, businesses, and aviation organisations. The airport remains open for general aviation operations, but is not served by commercial airlines.

European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker said the UK may want to be more "obliging" to certain countries to secure future commercial advantages. The EU is keen to maintain a united front on Brexit and insists that the UK must abide by its obligations under the withdrawal agreement, including paying any financial commitments it has made. Juncker also said that the UK should be careful not to damage its relations with other EU countries in its pursuit of future trade deals.

Last month he became the first player to speak publicly about being sexually abused as a boy at Crewe in the 1980s. There are now 155 suspects in the UK-wide investigation into non-recent child sexual abuse in football. The impact of his decision to come forward has been immense, with more and more survivors finding the courage to speak out about their experiences. It is only through brave acts like this that we can begin to tackle the issue, ensuring that children are safe from harm and that those responsible for abusing them are brought to justice.

The man, who has not been named, was dismissed following disciplinary proceedings, Devon and Somerset Fire Service said. Molly Wigmore, 76, died in the fire at her Plymouth home in April. The fire service said it accepted there were "shortcomings" in its response to the fire, which was attended by just one fire engine. Mrs Wigmore's family said they were "disappointed" with the outcome of the disciplinary process. The fire service had previously apologised to the family, saying it should have sent two fire engines.

The star wore a Gary Barlow mask as he began playing Could It Be Magic on a piano at Cabot Circus shopping centre. Shoppers watching the mystery performer were astonished to learn that it was none other than the Take That frontman. The impromptu performance was part of a new campaign from Cabot Circus, which is encouraging shoppers to "Listen With Your Eyes" and explore the centre's range of iconic stores in a new way. Barlow's surprise performance was designed to encourage shoppers to look beyond what they expect from their usual shopping experience and try something different. Barlow said: "It's great to be here in Bristol for this special performance. I hope it inspires people to stop, listen, and enjoy all that Cabot Circus has to offer - you never know what you might find."

The 28-year-old's nine-year-old daughter was also threatened by a member of the gang, who had a knife. The burglary happened at their home in the Turf Hill area at about 22:00 BST on Wednesday. The father was taken to hospital with a wound to his hand, but has since been discharged. He said he wanted to thank the members of the public who came to their aid during the incident. "I would like to thank everyone who helped us during this difficult time," he said. "We are extremely thankful for the support we have received and I hope that those responsible will be brought to justice."

The left-handed opener, 36, who played six Tests for England, last appeared for his county in July 2016 before he was diagnosed with a cancerous tumour. He immediately started treatment and underwent chemotherapy." Cook was diagnosed with testicular cancer in July 2016, and he immediately began treatment. He underwent chemotherapy to fight the cancerous tumor and has since returned to playing cricket for Essex in June 2017.

The Chesterfield striker was cleared of rape at a retrial in 2016. He had been charged with attacking the woman in a hotel room in Rhyl, Denbighshire. Following the retrial, the jury found him not guilty of rape and he was acquitted.

The tour players were also given an option to scrap the tournament after last month's controversy in Watford. World number 20 Dave Gilbert was knocked out in the quarter-finals after being accused of using an illegal technique. Gilbert has denied the accusation and the World Professional Darts Corporation said that evidence suggested he had not used an illegal technique. The tournament was ultimately allowed to proceed, and Gilbert's case remains open. The players were given the option to scrap the tournament, but most decided to continue, citing their commitment to the sport and desire to keep playing. Some players also felt that the controversy should not overshadow the event, which is the last major before the 2020 PDC World Darts Championship.

The latest stage of the government's auto-enrolment programme has seen a 95 compliance rate among small businesses. All employers will eventually need to offer pensions to anyone who is over the age of 22, earns more than 10,000 a year, and works in the UK. Auto-enrolment is an important part of the government's efforts to ensure that all employees have access to a retirement savings plan. It is intended to make it easier for people to save for their retirement. The 95 compliance rate among small businesses is testament to the success of the scheme so far. The next step for the auto-enrolment programme is to increase the minimum contribution rate from 2 to 5. This means that employers will be required to contribute at least 5 of their employee's salary towards their pension. This will help to ensure that people are able to build up an adequate amount of savings for their retirement. The government is also currently considering changes to the way in which pensions are taxed. These could involve changing the rate of tax relief on contributions, or introducing a 'flat rate' of tax relief. Any changes to the current system could have significant implications for how much people are able to save for their retirement. Overall, the auto-enrolment programme has been successful so far and is helping to ensure that more people are able to save for their retirement. However, further changes may be necessary in order to ensure that people can build up sufficient savings for later life.

Anna Jacobs read the description by Tecomak Environmental Services in an email inviting her for interview. Attached seemingly by accident, the comments suggested Ms Jacobs, of Horsmonden in Kent, was 'a suitable candidate'. Ms Jacobs was shocked to see the comments and was both surprised and pleased that her qualifications and experience had been seen as a good fit for the role she was applying for. She also felt reassured that someone had taken the time to read her CV and appreciate her capabilities. The comments made her feel more confident about attending the interview and gave her a boost of motivation.

HS2 Action Alliance says a paper by HS2 Ltd shows engineering work will mean closing parts of some passenger lines for 133 weekends, and some freight lines for 50 weekends. HS2 Ltd, the government-owned company responsible for delivering the high-speed rail network, has published a paper which states that engineering work associated with the construction of Phase One of HS2 (London to Birmingham) will require the closure of parts of some passenger lines for 133 weekends and some freight lines for 50 weekends. The HS2 Action Alliance, an organisation opposed to the project, has raised concerns about the potential disruption this could cause to local communities and businesses.

The incident happened within the grounds of the city's bus station in Smithfield Street just before 10:30 GMT on Monday. The woman was in her 30s but her name has not yet been released. Police said the woman was taken to hospital but died a short time later. A post-mortem examination is due to take place in due course. No arrests have been made and police are appealing for anyone with information to come forward.

In an interview with Fox News, he said: "There are a lot of killers. We've got a lot of killers. What do you think? Our country's so innocent?" Mr Trump was referring to the fact that many countries, including the United States, are involved in military interventions and wars around the world. He was implying that our country is not as innocent as some may think.

The 29-year-old former Manchester United player will now fly to London to finalise personal terms and have a medical with the Hammers. Meanwhile, Austria forward Marko Arnautovic is due to fly to China on Thursday to complete his move to Shanghai SIPG. West Ham have been searching for a replacement for Arnautovic since the Chinese Super League club made their move for the 30-year-old striker last week. Ighalo, who has scored 16 goals in 55 appearances for Nigeria, was identified as a target for West Ham early this week and it appears that the deal is now close to being completed. The former Watford forward had been playing for Chinese Super League side Changchun Yatai but he is now set to make a return to England after three years away from the Premier League. West Ham are believed to be paying in the region of 20million for Ighalo, who scored 39 goals in 99 appearances for Watford between 2014 and 2017.

The Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information said that the social network had not obtained effective approval from WhatsApp's 35 million German users. Facebook bought WhatsApp for 19 billion in 2014 The Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information said that Facebook had not obtained effective consent from WhatsApp's 35 million German users before it began sharing data between the two services. The commissioner said that Facebook was taking advantage of its market dominance to push through changes to its terms of service that were not in line with European data protection law. Facebook has been given a deadline of four weeks to comply with the regulator's demands or face fines of up to 300,000.

He had been making his way down the south ridge of 3,000ft-high Tryfan when he slipped on Saturday afternoon. An RAF Sea King helicopter, based at Valley in Anglesey, was scrambled to the scene and the man was airlifted in a "serious condition" to Ysbyty Gwynedd, Bangor. The mountain rescue team from Ogwen Valley said conditions on the ridge were "very icy" following a period of heavy snowfall. Tryfan is one of the most popular mountains for climbers in Snowdonia, particularly the south ridge which features two rocky outcrops known as Adam and Eve. A spokesman for the Ogwen Valley Mountain Rescue Organisation said: "We were called at 15:42 BST by North Wales Police. "An adult male had slipped while walking down the south ridge of Tryfan. "He was airlifted by an RAF Sea King helicopter - his injuries were serious and he was taken to Ysbyty Gwynedd in Bangor."

India's greatest leader had moved to a village called Segaon two years earlier. He had renamed it Sevagram or a village of service. He built an ashram, a commune which was based on the principles of truth, non-violence and simple living. He believed in self-sufficiency and started several projects such as a handloom weaving center, a dairy, a cattle shed and a school for poor children. He was Mahatma Gandhi, India's preeminent leader who led the country to freedom from British rule. Gandhi was an advocate of non-violent civil disobedience and an inspiration to millions of people across India and beyond. His commitment to justice and his dedication to the principles of non-violence and simple living earned him the title of 'Father of the Nation'. During his time at Sevagram, Gandhi focused on developing the village into a model of self-reliance. He organized agricultural cooperatives, provided education to local children, and helped build a hospital. He also held regular meetings with local leaders, encouraging them to work together in order to improve the lives of their constituents. Gandhi's legacy lives on today, inspiring people to lead lives of truth, non-violence and service to others.

The three judges scored the 12-round bout 115-112 to Burns, 115-113 to Beltran and 114-114, which did not seem to reflect Beltran flooring Burns or his dislocating the champion's jaw. The three judges' scores for the 12-round bout reflect the fact that Beltran was able to floor Burns and even dislocate his jaw, but that the champion still managed to retain his title. The overall score favored Burns with two judges scoring 115-112 and 115-113 in his favor, while the third judge scored it a draw at 114-114.

Sir Alex Ferguson's Premier League champions responded in spectacular fashion to Manchester City's outstanding 5-1 win at Spurs by returning to the top of the table with a result that was every bit as emphatic. United put five past Fulham at Craven Cottage, with Robin van Persie scoring his first hat-trick for the club and Wayne Rooney netting twice. The victory moved United two points clear of City, albeit having played a game more, while also sending out a powerful message to their rivals that they remain a force to be reckoned with. The result was in no small part due to Ferguson's tactical acumen. He switched to a three-man midfield containing Michael Carrick, Tom Cleverley and Shinji Kagawa, allowing Rooney and van Persie the freedom to roam and exploit the space behind Fulham's defence. His decision to bring on Antonio Valencia late on also paid dividends, with the Ecuadorian adding yet another goal to the rout. In short, it was a masterclass from the veteran manager.

Media playback is unsupported on your device 13 September 2015 Last updated at 09:11 BST While they sing artist William Mackrell draws the bumps and swerves. His installation Gaps, Glitches and Glitches has been made in the grounds of Kensington Palace. The artwork is a response to sounds recorded outside the palace and the combination of their melodies, which Mackrell captured and then distorted. He said: "This is an exploration of the intangible qualities of sound, something that you can feel but not see. I'm really interested in how we experience sound and how it affects our perception of the environment." The installation consists of two giant slinkies made from steel and aluminium wire, suspended 8 metres above the ground. As visitors walk through the sculpture, the vibrations cause the wires to move and hum, creating a haunting soundscape. Mackrell added: "It's a kind of architectural drawing in space - a three-dimensional drawing that changes as you move around it, so it becomes like a movable drawing or sculpture."

The Confederation of African Football (Caf) are inviting new bidders for the tournament. Caf say that countries wishing to host the tournament have until 30 September to express their interest. Caf say that the criteria for bidders include: the technical quality of the stadiums, infrastructure, hotels, safety and security measures, transport and communication facilities, marketing proposals, and other aspects. They also want to ensure that the host country has a strong commitment to developing football in Africa. As part of the bid process, Caf will conduct an initial assessment of each candidate country.
