This will be followed by a detailed evaluation of the bids before the final selection is made.

Police said that someone opened fire from a passing car and witnesses spoke of up to a dozen shots being fired close to the main police station. "Nothing is known about the identity of the attackers," a police spokesman said. The attack happened early in the morning and police have closed off the area while they investigate. There have been no reports of any injuries or fatalities. It is also not known whether the attack was related to terrorism.

Dartmoor Hill Pony Association (DHPA) said it had put forward the idea "reluctantly." The group claims numbers have dropped from about 30,000 at the beginning of the century to just 2,000 now, and that a registration system would help protect the ponies. The DHPA said it was not advocating for a full-scale registration scheme, but rather a voluntary one. The group said it wanted to ensure that high quality Dartmoor Hill Ponies remain in the population, by providing owners with an incentive to register their animals. This would also provide assurance to potential buyers that the pony they were buying was of good quality. The proposal has been met with mixed reactions from pony enthusiasts, with some questioning whether such a scheme is necessary or practical. Some have argued that there is no real way to verify a pony's pedigree or quality without rigorous testing, while others have argued that such a scheme could be abused by unscrupulous traders. The British Horse Society (BHS) has backed the DHPA's proposal, saying that it could help protect the welfare of the ponies and prevent them being exploited. It said that any scheme should be based on "robust" data collection, which includes microchipping, health checks and genetic testing. The BHS is encouraging anyone who owns a Dartmoor Hill Pony to consider registering it voluntarily, and said that this could help to ensure the future of the breed.

The 22-year-old, who is on a season-long loan at Turkish side Kasimpasa from Chelsea, has been told by the team doctor he needs time to recover. "I feel sad about the injury, but I'm doing my best to get back as soon as possible," he said. He is unlikely to play again this season and will return to Chelsea in the summer. He has made nine appearances for Kasimpasa so far this season, scoring one goal. Kenedy had impressed at the start of his spell with the Turkish club, making four appearances in all competitions before the injury. Last summer, Chelsea decided to send him on loan due to a lack of first-team opportunities in west London.

Nick Hardwick said staff shortages, population pressures and prison policy all contributed to problems, with a 69 rise in self-inflicted deaths. The Ministry of Justice said there was no evidence to suggest the increase was linked to staffing levels. Nick Hardwick noted that staffing shortages, population pressures, and prison policy all had a role to play in the 69 increase in self-inflicted deaths of inmates. However, the Ministry of Justice argued that there is no evidence to suggest that this increase was linked to staffing levels.

The force said paedophile hunter activities can hinder investigations and lead to offenders walking free. Det Ch Supt Tom Richards of Kent Police said it also diverts resources away from protecting the vulnerable. He said: "We have real concerns about vigilantes taking the law into their own hands and carrying out investigations, as this can put children at further risk of harm and undermine police investigations. "We understand that people may feel strongly about child abuse and want to take action, but we would urge them not to do this and instead to report any suspicions or information they may have to the police so that it can be investigated properly."

Many people have been reluctant to seek medical treatment for Ebola, fearing that diagnosis might mean death as there is no proven cure. A team of 30,000 people is going door-to-door in affected countries to encourage people to seek treatment, and provide education on how to avoid the spread of the virus. They are also providing information about the treatments and services available at health centers. In some cases, they are providing transportation to health centers for those who cannot afford it. The teams also offer psychosocial support to those affected by Ebola, such as counseling and bereavement services for those who have lost loved ones to Ebola.

The boar - which has a moving head - is one of a number of animated replica creatures at Mountfitchet Castle. Staff at the site, an open air museum, were so taken with the creature that they decided to keep it as part of the attraction. The boar is made from plastic and has a motorized head, which moves up and down. Its eyes light up and it makes sounds. It stands about three feet tall and is painted in browns and blacks.

The next public consultation in the Greater Manchester Spatial Framework (GMSF) scheme was due in September but may not be published until summer 2018. Regional mayor Andy Burnham promised to publish the draft GMSF in spring 2018 but this has been delayed due to a number of issues. The plan proposes to build up to 200,000 new homes across Greater Manchester over the next 20 years, alongside transport and infrastructure improvements. It includes measures to protect green belt land and ensure development is focused on areas where there are existing services and facilities. The delay in publishing the draft GMSF means that the public consultation will likely take place later than anticipated. However, the Greater Manchester Combined Authority (GMCA) is still working hard to make sure the plan meets local needs and takes into account all views from across the region. The GMCA is holding a series of workshops throughout the summer to ensure everyone's voice can be heard, and the feedback from these events will be used to shape the GMSF. Once the draft plan has been published, there will be an additional period of public consultation before any final recommendations are made.

Police initially said that business rivalry was a more likely motive for the attack on the Movida bar restaurant outside Kuala Lumpur on 28 June. They added that two men on a motorcycle threw a hand grenade at the restaurant, but that no one was hurt. However, police later said they were now looking into the possibility that the attack may have been linked to terrorism. The country's Inspector-General of Police, Khalid Abu Bakar, said it was too early to confirm whether the incident was related to terrorism, but added that police would investigate all angles. The attack comes amid heightened security in Malaysia, following recent attacks by the Islamic State (IS) group in neighbouring countries such as Indonesia and the Philippines. Malaysia has also seen a spate of Islamic State-inspired attacks in recent months, including one in April where a grenade was thrown at a nightclub in Kuala Lumpur.

England's win over South Africa on Sunday secured the Twenty20 series. The game was officially sold out, as were England's two ICC Champions Trophy matches at the SSE Swalec Stadium. England won the match by nine wickets, with Joe Root and Alex Hales contributing 95 and 78 runs respectively. The victory sealed the series win for England, as they had already won the first T20 international on Friday. This is the first time that England have won a T20 series against South Africa.

The Scottish airline believes the flights, from 15 October, will attract passengers working in the offshore energy industries. The routes will be operated by 33-seat Saab 340 aircraft. Durham Tees Valley Airport business development director, Richard Airey, said: "We are delighted to welcome Loganair on board and look forward to a long and successful partnership. "The new service will be of great benefit to the offshore energy sector, providing an essential link between Teesside and the North Sea oil and gas platforms." Loganair managing director, Jonathan Hinkles, added: "This is a major step for Loganair as we continue to expand our network of routes from Durham Tees Valley and bring further benefits to our customers in the North. "The new flights will open up convenient connections between the key hubs of Newcastle and Aberdeen, providing a valuable air link for businesses and leisure travellers alike."

Leaving the union would see prices rise and threaten jobs, the prime minister said, in a move seen as an attempt to reach out to Labour voters. Writing in the Sunday Telegraph, David Cameron said the UK should stay in a reformed EU because it is "good for jobs, good for British business and good for our national security." He acknowledged that people had concerns about the EU but argued that the risk posed by leaving was too great. "The question we have to ask ourselves is this: do we want to be part of this European Union - with all its flaws - or not? I say yes, and I will make the positive case for Britain to remain in the EU." He added that he wanted to see reforms to the way the EU works, including reducing red tape, cutting the cost of bureaucracy and protecting jobs.

Paul captured global attention after he successfully predicted the results of all of Germany's seven games at the 2010 World Cup, as well as the final. Each time he opened a mussel and revealed the flag of the winning team. Paul's predictions made him an international celebrity, and he has been featured in several documentaries and news articles. He was even presented with a signed German national team jersey by the players themselves. Paul also became an honorary member of the Sea Life Centre in Oberhausen, Germany, where he had lived since 2008. After his death in October 2010, his body was taxidermied and is now on display at the centre.

Ben, from Sheffield, was 21 months old when he disappeared from near a farmhouse in Iraklis on 24 July 1991. The site, which is 750m from where he was last seen, has been extensively searched by police, firefighters, and volunteers. Ben's disappearance sparked a massive search effort in Greece and beyond, involving hundreds of people, including police divers and helicopters, to try to find him. Despite all the efforts, Ben has never been found and his whereabouts remain unknown to this day. The case remains open and police have not ruled out foul play. In 2010, a Greek court convicted two men of kidnapping Ben and sentenced them to life in prison, but their convictions were later overturned on appeal due to lack of evidence. The search for Ben continues, with Ben's parents still hoping that one day he will be found. Over the years, multiple theories have been suggested as to what happened to Ben, but none have been proven and his fate remains a mystery.

Patrick Ewing, 66, collapsed at his home in Oakham, Rutland, and was given resuscitation by his partner, Yvonne Ainsworth. Paramedics used a defibrillator to shock Mr Ewing to restore his heart rhythm, and he was taken to the Queen's Medical Centre in Nottingham. Mr Ewing is in a stable condition and is being monitored by doctors at the hospital. His family have asked for privacy as they are still trying to determine what caused the collapse. They are grateful for all the support and best wishes they have received from friends and colleagues during this difficult time.

Marco Goncalves, 34, assaulted the referee after being sent off in last month's game against Rio Tinto, and was escorted off the pitch by police. Images of the attack went viral on social media, and he was subsequently banned from playing in the league for one year. The attack was a serious breach of sportsmanship and a violation of the rules of the game. As a result, Goncalves must accept the sanctions imposed by the league and abide by them. Additionally, he should seek counseling to understand why his actions were wrong and how to prevent similar behavior in the future. It is also important that he apologize to the referee for his actions and show remorse for what he has done. Finally, it is necessary to stress the importance of respecting referees and other players in order to keep everyone safe on the field.

The Labour leader has warned the terms of reference, which have yet to be published, could be too "narrow" and residents not properly consulted. He wants an interim report on the findings of the inquiry, which could take up to two years, ready by the end of this year. Mr Corbyn has promised a package of measures to help Grenfell survivors and their families, including free legal advice for those affected, financial help with housing costs and mental health support. He said Labour would also bring in laws to ensure all social housing meets "the highest standards of fire safety." The Prime Minister has promised that lessons will be learnt from the tragedy and taken action to make sure it never happens again. She has set up a public inquiry and pledged to carry out an independent review into building regulations and fire safety.

Tigers are fifth after a season of struggle which has seen them sack director of rugby Richard Cockerill. They are in danger of missing out on a top-four finish in the Premiership and have been unable to keep pace with the leading teams. The Tigers have had some good performances this season, particularly in Europe where they reached the quarter-finals of the Champions Cup. However, their lack of consistency has cost them and they have struggled to put together a run of wins in the league. The Tigers will need to regroup for next season if they are to challenge for a top-four finish. They must strengthen their squad and bring in some new faces to provide competition for places. They will also look to improve their defence and work on developing their attack. Overall, it has been a disappointing season for the Tigers but one which could act as a learning experience for the club as they look to build for the future.

Matthew Daley, 35, denies murder but has admitted attacking 79-year-old retired solicitor Donald Lock claiming diminished responsibility. Lynda Daley agreed at Lewes Crown Court the day Mr Lock was killed that she and her partner had been discussing the possibility of marriage. Mr Daley has pleaded not guilty to murder but admitted manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

The system can involve withdrawal of medication, food and fluids. It can offer a peaceful and dignified death but there have been problems with its implementation, the government-commissioned review is looking at the process in England and Wales. The review will seek to ensure that the system is not abused or misused, and safeguards are in place to protect vulnerable people. It will also consider how best to support those making decisions about end-of-life care and their families. The review may recommend changes to legislation and guidance to ensure the system operates properly.

Knight Frank found transaction volumes in the Granite City fell from over PS600m in 2014 to only PS55m last year. Investment in offices alone slumped from PS500m in 2014 to just PS17m in 2015. The research firm found that while Aberdeen's investment market is highly cyclical, with activity peaking in 2014 and taking a nosedive since then, the city remains attractive to investors looking for long-term potential. The city's strong education and healthcare sectors, as well as its position as a hub for energy production and services, provide an opportunity for investors to gain access to new markets and diversify their portfolios. Despite the slump in investment volumes, Knight Frank said rental values have remained relatively stable, and there has been some evidence of a pick up in the office sector, although this is largely due to existing tenants expanding or relocating within the city.

The 28-year-old has scored 37 goals in 98 appearances since joining the Lions from non-league Halifax in 2014. "Lee committing his future to us is a big boost for everybody ," said manager Neil Harris. "He's been a huge part of our success over the past few seasons and he continues to develop and improve as a player." Gregory has scored 16 goals in 35 appearances for Millwall this season, including an impressive hat-trick against West Bromwich Albion in February. His goals have helped Millwall to fourth place in the Championship table, putting them in contention for promotion to the Premier League.

Their lawyers had asked the court to declare "unlawful" the consultation process that led to the proposed axing of the PS320m fund. The five are among 19,000 people who receive benefits from the fund. Their lawyers argued that the government had failed to give proper consideration to the impact of their decision on the claimants, who rely on the fund to pay for essential services such as home care, respite care and adaptations to their homes. The court said that while it sympathised with the claimants' plight, it could not find any legal grounds on which to declare the consultation process unlawful. It also noted that the government had taken steps to ensure that those affected by the proposed cuts had been consulted in a meaningful way. The court did, however, express concern at the lack of information provided to the claimants about the potential impact of the proposals. It urged the government to ensure that future consultations are more transparent and provide more detail to claimants about the potential consequences of changes to their benefits.

The Asia Pacific, excluding Japan, held 47 trillion (PS30tn) in private wealth last year as the number of new millionaires rose in China and India. North America is the world's wealthiest region, with a combined PS47.6tn in private wealth, followed by Europe with PS44.4tn and Japan with PS17.9tn. The Asia Pacific is the fastest-growing region for wealth creation, according to a report from consultancy Capgemini. The number of millionaires in the region rose 11.3 on 2016, while the total amount of wealth held increased 10. China was the main driver of growth in the region, with its wealth increasing 15.2 to PS14.1tn. India was the second-biggest contributor, with wealth rising 11.5 to PS7.5tn. The report said the growth was due to rising incomes, buoyant stock markets, and favourable currency exchange rates. It also noted that the Asia Pacific's share of global wealth is expected to rise from 24.8 in 2017 to 28.2 by 2022.

The club's latest accounts, for the year ending May 2014, also show the Bluebirds owe around PS174m - most of it to owner Vincent Tan. This was despite revenue increasing to PS91m, a rise of almost PS10m on the previous season. The accounts also showed that the club's wage bill had risen to PS43.1m - up from PS40.8m in the previous year - representing 47 of the club's turnover. The club had made a pre-tax loss of just under PS30m for the year ending May 2014. The club's financial position has been a source of controversy since Tan took over in 2010. He has invested heavily in the club and has also funded a number of high-profile signings including Wilfried Zaha, Steven Caulker and Gary Medel. However, his ownership has come in for criticism due to his controversial decision to rebrand Cardiff City in 2012, when he changed their home kit colour from blue to red.

The Northern Ireland Rare Disease Partnership aims to give sufferers and their carers an independent voice. The group, created with the Patient Client Council, aims to improve treatment and care for people living with rare diseases in Northern Ireland. The group will provide a platform for patients, carers and campaigners to share their experiences and raise awareness of the issues they face. They will work with key stakeholders to ensure that the voice of those affected by rare diseases is heard and acted upon. The group aims to provide support and advice to those affected and to promote better understanding and information sharing between service providers, healthcare professionals and patients.

The Executive Office said the move was made "to enable doctors to conduct a medical assessment." Mr McGuinness was due to join the first minister on the trade mission. A spokeswoman said the decision was taken "in the best interests of Martin McGuinness." The move comes amid ongoing political tensions between the UK and Irish governments over Brexit. Last month, the DUP and Sinn Fein accused each other of "playing politics" in the negotiations to restore power-sharing in Northern Ireland. The two parties have been at loggerheads since the collapse of the devolved government in January 2017.

In May, 14 Fifa officials and sports marketing executives were indicted in the US on racketeering charges involving more than 150m (PS97m). "Substantial evidence" has been gathered so far, according to the US justice department, and further investigations into the scandal are ongoing. The US Department of Justice has alleged that the defendants were involved in a long-running scheme to solicit and receive bribes and kickbacks from sports marketing firms in exchange for media and marketing rights to major international soccer tournaments. The charges include wire fraud, money laundering, and racketeering. Additionally, two Fifa executives were also accused of bribery. The investigation is ongoing and further indictments may be forthcoming as the US authorities continue to probe into the corruption allegations. It is expected that more details about the case will emerge over the coming months.

The team discovered a set of 12,000-year-old Ice Age stone tools while excavating Rubha Port an t-Seilich, on Islay in the Inner Hebrides. The tools included scrapers used for cleaning animal hides and engraver tools used for creating art. The team believes that the findings indicate that humans were living in Islay during the Ice Age, which is much earlier than previously thought. This finding could provide insight into how humans adapted to the extreme climate changes during this period.

He was speaking after crowds in Tehran cheered negotiators who had agreed to curb some of Iran's nuclear activities in return for sanctions relief. The six-month interim deal agreed in Geneva on Sunday is intended to open the way for a final agreement that would ensure Iran does not develop nuclear weapons. But some hardliners in Iran have expressed anger at the deal, saying it goes too far in curbing Tehran's nuclear activities. Mr Obama said: "I understand the scepticism... I don't blame people for being sceptical. We have to work through a long process in which the world has confidence that, in fact, they're not pursuing a nuclear weapon." The president also said he was confident that if the negotiations over a permanent deal failed, the US and its allies had the capacity to exercise options that would keep Iran from developing a nuclear weapon. He added: "We will continue to put pressure on them and increase pressure on them until they take a different course."

The projection from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) shows a far-reaching shift in the balance of graduate numbers, with the rising Asian economies accelerating ahead of the West. This is due to the fact that countries like India and China have experienced a surge in the number of college graduates, while the West has seen its numbers decline. The OECD estimates that by 2030, nearly half of the world's tertiary educated population will be Asian, compared to just over a third in 2020. This shift is likely to have significant implications for global economic trends and international labour markets. In particular, there could be a surge of competition for jobs in the Western world from high-skilled workers from Asia. It could also create a new divide between high-and low-skilled work, with lower wages for those without a degree. Additionally, it could put pressure on Western governments to invest more heavily in their education systems and research and development, in order to keep up with their Asian counterparts.

The Carneddau Landscape Partnership has been awarded PS198,700 Heritage Lottery funding to help it manage the natural and cultural heritage of the area. It claims the mountains' archaeology, ecology, peatland and traditional land use will be protected and enhanced. The Carneddau Landscape Partnership is a five-year project which aims to conserve, protect and promote the special qualities of the Carneddau mountain range in North Wales. Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, the project will involve local communities, schools, universities and organisations working together to protect and improve the natural and cultural heritage of the area. The project will focus on improving access for people of all abilities, preserving and restoring important archaeological sites, conserving and enhancing habitats and species, and engaging with local communities to help them understand and appreciate the unique landscape. By the end of the five-year period, the project hopes to have created a lasting legacy for the Carneddau mountains and their surrounding areas.

Kaori Okuni, one of the women campaigning for change, said the ruling would lead to "suffering for those who plan to marry and those who are set to be born." "The decision shows how the Japanese government is not listening to the voices of LGBT people and their families," she said. "It's really a shame." Okuni added that the lack of legal recognition for same-sex relationships in Japan was a violation of human rights, and urged the government to take action to protect the rights of LGBT people. "It's time for the Japanese government to seriously consider how it can recognize same-sex relationships," she said. "We will continue to push for change until our basic human rights are recognized."

The aircraft, nicknamed "Bette" after one of its pilot's girlfriends, was built in 1941 from donations from the Borough of Lambeth Spitfire Fund. It was stationed in Cornwall, Hampshire, Norfolk , Suffolk and Kent during World War II. The aircraft saw extensive service in the Battle of Britain and later in the Mediterranean and Middle East theatres. It was credited with four confirmed kills and seven probables. In 1943 it was damaged in an accident while flying a training mission and had to be retired from active service. It was then used as a trainer before being donated to the Royal Air Force Museum in 1967. Today, "Bette" is on display at The Royal Air Force Museum in London. It is one of the few remaining original Spitfires still in existence and serves as a reminder of the courage and bravery of those who flew it during the war.

Alice's family had asked for the scope of the inquest to include why Arnis Zalkalns was allowed to live unchecked in the UK. The chief suspect who was jailed for Alice's murder, Arnis Zalkalns, had a criminal record in his native country of Latvia, which included serving a prison sentence for murdering his wife. The inquest heard that he was not placed on any UK watchlist and that the British authorities had no knowledge of his prior conviction when he arrived in the UK in 2007. The coroner made a number of recommendations to the Government at the conclusion of the inquest, including the introduction of a European-wide alert system for those with convictions abroad, and ensuring that police forces across the UK share all relevant information about known offenders. He also called on the Home Office to consider introducing tougher border controls for convicted criminals from outside the EU.

The Academy Selsey suffered extensive damage and much of its contents was destroyed in the blaze on 21 August. The school's 453 pupils are currently being taught at four locations across the area. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, but officials have said that it is likely to have been an electrical fault. The school has started a fundraising appeal to help rebuild the school and replace the damaged equipment. The school's staff and pupils have been praised for their resilience and determination in the face of this devastating event.

Figures shared with 5 live Investigates by the charity RoadPeace reveal a 23 drop in prosecutions in England and Wales in the five years to 2015. In the same period , the number of people killed or seriously injured on British roads rose by 6. The figures suggest that there has been a reduction in the effectiveness of the prosecution system for road traffic offences. This is concerning, as enforcement is an important tool in encouraging drivers to adhere to the law and reduce casualties. It is also possible that other factors have contributed to the rise in serious injuries and fatalities on the roads. These could include an increase in traffic volume, changes in driving behaviour or a lack of investment in safer infrastructure or improved education campaigns.

His widow Daphne phoned the PM's office on Saturday to "kindly decline" the offer, Mr Abbott said. The commentator himself had wished for "something very, very quiet and very, very private" in terms of his funeral arrangements. Daphne Howson, the widow of broadcaster Bill Peach, leaves St Mary's Cathedral following a memorial service for her husband. Credit:Dean Sewell The Prime Minister said he was disappointed but respected Daphne Howson's wishes. He described Mr Peach as "one of the great figures of Australian television." "He was a giant in so many ways," Mr Abbott said on Sunday.

A firmer dollar in the aftermath of the first Clinton-Trump presidential debate helped send gold prices lower. The Dow Jones Average was up 0.74 to 18,174, while the more tech-related NASDAQ was up 0.44 to 5,301. The US dollar index rose 0.27 percent to 95.80, sending gold prices down 0.11 percent to 1,331.50 an ounce. Silver prices also declined, falling 0.76 percent to 19.12 an ounce. The debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump caused a shift in investor sentiment, as the dollar strengthened against other major currencies. This put pressure on gold prices, which had been rising over the past few weeks due to expectations of further stimulus from the Federal Reserve. The increased demand for the US dollar that came after the debate reflects investors' preferences for safe-haven investments, such as the greenback. Meanwhile, oil prices were little changed after the debate, with West Texas Intermediate crude trading at 44.54 a barrel, up 0.01 percent. Oil prices have been weighed down by worries about oversupply and weak global demand. The next presidential debate is scheduled for October 9, so it remains to be seen if investors will continue to favor the dollar or if gold prices will rebound as investors look to take advantage of any uncertainty surrounding the election.

Ivan Cameron, who had cerebral palsy and epilepsy, died in hospital aged six in February 2009. Mrs Cameron told the Times: "Ive dying is such a massive thing that everything else pales into insignificance. We miss him every single day and our lives will never be the same without him. We are extremely proud of Ivan - he was a very special boy and touched the hearts of all who met him."

Smith, 34, lost WBO title bouts with Arthur Abraham in 2014 and 2015, and trainer Joe Gallagher said Saturday's fight was a "last roll of the dice." The Briton has been inactive after the loss to Abraham, and was forced to take a long break from the sport due to personal issues. Smith responded with an impressive performance, outboxing Andrade over 12 rounds and winning via unanimous decision (118-110, 117-111, 116-112). He earned the right to challenge for the WBO super middleweight title against Gilberto Ramirez, who is undefeated in 36 professional bouts. Smith said he hopes to put on a show when he fights Ramirez, and prove that he has not lost a step since his layoff. "I'm really looking forward to it," Smith said. "I've been out of the ring for a while but I'm ready to get back in there and show everyone what I can do."

But when Paul Gascoigne appeared on BT Sport's Fletch and Sav show, everyone listened, including Russell. For all of Gazza's amazing moments on the pitch, he's also known for his struggles off it. So when Fletch asked him if he had any advice for young footballers, his answer cut right to the heart of the matter. "If I could give them one bit of advice," said Gazza, "it'd be look after yourself, don't make the same mistakes as I did. Look after your body and your mind." It was a brutally honest assessment from the former England star, who has battled with addiction for much of his life. And it's a message that Russell clearly took to heart. "That's really important what he said," said Russell. "I think it's something that all young footballers should take on board. It's so easy to get caught up in the moment and forget about the long-term consequences of your actions." Russell is not alone in taking Gazza's advice to heart. In recent years, there has been a growing awareness among footballers of the importance of looking after their mental health. And Gazza's words are a reminder that even the most talented players can have struggles off the pitch. If we can learn anything from Gazza's story, it's that no one is immune to mental health issues.

Andronicos Sideras, 55, is accused of mixing horsemeat with beef before selling it on through his company Dinos Sons. Two men who ran FlexiFoods - a meat suppliers linked to Sideras - have also been charged with fraudulently labeling horsemeat as beef. Sideras and the two other men are accused of defrauding customers by falsely labeling products and knowingly sold horsemeat instead of beef. They are facing charges of fraud, mislabeling and breaching food safety regulations. If convicted, they could face up to five years in prison and significant fines. The trial is expected to begin later this year.

The 39-year-old Englishman has not played in a competitive match since the World Championship quarter-finals in April, and has not entered next week's UK Snooker Championship. "I do want a break," he told BBC Sport. "It's been a long time since I've taken a break, and I'm looking forward to it. The plan is just to take some time out - relax, get away from the game and enjoy life. I have no plans to compete in any tournaments until further notice. I want to keep my focus on other things, such as my family, friends, music and other interests. The decision was made after much deliberation. I am confident that taking some time off will be beneficial for me in the long run. It will also provide a good opportunity for me to spend more time with my family and friends, and recharge my batteries for whatever lies ahead. In the mean time, I'll continue to practice and work on improving my game. This break will give me the opportunity to reflect on where I am at, and how I can further develop my snooker skills. I look forward to returning to the game refreshed and recharged when the time is right.

Joseph Fox photographed the mudlarkers who comb the shore of London's River Thames. Originally a term for the city's poor who scraped a meagre living by scavenging in the river's mud, today's mudlarkers search the riverbed for artefacts, such as pottery and coins, which offer a fascinating insight into London's past. Fox spent time with mudlarkers on both sides of the Thames, exploring their motivations, expertise and stories. He wanted to capture a sense of how they experience the river and what it means to them. The resulting series of photographs captures the unique character of the city's river - from the early morning mists to the shifting light and the stillness of the water. It also reveals the mudlarkers' individual stories, as they seek out their treasures in the mud.

The research, by William C Campbell, Satoshi Omura and Youyou Tu, has led to drugs to treat diseases affecting more than 3.4 billion people around the world. One of them, Avermectin, has been used to treat river blindness, a parasitic disease that can cause blindness and is spread by blackflies. It has also been used to treat other parasitic diseases including lymphatic filariasis and scabies. The research team was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2015 for their work on avermectin. The researchers identified a new family of compounds from a soil bacterium and developed them into a drug that has revolutionized the treatment of parasitic diseases. Their work has greatly improved the health of millions of people who live in areas where these diseases are endemic.

A public consultation has opened on the new proposals, which include a single tower rather than two skyscrapers, for the Jackson's Row area of the city. The former Manchester United stars, Ryan Giggs and Gary Neville, have submitted plans for the redevelopment of the site. The new design includes a hotel, office space, retail units, apartments, and public areas. The consultation will give local people and businesses a chance to comment on the proposed development before it is taken any further. All comments must be submitted in writing by the closing date of 8th June 2021. The Manchester City Council has advised that all comments should include an email address or postal address. They also suggest that anyone who wishes to take part in the consultation should read the full proposal document carefully before submitting their comments. The consultation is open to everyone, including members of the public, local businesses and other stakeholders. The council is keen to hear from as many people as possible about the proposals and will be considering all responses. A report on the consultation will be published following its closure.

Media playback is unsupported on your device 9 July 2015 Last updated at 09:20 BST The Patron's Lunch will be attended by 10,000 guests - many from charities supported by The Queen - as well as members of the Royal Family The event is part of a weekend of celebrations for the Queen's 90th birthday It will be held in the Mall, near Buckingham Palace, and will feature food from all parts of the UK BBC royal correspondent Peter Hunt says it will be the "largest ever picnic" The menu includes a selection of sandwiches, salads, cakes, pastries and scones, as well as traditional British dishes such as fish and chips and roast beef. There will also be a range of drinks including tea, coffee, soft drinks, beer and Pimms. Organisers are also putting on entertainment throughout the day, with performances by military bands, choirs, street theatre and dance groups. The event is free to attend, but guests have been asked to make a donation to one of the charities supported by The Queen.

6 January 2016 Last updated at 12:15 GMT The technology lets people physically feel the buttons displayed on a touchscreen, which could help drivers keep their eyes on the road. The technology, called haptic feedback, has been developed by a team from the University of Bristol in the UK. It works by using an array of tiny actuators to create a 3D model of virtual buttons and sliders on a touchscreen. When users interact with the display, the actuators vibrate and move in order to generate a physical sensation. The researchers say the system could be used to help reduce driver distraction by allowing them to control features such as their car's navigation and climate control without looking away from the road. The team also believes their invention could be used to help people with impaired vision, who struggle to use touchscreen devices.

The Reds looked in control when Roberto Firmino converted James Milner's pass and Daniel Sturridge backheeled to Sadio Mane to clip home a second. But Leicester were given hope when Jamie Vardy tapped in for his 20th goal of the campaign and Danny Drinkwater forced a save from Simon Mignolet. The Reds were able to take some of the sting out of the game when Sturridge added a third, but they had to endure a tense finale when Shinji Okazaki scrambled in a consolation. Jurgen Klopp's side, however, held on to record their first league win since December 14 and move into eighth place - eight points off the top four with two games in hand. Leicester remain second but they are now five points behind leaders Arsenal, who have a game in hand. Klopp made three changes following Liverpool's 0-0 draw at Sunderland last time out, with Divock Origi and Lucas Leiva coming into the midfield, while Kolo Toure replaced Martin Skrtel at centre-back. Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri made four alterations as he looked to bounce back from the Foxes' FA Cup exit against Tottenham. Andy King and Demarai Gray came in for the injured duo of N'Golo Kante (hamstring) and Marc Albrighton (ankle), while Okazaki and Nathan Dyer were also brought in. After an even start, the visitors took the lead on 27 minutes when Milner's pass was volleyed home by Firmino at the far post after Leicester failed to clear their lines properly. Leicester almost responded immediately when Drinkwater's long-range effort forced a smart save from Mignolet, before Origi tested Kasper Schmeichel with a powerful drive from 20 yards. The hosts had an even better chance to level just before the break when Jeffrey Schlupp found space in the box, but his close-range effort was blocked brilliantly by Toure. Liverpool doubled their lead four minutes after the restart when Mane converted from close range after being teed up by Sturridge. And it should have been 3-0 moments later when Schmeichel parried Milner's effort straight to Origi, only for the Belgian to fire over with the goal gaping. Leicester were handed a lifeline on 63 minutes when Vardy nodded in Riyad Mahrez's cross, and Drinkwater then stung the palms of Mignolet with a fierce drive from 25 yards. But any hopes of a Leicester comeback were ended nine minutes from time when Sturridge capitalised on some poor defending to slot home his first league goal since October. Okazaki added a late consolation for Leicester, but it was not enough to deny Liverpool the win.

The 28-year-old footballer's contract was terminated hours after he was dropped for Saturday's Premier League match against Manchester United. He will stand trial on Friday on two further counts of sexual assault. The charges relate to an alleged incident in December 2018, when the player is alleged to have kissed and groped a woman without her consent at his home in Hale, Cheshire. He denies all charges. The footballer has not been named due to a court order, but it is understood he was signed by the club in June 2019. The club said in a statement: "We take seriously any allegations of this nature, and after careful consideration, we have decided to terminate the player's contract with immediate effect. "Any further comment on this matter, or any other matters relating to the case, will be made in due course."

She had come prepared to own up to her mistakes, apologising to the gathered throng just as a few hours earlier she had apologised to the cabinet. It had been a difficult decision to make, but she had done what she thought was best. She was ready to accept the consequences and move on. The response she received was overwhelming. People from all walks of life expressed their support and understanding, with many praising her for her bravery and integrity in owning up to her mistakes. It was clear that her honesty had earned her a great deal of respect and admiration, and it was an experience she would never forget.

Four tickets were purchased by Bournville College in Birmingham under former principal Norman Cave, a Freedom of Information request has revealed. The Longbridge further education college also held a PS170,000 contract to provide adult education services to the city council. The tickets were bought from the college's adult and community learning department in 200809. The purpose of the purchase was not specified but it is believed they were for staff members or students.

Eight year-old Phoebe Hanson wrote to BBC Radio 4's PM saying she worried how the "bongs" would be replaced while Big Ben is being repaired next year. PM's editor, Roger Sawyer, decided to write back to her. Dear Phoebe, Thank you for your letter to PM about Big Ben. It's a very interesting question and one that has been asked a lot since it was announced that the famous bell at the Houses of Parliament is to be silenced while repairs are carried out next year. The good news is that the bongs will not be lost while Big Ben is being repaired. The House of Commons has revealed plans to install a modernized version of the chimes - known as 'quarter bells' - in the tower while Big Ben is restored. This version of the bells is expected to sound every 15 minutes and will ensure that the famous chimes are still heard throughout Westminster. We hope this answer helps to alleviate your concerns about Big Ben and the bongs! Best wishes, Roger Sawyer Editor, PM

The 58-year-old school principal from Dublin won 144 out of a possible 278 votes and was 98 ahead of his nearest rivals Sean Walsh and Frank Burke. Horan will take over from outgoing principal Joe O'Reilly.

Now, as Jaguar Land Rover announces plans to create an extra 1,700 jobs at its base in Solihull - on top of 800 created in January - is the West Midlands finally coming out of recession? It is too early to say definitively whether the West Midlands is coming out of recession. While these job growth numbers are encouraging, there are still signs of economic weakness in the region, such as rising unemployment and stagnant wages. The region is also facing a number of challenges, including Brexit uncertainty, rising costs for businesses, and the impact of automation on existing jobs. Nevertheless, the 1,700 job creation announcement from Jaguar Land Rover is certainly a sign that the West Midlands economy is beginning to turn a corner.

Friars Walk has been years in the planning and the development ground to a halt in the 2008 financial crisis. Now it is opening with Debenhams as its anchor store . The development of Friars Walk began in 2008, but was delayed due to the global financial crisis. After years of planning and refurbishment, Debenhams opened its doors as the anchor store for the shopping centre in November 2015. The retail centre also includes a range of other stores, restaurants and leisure facilities, including Odeon Cinemas, Cineworld, Nando's and Frankie Benny's.

The Reds led in the 15th minute when Divock Origi flicked in from close range before Roberto Firmino made it 2-0, heading in Nathaniel Clyne's cross. Origi also went close with a volley and the hosts should have been out of sight by half-time. The visitors had a few chances of their own, with Olivier Giroud bringing a save from Alisson, while Bukayo Saka forced the Brazilian into action early in the second period. But Liverpool were never seriously threatened and sealed the points late on when substitute Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain fired home from the edge of the box. It was an impressive display from Jurgen Klopp's side, who moved to within three points of the top four, and here are five things we learned from the game... 1. Liverpool show attacking intent The Reds showed plenty of attacking intent from the outset, as Origi and Firmino combined to open the scoring inside 15 minutes. The hosts had an array of chances to extend their lead throughout the first half, with Origi going close with a volley and Sadio Mane narrowly missing the target with a header. Klopp's side continued to push forward after the break, but it wasn't until the introduction of Oxlade-Chamberlain that they finally found the third goal to seal the win. It was a performance full of attacking intent and one that will give the team confidence heading into the festive period.

Mr Blair said the party he used to lead should aspire to govern, rather than be a "fringe protest movement." He has been a vocal critic of leader Jeremy Corbyn, who was elected by the membership in 2015. Mr Blair said the party should be a "force for progress" with policies that are "for the mainstream majority." He added: "Our task is to make Labour again a party of government, and not just protest. We need to create a situation where at the next election, people see Labour as a potential government, not a fringe protest movement."

It's rare that the company delves too far into how the "magic" - as they call it - works. Their logic is a magic trick doesn't get better if you know how it's done. The basic idea behind their technology is that they use a combination of artificial intelligence and deep learning to provide customers with personalized recommendations. They have a proprietary algorithm which takes into account various factors such as user preferences, previous searches, browsing history, and purchase history. This data is then used to create a profile of the user and determine what products they may be interested in. The algorithm is designed to learn from user behavior over time, meaning that the more users interact with the platform, the better the recommendations become. The company also uses natural language processing (NLP) to understand customer queries and provide relevant results. They also use machine learning to track user interactions and optimize recommendations for each individual user. Finally, they utilize cloud-based services such as Amazon Web Services and Google Cloud Platform to store and process large amounts of data quickly and efficiently.

The end-of-season event gets under way on Sunday, with more than 250,000 spectators expected across eight days. Security is under review but the same measures are in place as last year. The Tour de France is one of the most watched sporting events in the world, and security is paramount. The French police have been working with the race organisers to ensure that all necessary steps are taken to provide a safe and secure environment for everyone involved. Security measures include enhanced identity checks, increased surveillance and control of vehicles entering the race route, and additional counter-terrorism measures. In addition, the use of drones has been banned along the entire route. Spectators are also encouraged to report any suspicious activity or behavior.

The end of last year saw growth across several sectors of the economy, but there are concerns about rising prices, skill shortages and falling sales. Manufacturers reported their highest growth rate in six years, driven by strong exports, while the service sector saw its best performance since 2016. Construction was also robust, with activity at a three-year high. However, inflation increased to its highest level in nearly four years, and business confidence dropped to its lowest level since the Brexit referendum in 2016. There are also mounting concerns about skill shortages and recruitment difficulties, as well as falling sales in some sectors. In addition, the UK economy remains highly uncertain due to Brexit negotiations and the possibility of a no-deal outcome. Overall, the end of 2018 showed strong growth across several sectors of the economy, but there are a number of headwinds that could impact performance in 2019.

The teenager suffered a serious leg injury in the fall at Devil's Cave in Chellow Dene, near Bradford, on Friday night. During the two-hour rescue, Calder Valley Search and Rescue Team (CVSRT) members had to abseil down 40ft cliffs in the dark, and use specialist stretchers to bring the casualty back up. The teenager was treated at the scene by paramedics before being airlifted to Leeds General Infirmary, where he is receiving treatment for his injury. CVSRT team leader Paul Henthorne said: "This was a very challenging rescue in difficult terrain, requiring a great deal of skill from our volunteers." He added: "We would like to thank everyone involved for their hard work, dedication and professionalism in bringing the casualty to safety."

Research suggests women will not earn as much as their male counterparts until 2069, nearly 100 years after the Equal Pay Act was introduced in 1970. Holyrood's economy, fair work and jobs secretary Fiona Hyslop said the figures were "shocking" and called on employers to take action: "These statistics are shocking. They show just how far we have to go in tackling the gender pay gap and achieving economic equality for women in Scotland. It is essential that employers take immediate action to ensure they comply with the law and are paying men and women equally for the same work. It is not acceptable that women in Scotland, or anywhere else, are still facing such a huge gap in what they earn compared to their male counterparts. We will continue to use all of the powers at our disposal to tackle this injustice, whether that's raising awareness of the gender pay gap reporting regulations or introducing a real living wage for all."

The 23-year-old, Ulster's Player of the Year, made his international debut for Ireland in the Six Nations game against England at Twickenham in February. McCloskey still had a year remaining on his current Ulster contract which was due to expire in the summer of 2020. McCloskey, who has made over 50 appearances for Ulster since making his debut in 2014, is a powerful ball-carrier and playmaker who can play at 12 or 13. He was also part of the Ireland squad that won the Grand Slam in 2018.

Amber Rudd told the BBC the manifesto was "not going to be identical to the last one" and said things had changed since 2015 because of Brexit. The target, set in the last manifesto, of reducing net migration to the tens of thousands "still stands," she added. Rudd said the party would "set out our plans on immigration" in due course and insisted that the manifesto was still a work in progress. She emphasized that the Conservatives would not be "abandoning our commitment to reduce net migration." The Conservatives will also consider introducing new measures to make sure the UK is attracting the "brightest and best" migrants, including a possible visa system for those coming to work in the UK after Brexit. The party may also review Britain's existing points-based immigration system. The Conservatives' manifesto will reflect the government's commitment to control migration through an effective border policy and measures to tackle illegal immigration. Rudd said the party would also look at reform of the asylum system, so that people who genuinely need protection can be helped, while those who do not should be "returned to their home country."

A deal was made by the two main parties and the British and Irish governments to resolve a crisis at Stormont. Solutions were found on issues over paramilitarism and welfare reform, which had been causing a political stalemate. The parties agreed to the formation of an Executive with Ministerial responsibility for the management of public services in Northern Ireland. They also agreed on the introduction of legislation to tackle paramilitarism and to provide protection for victims, as well as a new financial package that would help address economic and social issues. Additionally, solutions were found for language rights, marriage equality, LGBT rights, and other human rights issues.

Dywedodd Jeffrey John: "Yn eu barn nhw, byddai esgob sy'n hoyw yn peri gormod o drafferth." Gwadu'r honiadau mae Mainc Esgobion yr Eglwys yng Nghymru gan ddweud fod "yr holl Esgobion yn cefnogi'r safonau cyd-destun sydd wedi eu sefydlu a'u haddolygu ar gyfer yr holl fudiadau cydnabyddedig yng Nghymru." Mae Mainc Esgobion yr Eglwys yng Nghymru yn datgan nad oes unrhyw esgob sy'n mynd i droi ogwydd o'r safonau cyd-destun sydd wedi eu sefydlu a'u haddolygu. Roedd Jeffrey John yn anghytuno a'r honiadau, ond mae Mainc Esgobion yr Eglwys yng Nghymru yn dangos bod y safonau cyd-destun hynny'n cael eu cefnogi gan yr holl esgobion.

A group led by Americans Jason Levien and Steve Kaplan bought a controlling 60 stake in Swansea in a deal ratified by the Premier League on 1 July. They are the first American owners of a Premier League club. Levien and Kaplan are part of a consortium which purchased a controlling 60 stake in Swansea City from previous majority owners Huw Jenkins, Martin Morgan, and Leigh Dineen. The deal was approved by the English Premier League on July 1, 2016. Levien and Kaplan are the first Americans to own a Premier League club. Since their acquisition, Swansea City has seen a significant investment in both its playing squad and training facilities.

The systems, at Kentucky Methodist Hospital, Chino Valley Medical Center and Desert Valley Hospital, California, are now running normally again. None of the hospitals is believed to have paid the ransom. The systems were restored as a result of the hospitals' IT teams working with outside experts to resolve the issue. At Kentucky Methodist Hospital, the ransomware attack forced the hospital to temporarily suspend some services and re-direct patients to other facilities for care. The hospital has since resumed full operations. Chino Valley Medical Center was also impacted by the attack, but was able to continue providing patient care without interruption. Similarly, Desert Valley Hospital in California was able to continue providing patient care during the incident. The hospitals have not released any details on the exact nature of the attack or how it was resolved. However, they have indicated that preventive measures have been taken to ensure similar incidents do not occur in the future. These measures may include updating software regularly, patching known vulnerabilities, and implementing strong security protocols such as two-factor authentication.

Isabelle and Stanley Larson from Oxted, Surrey, were burgled in October 2005. The Marine Policing Unit's dive team were working on an unrelated case at Slade Ponds when they recovered a number of stolen items belonging to the Larsons, including jewellery and cash. The Marine Policing Unit used evidence from CCTV footage to identify the suspects and arrested them on suspicion of burglary. The suspects were subsequently charged with burglary and appeared in court. Following a successful prosecution, they were found guilty and sentenced to three years in prison.

Media playback is not supported on this device The 34-year-old beat three-time champion Tony Martin by 26.23 seconds on a hilly 47.1km course in Spain. After finishing second to Martin for the past two years, Froome was delighted to take his first world title. "It's a great feeling," he said. "I'm really proud of what I've achieved and it's something that I've been working towards for many years. It's a huge honour to be able to wear the rainbow jersey." Froome is the first British man in 28 years to win the elite time trial world title. He is also the second rider from Team Sky to win the event, after Bradley Wiggins in 2014.

Inderjit Singh Dhariwal, 49, was injured at Samsons in Rood End Road, Oldbury, in the early hours of Sunday. Nicolas Salhan, 36, of Haybridge Avenue, Stourbridge, and Jonathan Davies, 42, of no fixed address, have been charged with his murder. No further details have been released by police at this time. However, those charged will appear in court today (Monday). Our thoughts are with Mr Dhariwal's family and friends at this difficult time.

The rail union is calling on the Scottish government to set out an immediate timetable for Abellio to be stripped of its ScotRail franchise. It has said making Scotland's railways public again is the only way to improve services for passengers. The rail union is calling for an immediate end to Abellio's ScotRail contract and for the Scottish government to take back control of Scotland's railways. It says that the private sector has failed to deliver the improvements in services that passengers were promised and argues that public ownership is the only way to ensure Scotland's railways are run for the benefit of passengers and staff, and not for profit. The union also wants the Scottish government to set out plans for a publicly owned Scottish railway network. The Scottish government has said it is "actively considering options" for the future of Scottish rail, including public ownership, but has not yet revealed any concrete plans. The current franchise agreement with Abellio runs until 2025. The RMT is demanding that the Scottish government takes action now to set out an immediate timetable for Abellio to be stripped of its ScotRail franchise and a plan for a publicly owned Scottish railway network to be put in place. The union believes that this would enable better investment in the network, improved services, and lower fares for passengers.

Tens of thousands of pilgrims joined him for the Way of the Cross ceremony, recalling Jesus' crucifixion. Among the cross bearers were Syrian and Iraqi refugees, and Nigerians who had been held captive by Boko Haram militants. The pilgrims walked the streets of Rome in a solemn procession, stopping to pray at each of the 14 traditional stations that mark Jesus' journey to the cross. Pope Francis reflected on the suffering of refugees and victims of violence around the world, saying "we do not forget them." He also prayed for those who have been persecuted for their faith. The Pope concluded his remarks by calling on all Catholics to "take up our own burdens and carry them with hope."

Media playback is not supported on this device Doull emulated fellow Welshman Geraint Thomas, who won at the 2008 and 2012 Olympics, by helping Great Britain win team pursuit gold "I was quite lucky with my parents, they had a big influence on me and my brothers," said Doull. "They encouraged us to do whatever we wanted and have no barriers to anything. As long as we worked hard at it, they were willing to support us and help us out with our goals. "It's been great to see how cycling has grown in Wales over the last few years, with all the success of Geraint Thomas, Mark Cavendish and other British riders. "It's inspiring for young kids and I think it's great that there are more opportunities for them to get involved in the sport and progress to a high level."

The Shrimps lost their opening game of the season at newly-promoted Grimsby but then knocked Championship side Rotherham out of the EFL Cup 5-4 and have won three straight league games - including wins over promotion favourites Bolton and Coventry. "The start has been good, it was a tough game against Grimsby but since then we have gone on a good run," said the Shrimps' manager. "We've managed to beat Rotherham, who are in the Championship, and then follow up with two league wins. We're pleased with where we are at the moment, but there is still a long way to go. "The team spirit is great, the players are all working together and everyone is pulling in the same direction. It's been a positive start to the season and hopefully it can continue."

Charity Twelves Company, based in Devon, said it had turned away 112 people seeking support in 2015. A BBC investigation revealed that in Devon and Cornwall police have seen a 28 increase in reports of domestic abuse since the start of the coronavirus lockdown. In response to the BBC investigation and the increased demand for support, Charity Twelves Company has launched an emergency appeal to fund additional resources and help meet the rising demand for its services. The appeal will help to fund additional staff, provide outreach services to those affected by domestic abuse, as well as providing access to therapy, counselling and legal services. The charity is also calling for more public donations to help them continue their work. The charity is also working with local authorities in Devon to ensure that those who need help can access the right support. This includes raising awareness of the issue and ensuring that victims are aware of the resources available to them, such as refuge accommodation, therapeutic support and legal advice. Charity Twelves Company believes that everyone should be able to live free from fear and violence and they are committed to helping people affected by domestic abuse in Devon. They are encouraging anyone experiencing domestic abuse to contact them or seek help elsewhere.

In a statement (in French) it said it was "worried about the continued worsening of the situation." On Saturday, Turkey began shelling the militia, which it says is linked to the outlawed Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK). Le Conseil de l'Europe a declare qu'il etait "preoccupe par l'aggravation continue de la situation." Le samedi, la Turquie a commence a bombarder la milice qu'elle dit etre liee au Parti des travailleurs du Kurdistan interdit.

Firearms officers from the Met Police carried out a stop on a car in High Street shortly before 20:00 GMT on Wednesday. Two men in their 20s were arrested on suspicion of firearms offences. A search was conducted of the car and a shotgun, ammunition and other items were recovered. The two men remain in custody at a south London police station. The Met Police's Trident and Area Crime Command is investigating.

He faces a number of charges. First, he pulled out of a long-planned trip to Moscow after the US missile strike on a Syrian airfield. It was agreed the US would inform Russia in advance of the strike, but this did not happen. This is a violation of international law and could constitute a breach of trust between the two countries. Second, he has been accused of failing to adequately consult with Congress over his decision to launch the missile strike. This could be seen as an infringement on Congress' constitutional power to declare war. Third, he has been accused of violating the War Powers Resolution by launching the missile strike without Congressional approval. The War Powers Resolution requires the President to seek Congressional authorization before engaging in any military action that lasts longer than 60 days. Fourth, he faces allegations that he violated the Constitution by launching the missile strike without consulting the Senate. Under Article I, Section 8, Clause 11 of the Constitution, the Senate must approve all treaties before they can become binding. Finally, he may be accused of abusing his power by failing to seek approval from Congress before ordering the strike. This could be seen as a violation of the separation of powers doctrine, which states that the executive branch should not assume the prerogatives of other branches of government.

Activities also include wife carrying, husband dragging, gravy wrestling, Russian egg roulette, backward running, worm charming and ditch racing. The games, in Llanwrtyd Wells, continue every weekend until 29 August. Llanwrtyd Wells bills itself as the smallest town in Britain. It has a population of about 650 and is located in rural mid-Wales. Events such as the man versus horse race, bog snorkelling championships and the alternative Olympics are credited with putting the town "on the map," according to BBC Wales. The man versus horse race sees competitors pitted against each other and horses over 22 miles of rough terrain. The event was first held in 1980 and was won by Gordon Green, who completed the course in two hours and five minutes. The fastest horse took two hours and seven minutes. Organiser Eddie Davies said the alternative Olympic Games had become "hugely popular." He said: "It's great to see so many people coming together to test their skills and have fun. We have some unusual events, but they all require skill and agility - as do any Olympic Games."

Allan Whittern ran the grocer's store in Suffolk Parade from 1932 until his death 50 years later, in 1982. Following its closure in 1991, the door painted with his father's name, A.E. Whittern, was preserved in a local museum. Allan Whittern's store was a fixture of the Suffolk Parade neighborhood for almost 60 years. During this time, it provided a range of services to the local community including grocery items, household goods, and even some medical supplies. The store was also well known for the friendly and helpful service offered by the family and staff. In addition to running the store, Allan was also an active member of the local community and was involved in numerous charitable causes. He regularly attended church, served on committees, and participated in fundraisers for local organizations such as the Red Cross, Boy Scouts, and Girls' Club. When Allan passed away in 1982, his son took over the business until its closure in 1991. Although the store is no longer open, its legacy lives on in the form of the door preserved in the local museum which bears Allan's father's name. This serves as a reminder of Allan Whittern's commitment to serving the people of Suffolk Parade for so many years.

The humpback has been seen at Pettycur Bay, Kinghorn in Fife. Humpback sightings are not uncommon in Scotland, but a large whale so far up the Forth estuary is a rare event. The whale was spotted by a local fisherman, and the Scottish Marine Animal Stranding Scheme (SMASS) has confirmed its likely identity as a humpback. This sighting is an exciting development for conservationists in Scotland, as it suggests that the species may be attempting to expand its range into the North Sea. It is possible that the whale could have traveled from the North Atlantic or even further afield. Further research and monitoring of such sightings will help us understand more about the movements and habitats of these great creatures.

Noah Zunde, who was 22 months old, succumbed to heatstroke after being left in the car for seven hours. His mother, Romy Zunde, had mistakenly believed she dropped Noah at daycare that morning. Noah Zunde's death was a tragedy and a heartbreaking reminder of the dangers of leaving children in cars. Heatstroke can occur quickly, even on days with mild temperatures, and can have deadly consequences. It is essential for parents and caregivers to take extra care when transporting children and ensure they are never left alone in a car.

Anagha Nikam was travelling by rail when she spotted a mother trying to find milk for her baby daughter. She tweeted to the ministry and asked for help, and milk was sent to the mother. Anagha Nikam's act of kindness has been praised by many on social media, and she has become an inspiration for others to help those in need. Her story has shown that a small act of kindness can make a huge difference in someone's life.

Andrew Bickel, 39, was fixing a light at the Catwel shop in Cardiff two weeks ago when he nipped out to his van and returned to find his tools were missing. Andrew reported the incident to the police, who were able to track down the culprits and return his tools to him. The police also informed Andrew that they had apprehended a group of youths in connection with the theft and that they were being interviewed as part of their investigation. The police have yet to release any details on the identities of the suspects or the outcome of their investigation, but Andrew was relieved to have his tools back. He has since taken the necessary steps to secure his van better when he is away from it.

They were able to hold a metal plate a few centimetres above the rabbit's chest and use it to regulate the animal's heartbeat. If such medical implants could be made small enough, they could be used in humans to help regulate a heartbeat.

Inspectors criticised teaching and leadership at the Phoenix Academy and Lakeside Academy following visits in February, rating both schools inadequate in all areas. Wrockwardine Wood and Sutherland academies, also run by the Telford-based Academies Enterprise Trust, were rated as requiring improvement. The Ofsted reports said teaching at the Phoenix and Lakeside was "not consistently good enough" and that many pupils did not make enough progress. At Phoenix, inspectors noted that students' behaviour was "sometimes poor" and that bullying was an issue. At Lakeside, the report said there had been a "deterioration in the quality of teaching" since its last inspection, with teachers not having high enough expectations of pupils and pupils not given enough help to improve their work. The reports added that while staff at all four schools were "committed and hardworking," they lacked consistency in their approach and did not always have sufficient knowledge of the curriculum. Leadership was also criticised, with Ofsted saying that leaders at the four schools had not done enough to improve standards.

The prime minister stressed her belief he was committed to advancing the "special relationship" with the UK. But Mrs May told the Financial Times she expects "very frank" talks on the issue of immigration. The prime minister said she would be discussing with Mr Trump the importance of an "open and fair" immigration system that works for both countries. She said it was important to ensure the UK was able to attract the "brightest and best" people from around the world.

A 911 caller said "they were going to blow up the Statue of Liberty," the National Park Service said. Federal police arrived and when sniffer dogs found "an area of interest," the monument was evacuated and closed for six hours while the NYPD bomb squad investigated. No explosives were found and the area was reopened.

Kent Police detained the two suspects, aged 22 and 20, at Dover Eastern Docks in the early hours of Sunday. They are being held under Section 5 of the Terrorism Act 2006 on suspicion of terrorism offences. The arrests were made as part of a pre-planned operation following extensive investigation by Counter Terrorism officers. The two suspects are being questioned at a police station in Kent. At this stage, it is not appropriate to discuss any further details about the investigation. We would like to reassure the public that Kent Police are committed to combating all forms of terrorism and we will take robust action against those suspected of involvement in such activities.

The 44-year-old had been in charge at Rugby Park since February 2016, when he replaced Gary Locke. He kept Killie in the Premiership last season and leaves them in sixth place. Killie said in a statement: "The club would like to thank Lee for his commitment and dedication during his time at Rugby Park and we wish him all the best for the future." Findlay was previously caretaker manager at Aberdeen, where he had been assistant manager under Craig Brown. Before that, he had worked with Locke at Raith Rovers. A former Scotland Under-21 international, Findlay enjoyed a distinguished playing career. He began at Dundee United, before spells with Sheffield Wednesday, Brentford and Reading. He moved back north to join Aberdeen in 2000 and won the League Cup with the Dons in 1995. After leaving Pittodrie, he had a spell at Falkirk.

Media playback is not supported on this device The Premier League paid PS174m to agents, up from PS130m, with Manchester City being the biggest spenders (PS26.3m) ahead of Chelsea (PS25.1m) The Premier League paid a record amount of money to agents in the 201920 season. A total of PS174 million was paid out, up from PS130 million the previous season. Manchester City were the biggest spenders, paying out PS26.3 million, followed by Chelsea (PS25.1 million) and Liverpool (PS23.2 million). The figures come from the Premier League's annual report on agent fees, which shows that clubs spent more than PS500 million on agents over the past five years. The report also revealed that almost half (48.9) of the money went to agents based in England and Wales, while 16.4 went to agents based abroad. The highest individual payment made to an agent was PS8.1 million, paid by Chelsea to Pini Zahavi. The report comes amid growing scrutiny of agent fees, with some football clubs and supporters calling for greater transparency and regulation of the industry.

"Fracking" involves pumping water and chemicals into shale rock at pressure. The joint report from the Royal Society and Royal Academy of Engineering say the technique is safe if firms comply with regulations. Fracking involves the use of high pressure to fracture shale rock and release trapped natural gas. During the process, water, sand, and chemical additives are injected into the well at a high pressure to fracture the rock. The fractures allow the natural gas to flow out and be collected. The technique has become more popular in recent years as advances in technology have allowed companies to access previously inaccessible reserves of natural gas. While fracking has been safely used in the United States for decades, it has become a controversial topic in other countries due to concerns over potential environmental impacts.

The Lions, who won the semi-final first leg 3-1, looked to have put the tie to bed when Lee Gregory slotted home. But Jamie Proctor's strike just before half-time, after some good work from Ben Pringle, gave Rotherham hope. The second half saw a much more open game, with both teams creating chances and the Millers pushing for an equaliser. But despite their best efforts, they were unable to break down a resilient Lions' defence as Millwall ran out 4-2 aggregate winners.

The team-mates collided while racing for the lead on the last lap of the Austrian Grand Prix on Sunday. Hamilton went on to win and now trails Rosberg, who was second, by 11 points in the championship. The incident is being investigated by race stewards and a decision on any possible penalties will be made later this week. Hamilton may face a grid penalty if found guilty of causing the collision, which could leave him facing an uphill battle to take the title from Rosberg.

It said just 8 of councils had built enough to replace half of their stock sold through the scheme, which allows council tenants to buy their homes. The charity said local authorities were not doing enough to replace the homes sold. Housing charity Shelter said it was "deeply concerning" that so few councils had managed to replace half of their stock sold under the Right to Buy scheme. It called on the government to take action to ensure more homes were available for social rent. The charity's chief executive, Polly Neate, said: "Right to Buy has been a huge success for many people who have been able to buy their council home and get onto the property ladder. But it's deeply concerning that so few councils have replaced even half of what they've sold off. "With millions of people stuck on housing waiting lists, we need urgent action to make sure those who desperately need a secure, affordable home are not left behind. The government must act now to ensure more social homes are built to replace the ones lost to Right to Buy."

Devon and Cornwall Police were called to the statue of General Buller in Exeter at 23:40 BST on Saturday. The 18-year-old, from the Exeter area, was climbing on the 15ft statue. Police officers attended the scene and spoke to the 18-year-old, who was subsequently issued a Community Resolution Order for criminal damage. This involves the offender making an apology and restitution for any damage caused. The order also includes other requirements such as carrying out unpaid work or attending education or training sessions.

The 29-year-old limped off after just seven minutes of the 2-0 win over Leicester City on Sunday. A Premier League winner while on loan at Leicester last season, Dyer will miss the remainder of this season. He has played just 14 times in all competitions since joining the club from Swansea City in the summer of 2018. "It's devastating," said Newcastle manager Steve Bruce. "He's been a great professional, he's worked hard, he's trained hard and he's so unfortunate to pick up this injury. "We wish him all the best for his recovery."
