Speaking after the game, Dyer said: "I'm devastated. I was really looking forward to helping the team push for a top-four finish and hopefully a trophy or two. "The support I have had from my teammates, the staff, the fans and everyone at the club has been amazing. I'd like to thank them all for their kind words and wish the team all the best for the rest of the season."

They arrested 57 people in Barcelona, Valencia, San Sebastian and Las Palmas in the Canary Islands. Chinese nationals illegally living in Spain reportedly paid the ring EUR8,000 (8,960; PS6,820) each for the documents. The Spanish police said that those arrested included 13 people for running an organized criminal group, 21 people for document falsification and 23 people for using false documents. They also seized more than 3,000 forged identity documents, including passports, driving licenses, residency cards and health cards. The authorities believe the gang had been in operation since November 2017 and had managed to smuggle over 100 Chinese nationals into Spain.

The pop star was given the night's top honour for her multi-million selling record 25, but told the audience, "I can't possibly accept this award." "I'm very humbled and I'm very grateful, but the truth is that I'm not really sure I deserve it," she said. "There are so many other artists out there who have worked much harder than I have and who have made much more of an impact in the music industry than I have." She thanked her fans for their support and dedication, saying, "I owe everything to you guys. Without your love and encouragement, I wouldn't be here today." She also thanked her family and extended family for their love and support over the years. The pop star then went on to acknowledge the award by saying, "I am deeply honoured to receive this award and I thank you from the bottom of my heart. I'm truly humbled by the recognition and I will do my best to continue to make music that connects with and resonates with all of you."

The 27-year-old's career, which started at French club Montpellier, has taken him to Ukraine and Germany and he spent last season on loan at Ligue 1 side Nice. "I've joined a great team and I'm very happy to be here. This is an important step in my career and I am looking forward to working hard and helping the team to achieve its goals," he said of his move to Stuttgart. On the international stage, Kwon has made 12 appearances for South Korea since making his debut in 2014. He was part of the squad that reached the Round of 16 at the 2018 FIFA World Cup in Russia and is expected to play an important role for his country during qualifying for the 2022 edition. Kwon carries a wealth of experience with him and has played in a variety of positions. He is comfortable playing as a central midfielder but can also operate on either flank or in a more advanced role. His tactical versatility will be invaluable to Stuttgart and will give them added flexibility in their approach to games. Kwon's arrival is another positive addition to the club and gives them valuable cover in midfield. The South Korean brings a wealth of experience to the side and should be able to help them push for European qualification this season.

The images appeared to show the pair on foot during a safari in June at the Gir National Park in western Gujarat state. Officials at the park said they imposed a 10,000 rupee (130) fine on the couple for the violation. The incident has highlighted the issue of irresponsible behaviour by some tourists in India's national parks, which are home to thousands of wild animals including tigers, lions and leopards. India is home to more than 40 tiger reserves and other wildlife sanctuaries that attract thousands of visitors every year. But some visitors ignore warnings not to venture too close to the animals, often with tragic results. In January, a leopard was killed by villagers in the western state of Maharashtra after it attacked a tourist who had tried to take its picture.

Just minutes after leaving harbour, the ferry capsized. 193 people were killed in the tragedy. Belfast man Bill McCrea was more than 1,500 miles away in Kent, when the ship went down. The tragedy occurred on 31 March 1987 and is remembered as one of the worst maritime disasters in British history. The ferry, known as the Herald of Free Enterprise, was heading from Zeebrugge in Belgium to Dover in England with over 500 passengers and crew on board when it capsized and sank in just minutes. Investigations later found that the disaster had been caused by human error, with the ship's bow doors left open and a failure to properly check them before setting off. As a result, water flooded into the vessel, causing it to capsize. 193 people were killed, including many from Northern Ireland, among them Bill McCrea.

Beauly will be the only representatives of the lower leagues in the semi-final draw at BBC Scotland's Pacific Quay on Monday 11 July. This follows a heroic 1-1 draw away to Cove Rangers in the quarter-final of the Scottish Cup. Beauly will be joined by teams from Scotland's top three divisions, including Premiership sides Hearts and Hibernian, as well as Championship club Alloa Athletic.

Both sustained leg injuries in the incident on Thursday. A spokesman for the force said one of the two male officers had been discharged from the Princess Elizabeth Hospital. The other officer was being kept in the hospital for further observation.

Russia's plan for "de-escalation" zones was backed by Iran at talks in Kazakhstan. Both countries support Syrian president Bashar al-Assad. Turkey, which supports rebel groups, also agreed to act as a guarantor of the plan. Under the plan, Russia, Iran, and Turkey will create four "de-escalation" zones in Syria where fighting between government forces and rebel groups will be halted. The zones will be monitored by Russian military police and jointly patrolled by Iranian and Turkish forces. Civilians in the zones will receive humanitarian aid and the Syrian government will restore infrastructure. The agreement is designed to pave the way for a political solution to be negotiated at peace talks in Geneva.

The birds, which are native to southern Europe, set up nests by burrowing tunnels in the banks of Low Gelt Quarry, near Brampton. An RSPB viewpoint on the perimeter of the quarry provides great views of the nesting birds. The birds are also often seen flying around and perched on the rocks within the quarry. During the breeding season, they feed mainly on small invertebrates such as spiders, beetles, flies and caterpillars. The birds lay their eggs in a shallow depression in the ground, which is then lined with feathers and wool by the female.

Entertainers Starkidz were "cornered" by the gang after a Christmas lights switch-on in Formby, Merseyside. The performers, including one as young as 13, were abused, with one punched and another threatened with a knife. This incident is extremely concerning and must be investigated by the police. It is vital that those responsible are brought to justice, and that the victims of this attack receive the support they need. We urge anyone with information about this incident to contact the police as soon as possible.

The Romanian diners, who had paid a deposit of a'!900 (950; PS770), left the El Carmen restaurant in Bembibre as dessert was due to be served, Antonio Rodriguez said. "It was a misunderstanding," he said. The diners had booked the table for 19:30 but arrived at 21:00, which is when the restaurant normally closes. "They thought it was open until 22:00," Rodriguez said. He added that although the customers had already paid a deposit, the restaurant asked them to pay the full amount as they were late. The diners refused and left without eating. Rodriguez said the restaurant would not reimburse the deposit, and that the misunderstanding was due to a lack of communication between the customer and the restaurant. He apologized to the diners and said that the El Carmen restaurant would try to improve its communication with customers in the future.

3 April 2017 Last updated at 09:17 BST Demand for property in China's top cities is so red hot, some couples are even undergoing fake divorces in order to buy a home. The practice has become so common that Chinese estate agents are now being told to report such deals to the authorities, according to state media. Some couples opt for a fake divorce in order to get around China's strict rules on buying property in big cities. Under these regulations, only one member of a couple can own a home - which makes it financially difficult for two people to buy together. By opting for a fake divorce, one partner can purchase the property alone, while the other still remains living there. The reports by CCTV, China's national broadcaster, come amid a nationwide housing boom, with prices in some cities soaring 20-30 over the past year. The government says it is clamping down on the practice, with estate agents now being held responsible for reporting any suspicious transactions. China's ministry of civil affairs has also said it will be setting up a database to track divorces and help detect any fakes. Divorce in China is relatively easy, but the law states that a couple must wait at least six months after splitting before remarrying again.

Police forces tasked with implementing strict state interpretations of Islamic morality exist in several other states, including Saudi Arabia, Sudan and Malaysia. Many - especially those with an affinity with Saudi Arabia - enforce highly-conservative interpretations of Islamic law, often punishing perceived moral transgressions with physical punishments like flogging. In Saudi Arabia, for example, the religious police (also known as the Mutaween) are responsible for enforcing the country's strict interpretation of Sharia law. This includes prohibiting activities such as mixing genders in public, playing music, drinking alcohol, and other activities deemed to be immoral by the government. They patrol public areas and can also confiscate goods that they deem to be offensive or immoral. In some cases, they can even arrest individuals suspected of violating Sharia law. In Sudan, the Hisba police are responsible for enforcing morality in accordance with Islamic law. This includes monitoring dress codes, preventing the sale and consumption of alcohol, and prohibiting activities deemed to be immoral. They are also tasked with preventing "inappropriate behavior" and have been known to use physical punishments such as flogging to punish those who violate Islamic laws. In Malaysia, there is the Federal Territories Islamic Religious Department, which is responsible for enforcing morality and Islamic law in the country's federal territories. They monitor clothing and behavior in public places, and have the power to issue fines and even detain suspects for alleged violations of Islamic law.

According to organisers a record 3.6 million turned out to vote in the Scottish independence referendum. More than 100,000 of the total were 16 to 17-year-olds who had registered to vote for the first time. The high turnout was credited to a wide range of people coming together to raise awareness, including the media, politicians and grassroots organisations like Yes Scotland, which ran the official Yes campaign, and the National Collective, a group of artists and activists who campaigned for independence.

Inspired by the lily pond in Monet's garden at Giverny in France, the painting was the top lot at Sotheby's sale of modern and impressionist works. It totalled just under 50 million, setting a new record for the artist. The painting was Monet's Water Lilies, painted in 1906. The painting is an oil on canvas and measures approximately 198 by 626 cm (78 by 246 in). It is part of Monet's celebrated series of 250 works depicting his garden's lily pond in various light and weather conditions. The painting depicts a tranquil scene of a flowering lily pond with pink water lilies in the foreground and a small bridge in the background. The bright colors and free brushstrokes of the painting are characteristic of Monet's impressionist style. Monet's Water Lilies has been featured in many major exhibitions, including the Museum of Modern Art's "Monet in the 20th Century" show in 1998, and was acquired by a private European collector in the Sotheby's auction.

The Scot dug deep to claim a 2-6 6-4 7-6 (7-4) victory in a match that lasted two hours 59 minutes. He recovered from two breaks of serve in the third set to take the match into a tiebreak, which he won convincingly. Murray broke twice in the opening set and was on top for most of the second before his opponent clawed back to level the match. In the decider, Murray again looked set to seal victory but Cilic fought back to ensure the contest went the distance. The tiebreak proved to be the difference with Murray producing some stunning shots to take the win.

Yet again, you feel for the families of those killed on board, and the people that actually survived the ordeal. It seems never ending. In less than a year two of these horrific tragedies have taken place and it is just heartbreaking. It is important to remember that while we feel sadness, the families of those killed are feeling an unimaginable grief and pain. Our hearts go out to them, and we hope and pray for justice and peace in their lives.

The veteran broadcaster died of cancer on Sunday at the age of 77. The books, in Sir Terry's birthplace of Limerick, will allow people to mark the passing of "a great Irishman." The books are being opened in Limerick City Council's offices in Merchant's Quay, where members of the public can sign them or leave messages of condolence. The books will be open until Friday evening and at that point they will be sent to Sir Terry's family. Lord Mayor of Limerick Cllr Kevin Kiely said: "We are very sorry for the death of Terry Wogan who was a great friend to Limerick. He was an iconic broadcaster, much loved by generations across the UK and Ireland." He added: "It is fitting that we should remember him in his home city and I hope people will join us in offering their condolences to his family and friends."

The hosts had Josh Passley dismissed for bringing down Garry Thompson before Wycombe went ahead when Paul Hayes fired home Paris Cowan-Hall's ball. Thompson later saw red for a challenge on Billy Knott, but the hosts held on to their lead. Kenny Jackett's side had chances to level late on, but could not find an equaliser. The result leaves the Gills in 15th place in the League Two table, while Wycombe move up to seventh.

The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration closed its investigation after it found no evidence of a defect in the vehicle. Joshua Brown was killed when his car collided with a truck, but it was due to Brown's own errors and not because of a defect in the vehicle. The NHTSA concluded that the crash was due to driver error and not a defect in the Autopilot system. The NHTSA noted that Tesla's Autopilot technology is a driver assistance system, and drivers are responsible for maintaining control of their vehicles at all times. The agency found no evidence of a safety-related defect in the vehicle or the Autopilot system that contributed to the incident.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad told the BBC "Syria is doing its best" to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. Syria missed Wednesday's deadline to hand over an inventory of its chemical weapons programme. Al-Mekdad said Syria was in the process of handing over a detailed inventory of its chemical weapons to the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). He added that the country was "trying to meet the deadline" set by the OPCW, but that this had been complicated by the security situation in the country. He also said that Syria was committed to the destruction of its chemical weapons and that it was working with the OPCW to ensure this was done as quickly as possible. The OPCW is overseeing the destruction of Syria's chemical weapons and has set a June 30th deadline for the destruction of all of Syria's declared chemical weapons stockpiles.

PC Gareth Browning, 33, was on foot in Whitley, Reading on 30 November when he was hit by a black Mazda Aerosport driven by Luke Haywood, 28. Haywood admitted causing death by careless driving and was jailed for 18 months at Reading Crown Court on 10 May. On 30 November 2019, Gareth Browning, a 33-year-old police officer, was on foot in Whitley, Reading when he was struck by a black Mazda Aerosport driven by Luke Haywood, 28. The tragic incident occurred during the evening rush hour, leaving Browning with fatal injuries. Haywood appeared at Reading Crown Court on 10 May 2020 and pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving. He was sentenced to 18 months in prison and was also banned from driving for two years and four months. In addition, he must take an extended re-test before getting his licence back. The court heard that Haywood had been driving at excess speed and had failed to spot Browning until it was too late. Judge Angela Morris said that Haywood's actions had caused a "tragic loss of life" and that his sentence should act as a deterrent to other drivers. Browning's family paid tribute to him as "a devoted father, husband and son" who "brought joy and laughter to all those around him."

But many of the people using the health service in England or Northern Ireland on Monday morning may not have noticed a huge difference. Why? Walkouts in the NHS are very rare, so when they do happen it is usually only in a few areas. This means that the vast majority of people using the health service on Monday morning may not have noticed any difference.

Tour de France winner Wiggins became the most decorated Olympian in British history, with a total of seven medals. He won the cycling time trial after Glover and Stanning rowed to victory in the women's pairs. He also took bronze in the men's team pursuit and golds in the individual pursuit, team pursuit and Madison.

However, the resolution is non-binding, with Nigeria and Senegal opposing a withdrawal. South Africa and Burundi have already decided to withdraw, accusing the ICC of undermining their sovereignty and unfairly targeting African leaders. The ICC was established in 2002 to investigate and try individuals accused of international crimes such as genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. It has been criticized for its focus on Africa, where most of its investigations have taken place.

He also said he hoped that Kyrgios would take the positives from the match and use them to build on his future performances.

Gwent Police said it was "extremely concerned" after five incidents potentially linked to heroin were reported between 23 October and Friday. They happened in Caerphilly, Newport and Blaenau Gwent. Det Insp John Weaver said: "The consequences of taking heroin can be fatal, and it is important that people are aware of the risks. "We are working closely with partner agencies to identify those responsible for supplying this illegal drug within our communities. I would urge anyone with information about any of these incidents or who knows who is supplying heroin in our area to please contact us."

He complained that Dawn Bowden referred to "Goebbels-like propaganda from the right-wing media" in a recent debate. He claimed Eluned Morgan "trivialised suicide" when saying Brexit would "slit the wrists " of the economy. It appears that the anonymous individual taking issue with those comments is expressing a right-wing viewpoint and disagreeing with Dawn Bowden's and Eluned Morgan's opinions. The individual does not appear to have taken any direct action against either politician, but is instead simply voicing his disagreement.

The Staffordshire club are second in the Premiership - the top-flight of English rugby as it stands - and have been part of the league for 15 seasons. Lichfield director of rugby and head coach Steve Salvin has been in charge of the club since 2010 and has overseen a period of unprecedented success. The team won the league title in 2015 and have also reached the final twice since then. They have also won the Powergen Cup, a prestigious competition for teams at the top end of the English game. Off the field, Lichfield are highly regarded and respected throughout the rugby community. They boast a strong youth set-up and their Academy programme is renowned for producing high quality players. The club also run a number of community programmes to provide opportunities for those from disadvantaged backgrounds to get involved in the sport. As well as this, Lichfield are committed to leading the way in terms of sustainability and have recently opened their own solar farm.

They started arriving at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard on Sunday, and National Trust volunteers have been clearing them away as they are said to pose a risk to wildlife. But the shells - which have been found as far away as St Ives - are believed to have been brought in by a ship travelling from outside the UK. The trust said it had received reports of "large numbers" being washed up along the coast and warned people to be careful if they come across them. It advised beachgoers not to pick up or move the shells, as they can contain toxins that can cause skin irritation. A spokesman said: "We are aware of large numbers of the shells washing up on the Lizard and other areas of Cornwall, including St Ives. "We believe they were brought in by a ship travelling from outside the UK, or possibly discarded by fishing vessels operating in our waters. "We would advise people not to pick up or move these shells, as they may contain toxins which can cause skin irritation. "We are working with our partners to assess the situation and take any necessary action."

Media playback is not supported on this device Qatar's Femi Ogunode was also given the same time, but Gatlin got the nod with France's Jimmy Vicaut third in 9.99. Briton James Dasaolu was fourth in 10.00. Gatlin's victory came despite a series of drug-related scandals that have blighted his career. The 33-year-old served two suspensions, including one in 2006 that lasted four years, after testing positive for testosterone. But the American has rebuilt his reputation and he now holds the 100m world title, having won gold at the World Championships in Moscow last year. At the time, Gatlin said: "I've been through some tough times but I'm back on top of the world. A lot of people have supported me through this long journey."

The Hydrus Group, an oil and gas service company, has started work on a specialist manufacturing base at the Brechin Business Park. It is forecast the new development will bring up to 80 jobs to the local economy. The new facility will allow The Hydrus Group to expand its current capabilities in oil and gas services, such as engineering, manufacturing and construction. These services are essential to the success of the energy sector in Scotland, particularly with the development of renewable energy sources. The Hydrus Group is committed to working closely with the local community and will be engaging with schools, colleges and universities to ensure that local people have access to the skills and training they need to take advantage of the job opportunities created by the new manufacturing base. The company has pledged to invest in the local area and improve education and training facilities for young people. It is also in talks with local businesses to develop apprenticeships and work placements which could potentially provide new career pathways for those living in the area. The Hydrus Group is looking forward to playing its part in the future development of the Brechin Business Park and will be working hard to ensure that the local community benefits from this exciting new project.

Whilst on patrol over Winnipeg, the chopper's crew accidentally turned on its loudspeaker allowing members of the public below to hear them. Those listening say they heard pilots swearing and discussing inappropriate topics, including sex. The Royal Canadian Air Force (RCAF) has launched an investigation into the incident. The RCAF has also issued a formal apology to anyone who may have been offended by the language used. The RCAF is committed to upholding the highest standards of professionalism and behaviour, and such language is not reflective of these values. Those involved will be held accountable for their actions.

Officials from Staffordshire County Council and the university said the historic building, in the town centre, would become an information centre for prospective students. A number of courses will also be available. The building, which dates back to the 19th century, was originally a school and has been used for various purposes since then. It is now set to become the new home of Staffordshire University's academic and student services teams. The university said it was looking forward to providing a "warm welcome" to prospective students at the centre and to offering a range of courses. The centre is expected to open later this year and will also provide information about accommodation, financial support and other student services.

Failed leadership candidate Lisa Duffy was having dinner with her staff in Bournemouth on Friday. No action was taken against the curry house, which had completed pre-employment checks. UKIP has confirmed that no party funds were used to pay for the meal. The incident has raised questions about the use of public funds during a political campaign. It is unclear what investigation, if any, UKIP will undertake into Duffy's use of party funds during her failed leadership bid. Party officials have yet to comment on the matter.

David Cameron said a stadium would "inspire young people, brings jobs and wealth" to the county. Labour said it was a "cynical" attempt to distract voters, the Liberal Democrats questioned whether it was "value for money." Cameron has defended his proposal for a stadium, arguing that it would bring much-needed investment and jobs to the county. He has argued that it could be an important source of inspiration for young people in the area, with potential for grassroots sports development, as well as providing entertainment for local residents. Labour has criticised the plan as a "cynical" attempt to distract voters from other issues, such as the collapse of public services or the lack of affordable housing. The Liberal Democrats have questioned whether the stadium is value for money, and have called for an independent review of the project to ensure it is cost effective.

Mohammed Sufiyan Choudry and Zaiur Rahman, both members of the Luton chapter of the banned group Al-Muhajiroun, were caught in an undercover police operation in 2015. Choudry, 23, from Maidenhead, was convicted of preparing for acts of terrorism, while Rahman, 36, from Luton, was found guilty of possessing a document likely to be useful to a person committing or preparing an act of terrorism. Choudry was sentenced to nine years in prison, while Rahman was sentenced to five-and-a-half years in prison. The two men were part of a larger group known as "Al-Muhajiroun" that has been linked to a number of terrorist attacks, including the July 7th London bombings in 2005 and the attempted bombing of Glasgow Airport in 2007. The group is believed to have radicalised hundreds of people in the UK, and is thought to be responsible for inspiring a number of other terrorist plots. Choudry and Rahman were caught in an undercover police operation, which involved officers posing as members of the Al-Muhajiroun group. During the investigation, the pair discussed possible targets for terrorist attacks, including military bases and shopping centres. They also discussed their plans to travel to Syria to join Islamic State fighters. The sentencing judge described the pair as "dangerous" and said they posed a "real and immediate risk to the public." He said they had shown no remorse for their actions and showed "no sign of being deterred" from engaging in terrorist activity. In response to the sentence, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe, praised the work of the undercover officers and said: "This case shows how important it is to take swift and robust action against those who seek to harm the public. We will continue to use every legal means at our disposal to disrupt and prevent terrorism."

The 23-year-old has played nine league games for the Spireites this season, all as a substitute, but started two cup matches. The 6ft 4ins former Ivory Coast Under-20 international has scored two goals. He has also spent time on loan at FC Halifax Town and Alfreton Town this season. "I am pleased to sign for the club and I am looking forward to helping the team," Beleck told the Club website. "The manager has already spoken to me about how he wants to play and I think that suits me. "I am a very technical player - I like to keep the ball and pass it well."

Jolie, whose directorial debut is set in Bosnia's 1992 to 1995 war, received a standing ovation as she picked up the honorary Heart of Sarajevo award. "I told Brad in the car on the way here, 'No matter what happens, I'm so proud of this film'," she said, referring to her partner, Brad Pitt. The movie, which was filmed in Hungary and Bosnia and Herzegovina, is based on a true story about a Bosnian woman's struggle for justice after her husband and son are killed in the war. The film follows the woman as she pursues justice and eventually wins a case against a Serbian war criminal before the United Nations' International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. Jolie said that when she heard the story of the woman's fight for justice, it inspired her to make the movie. "It made me realise how little we know about other people's stories and how much we take for granted our own freedom," she said. In accepting the award, Jolie said she hoped the film would help bring attention to the suffering of the victims of the conflict, and also serve as a reminder that peace can be achieved. "I have seen with my own eyes the effects of war and what it does to people, and I hope that young people all over the world will be reminded by this movie that peace is possible," she said.

Many of the dead were young boys who were in a trophy ceremony hit by the bomber, himself said to be a teenager. So-called Islamic State (IS) said it carried out the attack. The bomber was identified as 15-year-old Ibrahim Hassan al-Hassan, who was born in 2002 and lived in a suburb of Baghdad. He had been reported missing for two days before the attack. According to police, he detonated an explosives belt hidden under his clothes during a ceremony at the Al-Tayaran Square, where dozens of young men were receiving awards. The bombing killed over 30 people and injured more than 60 others.

Hearn is trying to line up a spot for Taylor on the undercard of Mikey Garcia's clash with four-time world champion Adrien Broner on 28 July. Taylor stopped German Nina Meinke in her most recent fight in April. The 27-year-old from London is undefeated in eight bouts and Hearn believes she has the ability to become a world champion. "Katie Taylor going up against Adrien Broner, that's a massive fight," he said. "We want to give Katie Taylor as many big fights as possible. "Winning a world title is one thing but it's all about the big fights and being part of big events and being on the same card as Adrien Broner, for example, would be huge for her." Taylor won gold at the 2012 Olympics and turned professional shortly afterwards. She recently signed with Matchroom Sport, Hearn's promotional company, and will make her debut with them in July.

Austin Haughwout claims he was kicked out of Central Connecticut state university over the footage. The institution says he was expelled over threats to shoot people there. Mr Haughwout argued his expulsion was in retaliation for the videos. The university has denied this, and said they acted because of threatening behavior.

The 18-year-old can play at right-back, centre-half and in central midfield. Born in Birmingham, Suliman signed a professional deal with Villa in January 2015 until 2017, but is yet to make his first-team debut. He has been involved in the matchday squad several times, but is yet to be named on the bench. Suliman is a highly rated young player and was called into the England U18s squad in April 2016. He has also played for the U19s and U20s. He is a versatile player who can play anywhere across the back four or in midfield and has the potential to become a top performer.

The trial, which targets women who are too late to undergo surgery, gives six weeks of additional chemotherapy. On average, 94 women in Northern Ireland each year are diagnosed with late-stage ovarian cancer, a disease that is often not detected until it has spread to other parts of the body. The trial aims to determine whether giving additional chemotherapy can extend the length of time women survive with the disease. Women who are eligible for the trial will receive either the standard three-month course of chemotherapy or an additional six weeks of chemotherapy. The aim of the trial is to see if the additional chemotherapy can increase the chance of survival. The trial has been designed to provide the best possible medical care and support to the women taking part. It also aims to ensure that they have access to all the relevant information they need during their treatment. All women will be offered psychological and social support throughout the trial.

Police are investigating events linked to the funeral and wake of the mother of INLA man Patsy O'Hara, who died in the 1981 hunger strike. Dozens of people wearing military-style clothing and masks attended the funeral service in Derry last week. Police have confirmed that they are investigating the events surrounding the funeral and wake of the mother of INLA man Patsy O'Hara, who died in the 1981 hunger strike. They said that officers had been deployed to the scene and were carrying out inquiries into potential breaches of covid-19 regulations. The PSNI said: "Police are aware of reports that a large number of people dressed in military-style clothing and masks attended a funeral and wake in the Cityside area of Derry on Thursday 8 April 2021. Officers attended the scene and are conducting enquiries into any potential breaches of COVID-19 regulations." The INLA (Irish National Liberation Army) is an Irish republican paramilitary organization which was active during the Troubles in Northern Ireland. It was formed in 1975 as a splinter group from the Provisional IRA, with the intention of bringing about a socialist republic. The organisation has been largely inactive since the 1990s.

With all the walking, running, cycling and gym activity you intend to do, obviously you need an activity tracker -a small, trusty device that you can wear 247 to monitor your steps, sleep, calorie burn and heart rate. There are many activity trackers on the market today, so it's important to do your research before you make a purchase. Many trackers offer features such as GPS tracking, sleep tracking, calories burned, heart rate monitoring, and more. It's important to consider the features that are important to you, as well as the battery life, accuracy, and design of the device. When it comes to choosing the right activity tracker, it is important to consider your lifestyle, budget, and goals. If you are looking for an activity tracker that will be used exclusively for running, then you might want to prioritize features like GPS tracking and heart rate monitoring. On the other hand, if you are looking for an activity tracker to monitor your everyday activities, then a basic step counter with a long battery life may be all you need. No matter what type of activity tracker you decide to purchase, it is important to remember that it should be comfortable and easy to wear. Additionally, you should check reviews from other users to make sure you are getting a quality product that is accurate and reliable.

Flanker Peter O'Mahony captains the side in Rotorua, with tour skipper Sam Warburton on the replacements' bench. Maro Itoje starts at lock in an otherwise unchanged pack from the one that started against the Highlanders last weekend. In the backs, George Ford and Owen Farrell continue their half-back partnership with Jonathan Joseph and Elliot Daly making up the centre pairing. Anthony Watson and Jack Nowell are on the wings, with Mike Brown at full-back. The bench features Joe Marler, Jamie George and Kyle Sinckler as the front-row cover, with Warburton, Nathan Hughes and Ben Te'o providing back row support. The works on Gdynia Way near Plymouth's city centre have been in place since June to widen the road to three lanes. But police said they had seen an increase in the number of collisions on the route since the works started. The works have increased traffic congestion in the area, and it is believed this has contributed to the increase in accidents. The police have also noted that some drivers have been driving too fast through the roadworks, despite warnings to slow down. To improve safety on Gdynia Way, Plymouth City Council are taking action. They have installed additional signage and speed cameras to remind drivers to take extra care when travelling through the roadworks. Additionally, they have reduced the speed limit from 30mph to 20mph, and are encouraging drivers to be more aware of their surroundings. In response to the increase in collisions, the council has also set up an online survey for people to submit their views about the works and how they can be improved. The results will be used to help inform any changes that need to be made to make the route safer for all road users.

He argued that you can only have a vibrant West End if you've got a strong regional base developing the talent and he sees no reason why so much more couldn't be done in that area. He argued that a vibrant West End could only be achieved if the region had a strong base for developing talent, and suggested that much more could be done to achieve this. He believes that it is possible to have a thriving West End with a strong regional talent base behind it.

East Sussex Wildlife Rescue said it had rescued 25 birds in the last 12 months at Ditchling Common Country Park. In the latest incident a fishing hook had to be removed from a seagull. The rescue team works hard to ensure that the birds are released back into the wild in the best condition possible. This includes providing medical care, making sure they are well-fed and hydrated, and ensuring they have plenty of space to fly and hunt for food. If necessary, the team will also provide artificial nesting materials to help encourage successful breeding. The team is made up of volunteers who take on all aspects of bird rescue, from rescuing to rehabilitating and releasing birds. They are always looking for new volunteers to help out with their work.

Stuart Coffey, 44, transferred cash from Bracebridge Heath Medical Practice into his own account between 2008 and 2013. Lincoln Crown Court heard he stole so much money the surgery fell into debt and had to close. Coffey was found guilty of four counts of fraud by abuse of position and one count of false accounting. He was sentenced to four years in prison and ordered to pay back 38,000. The court heard Coffey used his position as the practice manager to write cheques to himself, transfer money from the practice's bank account into his own, and make unauthorised refunds to himself. He also doctored the accounts to try and cover his tracks. The court heard that Coffey's actions caused significant financial harm to the practice, leaving it with a large deficit. As a result, the practice was forced to close its doors in 2013, leaving thousands of patients without care.

21 October 2016 Last updated at 15:03 BST In 2008, about 40 were recorded on the seahorse study site at South Beach in the bay, but none have been spotted since The seahorse population at South Beach in San Francisco Bay has not been seen for more than eight years. In 2008, about 40 were recorded on the site during a study, but none have been spotted since. The reason for the disappearance of the seahorses is not clear, but it is thought that overfishing and habitat degradation could be factors. The seahorse population is also vulnerable to changes in water temperature and pollution levels. The discovery of this once abundant species has led to a new research project by the California Academy of Sciences, which hopes to determine what happened to the seahorses and how they can be reintroduced to the area. Researchers are studying the behavior of other types of fish in the bay and looking for signs of seahorse life. The research team will also examine whether the introduction of artificial habitats, such as artificial reefs, could help the seahorses re-establish their presence in the bay. Artificial habitats can provide secure places for seahorses to breed and hide from predators. In addition to the research project, conservation groups are working to protect the remaining seahorse populations in the bay. They are encouraging local fishermen to use sustainable fishing practices and are advocating for better protection of the seahorse habitats. The disappearance of the seahorses from South Beach is a reminder of the fragility of marine ecosystems and the importance of protecting them. Hopefully, with increased awareness and conservation efforts, the seahorses will return to the bay.

The 35-year-old has been without a club since at the end of last season. Morrison scored nine goals in 36 games for Ireland and was part of their squad at Euro 2016. Morrison is a veteran of English football, having played for clubs such as Manchester United, West Ham United, Birmingham City and Cardiff City. He has also had spells in Scotland with Rangers and Hibernian, as well as in Italy with Lazio.

The Lions looked the more dangerous side in the early stages and experienced striker Steve Morison twice hammered efforts over the crossbar. There was little goalmouth action at either end as both sides struggled to get into their passing rhythm. The visitors went close to breaking the deadlock on 28 minutes when Shaun Williams' shot from 25 yards was deflected narrowly over the bar. Millwall began to dominate proceedings and Morison was denied again five minutes later, this time by a stunning save from goalkeeper Joe Murphy. The Shrews strived to hit back but were unable to create any clear-cut chances and went into the break goalless. The second period saw Millwall continue to press for the opener and Ed Upson's free-kick almost did the trick, only for the ball to be cleared off the line by Abu Ogogo. The home side eventually made the breakthrough on 67 minutes when Morison headed home from close range after a brilliant cross from debutant Shane Lowry. The Lions sealed the victory in injury time when substitute John Marquis finished off a fine move with a perfectly struck shot from 12 yards. The win sees Millwall move up to fifth in the table and they will now look to make it four wins in a row when they travel to Peterborough United next week.

Donald Skene grappled with worshippers and headbutted prayers posted on the walls of the Taj Madina Mosque in Victoria Road last December. Skene, 38, was ordered to complete 156 days of unpaid work, pay 85 costs and a statutory surcharge. Skene had pleaded guilty to religiously aggravated intentional harassment, alarm or distress when he appeared before magistrates in Paisley. The court heard that Skene had been drinking heavily when he entered the mosque during prayer time and began shouting abuse and pushing people. He then headbutted the prayers posted on the walls, causing damage to them. Witnesses at the mosque said they feared for their safety and were left shaken by the incident.

A consultation prompted 620 responses, with 98 saying owners should clean up after pets and 69 saying dogs should be excluded from play areas. But 70 did not want to restrict access to play areas. This shows that the majority of people who responded to the consultation felt that owners should clean up after their pets, and over half (69 out of 98) wanted to exclude dogs from play areas. However, a significant minority (70 out of 620) did not want to restrict access to play areas.

Dermot Nolan, chief executive of Ofgem, told the BBC that domestic gas and electricity prices should be cheaper "for the vast majority of people." Wholesale energy costs make up nearly half the average domestic energy bill, and with these costs currently at their lowest in years, many people are asking why their bills have not been cut. Ofgem is working to ensure that customers are benefiting from lower wholesale prices. This includes introducing measures such as the new price cap, which came into effect on 1 January 2019, to protect 11 million households from being overcharged for their energy. Ofgem has also introduced a package of reforms designed to make the energy market more competitive and transparent, including stronger protections for consumers who switch suppliers. This should help customers get the best deal possible, and drive down bills. In addition, Ofgem is working to support innovation in the energy market, to ensure that customers can access smarter, greener energy services. This includes supporting investment in new technologies such as smart meters, which give customers greater control over their energy use and help them save money. Overall, Ofgem is committed to helping customers get the best deal, both now and in the future.

The classic adaptation, which opened on Wednesday, is presented on a set designed like a Victorian toy theatre. Broadbent plays his role with an undercurrent of his well-known affability, according to one reviewer. The production also features a talented cast of young actors, including Isabelle Allen as Little Nell and William Price in the role of Ebenezer Scrooge. The production has received glowing reviews from critics, who praised Broadbent's performance in particular. One reviewer said, "Broadbent is an actor of great subtlety and depth, and his portrayal of Scrooge is both comic and moving." Other reviewers noted the production's attention to detail, with one saying, "The sets, costumes and special effects all combine to create a wonderfully atmospheric and immersive experience." The production has been hailed as a faithful adaptation of the classic tale, and a reminder of the power of Dickens's writing. One reviewer said, "This production captures the spirit of the original story, while also providing a modern twist that will appeal to audiences of all ages." The production is sure to be a hit with fans of the original novel, and of Dickens's work in general.

The pontiff granted Spanish Monsignor Lucio Vallejo Balda a Christmas-time clemency after he served half of his 18-month sentence, the Vatican said. The priest was convicted in July. The leaked information concerned a secret Vatican document on financial reform and the Holy See's relationship with Italian banks. The pontiff granted clemency "out of the love that Jesus has for all of us and especially those who are suffering," a statement from the Vatican said. It added that Pope Francis was taking into consideration "the request for clemency, the conditions of detention and the health status of Monsignor Vallejo Balda." The pope also pardoned Francesca Chaouqui, a former public relations consultant who had been convicted along with the monsignor. The Vatican said she received a "conditional suspension of sentence" because the time limit to serve the brief sentence had already expired. She was sentenced to 10 months in jail but was released after four months in prison due to good behavior and regular attendance of church activities. The pontiff's action came as a sign of mercy during the Christmas season and was seen as a gesture of reconciliation. The pope's decision to grant clemency was also viewed as a way to put an end to the conflict, which had become a distraction to the Vatican's efforts to combat financial scandals.

In a town north of Paris, the two brothers suspected of carrying out the attack on Charlie Hebdo magazine had been holed up at a printing warehouse. They have now been killed. The French police launched a massive manhunt to find the two brothers, Said and Cherif Kouachi, who were wanted in connection with the attack on Charlie Hebdo magazine Wednesday which left 12 people dead. After an intense search, the two brothers were located at a printing warehouse in Dammartin-en-Goele, north of Paris. The two brothers then engaged in an extended gunfight with French police, resulting in their deaths. It is believed that they had taken one person hostage during the stand-off. No other casualties have been reported.

Officers searched properties in the Waterfront Park and Colonsay View areas of the city on Wednesday. Detectives said three firearms, ammunition and a five-figure sum of money were recovered. A man has been charged in connection with the incident. A police spokesperson said: "The firearms are believed to have been used in a number of serious offences, including the attempted murder of a man in the city centre in May this year. "A 31-year-old man has been arrested and charged in connection with the incident and remanded in custody. He will appear at Aberdeen Sheriff Court on Thursday."

A Munster statement said O'Connell, 36, would provide "invaluable technical expertise and advice" to the Irish province's next generation of players. "Every club in the world would love to have Paul in their set-up, so we are absolutely delighted that he has agreed to work with Munster and help develop our next generation of players," said head coach Anthony Foley. The former Ireland lock will work with the province's academy and senior teams, providing coaching and mentoring support along with his technical expertise. He will also be involved in the development and delivery of the Munster Rugby Academy's education programmes. O'Connell, who made 108 Test appearances for Ireland, retired from playing this summer after suffering a serious hamstring injury during the 2015 World Cup. He ended his career at Irish provincial side Munster, where he had spent 14 years. "Munster Rugby played an immensely influential role in my life as a professional rugby player and I am looking forward to being able to contribute back to the province in my new role," he said. "I am passionate about passing on my knowledge and experience to the next generation of Munster players, and I am really excited about the challenge ahead." O'Connell was one of the most successful captains in Irish rugby history, leading Ireland to two Six Nations titles, including the 2009 Grand Slam, and captaining the British Irish Lions in their 2013 series against Australia. He has also been a strong advocate for player welfare, and recently took up a position as an adviser to World Rugby on the issue.

The 777-200, which was carrying 294 passengers from Paris to Vancouver, was diverted to Prestwick after taking off at 10:57 on Saturday. The airline said the plane landed "normally" at 12:48 local time. The cause of the diversion is not yet known, but after an inspection and safety check by engineers, it was determined that the flight could continue to Vancouver. The passengers were given food, drinks, and accommodation during the wait at Prestwick. A spokesperson for Air France said that the diversion was made as a precautionary measure due to a technical issue with the aircraft. The airline added that the safety of the passengers and crew was their top priority. Air France is working to provide the passengers with further assistance and support after their disrupted journey. The airline has offered to reimburse the passengers for any additional expenses incurred due to the diversion. The diverted plane finally arrived in Vancouver on Sunday evening.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi scrapped 1,000 (PS11.8) and 500 notes in a surprise move last week as part of a tax evasion and corruption crackdown. People have a limited time period to deposit the old notes in banks, with the deadline being December 30. The move has been taken to tackle the problem of black money, corruption and counterfeiting of currency. It is also expected to reduce terrorism financing and drug trafficking. The new notes of 500 (PS6.2) and 2,000 (PS24.5) denominations will replace the existing ones. In order to withdraw cash, people need to produce valid identity documents such as Aadhar cards, PAN cards or passports. Banks have been instructed to open special counters for senior citizens and differently abled people to facilitate the process. People can also exchange the old notes at post offices across the country. The government has also announced a number of measures to make sure that people do not face any difficulty during this transition period. This includes allowing households to withdraw up to 24,000 (PS297.4) per week from their bank accounts and providing farmers access to short-term loans using the old notes until November 24.

Hamilton said he was drawing on Ali's famous "rope-a-dope" victory over George Foreman in 1974 as he seeks to close the 29-point gap to the German. "I think about Muhammad Ali and the 'rope-a-dope'," he said. "The 'rope-a-dope' was when Muhammad Ali lay back on the ropes and absorbed all of Foreman's punches and then came back in the later rounds to win. "I feel I am absorbing all of Rosberg's punches but I will come back strong towards the end." Hamilton trails Rosberg by 29 points heading into this weekend's United States Grand Prix, the first of four races remaining in the 2016 season. A victory for Hamilton at Circuit of The Americas would reduce his deficit to 19 points, while a second successive win for Rosberg would see him crowned champion. Hamilton won 10 of the 16 races held so far this year, but two retirements and two other races where he finished off the podium have cost him dearly. He said: "I'm not thinking about trying to win the championship, I'm just thinking about trying to win the race. "It is still possible for me to win the title and I will do everything I can to make it happen. "But my focus is on the race this weekend and winning that. If I can do that then I will be in a better position and take it from there. "I'm not going to give up until it's mathematically impossible."

The service was held at the 22-year-old's school in Ohio, before his burial at a nearby cemetery. His death has heightened tensions between the US and North Korea. Pyongyang has accused the US of "torturing" and "murdering" Warmbier, though US doctors have said there was no evidence of torture. The service itself was a solemn affair, with family members, friends, teachers and community members all in attendance. Hundreds of people lined up to pay their respects to the young man who had tragically lost his life. In his eulogy, Warmbier's father Fred spoke about how his son's death has left an indelible mark on their lives. He also criticized North Korea for its treatment of his son, saying that he had been treated inhumanely by the regime. He concluded his remarks with a call for peace between the two countries. The service also featured several musical performances, including a rendition of "Amazing Grace" and a recording of "What a Wonderful World," which Warmbier had originally recorded as a gift for his family. The church also held a moment of silence for the fallen student, with many attendees wiping away tears during the observance. At the end of the service, Warmbier's family members carried his casket out of the church and to the cemetery, where a private burial would be held. Warmbier's death has sparked debate around the world, with many people questioning why the US government did not do more to help him while he was detained in North Korea. It is clear, however, that his family and friends will never forget the life he lived and the impact he left on those who knew him.
He is the latest casualty of the Trump White House, and takes the record for the shortest term in a top job: he was fired 10 days after being announced as the nominee for National Security Adviser.

Media playback is unsupported on your device 4 May 2015 Last updated at 16:22 BST It's a big deal for people across the country, but everyone's watching Scotland in particular. Voters there will be deciding whether to stay part of the United Kingdom or to become an independent nation. It's a decision that could shape the future of the UK, and it's one that Scots have been discussing for years. So what exactly is at stake? Well, the big question is whether Scotland would remain in the UK if they voted "Yes" to independence. Supporters of the Yes campaign say that if Scotland left the UK, they would still be a member of the European Union, but would not have the same level of representation or influence as they do now. This could mean that decisions made at an EU level could impact on Scotland more than they currently do. On the other hand, those who are against independence argue that being part of the UK gives Scotland more stability and security than it would have as an independent country. They also point out that Scotland benefits from the resources and services provided by the UK government. Ultimately, Scots will need to weigh up these pros and cons when considering their vote on Thursday. Whatever the outcome, it's sure to be an historic day.

13 April 2016 Last updated at 20:41 BST She told BBC TV's Ask the Leader election special it had been a "terrible mistake" for the Lib Dems to make "a foolish promise" to abolish tuition fees in the 2010 election. But she said her party had "learnt from that mistake." Ms Swinson also defended the Lib Dems' decision to go into coalition with the Conservatives in 2010, saying it had allowed the party to deliver "real change." The Lib Dem leader also said she wanted to see a new immigration system based on skills rather than nationality and for the UK to remain part of the EU. She said: "It's a tragedy of historic proportions that we are having this referendum at all."

Cumbernauld has the dubious distinction of winning the Plook on the Plinth title for having Scotland's "most dismal" town centre in 2001 and 2005. Judges have compared it to Kabul and Berlin in 1945. The Plook on the Plinth title, awarded by the think-tank Scotland Future Forum, was given to Cumbernauld in both 2001 and 2005 due to its lack of attractive public space, poor pedestrian access and derelict buildings. The town centre has been described as a "concrete jungle" with "unattractive architecture." The judges compared it to Kabul and Berlin in 1945, labelling it an "urban disaster." Since winning the award, Cumbernauld has sought to improve its town centre through a major regeneration project. This includes investment in public spaces, new housing and improved transport links.

Speaking about the 1948 contract Nye Bevan, the founding father of the NHS, offered consultants, he said he had "stuffed their mouths with gold." That gold was the ability to be able to work independently, free from government interference. This contract gave consultants job security, more money, and the autonomy to practice medicine as they saw fit. This was a radical shift away from the previous system of salaried civil servants working within a set structure. The new contract offered the promise of greater professional freedom and higher wages, but it also came with a new set of responsibilities, such as being accountable for their own decisions and taking responsibility for their own performance. In return, consultants were expected to provide an efficient and effective service.

Only 50.5 overs were possible at the MCG, but Australia still got wickets at regular intervals with Jackson Bird taking two for 53. Azhar's 110-ball half-century saw him pass 1,000 Test runs, and he was eventually dismissed by Mitchell Starc for 65. Pat Cummins also claimed two wickets in the day's play, while Nathan Lyon finished with figures of one for 22 from his eight overs. The Pakistan innings ended on a low note as they were bowled out for 240 in 68.5 overs, giving Australia a lead of 179 runs. Steven Smith (59) and David Warner (58) then put on a century partnership to help Australia reach 2382 before the close of play. Australia will be aiming to build on their lead tomorrow, with Usman Khawaja, Steve Smith and Travis Head all looking in good form. Pakistan will need to take early wickets if they are to have any chance of salvaging a draw from this match.

7 November 2016 Last updated at 09:30 GMT The balls are formed naturally and happen when pieces of ice get rolled by wind and water. They stretch on the Siberian coast of the Arctic Ocean. The balls are up to 15cm in diameter and look like snowballs but they are made of ice. The natural phenomenon has been known since the 19th century, but scientists have still not explained why they form. Some have suggested that ice on the beach is pushed around by powerful waves, while others believe that snow becomes water-logged and then freezes into a ball shape. Whatever the explanation, the balls are now a tourist attraction in Siberia, with people coming from all over the world to see them. They are also a reminder of the importance of looking after our environment, as climate change affects the Arctic region faster than anywhere else in the world.

The security breach led to the possible theft of bitcoin worth 65m (PS49m). Bitfinex told the Reuters news agency on Wednesday that nearly 120,000 bitcoin were stolen from its exchange , which the company valued at around 65 million. The breach occurred on Tuesday evening and Bitfinex was able to quickly identify the intrusion and immediately shut down all operations. The company stated that it is cooperating with law enforcement agencies to investigate the matter and take whatever steps are necessary to protect its customers' funds. Bitfinex is one of the world's largest digital currency exchanges and reported a high-profile hack in August 2016. It said that approximately 72 million worth of bitcoin were stolen in that attack. This latest theft is significantly higher than the previous one and could have a significant impact on the cryptocurrency market.

Ex-Manchester United trainee McGinty, 21, played 13 times for the Conference club after joining on loan in February. "It's a fantastic move for me at this stage in my career. I am looking forward to the challenge of playing in League One," he said. I am excited and humbled to have signed for Rochdale FC. This is a great opportunity for me to continue my development as a footballer, and I cannot wait to get started. I know that Rochdale is an ambitious club with a passionate fanbase and I am looking forward to helping the team achieve success this season.
Reactions range from the "BBC has killed Top Gear," to praise for a "brave BBC." The story was also news for media in areas as far apart as Latin America and the Middle East.

The company said it had faced a "chorus of music label representatives and artists" accusing it of "mistreating" songwriters and performers. Hank Green, a prominent video producer and entrepreneur, said he had been in touch with SoundCloud about the issue. "We've been talking with SoundCloud for months about the need to pay artists and songwriters more fairly," Green wrote on Twitter. "While they have taken some steps, there's still a lot of work to be done." The company said it was taking "immediate action" to address the concerns, including introducing a new royalty system that will give artists and labels a larger share of revenue generated from their music. It also said it would create new tools to improve transparency and visibility into how its payments are distributed. SoundCloud said it was also working with labels and artists to ensure the platform is "fairly compensated" for their work. "We take our responsibility to the creative community very seriously, and we want to make sure everyone has a chance to see the fruits of their labor," the company said in a statement.

The move was announced by President Thein Sein, who earlier rejected UN calls for an independent inquiry. The clashes between Rakhine Buddhists and Rohingya Muslims also displaced thousands of people. The government said it would investigate the clashes, but rights groups have criticised the lack of independence and impartiality of the inquiry. The government has been accused of discriminating against the Rohingya, who are denied citizenship and face restrictions on their movement.

Grant Ward's scuffed shot put Town ahead before Luke Varney rolled the ball into an empty net after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance. Cole Skuse's long-range shot fell to Varney in the box, who drove the ball home for his second goal of the season. Ward was fouled on the edge of the area and stepped up to take the free kick, curling it over the wall and into the bottom corner past the despairing dive of Smithies.

Jim McCafferty, 71, appeared before Belfast Magistrates' Court charged with eight counts of touching a boy under the age of 16. The crimes are alleged to have happened in Belfast between August 1979 and August 1980. McCafferty, who was a youth coach at Manchester United, appeared in court wearing a white baseball cap and blue shirt. He spoke only to confirm his name, age and address during the brief hearing. The judge refused bail and McCafferty was remanded in custody until October 10th. He was also ordered to sign the Police Service of Northern Ireland's sex offenders' register. McCafferty has indicated that he will plead not guilty to all charges.

The 30-year-old signed a new three-year contract with Notts on Monday. Gurney told BBC Radio Nottingham: "Notts are a very special club with a lot of history. In my five years here, I've grown more and more to love it. "I'm very proud to commit my future here and hopefully help the club go from strength to strength. I hope to have many more successful years with Notts."

Gerard Kevin Hughes, 29, and Gavin Martin Hughes, 31, who are both from Springfield Park in Belfast, appeared in court alongside their older brother Joseph Christopher Hughes, 35, from The Dales in Belfast. Gerard Hughes pleaded guilty to possession of a firearm with intent to cause fear of violence and two counts of assaulting police officers. Gavin Hughes admitted one count of possessing a firearm with intent to cause fear of violence and one count of affray. Joseph Hughes pleaded guilty to one count of affray. The court heard that on the evening of 2 August 2020 the three brothers had been at a bar in Belfast city centre and had become involved in an altercation with another group of people. When police arrived, the brothers began to walk away, but Gerard Hughes produced a handgun and pointed it at police officers, who challenged him and he dropped the weapon. The gun was later found to be an imitation firearm. The court also heard that Gavin Hughes punched one of the officers in the face and Gerard Hughes attempted to punch and kick the officers before they were eventually restrained. Sentencing the brothers, Judge David McFarland said: "This was a serious incident involving firearms in a busy city centre and could have had devastating consequences. "It is clear from the CCTV footage that the police officers acted bravely and professionally in trying to diffuse the situation and that their actions prevented a more serious incident from occurring." Gerard Hughes was sentenced to four years imprisonment, Gavin Hughes was sentenced to 12 months imprisonment and Joseph Hughes was given a suspended sentence of 15 months.

The government wants some households to pay more to raise money for education, and finance secretary Derek Mackay gave evidence to committee backing the plan. The committee formally recommended the plan, expressing support for the policy. Mackay argued that it was necessary to raise more money to fund improvements in education. He argued that the additional revenue would allow the government to provide more resources and reduce class sizes, as well as invest in high-quality teaching and learning. The committee proposed a graduated tax system, which would see some households paying higher rates of taxation than others, depending on their level of income. This would be implemented through changes to the Council Tax system, with different thresholds for each band. Mackay noted that the Scottish Government had already committed to freezing the basic rate of income tax, and that this plan would not increase the overall tax burden for Scots. He also pointed out that the additional revenues generated by these new taxes would be invested back into public services, such as education, and that this would help Scotland reach its ambition of becoming one of the most successful small countries in the world. Finally, Mackay highlighted the need to ensure that any changes to the tax system are fair and that those on lower incomes are not disproportionately impacted. To this end, the Scottish Government will set up an independent body to review the impact of any reforms.

Hirst rose from humble beginnings in Leeds to become the UK's richest living artist, worth PS215m according to the Sunday Times' Rich List. Penguin Books has promised to push the boundaries of art by publishing his first book. The book, entitled "Damien Hirst: Thoughts, Work, Life" will be an intimate look at the artist's creative process and the story behind some of his most iconic works. It will also feature interviews with Hirst, as well as contributions from leading curators, dealers, critics and collectors. The book will give readers unprecedented access to the man behind the artwork, as well as insight into the art world and what it takes to become a successful artist. Hirst is known for his often controversial work that ranges from sculpture, painting and photography to installations, prints and drawings. He has been described as both an innovator and provocateur. His art has been exhibited in some of the world's most prestigious galleries, including the Tate Modern and the Guggenheim Museum. Penguin Books are confident that the book will be popular amongst fans of Hirst's work, as well as those who are interested in contemporary art. The publisher believes that the book will provide a unique insight into the mind of one of today's most influential artists.

They were arrested last week by police investigating dissident republican activity in the area. Three men, aged 22, 24 and 46, have been charged with targeting a former member of the security forces and with preparing for acts of terrorism. The three men have been remanded in custody and are due to appear before Belfast Magistrates' Court on November 12. The Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) has confirmed that the investigation is ongoing. The charges are in relation to the attempted murder of a former member of the security forces, which occurred at the end of August this year. The PSNI said it had uncovered evidence that an explosive device was placed in a vehicle in order to target the former member of the security forces. The PSNI has also stated that they believe the men were part of a wider dissident republican group that is active in the area. They are also investigating links between the men and other dissident republican groups in Northern Ireland.

United Nations officials rarely use the words "genocide" and "ethnic cleansing," but they now say potentially both could envelop the world's youngest country. Since violence flared in Juba in July , the UN estimates that 300,000 people have been forced from their homes. The United Nations has warned that the situation in South Sudan could spiral into genocide and ethnic cleansing if the violence is not stopped. The UN's special representative to South Sudan, David Shearer, said at a press conference on Wednesday that the humanitarian crisis in the country is "deeply alarming" and that the UN is "extremely concerned" about reports of targeted killings and displacement along ethnic lines. He also noted that the UN has seen an increase in cases of sexual violence, including rape and abduction of women and girls. Shearer called on all parties to the conflict to immediately cease hostilities and engage in a meaningful dialogue to find a political solution to the crisis.

Media playback is not supported on this device Serena, 35, won 6-4 6-4 to pass Steffi Graf in the all-time list of major winners since the Grand Slams accepted professional players in 1968. Serena Williams has broken the record for most Grand Slam singles titles won by a professional tennis player, male or female, after winning her 23rd major title at the 2017 Australian Open. Williams, 35, beat her sister Venus 6-4 6-4 in the final in Melbourne to pass Steffi Graf's 22-title haul. It was her seventh Australian Open crown and she is now one ahead of Graf on the all-time list of major winners since the Grand Slams accepted professional players in 1968. Williams, who is also the oldest women's Grand Slam singles champion in the professional era, said: "It's such a great feeling. I don't even know how to feel because I literally didn't think I'd get this far." The American has now won more than twice as many majors as any other active female player. She has earned 84 million (74m) in prize money alone, making her the highest-earning female sportswoman in history.

"I'm frustrated to say the least, but very pleased that we've stayed in this division," Hodges told BBC Cornwall. "In a couple weeks time I'll be pleased we're still in the league. "It's not been a season to remember, but survival is survival and I will take it." The result leaves Truro one point above fellow strugglers Weston-super-Mare with one game remaining, knowing that victory would secure their place in the division for another season. Hodges added: "The team have been unbelievable since I've come in, they worked their socks off. "It's a relief more than anything else. We need to make sure that we finish the job on Saturday and get the three points."

Panthers kept alive their title hopes and closed the gap on leaders Devils to four points. Two goals from Matthew Myers put Panthers in control before Joey Martin replied. Franklin Morrison then made sure of the points with a late third. Panthers now have six games left to play in their title chase and will be hoping to continue their strong form in order to overtake the Devils. The next game for Panthers is against fellow title contenders, Wolves, so a win there could be crucial in deciding which team lifts the trophy.

Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others, a sweeping account of life in 1960s Calcutta, is 52 favourite to win with bookmakers William Hill. It is the first year that the prize has been open to writers from India and Pakistan, as well as authors from the UK. The novel tells the story of a group of characters who are caught up in a period of sweeping social upheaval, as the city of Calcutta is transformed by an influx of migrants from rural areas. It examines how their lives intersect with those of the city's wealthy elite, and how the forces of politics, religion, and culture shape their experiences. Through its vivid and intimate portrayals, Mukherjee's novel offers a unique window into the life of a city in transition.

As Abid Naseer started his cross-examination in a New York courtroom of the police officer who searched his Manchester bedroom in 2009, he commented it was nice to hear a witness who "wasn't paid by the prosecution." Naseer is charged with plotting to blow up a shopping center in Manchester and other locations in the United Kingdom. The trial has been underway since March 2017, and is expected to conclude in late April or early May 2018. Naseer has maintained his innocence throughout the proceedings, claiming he was merely in the wrong place at the wrong time. He alleges that the police officers who searched his bedroom did not mention the presence of any explosives or weapons during the search. Naseer has also stated that he was not an active member of Al Qaeda, as prosecutors have claimed. The police officer in question was one of several officers involved in the search of Naseer's bedroom in 2009. He testified that he found no evidence of terrorist activity during the search. On cross-examination, Naseer asked the officer if it was possible that something could have been missed during the search, to which the officer replied that it was "possible but highly unlikely." Naseer's attorneys are hopeful that the officer's testimony will help their client's case, as it provides evidence that there were no explosives or weapons present during the search. However, the jury is still deliberating on the verdict and it remains to be seen how they will decide.

Jimmy Carlson, 64, from Islington, north London, has been appointed OBE for helping to improve services. The former alcoholic became homeless after he was discharged from the Army. Doctor Daniel Fisher, a consultant psychiatrist at the Royal National Hospital for Rheumatic Diseases in Bath, said: "Jimmy has been a valuable member of our team for many years. He is an inspiration to anyone who has suffered from addiction or homelessness. His work has made a real difference in improving services for vulnerable people." Jimmy Carlson's appointment as an OBE is a well-deserved recognition of his tireless hard work in helping to improve services for vulnerable people. His own personal struggles have made him an excellent role model for those affected by addiction and homelessness. His commitment to helping others is admirable and he is a true asset to our society. We are proud of him and thankful for all he has done.

Angus Carpenter, of Liverpool, who has played in the city centre for more than 30 years, denied three counts of fraud. The 62-year-old was found guilty of one count when a jury at Liverpool Crown Court returned its verdict after less than two hours of deliberation. Carpenter had previously pleaded guilty to two counts of fraudulently obtaining money from members of the public by claiming he was entitled to receive donations for his guitar playing. He had denied the third charge, which related to him falsely claiming to be the owner of guitars and amplifiers that he used while performing in the city centre. At trial, Carpenter argued that he genuinely believed he was entitled to accept donations and that the guitars and equipment belonged to him, as he had a past agreement with the owner of the equipment. However, the prosecution said that Carpenter had deceived members of the public and had not made it clear that he was asking for donations. The judge sentenced Carpenter to a 12-month community order, 150 hours of unpaid work and ordered him to pay costs of 1,000.

The leak happened at the Worthy Farm site in Somerset in June 2014 and damaged water quality and killed fish. Founder Michael Eavis, who was at Yeovil Magistrates' Court, said he had failed to act "with due diligence" in not taking steps to prevent the pollution. The leak was caused by a blocked or damaged pipe which allowed diesel fuel to flow into a field, polluting a nearby watercourse. The Environment Agency said the leak killed around 600 fish, including eels and trout, and affected 200 metres of the stream.
