Some 1,500 officers have been deployed to the Olympic Stadium area, authorities have said. Officials are in high alert following Tuesday's attacks in Brussels. Last year, a friendly between Germany and France was cancelled after a suspect was arrested with explosives near the stadium. Police have increased patrols in the area, and will be conducting random searches of bags and vehicles. Authorities have also asked citizens to remain vigilant and to report any suspicious activity. France's interior minister has said that there is no specific threat or intelligence of an imminent attack at the Olympic Stadium.

From April 2016, those in England and Wales will have to pay a 3 surcharge on each stamp duty band. George Osborne said the new surcharge would raise PS1bn extra each year. The extra money will be used to fund new homes for nurses, teachers and other public sector workers. The surcharge is a 3 tax on the purchase price of any residential property purchased in England or Wales. So, if you buy an 200,000 house, you would have to pay an additional 6,000 in stamp duty. The surcharge applies to all residential properties, including buy-to-let investments and second homes. However, the government has said that first-time buyers will be exempt from the extra 3 levy. The new surcharge is part of a package of measures announced by the Chancellor to help tackle the UK's housing crisis. Other measures include allowing local councils to borrow more money to build new homes, and giving them more powers to charge higher council tax on empty homes.

Even with the usual caveats attached to opinion polls, a 65 to 17 majority for Northern Ireland remaining in the UK suggests little room for doubt. The British and Irish governments should take it as a clear sign of the will of the people. This should be taken as a clear sign that the majority of people in Northern Ireland do not wish to leave the UK and that the British and Irish governments should respect this. It is important that the governments recognise the will of the people and work together to ensure their wishes are respected. This could mean finding a way to make the current arrangements work better, or it could involve finding an alternative solution that allows both sides to remain part of the UK while still respecting each other's autonomy. Whatever the solution, it is clear that the people of Northern Ireland have spoken and the governments must listen.

"It gives me a lot of confidence and a lot of good friends," says one of the players on a five-a-side football pitch in the north of Glasgow. He's moving the ball around with ease, his body language suggesting a kind of confidence that belies his years. He's part of a group of young people who meet here every Saturday afternoon to play five-a-side football. They come from all over Glasgow, some from as far away as East Kilbride and Cumbernauld. The sense of camaraderie between them is palpable. They banter, joke and encourage each other, but when the whistle blows it's time for business. The game begins in earnest and the players show off their skills. The ball zips around the pitch, bodies collide and the atmosphere is electric. There are no referees or rules; just an unspoken understanding that everyone is playing by the same set of rules. At the end of the match, the score doesn't matter; what matters is that everyone had a good time and they've made some new friends. That's why they come back week after week - not to win, but to enjoy each other's company. For these young people, five-a-side football isn't just about the game, it's about community. It's about building relationships and having fun. It's about developing skills and feeling accepted. In these few hours on the pitch, they find an escape from the pressures of everyday life and can just be themselves.

The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said it had identified 33 local areas where pubs would not face sufficient competition after the deal. Heineken, which already owns 1,100 pubs, must now sell off the pubs it bought from Greene King in those areas. The CMA said that allowing Heineken to keep the pubs could have resulted in pubgoers facing higher prices and reduced choice. Heineken must now find a buyer for the pubs or be forced to close them. The CMA has given the company six months to sell the pubs, with a further four months for the sale to be completed. The decision marks the end of an investigation that began in March 2020. It is the latest in a series of high-profile cases where the CMA has stepped in to protect competition in the UK's pub industry.

Two men were attacked in Ivory Blacks in Oswald Street, Glasgow, at about 23:00 on Friday 14 October. Last month, officers released images of two men they want to speak to in connection with the attack. The incident is being treated as a hate crime and police are appealing for anyone who was in the area at the time or has information about the two men to come forward. Police Scotland are asking anyone with information to contact them on 101, quoting incident number 4295 of 14 October. Alternatively, information can be passed anonymously to Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

The move apparently follows a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. It also comes ahead of a speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by US Secretary of State John Kerry. The move was seen as a sign that Netanyahu is concerned the US may present proposals on the conflict he will not find acceptable. It comes after Kerry met with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas in Jordan on Wednesday, and his talks with Netanyahu and other Israeli officials this week. Kerry has indicated he plans to present proposals for a way forward in peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians, which have been stalled since April 2014. There have been reports that Washington may be prepared to recognize a Palestinian state based on pre-1967 borders, with East Jerusalem as its capital. Netanyahu has repeatedly said he opposes any "artificial" solution imposed on Israel by the international community.

Five Give Up the Booze, Five Go Gluten Free, Five Go On A Strategy Away Day and Five Go Parenting will catch up with the sleuthing children as adults. The five who gave up the booze, gluten free, and went on a strategy away day will all have grown up to be successful adults who have figured out how to cope with the challenges life throws at them. The five who went parenting will have all developed strong relationships with their children, realizing the importance of communication and understanding in creating a strong family bond.

Energy company BG Group said it was gradually taking workers from the Lomond installation - about 145 miles east of Aberdeen - by helicopter. A Norwegian vessel which caught fire off the coast of Shetland on Tuesday was carrying a 100-strong crew, including BG Group staff. The company said it had taken all workers from Lomond to its St Fergus gas plant in Aberdeenshire. It said: "BG Group can confirm that all personnel have been taken from the Lomond installation and transferred to our St Fergus gas plant. "The transfer was completed by air and sea. We would again like to thank the emergency services for their prompt response and assistance." The fire broke out on board the Norwegian vessel Bourbon Dolphin, which was about seven miles south east of Sumburgh Head, Shetland, on Tuesday afternoon. All 100 people on board were rescued and no injuries were reported.

The 27-year-old Scot, who is back at number four in the world after dropping down the rankings following back surgery, is to marry girlfriend Kim Sears in April. Murray is a former US Open and Wimbledon champion. The couple have been together for several years and announced their engagement in November. Murray said he was "very happy" with the news and looked forward to starting a family with Sears. He also said that he hoped to win more Grand Slams in the future. The wedding will take place in the UK and is expected to be attended by Murray's family, friends, and fellow tennis players. Murray and Sears are already living together in Surrey.

Attempt saved. John Swift (Reading) left footed shot from the centre of the box is saved in the centre of the goal. Offside, Fulham. Ryan Fredericks tries a through ball, but it is blocked by the defender.

28 June 2016 Last updated at 08:03 BST On 1 July 1916, British soldiers started fighting in the Battle of the Somme. The people in charge said that the battle would be over in a few days. But it did not end until 18 November 1916. More than one million people were killed or injured. The Battle of the Somme was one of the biggest battles of World War I. It was fought between German and British-French forces. The battle started when British soldiers attacked German positions on 1 July 1916. They wanted to break through the German lines and take control of the River Somme. But the attack failed. The British soldiers had to fight for weeks in trenches full of mud and water. They faced strong German defenses, machine guns, and poison gas. On the first day of fighting, more than 19,000 British soldiers were killed and another 36,000 were injured. The battle lasted 150 days. In the end, neither side won. Britain and France took control of some ground but the Germans still held most of it. One million people were killed or injured on both sides. The Battle of the Somme is remembered as one of the bloodiest battles in history. It was also a big turning point in World War I. After the battle, both sides changed the way they fought and used new weapons like tanks.

During the first nine months of 1938, he oversaw the Czech Kindertransport, which brought Jewish children from German-occupied Czechoslovakia to safety in the UK. He worked tirelessly to ensure money was raised to support the children, and he also assisted in arranging travel documents, visas and other necessary paperwork. He visited refugee camps in Britain to assess and improve conditions for refugees, and he wrote several articles advocating for their rights. He also served as a liaison between the British government, Jewish organizations, and individuals seeking refuge in Britain.

Another 130 people were wounded in what authorities said was a "premeditated, violent terrorist attack." Four suspects were shot dead, one arrested and other are being sought Xinhua said. City police chief Li Jinguo called the attack an "organized, premeditated and carefully planned violent terrorist incident." The attack began around 10 p.m. when a group of assailants wearing black clothes, carrying knives, and some with explosives strapped to their bodies stormed into the railway station in Kunming, the capital of Yunnan province. The attackers hacked at people with knives and detonated explosive devices. It is not yet known who was behind the attack, but authorities said they were looking into all possibilities. Yunnan province borders Myanmar, Laos and Vietnam and has a large Muslim population.

Boyle struck the only goal in the 18th minute after lobbing over Graham Doyle following a moment of hesitancy in the Wexford defence. Derry needed fine saves from Gerard Doherty to deny Wexford a point in the final minutes. The win leaves Derry in second place, four points behind leaders Sligo Rovers and with a game in hand. Derry manager Stephen Kenny said he was pleased with the performance of his side, who had not played for three weeks due to postponements. "It was a difficult game. Wexford have done very well this season and they have a good set-up," said Kenny. "We were a bit rusty at times but we did enough to get the win. It was a great goal from Rory and it was important to get the win." Wexford manager Shane Keegan said he felt his side had created enough chances to get something out of the game. "We are disappointed because I thought we played well, especially in the second half," said Keegan. "We had some good chances but unfortunately we just couldn't take them."

The pedestrian died following an incident involving a green car in the Diamond area on Sunday afternoon. Police said an 18-year-old woman had been arrested. They have appealed for information. The Metropolitan Police said they were called to reports of a pedestrian being hit by a car in the Diamond area at around 4pm on Sunday. The pedestrian, who has not been named, was pronounced dead at the scene. A spokesperson for the police said: "We have arrested an 18-year-old woman on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving. She remains in custody." They have appealed for anyone who witnessed the incident to contact them, and for anyone with dashcam footage to come forward. In a statement, the Met Police said: "This is a tragic incident in which a person has lost their life. We are doing all we can to piece together the events leading up to the collision and would urge anyone who may be able to assist our investigation to get in touch."

He was chairman for 16 years, during which time the club enjoyed an 11-year stint in the Premier League and two Uefa Cup campaigns. "This is a very sad day for me and I wish the club all the best for the future," he said. Under his stewardship, Bolton Wanderers became one of the most successful clubs in England, winning the League Cup in 1995 and reaching the UEFA Cup final in 2004. He was also instrumental in the development of the Macron Stadium, the club's home ground since 1997.

Slovakia is launching a legal challenge to mandatory quotas that were passed in a majority vote on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Hungary's prime minister has proposed a radical budgetary revamp to raise funds to support the country's immigration policies. The Slovakian government has filed a legal challenge against the mandatory quotas at the European Court of Justice, arguing that they violated EU law. The move is likely to be seen as an attempt to undermine the European Union's refugee policy, which seeks to share the burden of hosting refugees among its member states. Slovakia argues that it should not be forced to accept refugees who are not from its own region and have little chance of being integrated into society. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban has proposed a radical budget revamp which includes cutting welfare benefits and raising taxes to fund his country's immigration policies. This includes deploying thousands of additional police officers to monitor Hungary's borders, as well as paying for the construction of a wall on the Serbian-Hungarian border. He also plans to create a "border hunter" unit to track down migrants who enter Hungary illegally. The proposal has been widely criticized by human rights activists, who argue it would lead to more human rights abuses.

Members of the RMT union will walk out at 11:00 BST on 26 April and at the same time on 10 and 12 May. The union is against plans for driver-only operated trains as part of a modernisation process introduced by South Western Railway. The strike action will affect the entire network, including routes from London Waterloo, Reading and Windsor Eton Riverside. Services on these routes will be severely disrupted, with many journeys being cancelled and some lines closed altogether. Passengers can expect to experience delays and overcrowding throughout the period. South Western Railway have said they are doing everything they can to minimise disruption and keep passengers informed. They have advised commuters to check their website for updates and allow extra time for their journey.

That phrase hinted both at an ideal flexible arrangement in the future and an ideal shared approach from both the UK and Irish governments, together stressing to the EU the need for flexibility in the context of Brexit. The phrase suggests that both the UK and Irish governments should work together to ensure that the European Union is open to finding flexible solutions that can accommodate the needs of both countries in the Brexit negotiations. It implies that the two governments should make their case to the EU as a unified front, emphasizing the importance of finding practical solutions that meet both sides' needs. This could involve advocating for more relaxed regulations, greater access to markets, or other measures that allow the UK and Ireland to benefit from Brexit without suffering economic hardship.

After no play was possible on the first day, Stevens led Kent to 389-7 after Essex's decision to bowl first. They had slipped to 208-6 with Essex seamer Matt Dixon taking 3-11. Kent's innings was rescued by the lower order with Stevens (75) and James Tredwell (66) both recording half centuries. Essex finished the second day on 106-2. Stevens, who was appointed Kent captain in October 2010, had been out of action since August 2011 when he suffered a broken ankle while batting against Surrey at The Oval. His last match before his injury was against Essex at Chelmsford when he made 71 not out. The 30-year-old has scored 4,936 first-class runs at an average of 31.30 and has taken 51 wickets with his medium pace bowling. He said: "I'm happy to be back playing for Kent again and it was great to get some runs. It was nice to see so many people turn up to watch me return as well." Kent coach Jimmy Adams added: "It was good to have Rob back in our team and it is especially pleasing that he was able to contribute with bat and ball. He will now look to build on this performance in the next few weeks."

The mayor of London has been criticised for pedalling his barrister wife Marina Wheeler through the capital on Thursday on a bicycle designed for one person. Giving a backie is illegal on all UK roads. The mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, has been criticised for allowing his barrister wife Marina Wheeler to ride on the back of his bicycle in the capital. While giving a backie is common in some countries, it is illegal in all UK roads and is considered to be an act of inconsiderate and dangerous cycling. Khan has since apologised for his "error of judgement" and said that he was unaware that it was against the law. He has reminded cyclists of the importance of always being aware of the rules of the road and abiding by them. He said he would take greater care in future to ensure he sets a good example.

Dewi and Dwynwen, named after two of Wales' most renowned patron saints, are nestled in a romantic "cwtch." Their arrival marks the launch of a campaign by heritage body Cadw to promote Wales as a destination for romantic getaways. The new campaign, called "Cwtch Wales," aims to encourage locals and visitors alike to explore the beauty of Wales and create special memories in its stunning landscapes. As part of the campaign, Cadw has launched an interactive website featuring romantic stories, tips and ideas on how to make the most of a romantic break in Wales. Visitors can also learn about the legends behind each saint and create their own personalised itinerary. The campaign also features an interactive map that highlights romantic places to visit in Wales, such as castles, beaches, forests, and villages. With its impressive array of activities, breathtaking scenery, and delicious food, Wales is the perfect destination for a romantic getaway. Cwtch Wales is a great way to discover Wales' hidden gems and find out more about its rich history and culture. Whether it's a romantic weekend away or a week-long adventure, couples will be sure to find something special in Wales.

Edwards, 23, has scored three goals in 127 games for the Shrimps since joining from Blackburn Rovers in May 2014, with two in 50 appearances last season. The centre-half was a regular in the Shrimps' starting line-up last season, making 36 appearances in League Two. He said: "I'm really pleased to get the move done. I'm excited to be here and looking forward to meeting the lads and starting pre-season training. "The club had a great season last year and I'm looking forward to helping the team push on even further this season." Edwards is the second new signing of the summer for Morecambe after the arrival of striker Tom Barkhuizen from Blackpool earlier this month.

The Newry firm had been run by its founder Lord Ballyedmond, until his death in a helicopter crash in March. Mr Nagle is currently the chairman of the Dublin-based Sisk Group and has been a director since 2011. He said: "Making this acquisition is a major milestone in the history of Newry-based Norbrook Laboratories. This transaction will secure the future of the business, its people and its customers. "The acquisition by Sisk provides an opportunity to grow the business in new markets and to continue to deliver high quality products and services. We are very excited about the prospects for Norbrook and look forward to building on its success." Sisk said it will invest in Norbrook's core business and research and development. It plans to expand Norbrook's presence in international markets, particularly in Europe and the United States. Norbrook was founded in 1969 and supplies veterinary pharmaceuticals and animal health products to more than 70 countries around the world. It employs over 1,000 people across six sites in Northern Ireland, England and the Republic of Ireland.

Media playback is not supported on this device City, who shocked Chelsea en route to last season's quarter-final, went ahead from Kyel Reid's 18-yard finish before James Hanson's angled strike. City, who were promoted from League Two last season, put the result beyond doubt with Hanson's second and Nahki Wells' 20-yard effort. Chelsea's best chance fell to Juan Mata, who hit the post late on. It was an impressive performance by City, who had knocked out Wigan Athletic in the fourth round, and they are now one of only four teams outside the top flight still in the competition. Manager Phil Parkinson said: "It was a magnificent performance. From start to finish we played some terrific football. "We're a team that can compete at this level. We've got a lot of confidence, a lot of belief and I'm very proud of the players."

The world's number one aeroplane manufacturer made sales of 94.6bn, down 2, and net earnings of 4.9bn, 5 lower. It said revenues were likely to slip further in 2017, to about 88bn. The company is Boeing, the largest manufacturer of commercial aircraft in the world. The 94.6 billion in sales and 4.9 billion in net earnings were reported for 2016. The company has forecast a further drop in revenues to around 88 billion in 2017 due to the current challenging market conditions.

Mr Jepson, who died in August, began his affiliation with the club in the 1960s and was named president in 2004. The service took place at Headingley Stadium earlier. Rhinos chairman Gary Hetherington spoke in tribute to Jepson. "He was a passionate and proud supporter of the club since the 1960s and his commitment to the Rhinos never wavered," said Hetherington. "He was an inspirational leader of the board for many years, always providing sound advice and a true sense of direction." Mr Jepson worked tirelessly for the Rhinos and was instrumental in securing the club's move from Headingley to their current home at Emerald Headingley Stadium. He was also heavily involved in the redevelopment of the North Stand and the move to full-time professional rugby league in 1996. "He was the driving force behind the redevelopment of the North Stand, which transformed the matchday experience for supporters," added Hetherington. "His legacy will live on, not just through the stadium but through the generations of supporters who have benefitted from his passion and commitment to the club."

Greg Dyke has invited Astle's widow Laraine and his daughters, Claire and Dawn, to Wembley Stadium on 10 August. The ex-West Bromwich Albion and England forward died in 2002. A memorial match is being held in his honour and Dyke hopes it will be a fitting tribute to the popular striker. The three family members of Astle have been invited to attend the match at Wembley Stadium on 10 August. They will be presented with a commemorative plaque by Dyke to mark the occasion, as a lasting tribute to their beloved husband and father. The match itself will feature current players from Astle's former clubs and international sides. As part of the pre-match festivities, there will be a minute's applause in memory of Astle, and a special video montage of his career highlights. There will also be an opportunity for fans to pay their respects and leave messages of love and appreciation.

Goals from Declan McManus and Cardle had the hosts 2-0 up in 11 minutes. Falkirk's Craig Sibbald was red carded for foul and abusive language and Lee Miller was also sent off for the visitors. McManus then added a third with a fine solo goal before Cardle notched his second from the penalty spot after John Baird had been brought down. Kallum Higginbotham made it five before Baird grabbed a late consolation for Falkirk.

The crash happened at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. Lincolnshire Police said the motorcyclist killed in the collision lived locally, but has not released his identity. The force said he was riding a black Honda CBR1000RR motorbike and that it was in collision with a green Ford Fiesta. The driver of the car, a 17-year-old man from Lincoln, was taken to hospital with minor injuries. The road was closed for several hours while emergency services attended the scene. Anyone who witnessed the crash or saw either vehicle before it happened is asked to contact police.

The report found that although alcohol consumption has dropped since 2008, those in poorer communities are more likely to suffer or die from alcohol-related disease. The coalition government rejected a minimum price for alcohol, fearing it would hit responsible drinkers. The report concluded that although a minimum price may not be the best course of action, more needs to be done to tackle the causes of alcohol-related harm in disadvantaged communities. It recommended providing better education and treatment services, introducing targeted pricing policies, and strengthening enforcement of existing laws on underage drinking. The government should also look into further regulation of the marketing and advertising of alcoholic beverages.

The 335ft (100m) Victorian structure, which closed last year, is one of the UK's shortest piers. Bryan Huxford, who co-owns Humberside Airport, said he would soon reopen the pier as a leisure attraction. The pier, which opened in 1854, was designed by the architect Sir John Hawkshaw and was a popular tourist destination for more than 150 years. The Grade II listed structure has been closed since 2014, when it was bought by Mr Huxford. Mr Huxford said he had teamed up with the local council to develop a plan to restore the pier and transform it into a leisure venue. He said that he hoped to reopen the pier with a restaurant, bar, and museum. He also plans to create a performance space for live music and theatre events. Mr Huxford said: "This is an exciting project and I'm passionate about creating something special for Hull. I want to make sure this wonderful pier becomes a focal point for the city once again." The restoration work is expected to begin later this year and should be finished by 2018.

Research shows Europeans are a mixture of three major ancestral populations - indigenous hunters, Middle Eastern farmers and a population that arrived from the east in the Bronze Age. DNA analysis of ancient remains has revealed that most Europeans are a mix of these three ancestral populations. The indigenous hunter-gatherers were the first inhabitants of Europe, living in the region for thousands of years before the arrival of Middle Eastern farmers and the Bronze Age population from the east. These hunter-gatherers had a predominantly dark skin tone and were distributed across Europe until they were eventually absorbed into the growing farming populations. Middle Eastern farmers migrated to Europe around 8,000 years ago, bringing with them their own unique genetic lineages. This group is thought to have played an important role in introducing new technology and crops to Europe, as well as contributing genetically to the European gene pool. The Bronze Age population from the east arrived in Europe around 3,500 years ago, bringing with them Indo-European languages and cultural influences. This population is believed to have been mainly composed of male warriors, who left a strong genetic legacy in the form of Y-chromosome haplogroups. Overall, Europeans today are a mixture of all three ancestral populations, and the proportions vary depending on geography. For example, northern Europeans tend to have higher levels of ancestry from the Middle Eastern farmers, while southern Europeans have higher levels of ancestry from the Bronze Age population.

A referendum on the UK's membership of the EU is to be held later this year. The survey indicates that only 11 of of the chamber's members in Northern Ireland are in favour of leaving the EU. Those 11 members, who represent a majority of people in Northern Ireland, have argued that leaving the EU would be beneficial for the region's economy and would help protect its borders from illegal immigration. They also believe that the UK should have more control over its own laws and regulations. However, opponents of leaving the EU counter that it would be damaging to Northern Ireland's economy and could lead to a hard border with the Republic of Ireland. They also point out that leaving the EU would mean losing access to the single market and other benefits associated with being part of the European Union.

Media playback is not supported on this device "You're not wanted any more" rang around Cherry Red Records Stadium in Kingston as the home supporters put their own twist on the chant after Mark Warburton's sacking The chant "You're not wanted any more" rang around Cherry Red Records Stadium in Kingston as home supporters put their own twist on the chant after the sacking of Mark Warburton. This incident highlighted the increasing tension between Warburton and the fans, who had grown frustrated with his style of play and lack of success. The incident was seen as a sign of how far his relationship with the club had deteriorated.

The 28-year-old former Manchester City defender joined the club, initially on loan, from Brentford in January 2014. And he has been a regular in Derek McInnes's side over the past two seasons, playing a key role in the team's run to the Scottish League Cup final last season. McKenna has made 66 appearances for Aberdeen and scored four goals. He also played a key role in helping the Dons to their first major trophy since 1995, when they defeated Inverness CT in the 2014-15 Scottish League Cup final. McKenna is highly regarded at Pittodrie and has been rewarded with a new three-year contract that will keep him at the club until 2018. He becomes the latest Aberdeen player to commit his future to the club, following Adam Rooney, Ash Taylor, Graeme Shinnie, Ryan Jack and Niall McGinn signing new deals in recent months. McKenna is delighted to have extended his stay at Pittodrie and is looking forward to helping the team build on their success of last season. "I'm really pleased to sign a new deal with Aberdeen and I'm excited to be part of the club for another three years," McKenna said. "It was a great season last year and we want to continue that progress over the coming campaigns. "I feel I'm learning all the time here and I'm looking forward to what lies ahead under Derek McInnes." McInnes added: "Mark has been an important member of the squad since he joined us and this new deal is fully deserved. "He's a great professional and always gives 100 per cent and I'm looking forward to continuing to work with him."

The 29-year-old was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and wounding with intent. Previously, a 30-year-old, 27-year-old and 20-year-old, all from Rugby, were arrested. All four men have been bailed pending further enquiries. The incident happened on Tuesday near the town's Whitehall Road. A man in his 30s was taken to hospital with serious injuries and remains in a stable condition. Detective Inspector Chris Hanson, from Warwickshire Police, said: "This was a serious assault which left a man with serious injuries. We are working hard to establish the full circumstances of what happened." He appealed for anyone who may have seen or heard anything suspicious near Whitehall Road at around 11pm on Tuesday night to contact police.

The airport is in competition with Heathrow to win approval for an additional runway. One of the guarantees is compensation for people living close to the airport. Gatwick's chairman Sir Roy McNulty has promised to provide financial help to local people affected by the expansion. This could include compensation for noise, vibration, and light pollution. The airport has also promised a fund of up to 50 million to be used for local infrastructure projects, such as new roads and schools. These measures are intended to help reduce the impact of the proposed expansion on the local community.

The Anglo-Dutch giant's chief executive Ben van Beurden accepted that Arctic drilling "divides society," but said the world needs new sources of oil. Greenpeace said Shell was taking a "massive gamble" with its decision to resume drilling off Alaska. Shell's chief executive accepted that Arctic drilling was controversial, but argued that the world needs new sources of oil. He said that Shell was taking a "responsible approach" and that the company's operations would be conducted in a safe and environmentally responsible manner. Greenpeace disagreed with this assessment, arguing that Shell was taking a "massive gamble" by proceeding with drilling in such a sensitive region.

Kohli made 107 and shared century stands with both Shikhar Dhawan (73) and Suresh Raina (74) at the Adelaide Oval. When Kohli fell as part of Sohail Khan's 5-55, Pakistan had the upper hand, but Raina and Ravindra Jadeja (61 not out) combined for a match-winning partnership of 113.

Royal Mail predicts that on what it calls Take-back Tuesday there will be a rise of more than 50 in returns against December's daily average. Clothing and footwear are the most popular items to be returned on Take-back Tuesday. This prediction is based on the data from previous Take-back Tuesdays, as well as other trends in online shopping. Royal Mail also expects that shoppers will be more mindful of their purchases and choose to return items they are not satisfied with or do not need.

Collymore, 46, expressed an interest in the role at a meeting with Forest owner Fawaz Al Hasawi on Tuesday. But after "time to reflect" on the meeting and feedback from other senior figures at the club, he said it was "with a heavy heart that I have decided to withdraw my interest." He said on his Twitter account: "I would like to thank the supporters of Nottingham Forest for their overwhelming support. It was humbling. "I would also like to pay tribute to Fawaz Al Hasawi and his family who have worked tirelessly to make this great club competitive again. "Having taken time to reflect on yesterday's meeting and having had feedback from other senior figures at the club, it is with a heavy heart that I have decided to withdraw my interest in becoming the next manager of NFFC. "I wish the team and its supporters all the very best for the season ahead." Collymore was one of several names linked with the job following the departure of Dougie Freedman last week. He had been out of football management since leaving Spanish side Real Oviedo in April 2015 and had earlier made an unsuccessful attempt to buy the League One club. Forest issued a statement confirming Collymore's decision but did not make any comment on their search for a new manager.

Duffy, 26, raced into a 3-0 lead and beat the world number nine easily. A furious Ding criticised the playing conditions at the York Barbican. Sheffield's Duffy, who is seeded fifth in the tournament, was quick to respond. "I understand Ding's frustrations but it's not my fault," he said. "The conditions were out of my hands and I took advantage of them. I won fair and square. I'm sorry that Ding is unhappy with the conditions, but it didn't affect me." Duffy went on to say that he felt he had played some of his best snooker of the season so far and that he had been pleased with his performance. He added that he hoped the match would become a turning point for him in the tournament, as he looks to make a deep run.

Howe, 37, has overseen three of the club's six promotions since he was first appointed manager in 2008-09. The new deal is believed to take Howe through until 2020. He said: "It's been an incredible journey, and I'm delighted to extend my commitment to the club." Howe has guided Bournemouth from the fourth tier of English football to the brink of Premier League safety this season. The Cherries have become well-known for their attractive style of play under Howe's stewardship, with the club currently sitting 12th in the top flight. The new contract is a reward for Howe's loyalty and success, and it ensures that he will remain at the helm for many years to come. It also reinforces the club's commitment to him and his vision for the future.

It follows suggestions third-party software had been used to steal intimate photos of celebrities - posted online last month - from iCloud. The action should stop the tool from being used to access accounts without authorization. Apple has taken several steps to prevent a repeat of the attack, including boosting security measures and sending emails to iCloud users warning them about the security risks of using third-party software. The company has also updated its system status page to provide more detailed information about the security measures it is taking, as well as its support for two-factor authentication. This feature requires a user to enter a code sent to their phone or email address in addition to their password when signing in. Apple has also said it is working with law enforcement to investigate the incident, and will continue to work on further improvements to its security systems in order to protect users' data.

"I'm 64," he said of his fascination with the 1836 battle. "When I was five or six years old, this thing began." Collins' collection includes a fringed leather pouch used by soldiers of the period, buttons, buckles and other artifacts. "I've been to the Alamo," he said. "It's the most holy place in Texas." As an avid collector and historian, Collins is certain the battle will be remembered and re-enacted for years to come. "When I get done with it, I'm sure there'll be a few people that will keep this tradition alive," he said.

Barcelona said it paid EUR57m (PS43m) for Neymar in 2013 but investigators say the fee was closer to EUR83m and Barcelona concealed part of the deal. Neymar spent an hour and a half at the court on Thursday, having been summoned to appear as part of an investigation into alleged fraud and corruption surrounding his transfer. Neymar is accused of defrauding Spanish authorities of EUR14.7m in unpaid taxes by creating a web of companies in Brazil and Spain to manage his finances. Prosecutors allege that Barcelona also hid part of the payment of Neymar's transfer fee from Brazilian club Santos, which could constitute tax fraud. Barcelona has denied any wrongdoing in the deal, while Neymar has maintained that he was unaware of any irregularities. The Spain-based prosecutor investigating the case, Jose Perals, said in court on Thursday that Neymar had acted with "dishonesty" and had "lied" about the details of his transfer.

The British supermarket giant, the world's third largest retailer, has been looking to dispose of its loss-making US food chain for some time. Around 4,000 of Fresh Easy's 5,000 employees face redundancy and the firm is likely to close all its stores in California, Arizona and Nevada. The company has been trying to find a buyer for the business but so far has failed to do so. In order to try and make the sale more attractive to potential buyers, Tesco is offering incentives such as cash payments, rent reductions and lease extensions. It is also offering to cover some of the costs associated with the closure of the stores. In addition, Tesco is offering to pay suppliers in advance for any goods or services they supply in the period up to the completion of the sale. The supermarket giant hopes to complete the sale by the end of the year, but it is unclear who may be interested in buying the chain. Some observers have speculated that private equity firms may be interested in taking over the business, while others suggest that US retailers could take advantage of the opportunity to acquire an established presence in the market. Regardless of who eventually purchases the chain, it is clear that Tesco's decision to offload Fresh Easy marks the end of an era for the British retailer, which had ambitious plans for the US market when it first bought the chain in 2013.

Van Gaal, 65, has been out of work since being sacked by United hours after winning the FA Cup in May 2016. "I thought maybe I would stop, then I had offers," he told the Dutch magazine. "I was close to a new club two times, then suddenly it stopped. That's why I still don't have a club. "The problem was always that clubs wanted me to start right away, and I said 'no'. "Because when you start somewhere in the middle of a season it is always difficult. You have to adapt to the situation, which isn't easy. It would be better for any coach to start at the beginning of a new season." Van Gaal is keen to return to management, but only if the opportunity is right for him. "I want to work with a club where I can feel the trust and faith of the board," he said. "Then I will immediately sign a contract. It must be a club that really wants me. I don't need a lot of money - I just need the trust of the board."

The poverty rate was 15 in 2011, meaning 46.2 million Americans were in poverty, staying flat after three previous years of increases. Real median income of households in the country was 50,054 in 2011, a 1.5 percent decline from the previous year. The poverty rate has been on the rise since 2007, with the highest rates recorded in 2011 and 2012, reaching 15.1 percent in both years. The economic recession caused by the financial crisis of 2007-2008 is widely believed to be the chief cause of this increase in poverty levels. In addition, the Great Recession of 2008-2009 further exacerbated the situation, leading to high unemployment and a weak labor market. The disparities between those who are wealthy and those living in poverty have become increasingly pronounced as well. The top 5 percent of Americans accounted for 21.9 percent of total household income in 2011, while the bottom 40 percent of Americans only accounted for 12.8 percent. The federal government has implemented several initiatives to address poverty and income inequality. These include programs like the Earned Income Tax Credit, which provides tax breaks to low-income earners, and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which helps low-income families purchase food. Additionally, the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 provided additional funds to states and localities to help those hit hardest by the recession. In spite of these efforts, the poverty rate and income inequality remain stubbornly high. Additional policies such as a higher minimum wage, increased access to education and job training, and stronger safety nets for vulnerable populations are needed to ensure that more Americans have the opportunity to escape poverty and build better lives for themselves and their families.

Jordan Edwards, 15, died after Officer Roy Oliver fired a rifle into a car that was driving away from a party in the Dallas suburb of Balch Springs. Police initially said the car was reversing toward officers in an "aggressive manner" but later retracted the statement. Officer Roy Oliver was fired and charged with murder after an investigation found that he had used excessive force, violating department policies. The charges against him include one count of murder, four counts of aggravated assault by a public servant, and two counts of criminal negligent homicide. He has pleaded not guilty and is awaiting trial. The shooting sparked outrage, as well as protests and calls for criminal justice reform. The case also highlighted issues of police accountability, as activists criticized the slow response of the Balch Springs Police Department to the incident. The family of Jordan Edwards has filed a civil lawsuit against the police department, alleging negligence and wrongful death.

Winners of the cup competition earn a place in the Europa League. Four-time cup winners Forest have failed to progress past the third round for the past 11 seasons and are yet to qualify for the Europa League. Forest have the opportunity to qualify for the Europa League by winning the cup competition, but have not done so in the past 11 seasons. They could also qualify for the competition through their league position, but that is often difficult for a club of Forest's size and financial resources.

Huw Irranca-Davies, who has announced he is leaving the shadow frontbench, told Radio Wales his party needed to "consistently re-invigorate" itself. He said the party was facing a "huge challenge" in its search for a new leader, but said it was important for its members to remain united. He also said that he believed the Labour Party had become "complacent" in recent years, and needed to take more responsibility for its own failings. He argued that the party should be open to ideas from outside of its traditional power base, and should focus more on policy than personality. The Labour MP said that his decision to leave the frontbench was a difficult one, but he felt it was the best decision for him and the party. He said that he wanted to focus on his constituency work as well as supporting Labour at a national level, and that this would be best achieved by taking a step back from politics.

Leanne Wood made the comments in a BBC TV debate, which took place a day after the terrorist attack in London. Ms Wood also said that she would like to see a "radical change" in the UK's approach to terrorism, which she says has not been effective in preventing attacks. She argued that the government needs to focus on issues like poverty and inequality, which she believes are root causes of radicalisation. She also criticised the current counter-terrorism strategy, saying that it is too focused on "security theatre" rather than real solutions.

Ten passengers on board the bus were reported to have been killed while all four crew members survived. Local TV showed the heavily damaged Boeing 727 Allied Air plane lying on its belly in a field with wreckage scattered around it. The cause of the crash is under investigation.

Lewis Hamilton was the fastest of the silver cars, despite a mistake-strewn final lap on a weekend when penalties mean he will start from the back. Team-mate Nico Rosberg, who will start on pole, was the only one of the silver cars to beat Hamilton's best lap time, but was unable to match his pace on the other laps. Hamilton had been in the top three all weekend, but an untimely spin at Turn 11 on his final lap saw him finish tenth and seventh overall. He had set a fastest sector two time which would have put him second, but the mistake cost him dearly. Rosberg, who finished fourth overall, was able to take advantage of Hamilton's mistake and secured his second pole position for the Spanish Grand Prix. It was his first front row start since Bahrain in April 2015. Meanwhile, Mercedes' other drivers Valtteri Bottas and Pascal Wehrlein were also able to capitalise on Hamilton's misfortune. Bottas, who had qualified fifth, was promoted to third while Wehrlein, who had originally started tenth, moved up to eighth.

The group were convicted of Tuesday of assaulting social worker and activist Ken Tsang as he took part in the 2014 pro-democracy rallies. TV cameras caught the officers removing Mr Tsang from a protest site, carrying him away and then beating him in a dark corner. The officers were found guilty of causing actual bodily harm to Mr Tsang and were sentenced to two years in prison for the assault. This is the first time that police officers have been convicted and sentenced for their involvement in pro-democracy protests. The ruling was welcomed by activists and human rights advocates who hailed it as a victory against police brutality. However, some criticized the verdict as too lenient and argued that the officers should have been given a harsher punishment. The case has also highlighted concerns about police accountability and transparency, as well as the need for greater public oversight of law enforcement. The conviction of these officers may signal that police officers are being held accountable for their actions, but it also highlights the need for further reforms and greater scrutiny of law enforcement in Hong Kong.

The event takes place at East Kirkcarswell Farm near Dundrennan on 25 and 26 July. Dizzee Rascal will headline the opening night in his only Scottish festival appearance of the year. The line-up also includes the likes of Mungo's Hi Fi, Bloxx, The Snuts, The Amazons, The Van T's, The Ninth Wave, and The Murder Capital. There will also be an array of international DJs, visual artists and more onsite to ensure a unique experience. The festival promises something for everyone, with activities such as yoga, art workshops and a silent disco. Food and drink from local vendors will also be available.

The raids came a day after it emerged a Frenchman was being held by police investigating the murder of three people at the Brussels Jewish Museum. Mehdi Nemmouche, 29, was arrested in the French port of Marseille on Friday after being traced through a suspected firearms purchase at an arms fair. Image copyright AFP Image caption The raids came a day after it emerged a Frenchman was being held by police investigating the Jewish Museum attack The raids were part of a "police operation unrelated to the inquiry into the Jewish Museum attacks," Brussels prosecutor's office spokesman Eric Van Der Sypt told reporters. He said the raids were part of an investigation into "suspected terrorist activities." No arrests were made and no weapons or explosives were found, Mr Van Der Sypt said. The raids targeted homes in the Molenbeek neighbourhood of Brussels and one in nearby Anderlecht. Molenbeek is home to a large Muslim population and has been linked to several Islamist militant plots in Europe.

Police said he was armed with a stolen gun and they had been tracking him. They blamed the violence on a small group of people. Four officers have been placed on administrative leave. This is a tragic incident and the police department is taking the situation very seriously. All four officers have been placed on administrative leave while an investigation is conducted to determine if proper protocol was followed during the confrontation with the suspect. The department is also conducting an internal review to ensure that all policies and procedures were followed by the officers involved. The police department has expressed their condolences to the family of the victim and will continue to investigate the matter thoroughly.

Ackerman was initially banned in October last year after being found guilty of corruption. He had laid bets against a horse knowing its jockey aimed not to win. Ackerman was banned for a period of 12 months, but the Racing Appeals and Disciplinary Board in Australia has now lifted the ban after an appeal was lodged. Ackerman is now free to return to horse racing, although he will still be subject to the terms and conditions of his original suspension. He must also undergo a "rehabilitation program" in order to demonstrate that he has made changes to his behaviour and is committed to upholding the integrity of racing.

Penglais Farm will have a total of 1,000 rooms, but only 700 will be ready this month to welcome students. The university said developer Balfour Beatty confirmed the remaining 300 will be ready for the start of the next academic year in September. The rooms range from one and two bedroom apartments to studio flats and come with en-suite bathrooms, a communal kitchen and living area, laundry facilities, bike storage and car parking. The university is investing 70 million into Penglais Farm, which is part of their wider campus development plan and is aimed at providing more student accommodation. The project is being built on the site of the former dairy farm, which had been used by the University since the 1940s. The new accommodation will provide students with modern amenities as well as an improved experience of university life. The university said they are committed to ensuring that all students have access to high quality accommodation, whether they live on or off campus. The development is also expected to create up to 1,000 jobs during its construction and will include a range of amenities such as a gym, cafe and retail outlets. The university hopes that the investment will help to further strengthen the connection between the town and its student population.

The video of Bailey Matthews showing him abandoning his walking aid to cross the finish line has been viewed on Facebook more than 27 million times. Bailey, from Doncaster, was diagnosed with cerebral palsy when he was 2 years old. He was taking part in a charity race and his dad had to encourage him to finish the race. With a huge cheer from the crowd, Bailey managed to take off his walking aid and walk across the finish line without it. The video of his inspiring moment has gone viral on social media, with many people praising his determination and courage.

Four US tourists and an Australian pilot died after their light plane came down on a shopping centre on Tuesday. It had just taken off from the small Essendon Airport, near Melbourne, when it hit a building, setting off a huge fireball. The victims were identified as US citizens Greg De Haven, Russell Munsch, Glenn Garland and John Washburn, and Australian pilot Max Quartermain. All five were killed instantly in the crash. The cause of the accident is still being investigated but officials have ruled out terrorism and said the plane was in good working condition. Witnesses reported hearing loud noises before the plane went down and some suggested the engine had failed. The shopping centre, which is located close to the airport, was evacuated after the crash. No one on the ground was injured, but several buildings were damaged. Police say they are still trying to identify the source of the explosion. The crash has shocked the local community, with many expressing grief and disbelief. The victims' families have been offered counseling and support.

Energy will travel via the world's longest sub-sea electricity interconnector. The a'!2bn (PS1.4bn) project has been rubber stamped between National Grid and its Norwegian equivalent Statnett. The UK aims to use the 730-mile interconnector to access renewable energy generated in Norway. The project, which is expected to be completed by 2021, will link Blyth in Northumberland with Kvilldal in Norway and will have a capacity of 1.4GW - enough to power approximately 500,000 homes. The electricity connection will run along the North Sea floor through the Norwegian and British Exclusive Economic Zones. The sub-sea electricity interconnector is part of a wider effort to develop an integrated European electricity market in order to maximize the use of renewable energy sources. It's also hoped that this project will help lower consumer electricity prices in both the UK and Norway. The UK hopes to benefit from Norway's abundant hydroelectric resources while Norway can benefit from the UK's wind energy production.

Adrian Simut, 35, travelled to Newport train station, where he thought he was meeting a 14-year-old girl called Sam. But he was confronted by so-called "paedophile hunters" and later arrested, charged and sentenced for attempting to meet a child following sexual grooming. Adrian Simut was sentenced to two years in prison after pleading guilty to attempting to meet a child following sexual grooming. He appeared at Cardiff Crown Court on July 3, 2019, and admitted one count of attempting to meet a child following sexual grooming. The court heard that he had been messaging someone he believed to be a 14-year-old girl called Sam, and arranged to meet her at Newport train station, but was instead confronted by members of the public who had been monitoring his conversations. The judge said that Simut had "realised what he was doing was wrong" when he saw the people waiting for him.

Media playback is not supported on this device Saturday's loss to Liverpool was the Swans' third in succession, leaving them a point above the bottom three and increasing the pressure on manager Carlos Carvalhal. The Portuguese took charge in December and guided the club to Premier League safety last season, but his side have won only three of their 20 league matches this term. Carvalhal admits his team are facing a "difficult situation" but is confident he can turn things around. "I am not worried about my job," he said. "I know I will be judged by results but I'm confident that if we stick together and work hard then we will get out of this situation." Carvalhal also highlighted the loss of key players in the transfer window as a factor in the Swans' recent struggles. "We lost five important players who had been with us for one-and-a-half years," he said. "That was very difficult to overcome and it has left us in a difficult situation. "But I am sure that we can still turn things around and that's what we are working hard to do."

Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) aims to reduce radiation leaks in three months and to cool the reactors within nine months. The firm said it also planned to cover the damaged reactor buildings with a special fabric that would reduce the amount of radiation being released. In order to achieve these goals, Tepco has implemented various measures such as improving the water-cooling system of the reactors, installing a new cooling system, and installing a filter to reduce the release of radioactive material into the atmosphere. The company is also researching how to contain the contaminated water that has already leaked from the plant, and has plans to construct underground storage tanks for the contaminated water. In addition, Tepco is also working on strengthening the integrity of the reactor containment structures in order to limit any future radiation leaks.

Germany forward Linden, who was signed from Frankfurt, nodded in from a Kerys Harrop cross to salvage a point. Melissa Fletcher had put the hosts ahead, meeting an Emma Follis cross in the 28th minute. The result, which leaves both teams level on points at the top of the table, means they will be joined by SC Sand and Wolfsburg, who are also on 33 points, at the summit. The draw was a fair reflection of the game, with both teams creating good chances throughout. Frankfurt dominated the early possession, with their experienced midfielders controlling the tempo. They came close to opening the scoring when Turkish forward Belinay Guveli hit the post from outside the box. Birmingham City Ladies responded well and created several chances of their own. Kerys Harrop went closest, forcing a fine save from goalkeeper Carolin Endler with a powerful drive from 20 yards. The Birmingham side eventually took the lead through Fletcher, who headed in the Follis cross. But Linden popped up late to ensure the spoils were shared. The draw keeps Frankfurt within touching distance of the top of the table and puts them firmly in contention for a Champions League spot. Birmingham City Ladies remain unbeaten in the league this season and look to be one of the promotion contenders.

Rolo, a chocolate Labrador, was saved after two coastguard rescue teams and an RNLI lifeboat were called in, near Brixham. She was hauled up in a "dog rescue bag" on a rope from the sea, and was reunited with her owners safe and sound.

The new plan is for training to be split across three different sites. There would be some joint training, but the three services would each have their own facilities. The plan would also include a centralized command and control center, with all training being coordinated from one location. This would help to coordinate the different services and ensure that all training is conducted in accordance with common standards. Additionally, there would be an increased focus on joint operations with other services, including the Navy and Air Force. Finally, the plan would provide for more specialized training for each service, allowing them to become better prepared for any potential mission.

"Dependency on giving that only appears to be charitable must end," he said in a tweet ahead of this weekend's African Union summit in South Africa. The BBC's Robert Kiptoo in Nairobi says Mr Macron's comments reflect growing frustration with the continent's donors. The French president has been outspoken about his commitment to Africa and its development. He has championed France's policy of investing in the continent and promoting financial independence from foreign aid. But he has also been critical of some African countries' reliance on foreign aid, which he believes has stifled innovation and hindered economic growth. In a series of tweets ahead of the summit, Mr Macron said "dependency on giving that only appears to be charitable must end." He added that Africa must take charge of its destiny and build its own future. Mr Macron's comments come at a time when the continent is facing numerous challenges, including poverty, inequality, climate change, insecurity and corruption. Many African countries have long relied on foreign aid to fund their development projects, but the funding has not always been used effectively or efficiently. The French president's comments were welcomed by several African leaders, who agreed that the continent must shift away from dependence on foreign aid and find ways to develop its own resources. Some experts believe that this shift could help reduce corruption and improve economic growth.

Culture Secretary Maria Miller said "decriminalisation of the licence fee should be on the table" during the BBC's charter review before 2017. The BBC said changing the law could lead to evasion, and said it was "well-equipped" to tackle evasion already. The BBC is currently funded through the licence fee, a fixed fee charged to households in the UK that watch or record live television programmes. The licence fee has been criminalised since 1946, meaning that non-payment can lead to prosecution and a fine. The BBC's charter review is currently underway, with the aim of setting out the corporation's governance and funding arrangements for the next 11 years. Culture Secretary Maria Miller said that decriminalisation of the licence fee should be on the table during the charter review. She argued that criminalising those who do not pay the licence fee is outdated and inappropriate, and suggested that civil penalties such as fines should be used instead. The BBC rejected the suggestion, arguing that changing the law could lead to more people evading payment of the licence fee. They said they were already "well-equipped" to tackle evasion. The BBC also argued that decriminalisation could create a loophole which would allow some people to avoid paying the licence fee without incurring a penalty.

A judge said there was a basis for concluding the officers, known as M and Q, may have perverted the course of justice and committed perjury while giving evidence. Pearse made the comments during a hearing held in relation to an application by the police watchdog, the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), for permission to investigate the two officers. The investigation relates to their involvement in the case of Sean Rigg, who died in police custody in 2008. The judge said there was evidence which suggested the officers may have lied about their knowledge of the circumstances surrounding Mr Rigg's arrest and the use of force against him. He also noted there were discrepancies between what the officers told the IOPC and what other witnesses had reported. Pearse concluded that the allegations were serious enough to warrant further investigation and that granting the IOPC's request would be appropriate. The judge's remarks will be welcomed by Mr Rigg's family, who have long campaigned for justice in relation to his death. The IOPC's investigation will now proceed and could potentially lead to criminal proceedings against M and Q.

The new bill, which would affect digital maps from Google, Apple, and Uber, is facing stiff opposition from campaign groups. It also bans "wrong" information, including disputed international borders. The bill seeks to give the government the power to demand that companies delete or modify any digital maps deemed incorrect. It has been criticized by those who feel it will limit freedom of expression and limit access to accurate information. Companies have argued that it would be difficult for them to comply with the proposed rules, as well as the potential for legal action if they fail to do so. The bill has implications for both users and companies, with many fearing that it could lead to censorship and a lack of access to important data.

The Northern Ireland international, 28, was charged on 29 July with breaching FA rule E8, which bars professional players from betting on football-related matters. The offence took place on 20 July. A statement from the FA said: "The charge is in relation to a breach of FA Rule E8 (1) (a) (ii) where it is alleged that the player placed bets on the result, progress, conduct or any other aspect of, or occurrence in, football matches or competitions in the period between 15 March and 20 July 2020." McNair has until 7 August to respond to the charge and could face a ban if found guilty. Middlesbrough have confirmed they are aware of the situation, with McNair set to miss Saturday's Championship match against Wycombe Wanderers. McNair, who joined Middlesbrough from Sunderland in January 2019, has made 40 appearances for the club, scoring four goals.

Vikki Thompson, 21, died at HMP Leeds on 13 November. She had been awaiting sentencing for robbery. Her partner Bob Steele said the letter should have alerted officials to her vulnerability. The tragic death of Vikki Thompson is a stark reminder of the duty of care prisons have towards those in their custody. It is deeply concerning that a letter from her partner, which should have alerted officials to her vulnerability and possibly led to her receiving the help she needed, was not acted upon. This tragedy highlights the urgent need for prison authorities to ensure they are doing everything possible to protect vulnerable inmates and prevent any further deaths.

US experts found B3, also known as nicotinamide, boosts the ability of immune cells to kill Staphylococcus bacteria. B3 increases the numbers and efficacy of neutrophils, white blood cells that are the body's first line of defense against bacterial invasion. In laboratory tests, B3 was found to increase the number of neutrophils and their ability to kill bacteria by up to 500.

The star whisked through 23 songs in 90 minutes, in a blur of pyrotechnics, lasers and multiple costume changes. She donned silken butterfly wings for a piano-led version of...Baby One More Time, and lapped the stage in a giant inflatable ball for Toxic. The setlist included all her classics as well as new singles from her upcoming album Glory. She opened with an energetic cover of Joan Jett's I Love Rock 'n' Roll before launching into 3, Oops!...I Did It Again and her iconic hit ...Baby One More Time. The show also featured a medley of some of her most popular songs including Womanizer, Circus, Stronger, Till the World Ends and Work Bitch. The show ended with a rousing rendition of Slumber Party before she said goodbye to the screaming crowd with a heartfelt speech about her fans. "Thank you for being here tonight, thank you for making me feel so loved," she said. "You guys are my everything, I love you."

Natalia Wilkanowska, 50, disappeared in 2003 after travelling to visit her ex-husband Gerald Doherty in Luton. Her body was found in December 2015, Luton Crown Court was told. Mr Doherty's trial for her murder is due to begin in the summer of 2016. Natalia Wilkanowska, a Polish national, moved to England with her two sons in 2001. She was reported missing by her family in 2003 after failing to return home from visiting her ex-husband Gerald Doherty in Luton. In December 2015 Wilkanowska's body was found buried in a shallow grave in a wooded area near to Mr Doherty's home. A postmortem examination revealed that she had died as a result of blunt force trauma to the head. Following this discovery, Mr Doherty was charged with her murder and was due to stand trial at Luton Crown Court in the summer of 2016.

The injury-hit Hammers lost to Romanian champions Astra Giurgiu in the qualifying round for the second season in succession. The visitors won Thursday's second leg at the London Stadium 1-0 courtesy of Constantin Budescu's 74th-minute strike. The victory means Astra go through 2-1 on aggregate and Slaven Bilic's side join Hull City, Celtic and Steaua Bucharest in being eliminated from the competition at the third qualifying round stage. Bilic was without a number of first-team players including Andy Carroll, Winston Reid, Aaron Cresswell, Manuel Lanzini and Diafra Sakho, while he lost Andre Ayew before the game. West Ham United West Ham United Astra Giurgiu Astra Giurgiu 0 1 FT Leg 2 Aggregate: 1 - 2 Game Details GameCast Lineups and Stats Positives Adrian made some good saves, while youngster Reece Oxford put in another assured performance in midfield. Jonathan Calleri continued to show glimpses of promise and Dimitri Payet was again the main threat for the hosts. Negatives West Ham lacked creativity going forward, failed to create enough chances and were vulnerable defensively once again. The team also looked tired in the second half, but that can be expected given the number of injuries Bilic is having to contend with. Bilic was unable to affect the game in any way by making substitutions and will now have to concentrate on getting West Ham ready for their Premier League opener against Chelsea.
