The group had been sailing around the County Down lough on Wednesday when three crew members went ashore on Green Island. The cabin cruiser then developed electrical problems as it was leaving the area, and the three crew members were unable to re-board. The Royal National Lifeboat Institution launched a lifeboat to rescue the three people, who were taken safely back to shore. No one was injured in the incident.

It seems in Northern Ireland we call it Tuesday. Politics dominates the front pages of the papers again today as the clock which was supposed to stop yesterday at 16:00 BST continues to tick. There is still no agreement between the parties as they continue to negotiate a deal that would restore devolution in the region. The focus of today's discussions will be on the Irish language, which has been a major sticking point between the two main parties. Both sides have agreed to protect the language but there are still disagreements over how it should be implemented. As talks continue, pressure is building for a breakthrough before the end of the week. Meanwhile, there is also concern that if a deal isn't reached soon, Northern Ireland could face a return to direct rule from Westminster. With tensions high and time running out, it remains to be seen if the politicians can reach an agreement.

The sentencing of David Gilroy, who killed Edinburgh woman Suzanne Pilley, is due to take place next Wednesday. Earlier this week permission was also granted to film the proceedings. Twitter user annasanmiguel asked us why this is the case. The decision to allow cameras into court during sentencing is made by the presiding judge, who must be satisfied that it's in the interests of open justice and will not interfere with the administration of justice. The decision to allow cameras at David Gilroy's sentencing has been made by Lord Bracadale, who believes filming will serve to enhance public understanding of the judicial process.

The beach where Seifeddine Rezgui stood on Friday, pulled a Kalashnikov from his parasol and unleashed Tunisia's worst ever terror attack, has already reopened. Camera crews capture the spot; passers-by look curiously at the memorials, of flowers and candles, that have been laid in tribute to those who died. The beach has been cordoned off to protect it from further damage and to give people time to reflect on what happened here. The parasol where Rezgui began his attack has been removed, replaced with a plaque that bears the names of those who lost their lives. At the same time, security has been tightened at tourist sites around Tunisia. Armed police patrol the beaches and armed guards are stationed at resorts to reassure visitors that their safety is a priority. But despite the increased security, many Tunisians are still wary, and some families have decided to cancel their holidays or stay away from busy tourist spots. This tragedy has cast a dark shadow over Tunisia's tourism industry, which was just beginning to recover from the political unrest that followed the Arab Spring uprisings in 2011. It will take some time for the country to regain its reputation as a safe holiday destination.

Thieves broke into the house in Intake, Doncaster on Thursday, a week after Paris Mulholland's 11th birthday. In the letter, she tells the burglars "how much they hurt me," that she feels "so scared" and that she doesn't understand why they took her things. Dear Burglars, I am writing this letter to you because I am sure you can hear my voice better through words on a page than what I would say if I saw you in person. Last Thursday, you broke into my home. I was so scared when I found out what had happened. I had been looking forward to my 11th birthday the week before and to have it spoiled by something like this is unbearable. It's not fair that somebody like you could come in here and take away all my possessions without any regard for how much they mean to me. It's even worse that you must know how much it hurts me that you did this. You must know how violated I feel knowing that strangers were in my room, taking away my belongings. So why did you do it? What did you think you'd gain from it? I hope you can read this and maybe think twice about what you do. Nothing good comes of stealing, and hopefully, you will realize that soon. Sincerely, Paris Mulholland

Philae, the first spacecraft to land on a comet, was dropped on to the surface of Comet 67P by its mothership, Rosetta, last November. It worked for 60 hours before it ran out of power and went into hibernation. Its mission included an initial survey of the comet, sampling its atmosphere and surface, and using several instruments to analyze the data. The Philae lander then transmitted all of the data collected back to Earth for further analysis.

All 42 of its member clubs are expected to take strict disciplinary measures against fans who indulge in anti-social behaviour during matches. The updated guidance, which comes into force immediately, includes a minimum three-year ban for those found guilty of discriminatory behaviour. The disciplinary measures can include banning the individual from matches, stadium bans, or even criminal prosecution if the offence is severe enough. Clubs are also urged to adopt zero tolerance approaches to any form of discrimination, including racism, sexism and homophobia, by setting out clear expectations in their codes of conduct or club rules. In addition, clubs are encouraged to act quickly and decisively when responding to reports of discrimination and to investigate all allegations thoroughly. The FA also wants clubs to work closely with local police forces to ensure that they have an effective procedure in place for dealing with any incidents. Finally, the FA wants clubs to adopt an education policy in order to inform fans about acceptable standards of behaviour and to encourage them to take a stand against discrimination. The organisation also wants clubs to support their staff, players and fans in challenging discriminatory behaviour. Overall, these measures are designed to help ensure that football remains a safe, welcoming and inclusive environment for everyone.

Andreu was denied from the spot by a brilliant save from Raith keeper Kevin Cuthbert 15 minutes from time. United were reduced to ten men when former Rovers defender Lewis Toshney was sent off for a second bookable offence. The match ended 0-0, with the save from Cuthbert proving to be a crucial moment in the game. Andreu had the chance to put United ahead, but his penalty kick was saved by the experienced goalkeeper. It proved to be a difficult afternoon for United, as they were unable to capitalize on their numerical advantage after Toshney's red card. Despite the result, it was an impressive display from Cuthbert, who showed great reflexes to keep out Andreu's effort.

The 86-year-old first became prime minister in 1982, beginning a third spell as leader in 2014. In a televised address Mr Jugnauth said he was resigning in favour of a younger generation of leaders. He announced that his son, Pravind Jugnauth, would be taking over as prime minister. The former prime minister said he would remain in politics, but would focus on his role as leader of the Militant Socialist Movement party.

Its shares slid 7.6 to their lowest level since March, and the company was the biggest faller on the FTSE 100, the UK's main share index. Operating profit before transformation costs fell by a third to 1.3bn in the six months to the end of June from 2bn a year earlier. The company had warned of the impact of the coronavirus crisis on its performance in May, and said it would be taking action to cut costs and reduce debt. It has now announced plans to cut 4,500 jobs worldwide, or about 15 of its workforce. Chief executive Steve Cahillane said: "Given the current uncertainty, we have taken decisive action to protect our financial strength, reduce costs and focus on cash generation." He added that the company is already seeing some signs of recovery in certain markets but said it was too early to predict the full impact of the pandemic on its business.

It has been hailed as the most comprehensive list to date. About 9,000 names - nearly all German - are on the Auschwitz garrison list, some with photographs attached. The list was compiled by a research team led by the Berlin-based Topography of Terror Foundation, which has been researching the history of Nazi persecution since 1997. The list is the most comprehensive available because it includes not only the names of Auschwitz guards, but also supervisors and other personnel who served in the camp. It also includes information about individuals' job roles and the dates they worked in the camp. The researchers used a range of sources to compile the list, including the German Federal Archive, archives from former East Germany, and the Auschwitz Museum. The list is an important resource for researchers, as well as survivors and victims' families, as it provides a clear view of who was responsible for the crimes committed in the camp. It will also help to shine a light on those who were complicit in the Holocaust and ensure that their actions are not forgotten.

Princess Anne spoke to well-wishers outside the church after attending the service with her father Prince Philip, brother Prince Edward and other royals. Buckingham Palace said the Queen is "still in good spirits" after her husband Prince Philip was admitted to hospital. Anne said: "It's been a very nice morning and we've all enjoyed the service." When asked how the Queen is doing, Anne replied: "Well, as you can see she's not here today. She's otherwise engaged." The Queen did not attend the service at St Mary Magdalene Church on the Sandringham Estate, where Prince Philip had a fall last week. The Duke of Edinburgh was taken to the King Edward VII Hospital in London for observation and treatment for an undisclosed condition. He is said to be in "good spirits."

Five justices in the Supreme Court dismissed the challenge for an inquiry into the shootings at Batang Kali in 1948 by a four to one majority. The families, who say 24 unarmed villagers were killed by British troops, had asked the court to declare that the government was legally obliged to hold an inquiry. The majority of justices ruled that the families could not use the Human Rights Act to bring a legal challenge against the government, as the events had taken place too long ago. The dissenting justice argued that the government should have had the opportunity to explain why there had been no investigation and why it did not intend to order one. The families are now considering taking their call for an inquiry to Parliament, although the government has so far made no commitment to do so.

Four-month-old Ted visits Wales twice a month to see his grandparents in Carmarthenshire and the TV star hopes he will be brought up to be bilingual. He will be heading to Wales twice a month for now, but as he grows older, his visits will likely become more frequent. It is great that Ted is being exposed to the Welsh language and culture from such an early age. Research has found that exposure to a new language before the age of three is key in developing a bilingual ability later on in life. To support Ted's development, there are several things his parents can do. Firstly, they should bring Welsh books and toys with them when they visit Wales so he can get used to hearing the language spoken and seeing it written down. They could also listen to Welsh songs or stories together and find Welsh-language nursery rhymes online or in bookstores. When Ted is old enough to understand, they can introduce him to Welsh TV shows and movies. Ted's parents should also speak Welsh to him when they are visiting Wales and encourage others to do the same. Finally, they could consider enrolling him in Welsh language classes or clubs which will help to build his confidence and understanding of the language. By introducing Ted to Welsh culture and language now, his parents are giving him a head start in developing his bilingual ability. With the right support and encouragement, he can be a proud Welsh speaker in no time!

The self-styled Islamic State group said two days ago that Abu-Zakariya al-Britani detonated a car bomb at an Iraqi army base in Tal Gaysum, south-west of Mosul. He is believed to have been a British national. The Islamic State group did not provide any evidence of the attack or name Abu-Zakariya al-Britani, but Iraqi security sources have confirmed the attack took place. It is unclear if anyone else was killed or injured in the bombing. The UK government has condemned the attack and said it will continue to work with its allies to counter terrorism. Prime Minister Theresa May said: "This attack serves as a stark reminder of the threats we face from those who wish to do us harm. We are determined to stand strong against terrorism and its poisonous ideology."

He crossed his hands above his head as he finished the race - a gesture made by Ethiopia's Oromo people who have suffered brutal police crackdowns. He says he may have been the first athlete to make such a gesture at an international event. The gesture was made by Feyisa Lilesa, an Ethiopian marathoner, at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. He crossed his hands above his head as he finished the race in protest of the government's brutal crackdown on the Oromo people, an ethnic group in Ethiopia. The gesture quickly became a symbol of resistance and solidarity among the Oromo people. It was seen around the world and inspired similar protests in other countries. Lilesa has since become an advocate for the Oromo people and has spoken out against human rights abuses in Ethiopia.

Few details of the deal agreed by the Russians and Americans have been released. There was indeed something of a decline in hostilities, though no comprehensive calm. The ceasefire was limited to certain parts of the country. The agreement included an exchange of prisoners, some humanitarian aid for those affected by the conflict, and a commitment from both sides to work towards a more permanent peace deal. It also involved a call for all foreign forces to leave Syria, including those of Russia and the US. However, this has yet to be realized, as neither side has fully withdrawn its military presence in the region.

In the corner of a busy hospital ward, tucked behind a curtain for our arrival, lies Joshua Davies. His face is alert and he's talkative, but take a look down the ward and you'll notice something different about him. Joshua is one of a growing number of children who have been diagnosed with Crohn's disease, a chronic inflammatory bowel disorder. Joshua has had to adjust to a new life since his diagnosis. He's restricted from eating certain foods, has to take medication every day, and often has to go for regular checkups. Despite this, he remains cheerful and resilient, determined to make the best of his situation. His parents are also learning how to cope with the changes that have come with his illness, but they have found solace in knowing that there is support available for them and their son. The hospital team have been an invaluable source of information and advice while Joshua undergoes treatment, and they have been there to provide emotional support too. Joshua is still living with Crohn's disease today, but he no longer lets it define him. He has found his own way of managing his condition, and is making the most of the extra time he now has to explore his interests and passions. His outlook on life is inspiring, and serves as a reminder that even when faced with adversity, it is possible to stay positive and find ways to cope.

It's not that surprising that even an experienced gardener like him looks a bit awkward. I'm not sure that many of us would quite know what to do when handed a spade and told to start digging, especially if we weren't expecting it! It can be quite daunting to know where to begin, even if you're an experienced gardener.

Media playback is unsupported on your device 18 July 2015 Last updated at 13:43 BST The video which was filmed around 1933, shows the Queen playing with a dog in the grounds of Balmoral Castle. The footage was discovered by the British Film Institute, who have now released it to the public. In the film, the young Princess Elizabeth is seen walking and playing with her pet Dookie - believed to be a Welsh corgi. It was taken during the summer of 1933, when the Queen was just seven-years-old. The Queen can also be seen playing with her younger sister Princess Margaret and exercising her pony in the grounds of Balmoral Castle. The video shows a glimpse into the past of the world's longest-serving monarch.

BHS.com will employ just 84 people, a fraction of the 11,000 who lost their jobs after efforts to find a buyer for the high-street business failed. The last of BHS's 163 stores closed in August 2016. The new BHS.com will focus on selling a range of products from mattresses and furniture to homeware and lighting, as well as clothing and accessories. The company will be headed up by former BHS boss Terry Duddy and supported by several former senior executives from the chain.

Edmund backed up two wins in qualifying with a 6-3 6-2 victory over world number 73 Garcia-Lopez in Beijing. The 21-year-old from Yorkshire, ranked 54th, goes on to face another Spaniard, Roberto Bautista-Agut, in the second round. Edmund had to battle hard in the first set, fighting back from 3-2 down to take it 6-3. He then made a better start to the second, breaking Garcia-Lopez's serve in the opening game and going on to take it 6-2. Edmund showed great composure throughout the match and his strong return of serve kept Garcia-Lopez under pressure. The British number two took the match in just over an hour. Edmund will now face world number 15 Bautista-Agut in the second round. The pair have met once before, with Edmund winning in straight sets at the Shenzhen Open in January.

Leicester's Matty James and Villa's Ciaran Clark were sent off in the game. Both clubs admitted an FA charge of "failing to ensure their players conducted themselves in an orderly fashion andor refrained from provocative behaviour." Both clubs were fined 20,000 for the incident. The players received a three match ban each.

The adware - dubbed Superfish - was potentially compromising their security, said experts. The hidden software was also injecting adverts on to browsers using techniques more akin to malware, they added. The adware, which was pre-installed on some Lenovo laptops, was injecting ads into webpages by intercepting traffic between users and websites. This could make it easier for hackers to capture people's personal information, the experts said. Superfish also came with a root certificate that allowed it to read all encrypted traffic passing through the laptop. This meant it could potentially be used to spy on its user. Lenovo has since removed Superfish from its systems and released an automated tool to remove it. But security experts have warned that even after removal, the software could still leave backdoors open for attackers.

Clubs could buy domestic players again once they had played their final game of the season. International deals can go through from 10 June. Once the transfer window closes, teams will not be able to sign any new players until the next window opens, usually in January. The transfer window for the 202021 season opened on 27 July, and closed at 11pm BST on 5 October.

As we walked in, three or four people were waiting around a table - but which one, I wondered, was the father of Bitcoin? Then I realised that one man was sitting at the head of the table, looking a little out of place with his laptop and notes. He looked up and grinned as we approached. "Hello," he said. "I'm Satoshi Nakamoto, the creator of Bitcoin." We shook hands and exchanged pleasantries while the other people in the room seemed to be hanging on his every word. I soon realised why - this man had changed the face of money as we know it. He explained the concept of Bitcoin, how it works and how it could revolutionize our economy. It sounded complex and revolutionary, but he made it clear and simple. Everyone in the room was enthralled by his vision. As the meeting ended, I left feeling inspired and energised. I had just met the father of Bitcoin, and I was certain that his creation was going to change the world.

This is the full statement to the inquests read by his son, Stephen Clark, on behalf of his mother Jacqueline Gilchrist: Jacqueline Gilchrist speaking on behalf of the Clark family. We are here today to remember and mourn the tragic loss of our father, John Clark, who died on the evening of June 25th 2020. John was a loving husband and devoted father to his three children, Stephen, Rebecca and Claire. He was a proud grandfather to his four grandchildren. John had an extremely successful career as a chemical engineer in the oil and gas industry. But above all, he was a wonderful person, with a great sense of humour and a kind and generous spirit. John was a man of great integrity and dignity. He was always ready to help others, never expecting anything in return. He enjoyed taking part in local events and activities and was a much-loved member of the community. His death has left a huge hole in all of our lives and we miss him more than words can express. Our thoughts are with his wife, Jacqueline, his children and grandchildren at this difficult time. We would like to thank everyone for their support during this very difficult period. We now ask that you respect our privacy as we come to terms with our loss.

Cheshire East Council said the suspension of chief executive Mike Suarez after a disciplinary committee meeting on Monday was a "neutral act." The Conservative-run authority will not reveal details of the case, but said it was not related to any financial matters. Councillors had made a complaint about Mr Suarez, who has been in the role since 2013, and the council then launched an investigation. The suspension is understood to have been made with full pay, pending the outcome of the disciplinary process. The council has appointed John Prior as interim chief executive while the investigation takes place.

Just over 46,000 vehicles were registered north of the border - a year-on-year increase of more than 2.7. However, UK sales increased by 5.3 to almost 519,000 - the strongest first quarter since 2007.

Media playback is not supported on this device Real took the lead in the ninth minute through Karim Benzema, but Gaku Shibasaki scored either side of half-time to put Kashima Antlers 2-1 up. In the closing stages, Real Madrid were awarded a penalty and Sergio Ramos made no mistake to secure a dramatic draw. Real Madrid came from behind to salvage a dramatic draw in Wednesday's Club World Cup semi-final against Japan's Kashima Antlers. Karim Benzema gave Real a ninth-minute lead, but Gaku Shibasaki equalised shortly before half-time and then put the J-League champions ahead soon after the break. With time running out, Real won a penalty and captain Sergio Ramos converted to send the game into extra time. Real eventually won 4-2 after penalties, with Thibaut Courtois saving two spot kicks. They will now face either Al Ain or South American champions River Plate in Saturday's final in Abu Dhabi.

The Reverend Gavin Ashenden, a senior clergyman in the Church of England, left his position as chaplain in order to be free to criticise the move. A passage from the Bible was used by Ashenden to explain his decision: "Be not conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewal of your mind, that by testing you may discern what is the will of God, what is good and acceptable and perfect." (Romans 12:2)

The party secured about 19 of the vote, unofficial tallies show. But it is not clear if it will meet the 25 voting threshold to enter Jakarta Governor Joko Widodo 's City Council. It is possible that the outcome will be decided in a run-off election, which could take place in November. The party is expected to announce its official results soon.

Aweys Faqey, from North London, was arrested at the airport, north-east of London, on 23 May. He is due to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Tuesday afternoon. His arrest is related to terrorism offences.

The Lord Chief Justice said a failure to do so could frustrate the rule of law. Sir Declan Morgan added that the government and Stormont Executive must address the issue . The Lord Chief Justice said that the lack of a functioning devolved government in Northern Ireland was having a "major impact" on the justice system and "some of the most vulnerable members of society." He said that many areas, such as criminal justice, were facing an "acute crisis" due to the lack of political oversight. Sir Declan said that the civil justice system was also suffering from the stalemate, as there had been an increase in delays in the resolution of cases. He added that the situation was unsustainable and must be addressed urgently.

EDF boss Jean-Bernard Levy joined officials from the UK, France and China at the behind-closed-doors ceremony in London on Thursday. Earlier this month, the government gave the go-ahead for the 18bn project, which is set to become the first nuclear power station in the UK in a generation. The Sizewell C project will be led by EDF, with China General Nuclear Power Corporation (CGN) taking a 33.5 stake alongside EDF's 66.5. At the ceremony, Levy said: "This marks a major milestone for the Sizewell C project and is the result of more than 10 years of hard work. We are now ready to deliver a low-carbon reliable energy source that will help the UK meet its climate goals and provide secure, affordable energy to millions of homes and businesses." He added that the project would create thousands of jobs at the site itself and many more across the wider supply chain. It is expected to generate enough electricity to power six million homes. EDF has also announced it will invest 200m in skills and training initiatives across the UK to support the nuclear industry. The company said this investment will include the establishment of a new centre of excellence to accelerate nuclear skills development and the creation of an apprenticeship programme to train young people in engineering and nuclear technology.

Sports Minister Caral Ni Chuilin said they stood down just before she was due to meet board representatives. They were there to discuss a report by the Head of Internal Audit, who had been commissioned to review the board's governance. The Minister said: "I am disappointed and frustrated that the Board of Sport Northern Ireland has chosen today, ahead of a scheduled meeting with me this afternoon, to stand down without having had the opportunity to discuss the findings of the Head of Internal Audit's report into governance at Sport NI. "This decision is particularly concerning given the ongoing challenges facing sport across Northern Ireland, with the need for an effective and efficient organisation to support our sports sector during these difficult times."

His first spell at the club saw him win the Premier League twice, the FA Cup, the League Cup twice and the Community Shield. He was one of the most successful managers in the club's history. He returned for a second spell in 2009 and won the League Cup, the Community Shield and the FA Cup. He also led the team to their first Champions League final, where they were defeated by Barcelona. He departed the club in 2013 but was warmly welcomed back when he returned as manager in 2016. During his third stint at the club, he won the UEFA Europa League, the Carabao Cup and the Community Shield. He left the club in 2018 after two-and-a-half seasons.

The partnership running the current system in Rhyl, Prestatyn and Rhuddlan say it is not sustainable and has agreed to pass it to Cheshire West and Chester council. The scheme has been running since the early 1990s and allows people to get around Rhyl, Prestatyn and Rhuddlan for free. The council said it will work with local businesses and residents to ensure a smooth transition of the service and to continue providing free transport within the area. It also wants to explore options for expanding the scheme further, including exploring potential funding sources to expand it into other areas. The council will also be looking at ways to make the service more attractive to users, such as introducing loyalty schemes and discounts.

Commentators on the internet have been quick to make fun of Mr Boehner over the years, but his willingness to show emotion has also endeared him to many. His latest emotional display is likely to further that perception, as he showed genuine emotion in his farewell address. It was a fitting end to a long political career, and one that will be remembered fondly by many.

Mark McCarroll, a father-of-one, was working as a fork lift driver at Hayes Fuels depot in Belfast's Harbour estate when the accident happened. Hayes Fuels director Allister Hayes and risk assessment expert Brian Rodgers both attended the inquest. At the inquest it was determined that the accident was caused by a lack of proper risk assessments and safety procedures in place at the depot, as well as inadequate training for the staff working there. It was also revealed that there had been several other incidents at the depot in the run up to Mark's death, including two previous fork lift accidents. The coroner found that Hayes Fuels had failed to take appropriate action in response to these incidents and that this failure had contributed to the fatal accident. The coroner made a number of recommendations to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future, including the adoption of a formal safety policy, proper risk assessments, improved staff training and a review of machinery used at the depot. Hayes Fuels has since implemented the recommendations in full and has taken steps to ensure that all employees understand their responsibilities when it comes to health and safety.

They had no phone signal so were only able to contact the emergency services by using Facebook. The coastguard received the alert just before 23:00 GMT on Saturday and said two people were rescued from the sea off the coast of Cornwall. The coastguard said that the two people had been in the water for nearly an hour before they were found. The rescue mission included a lifeboat and a helicopter, and both persons were taken to hospital with mild hypothermia. The Facebook message was sent by one of the people who was rescued, and it read: "Help! We're in the water off the Cornish coast. Please send help!" The coastguard said it was a "rare but effective" use of social media to alert authorities to their plight.

Hughes qualified on residency this summer and features for the first time under head coach Eddie Jones. Leicester hooker Tom Youngs, who was overlooked earlier in the year by Jones, has been recalled to the squad. Youngs' brother Ben is among the new faces along with Wasps centre Elliot Daly, Gloucester back-rower Ross Moriarty and Saracens prop Petrus du Plessis. The experienced quartet of Danny Care, Dylan Hartley, Joe Marler and James Haskell are all included after being rested for the summer tour to Australia. Bath No 8 Leroy Houston was also named in the squad, despite announcing his intention to move to Australia next season. The squad includes four players who have yet to make their England debuts - Worcester Warriors scrum-half Dan Robson, Exeter Chiefs lock Geoff Parling, Sale Sharks winger Mark Jennings and Northampton Saints flanker Teimana Harrison. Jones said: "We have a good blend of experience and youth in the squad and it is great to be able to call on the services of players like Tom Youngs, Danny Care and Dylan Hartley, who have all done so much for England in the past. "It is also exciting to see the emergence of new players such as Petrus du Plessis, Ross Moriarty and Elliot Daly, who have earned their place in the squad through strong performances in the Aviva Premiership this season." England Squad Forwards: Dave Attwood (Bath Rugby), Kieran Brookes (Newcastle Falcons), Calum Clark (Northampton Saints), Alex Corbisiero (Northampton Saints), Dan Cole (Leicester Tigers), Nick Easter (Harlequins), Dylan Hartley (Northampton Saints), James Haskell (Wasps), Teimana Harrison (Northampton Saints), Matt Kvesic (Gloucester Rugby), Joe Launchbury (Wasps), Courtney Lawes (Northampton Saints), Joe Marler (Harlequins), Ben Morgan (Gloucester Rugby), Geoff Parling (Exeter Chiefs), Chris Robshaw (captain, Harlequins), Billy Vunipola (Saracens), Mako Vunipola (Saracens), David Wilson (Bath Rugby), Tom Wood (Northampton Saints), Tom Youngs (Leicester Tigers). Backs: Brad Barritt (Saracens), Mike Brown (Harlequins), Danny Care (Harlequins), Elliot Daly (Wasps), Owen Farrell (Saracens), George Ford (Bath Rugby), Alex Goode (Saracens), Stephen Myler (Northampton Saints), Jonny May (Gloucester Rugby), Jack Nowell (Exeter Chiefs), Henry Slade (Exeter Chiefs), Dan Robson (Worcester Warriors), Billy Twelvetrees (Gloucester Rugby), Anthony Watson (Bath Rugby), Richard Wigglesworth (Saracens), Mark Jennings (Sale Sharks), Luther Burrell (Northampton Saints), Leroy Houston (Bath Rugby).

The visitors took the lead when a clever dummy from the impressive Oscar Dorley set up Maksim Maksimov to net. Defender Joe Shaughnessy headed home Liam Craig's corner to level the scores and then, from a second Craig corner, Shaughnessy glanced the ball back across goal for Lawrence Shankland to head home. Shankland sealed victory in the 84th minute when he turned the ball home from eight yards after being set up by Jamie McCart. The result was St Johnstone's fourth successive league win and moved them into third place in the Scottish Premiership.

Most flights coming out of or landing in Chile's main airports were cancelled or delayed. The strike hit Chile in the busy run-up to the Christmas holiday period, leaving thousands of passengers stranded. Airlines such as Latam, Sky Airline, JetSmart and Aerolineas Argentinas were among those affected. The strike was over wages and working conditions for air traffic controllers, who are demanding a collective bargaining agreement with the government.

Visiting striker Harry Kane fired home from the spot in the second half after Raheem Sterling was controversially penalised for handball. Yaya Toure struck a 20-yard free-kick against the bar in the closing stages as City pressed for an equaliser, but they were unable to find a way through. Kane's goal was enough to seal all three points for Spurs and move them up to third in the table, while City remain fourth. It was a hard-fought contest between two sides with genuine ambitions of securing Champions League football next season.

Six members of Cymdeithas yr Iaith Gymraeg blocked the entrance to the building at Llandudno Junction at about 06:30 GMT. North Wales Police were called to the protest, which ended at 08:30 GMT. The protest was organised to oppose the Welsh Language Bill, which proposes to give the Welsh language equal status with English in Wales. The protesters argued that the bill does not go far enough in protecting Welsh language rights and that it should provide more protection for Welsh speakers in their day-to-day lives. The protesters chanted slogans such as "Yr iaith gyntaf - daliwch ei grym!" (Support the first language!) and held banners with messages such as "Mae'n rhaid i Gymru gyfiawnhau iaith y bobl" (Wales must recognise the language of its people). Cymdeithas yr Iaith said it was disappointed at how little progress had been made in terms of Welsh language rights since the bill was agreed by the Welsh Assembly in 2017. The group's chair, Ffred Ffransis, said: "We are here today to demonstrate our determination that the Welsh Government will do more to protect our language." The Welsh Government said it was "disappointed" that the protesters had chosen to demonstrate in this way, adding that it had already made progress on the Welsh Language Bill.

Joshua Bwalya, who was 16, was found dead in the street when officers were called to Movers Lane, Barking, at about 01:00 BST on Wednesday. Det Ch Insp Gary Holmes said police were "urgently appealing for information." Joshua's family have been informed and are being supported by specially trained officers. A post-mortem examination is due to take place and the cause of death is not yet known. The Metropolitan Police said officers from the Homicide and Major Crime Command were leading the investigation, but had not yet established a motive or any suspects. Detectives are now working around the clock to piece together his last movements and are appealing for anyone with information about what happened to come forward.

Around 155 countries are expected to formally sign the deal at the UN, setting in motion events that could see the treaty operational within a year. The UN says the treaty has the backing of more than 130 countries and that it could come into force within a year if ratified by 50 nations. The treaty will require all signatories to take steps to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, promote renewable energy sources and provide financial assistance to developing countries. It also calls for greater transparency and accountability from countries in how they measure and report their emissions. The agreement has been hailed as an historic moment, as it marks the first time that nearly every country has agreed to tackle climate change on a global level. The Paris Agreement sets out a framework for countries to work together to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, and to pursue efforts to keep global temperature increases to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The deal is seen as an important step forward in international efforts to tackle climate change, as it commits every country to take action to reduce emissions. However, some have argued that it does not go far enough, and there are still questions over how countries will meet their targets.

The group, reported to be three men, two women and four children aged from two to 11, was held at Reyhanli, in Hatay province, near the Syrian border. Their intention was to cross the border illegally. The Interior Ministry said the group were in possession of fake passports and documents and had been taken into custody following an operation by the provincial gendarmerie forces. The ministry did not provide further details about the group or their nationalities but said they had been handed over to the Hatay Security Directorate for deportation procedures.

The former Scunthorpe, Sheffield Wednesday and Preston player worked with Blackpool manager Gary Bowyer as a trainee at Blackburn. The 27-year-old was released by York in January after making 18 appearances for the National League side this season. David Mirfin began his career at Scunthorpe United, joining them as a trainee in 2003 and making his first team debut in 2004. He went on to make over 200 appearances for the Iron before moving to Sheffield Wednesday in 2011. He made over 50 appearances for Wednesday in two seasons before joining Preston North End in 2013. During his time at Deepdale he made over 70 appearances, playing both at centre back and right back. In 2015 Mirfin joined Walsall, where he made 25 appearances in the 201516 season, before joining York City in 2016. He made 18 appearances for the Minstermen before being released in January 2017. He has now signed for Blackpool, reuniting with manager Gary Bowyer who was his coach at Blackburn Rovers when Mirfin was a trainee at Ewood Park.

Mobile measurement firm RootMetrics conducted over 840,000 checks, ranking operators for reliability and speed of voice, data and text services. While EE dominated for speed, Three was a close second , and O2 was just behind its rival. EE was the clear leader in terms of speed, achieving an overall RootScore of 87.7 out of a possible 100. Three followed closely with 85.8, while O2 trailed slightly with 83.5. EE also achieved the highest scores in all four individual categories (data, text, voice, and overall performance). In terms of reliability, EE again led the way with a RootScore of 86.3, followed by O2 with 82.0 and Three with 81.4. EE also achieved the highest scores in all four individual categories (data, text, voice, and overall performance). Overall, EE emerged as the clear winner for both speed and reliability. The operator achieved the highest overall score in both categories, as well as the highest scores in each of the four individual categories.

Experts reassembled pieces of tiles found amid tons of earth from the site known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as Haram al-Sharif. They say the tiles date to the 10th century and were used in a mosque that was built at the site. The reassembled pieces of tiles, which date to the 10th century, are part of an elaborate mosaic that was found amid tons of earth from the site known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as Haram al-Sharif. The tiles are believed to have been used in a mosque that was built at the site during the Fatimid period . According to experts, the mosaic includes geometric shapes, interlacing circles and stars, along with floral motifs. The complex design and vibrant colors suggest the presence of a highly skilled artisan. The discovery is important for understanding the history of the area and the religious and cultural practices of the people who lived there.

Performers from the comic opera L'elisir d'amore gathered outside the Bow Street venue in full costume at 20:30 BST, alongside members of the audience. The theatre said the interruption was "a surprise for the audience to mark the beginning of the show." The performers sang arias from the opera and interacted with the audience, who were reportedly delighted with the impromptu performance. The performance was also broadcast live on social media, with the hashtag elisirbowstreet trending on Twitter. The production was part of the Royal Opera House's Cinema Series, which broadcasts full-length performances to cinemas across the UK.
